(conf) another case.\nhttp://www.modenatoday.it/cronaca/cas-chikungunya-carpi-castelfranco-12-13-ttobre-2017.html [in Italian]\n[This is a belated addition of another locality in the October 2017 chikungunya virus outbreak in Italy. The total number of cases is not given.\n[Maps of Italy: http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/italy_admin_06.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/33517. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia\n- National. 9 Nov 2017. (susp) 47 500 cases. States most affected: Karnataka 25 800 cases, Gujarat 5896 cases, and Maharashtra 4727 cases.\nhttp://www.deccanherald.com/content/641840/karnataka-accounts-more-half-nations.html\n\n[Maps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Nawalpura, Madhya Pradesh state. 13 Nov 2017. (susp) 44 cases.\nhttps://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/blood-samples-of-44-patients-with-symptoms-of-chikungunya-sent-for-test/articleshow/61620483.cms\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland H\u00fcbner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Senegal: sylvatic cycle\nDate: Mon 16 Oct 2017\nSource: bioRxiv [edited]\nhttps://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/10/13/079046\n\n\nref: Althouse BM, Guerbois M, Cummings DAT, et al. Role of monkeys in the sylvatic cycle of chikungunya virus in Senegal. bioRxiv; doi: 10.1101/079046\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nArthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses) pose the greatest risk of spillover into humans of any class of pathogens. Such spillover may occur as a one-step jump from a reservoir host species into humans or as a 2-step jump from the reservoir to a different amplification host species and thence to humans. Despite the widespread havoc wreaked by emerging arboviruses, little is known about their transmission dynamics in reservoir and amplification hosts. Here we used serosurveillance and mathematical modeling to elucidate the role of monkeys in the sylvatic, enzootic cycle of chikungunya virus (CHIKV). Over 3 years, 219 African green monkeys, 78 patas monkeys, and 440 Guinea baboons were captured in the region surrounding Kedougou, Senegal. The age of each animal was determined by anthropometry and dentition, and exposure to CHIKV was determined by detection of neutralizing antibodies. We estimate age-specific CHIKV seroprevalence, force of infection (FoI), and basic reproductive number (R0) in each species. Among the different species, CHIKV FoI ranged from 0.13 to 1.12 (95 per cent confidence interval [CI] 0.81-2.28) and R0 ranged from 1.5 (CI 1.3-1.9) to 6.6 (CI 5.1-10.4). CHIKV infection of infant monkeys was detected even when the virus was not detected in a concurrent survey of primatophilic mosquitoes and when population seropositivity, and therefore immunity, was too high for monkeys themselves to support continuous CHIKV transmission. We therefore conclude that monkeys in this region serve primarily as amplification rather than reservoir hosts of CHIKV. Additional efforts are needed to identify other vertebrate hosts capable of supporting continuous circulation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One hopes that a comprehensive serosurvey of other vertebrate animals will be undertaken in the areas where the positive monkeys were found, followed by laboratory tests of susceptibility to determine the amplitude and duration of viremia (if any) in the positive species. Similar studies are needed in the tropical Americas to determine is spill-back from humans to wild vertebrates, and especially non-human primates, has occurred there. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nKedougou, Senegal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38299]\n\n******\n[3] Colombia: persistent arthralgia\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017\nSource: Arthritis and Rheumatology journal [edited]\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/art.40384/abstract\n\n\nref: Chang AY, Encinales L, Porras A, et al. Frequency of chronic joint pain following chikungunya infection: a Colombian cohort study. Arthritis Rheumatol. 2017. doi: 10.1002/art.40384. [Epub ahead of print]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective\nTo estimate the frequency of chronic joint pain after infection with chikungunya virus in a Latin American cohort.\nMethods\nA cross sectional follow-up of a prospective cohort of 500 chikungunya patients from Atl\u00e1ntico department, Colombia clinically diagnosed with chikungunya during the 2014-2015 Colombian epidemic. Baseline and follow-up (20 months) symptoms were evaluated in serologically confirmed cases.\nResults\nAmong 500 patients enrolled, 485 cases were serologically confirmed with chikungunya [virus infections]. Patients were predominantly adults (age 49 +/- 16 years), female, had a high school or less level of education, and were of mestizo ethnicity. The most commonly affected joints were the small joints including the wrists, ankles, and fingers. The initial joint pain lasted a median of 4 days (interquartile range [IQR] 3-8); 16 per cent of participants reported missing a median of 4 days (IQR 2-7) of school or work. After 20-months, 1/4 of the participants had persistent joint pain. A multivariable analysis indicated that significant predictors of persistent joint pain included college graduate status, initial symptoms of headache or knee pain, missed work, normal activities affected, 4 or more days of initial symptoms, and 4 or more weeks of initial pain.\nConclusions\nThis is the 1st report to describe the frequency of chikungunya-related arthritis in the Americas after a 20 month follow-up. The high frequency of chronic disease highlights the importance of development of prevention and treatment interventions.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are many anecdotal accounts of persistent and sometimes disabling persistent joint pain following chikungunya virus infections. The report above provides the results of a quantitative study of arthralgia, lasting 20 or more months following infection in a quarter of the study group. A follow up study of 36 pregnant women hospitalized in Colombia in 2015, 1 year after acute viremia, reported arthralgia in 2 or more joints in 13 patients. Despite disease severity, pregnant women with chikungunya should be treated in high-complexity obstetric units to rule out adverse outcomes. These women should also be followed up to treat potential relapses (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/11/17-0480_article). - Mod.TY]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAtl\u00e1ntico, Colombia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31670]\n\n******\n[4] Brazil: mortality\nDate: Mon 13 Nov 2017\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Currents Outbreaks journal [edited]\nhttp://currents.plos.org/outbreaks/article/excess-mortality-related-to-chikungunya-epidemics-in-the-context-of-co-circulation-of-other-arboviruses-in-brazil/\n\n\nFreitas ARR, Cavalcanti L, Von Zuben AP, Donalisio MR. Excess mortality related to chikungunya epidemics in the context of co-circulation of other arboviruses in Brazil. PLOS Currents Outbreaks. 2017 . Edition 1. doi: 10.1371/currents.outbreaks.14608e586cd321d8d5088652d7a0d884\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nIntroduction\nChikungunya is an emerging arbovirus that reached the Western Hemisphere at the end of 2013. Studies in the Indian Ocean and India suggest that passive surveillance systems cannot recognize many of deaths associated with chikungunya, which can be inferred by an increase in the overall mortality observed during chikungunya epidemics.\nObjective\nWe assess the mortality associated with chikungunya epidemics in the most affected states in Brazil, from 2015 and 2016.\nMethods\nWe studied the monthly mortality by age group, comparing a period without epidemics to a chikungunya epidemic period, which we defined arbitrarily as consecutive months with incidences of more than 50 cases/100 000 persons.\nResults\nWe obtained official data from the National System of Reported Diseases (SINAN) and the Mortality Information System (SIM), both maintained by the Ministry of Health. We identified a significant increase in the all-cause mortality rate during chikungunya epidemics, while there was no similar mortality in the previous years, even during dengue epidemics. We estimated an excess of 4505 deaths in Pernambuco during the chikungunya epidemics (47.9 per 100 000 persons). The most affected age groups were the elderly and those under 1 year of age, and the same pattern occurred in all the states.\nDiscussion\nFurther studies at other sites are needed to confirm the association between increased mortality and chikungunya epidemics in different age groups. If these findings are confirmed, it will be necessary to revise the guidelines to recognize the actual mortality associated with chikungunya and to improve therapeutic approaches and protective measures in the most vulnerable groups.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Although the case fatality rate has been very low, there have been sporadic deaths due to chikungunya virus infections in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nBrazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nChikungunya (50): Asia (susp) 44 cases.\nhttps://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/blood-samples-of-44-patients-with-symptoms-of-chikungunya-sent-for-test/articleshow/61620483.cms\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland H\u00fcbner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Senegal: sylvatic cycle\nDate: Mon 16 Oct 2017\nSource: bioRxiv [edited]\nhttps://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/10/13/079046\n\n\nref: Althouse BM, Guerbois M, Cummings DAT, et al. Role of monkeys in the sylvatic cycle of chikungunya virus in Senegal. bioRxiv; doi: 10.1101/079046\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nArthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses) pose the greatest risk of spillover into humans of any class of pathogens. Such spillover may occur as a one-step jump from a reservoir host species into humans or as a 2-step jump from the reservoir to a different amplification host species and thence to humans. Despite the widespread havoc wreaked by emerging arboviruses, little is known about their transmission dynamics in reservoir and amplification hosts. Here we used serosurveillance and mathematical modeling to elucidate the role of monkeys in the sylvatic, enzootic cycle of chikungunya virus (CHIKV). Over 3 years, 219 African green monkeys, 78 patas monkeys, and 440 Guinea baboons were captured in the region surrounding Kedougou, Senegal. The age of each animal was determined by anthropometry and dentition, and exposure to CHIKV was determined by detection of neutralizing antibodies. We estimate age-specific CHIKV seroprevalence, force of infection (FoI), and basic reproductive number (R0) in each species. Among the different species, CHIKV FoI ranged from 0.13 to 1.12 (95 per cent confidence interval [CI] 0.81-2.28) and R0 ranged from 1.5 (CI 1.3-1.9) to 6.6 (CI 5.1-10.4). CHIKV infection of infant monkeys was detected even when the virus was not detected in a concurrent survey of primatophilic mosquitoes and when population seropositivity, and therefore immunity, was too high for monkeys themselves to support continuous CHIKV transmission. We therefore conclude that monkeys in this region serve primarily as amplification rather than reservoir hosts of CHIKV. Additional efforts are needed to identify other vertebrate hosts capable of supporting continuous circulation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One hopes that a comprehensive serosurvey of other vertebrate animals will be undertaken in the areas where the positive monkeys were found, followed by laboratory tests of susceptibility to determine the amplitude and duration of viremia (if any) in the positive species. Similar studies are needed in the tropical Americas to determine is spill-back from humans to wild vertebrates, and especially non-human primates, has occurred there. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nKedougou, Senegal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38299]\n\n******\n[3] Colombia: persistent arthralgia\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017\nSource: Arthritis and Rheumatology journal [edited]\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/art.40384/abstract\n\n\nref: Chang AY, Encinales L, Porras A, et al. Frequency of chronic joint pain following chikungunya infection: a Colombian cohort study. Arthritis Rheumatol. 2017. doi: 10.1002/art.40384. [Epub ahead of print]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective\nTo estimate the frequency of chronic joint pain after infection with chikungunya virus in a Latin American cohort.\nMethods\nA cross sectional follow-up of a prospective cohort of 500 chikungunya patients from Atl\u00e1ntico department, Colombia clinically diagnosed with chikungunya during the 2014-2015 Colombian epidemic. Baseline and follow-up (20 months) symptoms were evaluated in serologically confirmed cases.\nResults\nAmong 500 patients enrolled, 485 cases were serologically confirmed with chikungunya [virus infections]. Patients were predominantly adults (age 49 +/- 16 years), female, had a high school or less level of education, and were of mestizo ethnicity. The most commonly affected joints were the small joints including the wrists, ankles, and fingers. The initial joint pain lasted a median of 4 days (interquartile range [IQR] 3-8); 16 per cent of participants reported missing a median of 4 days (IQR 2-7) of school or work. After 20-months, 1/4 of the participants had persistent joint pain. A multivariable analysis indicated that significant predictors of persistent joint pain included college graduate status, initial symptoms of headache or knee pain, missed work, normal activities affected, 4 or more days of initial symptoms, and 4 or more weeks of initial pain.\nConclusions\nThis is the 1st report to describe the frequency of chikungunya-related arthritis in the Americas after a 20 month follow-up. The high frequency of chronic disease highlights the importance of development of prevention and treatment interventions.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are many anecdotal accounts of persistent and sometimes disabling persistent joint pain following chikungunya virus infections. The report above provides the results of a quantitative study of arthralgia, lasting 20 or more months following infection in a quarter of the study group. A follow up study of 36 pregnant women hospitalized in Colombia in 2015, 1 year after acute viremia, reported arthralgia in 2 or more joints in 13 patients. Despite disease severity, pregnant women with chikungunya should be treated in high-complexity obstetric units to rule out adverse outcomes. These women should also be followed up to treat potential relapses (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/11/17-0480_article). - Mod.TY]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAtl\u00e1ntico, Colombia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31670]\n\n******\n[4] Brazil: mortality\nDate: Mon 13 Nov 2017\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Currents Outbreaks journal [edited]\nhttp://currents.plos.org/outbreaks/article/excess-mortality-related-to-chikungunya-epidemics-in-the-context-of-co-circulation-of-other-arboviruses-in-brazil/\n\n\nFreitas ARR, Cavalcanti L, Von Zuben AP, Donalisio MR. Excess mortality related to chikungunya epidemics in the context of co-circulation of other arboviruses in Brazil. PLOS Currents Outbreaks. 2017 . Edition 1. doi: 10.1371/currents.outbreaks.14608e586cd321d8d5088652d7a0d884\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nIntroduction\nChikungunya is an emerging arbovirus that reached the Western Hemisphere at the end of 2013. Studies in the Indian Ocean and India suggest that passive surveillance systems cannot recognize many of deaths associated with chikungunya, which can be inferred by an increase in the overall mortality observed during chikungunya epidemics.\nObjective\nWe assess the mortality associated with chikungunya epidemics in the most affected states in Brazil, from 2015 and 2016.\nMethods\nWe studied the monthly mortality by age group, comparing a period without epidemics to a chikungunya epidemic period, which we defined arbitrarily as consecutive months with incidences of more than 50 cases/100 000 persons.\nResults\nWe obtained official data from the National System of Reported Diseases (SINAN) and the Mortality Information System (SIM), both maintained by the Ministry of Health. We identified a significant increase in the all-cause mortality rate during chikungunya epidemics, while there was no similar mortality in the previous years, even during dengue epidemics. We estimated an excess of 4505 deaths in Pernambuco during the chikungunya epidemics (47.9 per 100 000 persons). The most affected age groups were the elderly and those under 1 year of age, and the same pattern occurred in all the states.\nDiscussion\nFurther studies at other sites are needed to confirm the association between increased mortality and chikungunya epidemics in different age groups. If these findings are confirmed, it will be necessary to revise the guidelines to recognize the actual mortality associated with chikungunya and to improve therapeutic approaches and protective measures in the most vulnerable groups.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Although the case fatality rate has been very low, there have been sporadic deaths due to chikungunya virus infections in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nBrazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nChikungunya (50): Asia "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (01): AMERICAS, EUROPE, ASIA, RESEARCH\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO 2017\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or\nterritory - 2017 to EW 51 [week ending (w/e) 22 Dec 2017]. Cases before EW 46 are not given but are available at the above URL.\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week [w/e] / Local susp / Local conf / Imported conf / Deaths\n\nNorth America\n---\nMexico / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 0 / 57 / 0 / 0\nUSA / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 0 / 0 / 103 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nCosta Rica / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 389 / 42 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 561 / 0 / 0 / 0\nNicaragua / week 50 [w/e 15 Dec 2017] / 736 / 24 / 0 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean\n---\nGuadeloupe / week 46 [w/e 17 Nov 2017] / 0 / 56 / 0 / 0\nPuerto Rico / week 47 [w/e 24 Nov 2017] / 0 / 8 / 0 / 0\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean (no recent reports)\n---\n\nAndean Area\n---\nBolivia / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 3345 / 22 / 0 / 0\nColombia / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 1052 / 28 / 0 / 0\nEcuador / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 0 / 196 / 0 / 2\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nArgentina / week 50 [w/e 15 Dec 2017] / 0 / 0 / 1 / 0\nParaguay / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 739 / 8 / 0 / 0\n\nTotals (all of 2017) / 61 613 / 123 087 / 107 / 101\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455;\nCaribbean http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nNorth America\n---\nUSA (Dade County, Florida). (suspected [susp]) 134 223, (conf) 96 299; deaths 136. (conf) another case.\nhttp://www.modenatoday.it/cronaca/cas-chikungunya-carpi-castelfranco-12-13-ttobre-2017.html [in Italian]\n[This is a belated addition of another locality in the October 2017 chikungunya virus outbreak in Italy. The total number of cases is not given.\n[Maps of Italy: http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/italy_admin_06.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/33517. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia\n- National. 9 Nov 2017. (susp) 47 500 cases. States most affected: Karnataka 25 800 cases, Gujarat 5896 cases, and Maharashtra 4727 cases.\nhttp://www.deccanherald.com/content/641840/karnataka-accounts-more-half-nations.html\n\n[Maps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Nawalpura, Madhya Pradesh state. 13 Nov 2017. (susp) 44 cases.\nhttps://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/blood-samples-of-44-patients-with-symptoms-of-chikungunya-sent-for-test/articleshow/61620483.cms\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland H\u00fcbner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Senegal: sylvatic cycle\nDate: Mon 16 Oct 2017\nSource: bioRxiv [edited]\nhttps://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/10/13/079046\n\n\nref: Althouse BM, Guerbois M, Cummings DAT, et al. Role of monkeys in the sylvatic cycle of chikungunya virus in Senegal. bioRxiv; doi: 10.1101/079046\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nArthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses) pose the greatest risk of spillover into humans of any class of pathogens. Such spillover may occur as a one-step jump from a reservoir host species into humans or as a 2-step jump from the reservoir to a different amplification host species and thence to humans. Despite the widespread havoc wreaked by emerging arboviruses, little is known about their transmission dynamics in reservoir and amplification hosts. Here we used serosurveillance and mathematical modeling to elucidate the role of monkeys in the sylvatic, enzootic cycle of chikungunya virus (CHIKV). Over 3 years, 219 African green monkeys, 78 patas monkeys, and 440 Guinea baboons were captured in the region surrounding Kedougou, Senegal. The age of each animal was determined by anthropometry and dentition, and exposure to CHIKV was determined by detection of neutralizing antibodies. We estimate age-specific CHIKV seroprevalence, force of infection (FoI), and basic reproductive number (R0) in each species. Among the different species, CHIKV FoI ranged from 0.13 to 1.12 (95 per cent confidence interval [CI] 0.81-2.28) and R0 ranged from 1.5 (CI 1.3-1.9) to 6.6 (CI 5.1-10.4). CHIKV infection of infant monkeys was detected even when the virus was not detected in a concurrent survey of primatophilic mosquitoes and when population seropositivity, and therefore immunity, was too high for monkeys themselves to support continuous CHIKV transmission. We therefore conclude that monkeys in this region serve primarily as amplification rather than reservoir hosts of CHIKV. Additional efforts are needed to identify other vertebrate hosts capable of supporting continuous circulation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One hopes that a comprehensive serosurvey of other vertebrate animals will be undertaken in the areas where the positive monkeys were found, followed by laboratory tests of susceptibility to determine the amplitude and duration of viremia (if any) in the positive species. Similar studies are needed in the tropical Americas to determine is spill-back from humans to wild vertebrates, and especially non-human primates, has occurred there. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nKedougou, Senegal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38299]\n\n******\n[3] Colombia: persistent arthralgia\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017\nSource: Arthritis and Rheumatology journal [edited]\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/art.40384/abstract\n\n\nref: Chang AY, Encinales L, Porras A, et al. Frequency of chronic joint pain following chikungunya infection: a Colombian cohort study. Arthritis Rheumatol. 2017. doi: 10.1002/art.40384. [Epub ahead of print]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective\nTo estimate the frequency of chronic joint pain after infection with chikungunya virus in a Latin American cohort.\nMethods\nA cross sectional follow-up of a prospective cohort of 500 chikungunya patients from Atl\u00e1ntico department, Colombia clinically diagnosed with chikungunya during the 2014-2015 Colombian epidemic. Baseline and follow-up (20 months) symptoms were evaluated in serologically confirmed cases.\nResults\nAmong 500 patients enrolled, 485 cases were serologically confirmed with chikungunya [virus infections]. Patients were predominantly adults (age 49 +/- 16 years), female, had a high school or less level of education, and were of mestizo ethnicity. The most commonly affected joints were the small joints including the wrists, ankles, and fingers. The initial joint pain lasted a median of 4 days (interquartile range [IQR] 3-8); 16 per cent of participants reported missing a median of 4 days (IQR 2-7) of school or work. After 20-months, 1/4 of the participants had persistent joint pain. A multivariable analysis indicated that significant predictors of persistent joint pain included college graduate status, initial symptoms of headache or knee pain, missed work, normal activities affected, 4 or more days of initial symptoms, and 4 or more weeks of initial pain.\nConclusions\nThis is the 1st report to describe the frequency of chikungunya-related arthritis in the Americas after a 20 month follow-up. The high frequency of chronic disease highlights the importance of development of prevention and treatment interventions.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are many anecdotal accounts of persistent and sometimes disabling persistent joint pain following chikungunya virus infections. The report above provides the results of a quantitative study of arthralgia, lasting 20 or more months following infection in a quarter of the study group. A follow up study of 36 pregnant women hospitalized in Colombia in 2015, 1 year after acute viremia, reported arthralgia in 2 or more joints in 13 patients. Despite disease severity, pregnant women with chikungunya should be treated in high-complexity obstetric units to rule out adverse outcomes. These women should also be followed up to treat potential relapses (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/11/17-0480_article). - Mod.TY]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAtl\u00e1ntico, Colombia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31670]\n\n******\n[4] Brazil: mortality\nDate: Mon 13 Nov 2017\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Currents Outbreaks journal [edited]\nhttp://currents.plos.org/outbreaks/article/excess-mortality-related-to-chikungunya-epidemics-in-the-context-of-co-circulation-of-other-arboviruses-in-brazil/\n\n\nFreitas ARR, Cavalcanti L, Von Zuben AP, Donalisio MR. Excess mortality related to chikungunya epidemics in the context of co-circulation of other arboviruses in Brazil. PLOS Currents Outbreaks. 2017 . Edition 1. doi: 10.1371/currents.outbreaks.14608e586cd321d8d5088652d7a0d884\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nIntroduction\nChikungunya is an emerging arbovirus that reached the Western Hemisphere at the end of 2013. Studies in the Indian Ocean and India suggest that passive surveillance systems cannot recognize many of deaths associated with chikungunya, which can be inferred by an increase in the overall mortality observed during chikungunya epidemics.\nObjective\nWe assess the mortality associated with chikungunya epidemics in the most affected states in Brazil, from 2015 and 2016.\nMethods\nWe studied the monthly mortality by age group, comparing a period without epidemics to a chikungunya epidemic period, which we defined arbitrarily as consecutive months with incidences of more than 50 cases/100 000 persons.\nResults\nWe obtained official data from the National System of Reported Diseases (SINAN) and the Mortality Information System (SIM), both maintained by the Ministry of Health. We identified a significant increase in the all-cause mortality rate during chikungunya epidemics, while there was no similar mortality in the previous years, even during dengue epidemics. We estimated an excess of 4505 deaths in Pernambuco during the chikungunya epidemics (47.9 per 100 000 persons). The most affected age groups were the elderly and those under 1 year of age, and the same pattern occurred in all the states.\nDiscussion\nFurther studies at other sites are needed to confirm the association between increased mortality and chikungunya epidemics in different age groups. If these findings are confirmed, it will be necessary to revise the guidelines to recognize the actual mortality associated with chikungunya and to improve therapeutic approaches and protective measures in the most vulnerable groups.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Although the case fatality rate has been very low, there have been sporadic deaths due to chikungunya virus infections in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nBrazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nChikungunya (50): Asia archives\n.................................................sb/jh/mpp/ty/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 12:12:11", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (01): AMERICAS, EUROPE, ASIA, RESEARCH\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO 2017\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or\nterritory - 2017 to EW 51 [week Cases before EW 46 are not given but are available at the above URL.\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week [w/e] / Local susp / Local conf / Imported conf / Deaths\n\nNorth America\n---\nMexico / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 0 / 57 / 0 / 0\nUSA / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 0 / 0 / 103 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nCosta Rica / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 389 / 42 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 561 / 0 / 0 / 0\nNicaragua / week 50 [w/e 15 Dec 2017] / 736 / 24 / 0 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean\n---\nGuadeloupe / week 46 [w/e 17 Nov 2017] / 0 / 56 / 0 / 0\nPuerto Rico / week 47 [w/e 24 Nov 2017] / 0 / 8 / 0 / 0\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean (no recent reports)\n---\n\nAndean Area\n---\nBolivia / week 49 [w/e 8 Dec 2017] / 3345 / 22 / 0 / 0\nColombia / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 1052 / 28 / 0 / 0\nEcuador / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 0 / 196 / 0 / 2\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nArgentina / week 50 [w/e 15 Dec 2017] / 0 / 0 / 1 / 0\nParaguay / week 48 [w/e 1 Dec 2017] / 739 / 8 / 0 / 0\n\nTotals (all of 2017) / 61 613 / 123 087 / 107 / 101\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455;\nCaribbean http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nNorth America\n---\nUSA (Dade County, Florida). (conf) for 12 months, ending 9 Dec 2017, 2248 cases.\nhttps://g1.globo.com/mt/mato-grosso/noticia/casos-de-febre-chikungunya-em-varzea-grande-mt-sobem-de-12-para-2248-em-um-ano.ghtml [in Portuguese]\n\n- Santar\u00e9m, Par\u00e1 state. 2 Jan 2018. (suspected [susp]) 134 223, (conf) 96 299; deaths 136. The total number of cases is not given.\n[Maps of Italy: http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/italy_admin_06.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/33517. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia\n- National. 9 Nov 2017. (susp) 47 500 cases. States most affected: Karnataka 25 800 cases, Gujarat 5896 cases, and Maharashtra 4727 cases.\nhttp://www.deccanherald.com/content/641840/karnataka-accounts-more-half-nations.html\n\n[Maps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Nawalpura, Madhya Pradesh state. 13 Nov 2017. (susp) 44 cases.\nhttps://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/blood-samples-of-44-patients-with-symptoms-of-chikungunya-sent-for-test/articleshow/61620483.cms\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland H\u00fcbner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Senegal: sylvatic cycle\nDate: Mon 16 Oct 2017\nSource: bioRxiv [edited]\nhttps://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/10/13/079046\n\n\nref: Althouse BM, Guerbois M, Cummings DAT, et al. Role of monkeys in the sylvatic cycle of chikungunya virus in Senegal. bioRxiv; doi: 10.1101/079046\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nArthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses) pose the greatest risk of spillover into humans of any class of pathogens. Such spillover may occur as a one-step jump from a reservoir host species into humans or as a 2-step jump from the reservoir to a different amplification host species and thence to humans. Despite the widespread havoc wreaked by emerging arboviruses, little is known about their transmission dynamics in reservoir and amplification hosts. Here we used serosurveillance and mathematical modeling to elucidate the role of monkeys in the sylvatic, enzootic cycle of chikungunya virus (CHIKV). Over 3 years, 219 African green monkeys, 78 patas monkeys, and 440 Guinea baboons were captured in the region surrounding Kedougou, Senegal. The age of each animal was determined by anthropometry and dentition, and exposure to CHIKV was determined by detection of neutralizing antibodies. We estimate age-specific CHIKV seroprevalence, force of infection (FoI), and basic reproductive number (R0) in each species. Among the different species, CHIKV FoI ranged from 0.13 to 1.12 (95 per cent confidence interval [CI] 0.81-2.28) and R0 ranged from 1.5 (CI 1.3-1.9) to 6.6 (CI 5.1-10.4). CHIKV infection of infant monkeys was detected even when the virus was not detected in a concurrent survey of primatophilic mosquitoes and when population seropositivity, and therefore immunity, was too high for monkeys themselves to support continuous CHIKV transmission. We therefore conclude that monkeys in this region serve primarily as amplification rather than reservoir hosts of CHIKV. Additional efforts are needed to identify other vertebrate hosts capable of supporting continuous circulation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One hopes that a comprehensive serosurvey of other vertebrate animals will be undertaken in the areas where the positive monkeys were found, followed by laboratory tests of susceptibility to determine the amplitude and duration of viremia (if any) in the positive species. Similar studies are needed in the tropical Americas to determine is spill-back from humans to wild vertebrates, and especially non-human primates, has occurred there. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nKedougou, Senegal: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38299]\n\n******\n[3] Colombia: persistent arthralgia\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017\nSource: Arthritis and Rheumatology journal [edited]\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/art.40384/abstract\n\n\nref: Chang AY, Encinales L, Porras A, et al. Frequency of chronic joint pain following chikungunya infection: a Colombian cohort study. Arthritis Rheumatol. 2017. doi: 10.1002/art.40384. [Epub ahead of print]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective\nTo estimate the frequency of chronic joint pain after infection with chikungunya virus in a Latin American cohort.\nMethods\nA cross sectional follow-up of a prospective cohort of 500 chikungunya patients from Atl\u00e1ntico department, Colombia clinically diagnosed with chikungunya during the 2014-2015 Colombian epidemic. Baseline and follow-up (20 months) symptoms were evaluated in serologically confirmed cases.\nResults\nAmong 500 patients enrolled, 485 cases were serologically confirmed with chikungunya [virus infections]. Patients were predominantly adults (age 49 +/- 16 years), female, had a high school or less level of education, and were of mestizo ethnicity. The most commonly affected joints were the small joints including the wrists, ankles, and fingers. The initial joint pain lasted a median of 4 days (interquartile range [IQR] 3-8); 16 per cent of participants reported missing a median of 4 days (IQR 2-7) of school or work. After 20-months, 1/4 of the participants had persistent joint pain. A multivariable analysis indicated that significant predictors of persistent joint pain included college graduate status, initial symptoms of headache or knee pain, missed work, normal activities affected, 4 or more days of initial symptoms, and 4 or more weeks of initial pain.\nConclusions\nThis is the 1st report to describe the frequency of chikungunya-related arthritis in the Americas after a 20 month follow-up. The high frequency of chronic disease highlights the importance of development of prevention and treatment interventions.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are many anecdotal accounts of persistent and sometimes disabling persistent joint pain following chikungunya virus infections. The report above provides the results of a quantitative study of arthralgia, lasting 20 or more months following infection in a quarter of the study group. A follow up study of 36 pregnant women hospitalized in Colombia in 2015, 1 year after acute viremia, reported arthralgia in 2 or more joints in 13 patients. Despite disease severity, pregnant women with chikungunya should be treated in high-complexity obstetric units to rule out adverse outcomes. These women should also be followed up to treat potential relapses (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/11/17-0480_article). - Mod.TY]\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nAtl\u00e1ntico, Colombia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31670]\n\n******\n[4] Brazil: mortality\nDate: Mon 13 Nov 2017\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Currents Outbreaks journal [edited]\nhttp://currents.plos.org/outbreaks/article/excess-mortality-related-to-chikungunya-epidemics-in-the-context-of-co-circulation-of-other-arboviruses-in-brazil/\n\n\nFreitas ARR, Cavalcanti L, Von Zuben AP, Donalisio MR. Excess mortality related to chikungunya epidemics in the context of co-circulation of other arboviruses in Brazil. PLOS Currents Outbreaks. 2017 . Edition 1. doi: 10.1371/currents.outbreaks.14608e586cd321d8d5088652d7a0d884\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nIntroduction\nChikungunya is an emerging arbovirus that reached the Western Hemisphere at the end of 2013. Studies in the Indian Ocean and India suggest that passive surveillance systems cannot recognize many of deaths associated with chikungunya, which can be inferred by an increase in the overall mortality observed during chikungunya epidemics.\nObjective\nWe assess the mortality associated with chikungunya epidemics in the most affected states in Brazil, from 2015 and 2016.\nMethods\nWe studied the monthly mortality by age group, comparing a period without epidemics to a chikungunya epidemic period, which we defined arbitrarily as consecutive months with incidences of more than 50 cases/100 000 persons.\nResults\nWe obtained official data from the National System of Reported Diseases (SINAN) and the Mortality Information System (SIM), both maintained by the Ministry of Health. We identified a significant increase in the all-cause mortality rate during chikungunya epidemics, while there was no similar mortality in the previous years, even during dengue epidemics. We estimated an excess of 4505 deaths in Pernambuco during the chikungunya epidemics (47.9 per 100 000 persons). The most affected age groups were the elderly and those under 1 year of age, and the same pattern occurred in all the states.\nDiscussion\nFurther studies at other sites are needed to confirm the association between increased mortality and chikungunya epidemics in different age groups. If these findings are confirmed, it will be necessary to revise the guidelines to recognize the actual mortality associated with chikungunya and to improve therapeutic approaches and protective measures in the most vulnerable groups.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Although the case fatality rate has been very low, there have been sporadic deaths due to chikungunya virus infections in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nBrazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nChikungunya (50): Asia States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5528555", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (50): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5528555", "date": "2017-10-29 13:05:31", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (44): PAKISTAN\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 28 Oct 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttps://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/10/28/number-of-suspected-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise/\n\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases rose in Karachi as 12 more patients were admitted to hospitals, taking the total number of patients up to 243 since 1 Oct 2017.\n\nAccording to a report issued by the Sindh Health Department, a total 4602 chikungunya suspected cases have been reported across the province since 1 Jan 2017.\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases during October 2017 has reached 254 across Sindh, of which 243 cases have been reported from Karachi.\n\nIn 2016, the number of suspected chikungunya cases reported from Karachi was 405.\n\nChikungunya is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes, and its symptoms include high fever, joint pains, joint swellings, rashes, headaches, muscle pains, nausea and fatigue. Chikungunya is rarely fatal, with the death rate of those afflicted at less than one percent.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Currently, Sindh province is also reporting dengue cases from various districts including Karachi. The key to control of vector borne diseases such as dengue and chikungunya is intensive vector management, not only when the epidemic or outbreak situation arises, but particularly during the low activity season. Use of personal protective measures must be propagated for prevention of mosquito bites, such as wearing clothing to minimize skin exposure to the day-biting mosquito, application of repellents to exposed skin or clothing, use of screens in rooms, use of mosquito coils or other insecticide vaporizers and use of mosquito nets or insecticide-treated mosquito nets during daytime sleeping, particularly of young children or sick or older individuals. Furthermore, intensive efforts for community involvement in the control measures through education and participation of the religious and social members can make considerable impact. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Pakistan (42): (SD) Karachi 20171022.5395560\nChikungunya (41): Pakistan (NW) 20171015.5381619\nChikungunya (37): Pakistan 20171001.5352966\nChikungunya (32): Asia (Pakistan) 20170919.5323363\nChikungunya (31): Asia (Pakistan) 20170916.5320238\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karachi", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5505004", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (49): Pakistan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5505004", "date": "2017-10-29 13:05:31", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (44): PAKISTAN\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 28 Oct 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttps://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/10/28/number-of-suspected-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise/\n\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases rose in Karachi as 12 more patients were admitted to hospitals, taking the total number of patients up to 243 since 1 Oct 2017.\n\nAccording to a report issued by the Sindh Health Department, a total 4602 chikungunya suspected cases have been reported across the province since 1 Jan 2017.\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases during October 2017 has reached 254 across Sindh, of which 243 cases have been reported from Karachi.\n\nIn 2016, the number of suspected chikungunya cases reported from Karachi was 405.\n\nChikungunya is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes, and its symptoms include high fever, joint pains, joint swellings, rashes, headaches, muscle pains, nausea and fatigue. Chikungunya is rarely fatal, with the death rate of those afflicted at less than one percent.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Currently, Sindh province is also reporting dengue cases from various districts including Karachi. The key to control of vector borne diseases such as dengue and chikungunya is intensive vector management, not only when the epidemic or outbreak situation arises, but particularly during the low activity season. Use of personal protective measures must be propagated for prevention of mosquito bites, such as wearing clothing to minimize skin exposure to the day-biting mosquito, application of repellents to exposed skin or clothing, use of screens in rooms, use of mosquito coils or other insecticide vaporizers and use of mosquito nets or insecticide-treated mosquito nets during daytime sleeping, particularly of young children or sick or older individuals. Furthermore, intensive efforts for community involvement in the control measures through education and participation of the religious and social members can make considerable impact. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karachi", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5435925", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (45): Italy, France", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5435925", "date": "2017-10-29 13:05:31", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (44): PAKISTAN\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 28 Oct 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttps://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/10/28/number-of-suspected-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise/\n\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases rose in Karachi as 12 more patients were admitted to hospitals, taking the total number of patients up to 243 since 1 Oct 2017.\n\nAccording to a report issued by the Sindh Health Department, a total 4602 chikungunya suspected cases have been reported across the province since 1 Jan 2017.\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases during October 2017 has reached 254 across Sindh, of which 243 cases have been reported from Karachi.\n\nIn 2016, the number of suspected chikungunya cases reported from Karachi was 405.\n\nChikungunya is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes, and its symptoms include high fever, joint pains, joint swellings, rashes, headaches, muscle pains, nausea and fatigue. Chikungunya is rarely fatal, with the death rate of those afflicted at less than one percent.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Currently, Sindh province is also reporting dengue cases from various districts including Karachi. The key to control of vector borne diseases such as dengue and chikungunya is intensive vector management, not only when the epidemic or outbreak situation arises, but particularly during the low activity season. Use of personal protective measures must be propagated for prevention of mosquito bites, such as wearing clothing to minimize skin exposure to the day-biting mosquito, application of repellents to exposed skin or clothing, use of screens in rooms, use of mosquito coils or other insecticide vaporizers and use of mosquito nets or insecticide-treated mosquito nets during daytime sleeping, particularly of young children or sick or older individuals. Furthermore, intensive efforts for community involvement in the control measures through education and participation of the religious and social members can make considerable impact. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Pakistan (42): (SD) Karachi 20171022.5395560\nChikungunya (41): Pakistan (NW) Pakistan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5410638", "date": "2017-10-29 13:05:31", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (44): PAKISTAN\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 28 Oct 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttps://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/10/28/number-of-suspected-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise/\n\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases rose in Karachi as 12 more patients were admitted to hospitals, taking the total number of patients up to 243 since 1 Oct 2017.\n\nAccording to a report issued by the Sindh Health Department, a total 4602 chikungunya suspected cases have been reported across the province since 1 Jan 2017.\n\nThe number of suspected chikungunya cases during October 2017 has reached 254 across Sindh, of which 243 cases have been reported from Karachi.\n\nIn 2016, the number of suspected chikungunya cases reported from Karachi was 405.\n\nChikungunya is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes, and its symptoms include high fever, joint pains, joint swellings, rashes, headaches, muscle pains, nausea and fatigue. Chikungunya is rarely fatal, with the death rate of those afflicted at less than one percent.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Currently, Sindh province is also reporting dengue cases from various districts including Karachi. The key to control of vector borne diseases such as dengue and chikungunya is intensive vector management, not only when the epidemic or outbreak situation arises, but particularly during the low activity season. Use of personal protective measures must be propagated for prevention of mosquito bites, such as wearing clothing to minimize skin exposure to the day-biting mosquito, application of repellents to exposed skin or clothing, use of screens in rooms, use of mosquito coils or other insecticide vaporizers and use of mosquito nets or insecticide-treated mosquito nets during daytime sleeping, particularly of young children or sick or older individuals. Furthermore, intensive efforts for community involvement in the control measures through education and participation of the religious and social members can make considerable impact. - Mod.UBA\n\nA 20171015.5381619\nChikungunya (37): Pakistan 20171001.5352966\nChikungunya (32): Asia (Pakistan) 20170919.5323363\nChikungunya (31): Asia (Pakistan) 20170916.5320238\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170206.4817959\n.................................................sb/lxl/uba/msp/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-01-01 00:00:00", "2017-10-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2042-03-15 00:00:00", "2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karachi", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5401880", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (43): Italy, France, autochthonous", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5401880", "date": "2017-10-01 11:18:43", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (36): ITALY, AUTOCHTHONOUS\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/content/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2017.22.39.17-00646\n\n\nDetection of a chikungunya outbreak in Central Italy, August to September 2017.\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nDi Luca M, Fortuna C, Remoli ME, Riccardo F, Severini F, Toma L, Del Manso M, Benedetti E, Caporali MG, Amendola A, Fiorentini C, De Liberato C, Giammattei R, Romi R, Pezzotti P, Rezza G, Rizzo C.\n\nOutbreak identification and investigation\n----------------------------------------------\nOn 6 and 7 Sep 2017, the National Reference Laboratory for arboviral infections based at the National Institute of Health, Italy, received serum and urine samples from 3 patients with a history of high fever (over 38 C [101.4 F]), severe joint pain and an itching skin rash. Symptoms had started while they were on holiday near the coastal town of Anzio, in the province of Rome, Lazio region (ca 58 km [36 miles] from Rome). The dates of symptom onset were 5 and 11 Aug and 2 Sep [2017], respectively. The patients lived in the same home, and none had travelled to chikungunya, dengue or Zika [virus] endemic areas in the 2 weeks before symptom onset. The 2 patients who developed symptoms at the beginning of August were chikungunya IgM positive, and the infection was confirmed through a neutralisation test (PRNT). The 3rd patient, who was symptomatic at the time of sample collection, was IgM positive and PRNT borderline (PRNT 1:10). Chikungunya virus was detected by RT-PCR followed by nested PCR in both serum and urine and was isolated from urine.\n\nThe regional health authorities immediately implemented measures around this initial cluster, which are described in the national plan for chikungunya surveillance and control [1]. The 3 patients had referred to other individuals in their neighbourhood who had developed similar symptoms since the beginning of August 2017. Epidemiological surveillance was enhanced to identify additional cases (case finding trough general practitioners (GPs), paediatricians, emergency rooms and hospitals). As of 20 Sep 2017, 86 confirmed autochthonous cases of chikungunya were reported to the regional surveillance system; the investigation is ongoing. These were found among people living in Anzio, or people who had travelled there 15 days before symptom onset. Cases from Rome were also identified, with either travel history to Anzio or to other endemic areas. The primary viraemic case who imported the virus into the region has not been identified so far.\n\nEntomological investigation\n-------------------------------\nOn 7 and 8 Sep 2017, adult mosquitoes were collected in the Anzio municipality by using BG Sentinel traps baited with BG-Lure (Biogents, Regensburg, Germany) and captured directly using handheld electric aspirators on vegetation or on exposed skin. Larval collections were performed using dippers or droppers by inspecting artificial containers (removable or non-removable), as potential larval breeding sites. Adults and larvae of _Aedes albopictus_ (tiger mosquito) and _Culex pipiens_ were found in the Anzio municipality area. Mosquito adults were sorted into 12 pools to determine the species, distinguish males from females and to test for chikungunya virus. The number of specimens in each pool ranged from 1 to 13. Among 53 mosquitoes, one pool of 12 _Ae. albopictus_ females which had been collected near the house of the 1st 3 cases identified in Anzio was found to be chikungunya virus positive by PCR. The virus was isolated.\n\nPhylogenetic analysis of patient and mosquito sequences\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nSequences of the PCR amplicons of the virus envelope (E)1 gene from the patient (GenBank numbers: LT908477 and LT908478) and from the mosquitoes were identical (GenBank number: LT908476), and also showed a 100 percent similarity with the sequence of a chikungunya East Central South African (ECSA) strain involved in an ongoing epidemic in Pakistan, which does not carry the A226V mutation. In a phylogenetic analysis, the Italian sequences also clustered with ESCA strain sequences obtained from different parts of the world (Figure 1).\n\nFigure 1. Neighbour-joining phylogenetic analysis of sequences derived from chikungunya virus positive samples obtained in this study, Italy, August-September 2017 [Interested readers can access this figure at the above URL].\n\nHighlighted in the figure are 2 clusters. The 1st, identifiable as 'ESCA genotype', indicates sequences of the ESCA genotype. The 2nd cluster, identifiable as 'E1 A226V', includes all sequences with the A226V mutation in the envelope (E)1 gene, a mutation, which is involved in the increased susceptibility of _Aedes albopictus_ for infection and transmission of chikungunya virus.\n\nControl measures\n--------------------\nOn 8 Sep [2017] Italy launched a 1st alert through the Early Warning Response System (EWRS) in order to alert other European Union countries about the ongoing outbreak. In the affected municipality, vector control activities against larvae and adult mosquitoes were performed and the population was advised to take measures to avoid mosquito bites and to remove all potential breeding sites from their gardens. Moreover, measures such as clinical evaluation of blood donors, gathering post-donation information for donors residing in the Lazio region, and application of 28 days deferral of donors who visited the municipality of Anzio since 1 Aug 2017 were reinforced.\n\nBackground\n--------------\nChikungunya is a self-limiting mosquito-borne viral disease characterised by arthralgia/arthritis primarily of the wrists, knees, ankles and small joints of the extremities lasting from days to months. Between 1/3rd and one half of the patients develop a generally non-pruritic maculopapular rash primarily of the trunk and limbs 1-12 days after the onset of arthritis that resolves in 7-10 days. Myalgia, fatigue, fever and lymphadenopathy are common. Complications are rare; however, chikungunya [virus infection] leads to (self-perceived) long-term sequelae in a considerable proportion of patients. The incubation period ranges from 1 to 10 days (average 3 days).\n\nThe aetiological agent is a single strand, positive sense RNA virus of the Alphavirus genus, Togaviridae family of which 3 main genotypes have been identified: Asian, West African and ECSA [8]. The virus is transmitted by mosquitoes of the _Aedes spp._ primarily _Ae. aegypti_ and _Ae. albopictus_. Transmission through transfusion/transplantation has been demonstrated in animal models.\n\nChikungunya [virus] is endemic in Africa, southeast Asia, the Indian subcontinent, the Pacific region and in tropical regions of the Americas (since 2013). In Europe, autochthonous cases, which were linked to imported cases, were detected in France in the Var department, in September 2010 and in the city of Montpellier, Hrault department, in October 2014. In August 2017, a cluster of locally acquired cases consisting of 4 confirmed and one probable case was also described in the Var department.\n\nDiscussion\n------------\nThe outbreak described here is the 2nd autochthonous chikungunya outbreak detected in Italy. The 1st outbreak, with more than 200 reported cases, occurred between July and September 2007 in the northeast of the country, near the Adriatic coast, in the province of Ravenna. Subsequent to it, Italy set up a national plan for the surveillance and control of the disease. The aim of this surveillance system is to monitor imported cases and local transmission, identify outbreaks in a timely fashion, and to prevent transmission from substances of human origin (SoHO). The surveillance is enhanced during the high vector activity season (1 Jun-31 Oct). The competent vector, _Ae. albopictus_, which was 1st detected in north-western Italy in 1990, is now widely established throughout the country, including the Lazio region. Overall between 2014 and 2016, a total of 128 possible/probable/confirmed imported cases of chikungunya [virus infection] have been notified to the Italian health authorities (mean: 43 cases/year; range: 25 cases in 2015 and 70 cases in 2014). Most cases had a travel history to Central and South America.\n\nAnzio, one of the locations where autochonous chikungunya cases were currently detected, is a holiday resort less than one hour drive away from Rome. Many families visit the area until the beginning of the school year, which in 2017 was on 14 Sep 2017. During the summer, the population density increases in the area owing to the easy commute from Rome. Viraemic individuals exposed in August 2017 are likely to have travelled around resulting in new introductions in receptive areas and challenging the implementation of control measures. The delayed identification of the autochthonous cases in Anzio, a coastal recreational area close to the capital towards the end of summer may have triggered the local transmission in Rome. This suggests an extension of the outbreak and the presence of secondary multifocal transmission chains.\n\nThe lack of access to closed summer houses after mid-September may hamper vector control activities. Summer 2017 has been characterised by particularly high temperatures and by an unusual dry period from May to August, factors that would normally prevent high mosquito density. However, other concomitant factors favoured the activity and abundance of the tiger mosquito including the presence of numerous peridomestic 'man-made' breeding sites within constantly irrigated private gardens.\n\nThe identification of the viral strain involved in the current Italian outbreak as one very close to the ECSA strain involved in the ongoing epidemic in Pakistan is not surprising, even if this virus it is not carrying the A226V mutation, which has been involved in the increased susceptibility of _Ae. albopictus_ for infection and transmission of chikungunya virus. Other yet undefined mutations might be responsible for the vector competence of _Ae. albopictus_, allowing it to sustain the present outbreak. The fact that we found chikungunya RNA in a small size mosquito pool, suggests a high level of virus circulation in the area. The investigation is still ongoing and, due to enhanced surveillance and testing, further cases have been identified, with as of 22 Sep [2017], 102 laboratory-confirmed cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The count has now increased to 102 reported cases. There are 10 new cases. Of these 10 new cases: 5 concern individuals who had resided in the municipality of Anzio within 15 days prior to the onset of symptoms. The remaining 5 new cases concern people resident in the municipality of Rome and have no links with Anzio (http://www.regione.lazio.it/rl_main/?vw=newsDettaglio&id=4128 in Italian). Chikungunya virus transmission remains active in this area and will likely remain so until the onset of freezing temperatures unless vector control measures are effective. The surveillance system detected the 1st cases in a timely way. The Early Warning Response System will be important for notifying neighboring countries to be on the alert for cases.\n\nMaps of Italy can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/italy_admin_06.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63107. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (35): Americas, Europe 20170925.5339931\nChikungunya (34): Italy 20170919.5327495\nChikungunya (33): Asia (Pakistan) 20170919.5323363\nChikungunya (32): Americas, Europe, Asia, research 20170919.5326507\nChikungunya (30): Americas, Europe, Asia, research 20170912.5310090\n2007\n----\nChikungunya - Italy (Emilia Romagna) (08) 20071210.3980\n.................................................ty/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-09-07 00:00:00", "2017-09-20 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-09-15 00:00:00", "2014-10-15 00:00:00", "2017-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-09-14 00:00:00", "2017-08-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Rome", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Romi R", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location":
