"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5352835", "date": "2017-10-01 11:18:43", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (36): ITALY, AUTOCHTHONOUS\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Sep 2017\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/content/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2017.22.39.17-00646\n\n\nDetection of a chikungunya outbreak in Central Italy, August to September 2017.\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nDi Luca M, Fortuna C, Remoli ME, Riccardo F, Severini F, Toma L, Del Manso M, Benedetti E, Caporali MG, Amendola A, Fiorentini C, De Liberato C, Giammattei R, Romi R, Pezzotti P, Rezza G, Rizzo C.\n\nOutbreak identification and investigation\n----------------------------------------------\nOn 6 and 7 Sep 2017, the National Reference Laboratory for arboviral infections based at the National Institute of Health, Italy, received serum and urine samples from 3 patients with a history of high fever (over 38 C [101.4 F]), severe joint pain and an itching skin rash. Symptoms had started while they were on holiday near the coastal town of Anzio, in the province of Rome, Lazio region (ca 58 km [36 miles] from Rome). The dates of symptom onset were 5 and 11 Aug and 2 Sep [2017], respectively. The patients lived in the same home, and none had travelled to chikungunya, dengue or Zika [virus] endemic areas in the 2 weeks before symptom onset. The 2 patients who developed symptoms at the beginning of August were chikungunya IgM positive, and the infection was confirmed through a neutralisation test (PRNT). The 3rd patient, who was symptomatic at the time of sample collection, was IgM positive and PRNT borderline (PRNT 1:10). Chikungunya virus was detected by RT-PCR followed by nested PCR in both serum and urine and was isolated from urine.\n\nThe regional health authorities immediately implemented measures around this initial cluster, which are described in the national plan for chikungunya surveillance and control [1]. The 3 patients had referred to other individuals in their neighbourhood who had developed similar symptoms since the beginning of August 2017. Epidemiological surveillance was enhanced to identify additional cases (case finding trough general practitioners (GPs), paediatricians, emergency rooms and hospitals). As of 20 Sep 2017, 86 confirmed autochthonous cases of chikungunya were reported to the regional surveillance system; the investigation is ongoing. These were found among people living in Anzio, or people who had travelled there 15 days before symptom onset. Cases from Rome were also identified, with either travel history to Anzio or to other endemic areas. The primary viraemic case who imported the virus into the region has not been identified so far.\n\nEntomological investigation\n-------------------------------\nOn 7 and 8 Sep 2017, adult mosquitoes were collected in the Anzio municipality by using BG Sentinel traps baited with BG-Lure (Biogents, Regensburg, Germany) and captured directly using handheld electric aspirators on vegetation or on exposed skin. Larval collections were performed using dippers or droppers by inspecting artificial containers (removable or non-removable), as potential larval breeding sites. Adults and larvae of _Aedes albopictus_ (tiger mosquito) and _Culex pipiens_ were found in the Anzio municipality area. Mosquito adults were sorted into 12 pools to determine the species, distinguish males from females and to test for chikungunya virus. The number of specimens in each pool ranged from 1 to 13. Among 53 mosquitoes, one pool of 12 _Ae. albopictus_ females which had been collected near the house of the 1st 3 cases identified in Anzio was found to be chikungunya virus positive by PCR. The virus was isolated.\n\nPhylogenetic analysis of patient and mosquito sequences\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nSequences of the PCR amplicons of the virus envelope (E)1 gene from the patient (GenBank numbers: LT908477 and LT908478) and from the mosquitoes were identical (GenBank number: LT908476), and also showed a 100 percent similarity with the sequence of a chikungunya East Central South African (ECSA) strain involved in an ongoing epidemic in Pakistan, which does not carry the A226V mutation. In a phylogenetic analysis, the Italian sequences also clustered with ESCA strain sequences obtained from different parts of the world (Figure 1).\n\nFigure 1. Neighbour-joining phylogenetic analysis of sequences derived from chikungunya virus positive samples obtained in this study, Italy, August-September 2017 [Interested readers can access this figure at the above URL].\n\nHighlighted in the figure are 2 clusters. The 1st, identifiable as 'ESCA genotype', indicates sequences of the ESCA genotype. The 2nd cluster, identifiable as 'E1 A226V', includes all sequences with the A226V mutation in the envelope (E)1 gene, a mutation, which is involved in the increased susceptibility of _Aedes albopictus_ for infection and transmission of chikungunya virus.\n\nControl measures\n--------------------\nOn 8 Sep [2017] Italy launched a 1st alert through the Early Warning Response System (EWRS) in order to alert other European Union countries about the ongoing outbreak. In the affected municipality, vector control activities against larvae and adult mosquitoes were performed and the population was advised to take measures to avoid mosquito bites and to remove all potential breeding sites from their gardens. Moreover, measures such as clinical evaluation of blood donors, gathering post-donation information for donors residing in the Lazio region, and application of 28 days deferral of donors who visited the municipality of Anzio since 1 Aug 2017 were reinforced.\n\nBackground\n--------------\nChikungunya is a self-limiting mosquito-borne viral disease characterised by arthralgia/arthritis primarily of the wrists, knees, ankles and small joints of the extremities lasting from days to months. Between 1/3rd and one half of the patients develop a generally non-pruritic maculopapular rash primarily of the trunk and limbs 1-12 days after the onset of arthritis that resolves in 7-10 days. Myalgia, fatigue, fever and lymphadenopathy are common. Complications are rare; however, chikungunya [virus infection] leads to (self-perceived) long-term sequelae in a considerable proportion of patients. The incubation period ranges from 1 to 10 days (average 3 days).\n\nThe aetiological agent is a single strand, positive sense RNA virus of the Alphavirus genus, Togaviridae family of which 3 main genotypes have been identified: Asian, West African and ECSA [8]. The virus is transmitted by mosquitoes of the _Aedes spp._ primarily _Ae. aegypti_ and _Ae. albopictus_. Transmission through transfusion/transplantation has been demonstrated in animal models.\n\nChikungunya [virus] is endemic in Africa, southeast Asia, the Indian subcontinent, the Pacific region and in tropical regions of the Americas (since 2013). In Europe, autochthonous cases, which were linked to imported cases, were detected in France in the Var department, in September 2010 and in the city of Montpellier, Hrault department, in October 2014. In August 2017, a cluster of locally acquired cases consisting of 4 confirmed and one probable case was also described in the Var department.\n\nDiscussion\n------------\nThe outbreak described here is the 2nd autochthonous chikungunya outbreak detected in Italy. The 1st outbreak, with more than 200 reported cases, occurred between July and September 2007 in the northeast of the country, near the Adriatic coast, in the province of Ravenna. Subsequent to it, Italy set up a national plan for the surveillance and control of the disease. The aim of this surveillance system is to monitor imported cases and local transmission, identify outbreaks in a timely fashion, and to prevent transmission from substances of human origin (SoHO). The surveillance is enhanced during the high vector activity season (1 Jun-31 Oct). The competent vector, _Ae. albopictus_, which was 1st detected in north-western Italy in 1990, is now widely established throughout the country, including the Lazio region. Overall between 2014 and 2016, a total of 128 possible/probable/confirmed imported cases of chikungunya [virus infection] have been notified to the Italian health authorities (mean: 43 cases/year; range: 25 cases in 2015 and 70 cases in 2014). Most cases had a travel history to Central and South America.\n\nAnzio, one of the locations where autochonous chikungunya cases were currently detected, is a holiday resort less than one hour drive away from Rome. Many families visit the area until the beginning of the school year, which in 2017 was on 14 Sep 2017. During the summer, the population density increases in the area owing to the easy commute from Rome. Viraemic individuals exposed in August 2017 are likely to have travelled around resulting in new introductions in receptive areas and challenging the implementation of control measures. The delayed identification of the autochthonous cases in Anzio, a coastal recreational area close to the capital towards the end of summer may have triggered the local transmission in Rome. This suggests an extension of the outbreak and the presence of secondary multifocal transmission chains.\n\nThe lack of access to closed summer houses after mid-September may hamper vector control activities. Summer 2017 has been characterised by particularly high temperatures and by an unusual dry period from May to August, factors that would normally prevent high mosquito density. However, other concomitant factors favoured the activity and abundance of the tiger mosquito including the presence of numerous peridomestic 'man-made' breeding sites within constantly irrigated private gardens.\n\nThe identification of the viral strain involved in the current Italian outbreak as one very close to the ECSA strain involved in the ongoing epidemic in Pakistan is not surprising, even if this virus it is not carrying the A226V mutation, which has been involved in the increased susceptibility of _Ae. albopictus_ for infection and transmission of chikungunya virus. Other yet undefined mutations might be responsible for the vector competence of _Ae. albopictus_, allowing it to sustain the present outbreak. The fact that we found chikungunya RNA in a small size mosquito pool, suggests a high level of virus circulation in the area. The investigation is still ongoing and, due to enhanced surveillance and testing, further cases have been identified, with as of 22 Sep [2017], 102 laboratory-confirmed cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The count has now increased to 102 reported cases. There are 10 new cases. Of these 10 new cases: 5 concern individuals who had resided in the municipality of Anzio within 15 days prior to the onset of symptoms. The remaining 5 new cases concern people resident in the municipality of Rome and have no links with Anzio (http://www.regione.lazio.it/rl_main/?vw=newsDettaglio&id=4128 in Italian). Chikungunya virus transmission remains active in this area and will likely remain so until the onset of freezing temperatures unless vector control measures are effective. The surveillance system detected the 1st cases in a timely way. The Early Warning Response System will be important for notifying neighboring countries to be on the alert for cases.\n\nMaps of Italy can be accessed at ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama (San Miguelito district, Panama City)\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department)\n\nEurope\n---\nItaly (Anzio, Lazio region)\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur): WHO\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia (national)\n\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\n\n******\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nWHO/PAHO report\n8 Sep 2017\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory - 2017 to EW 36 [week ending (w/e) 1 Sep 2017]. Cases before EW 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] are not given but are available at the URL above.\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week [w/e] / Local susp. / Local conf. / Imported conf / Deaths\n\nNorth America\n---\nMexico / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 0 / 24 / 0 / 0\nUSA / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 0 / 0 / 38 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nCosta Rica / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 300 / 0 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 407 / 0 / 0 / 0\nNicaragua / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 640 / 18 / 0 / 0\nPanama / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 1996 / 24 / 1 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean\n---\nPuerto Rico / week 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] / 0 / 8 / 0 / 0\n\nAndean Area\n---\nBolivia / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 3192 / 22 / 0 / 0\nColombia / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 852 / 6 / 0 / 0\nPeru / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 833 / 601 / 0 / 0\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nBrazil / week 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] / 21 784 / 112 963 / 86\n\nTotals (all of 2017) / 31 185 / 113 942 / 41 / 88\n[Interestingly, Brazil is the only one of 2 countries reporting deaths this year (2017). - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455;\nCaribbean http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama (San Miguelito district, Panama City). 31 Jul 2017. (conf.) 2 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/Contabilizan-dengue-chikungunya-San-Miguelito_0_1049595573.html [in Spanish]\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department). 17 Aug 2017. (registered) 7 cases.\nhttp://elmundo.com.bo/web2/index.php/noticias/index?id=confirman-que-bebe-nacio-con-microcefalia-a-raiz-del-zika [in Spanish]\n\nEurope\n---\nItaly (Anzio, Lazio region). 8 Sep 2017. (conf.) 3 cases, apparently locally acquired.\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41198774\n\n[Maps of Italy can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/italy_admin_06.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63107.\n\nThis is not the 1st time that there has been local transmission of chikungunya virus in Italy. There was a locally transmitted chikungunya outbreak in 2007 in Emilia Romagna, central Italy. That outbreak was initiated by a viremic individual traveling from India (see Chikungunya - Italy (Emilia Romagna) (04) 20070907.2957)\n\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur). 25 Aug 2017. WHO; as of 23 Aug 2017, (susp.) 8 cases, (probable) 1 case, (conf.) 4 cases.\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/25-august-2017-chikungunya-france/en/\n\n[The case count has increased from 2 in the previous August 2017 report to the number given above. The mosquito vector is not stated, but is likely to be _Aedes albopictus_.\n\nMaps of France can be accessed at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France#Administrative_divisions and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34151. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia (national). 4 Aug 2017. (reported) over 12 255 cases. States most affected: Karnataka 8941 cases, Maharashtra 839, Andhra Pradesh 492.\nhttp://theindiasaga.com/saga-corner/national-capital-reeling-under-chikungunya-and-dengue-outbreaks\n\n[A 24-year-old woman from Delhi was reported to have been hospitalized presenting with dark purple-reddish rashes in multiple body parts, very low platelet count, and abnormal kidney function, among others. Her physicians indicated that this is the 1st case report of chikungunya fever presenting severe life-threatening clots in small blood vessels that they have seen (http://tinyurl.com/y7bdd85m).\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\nDate: October 2017 (ahead of print)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-0307_article\n\n\nRef: da Costa AC, Theze J, Komninakis SCV, et al. Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) 20170809.5235254\nChikungunya (24): Asia (Pakistan) 20170726.5205157\nChikungunya (23): Asia (Bangladesh), case numbers 20170711.5165290\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia 20170704.5149989\nChikungunya (21): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170626.5132080\nChikungunya (20): Asia (Pakistan) 20170623.5127317\nChikungunya (19): Americas, Asia, observations, research Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) Her physicians indicated that this is the 1st case report of chikungunya fever presenting severe life-threatening clots in small blood vessels that they have seen (http://tinyurl.com/y7bdd85m).\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\nDate: October 2017 (ahead of print)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-0307_article\n\n\nRef: da Costa AC, Theze J, Komninakis SCV, et al. Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) 20170809.5235254\nChikungunya (24): Asia (Pakistan) 20170726.5205157\nChikungunya (23): Asia (Bangladesh), case numbers 20170711.5165290\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia 20170704.5149989\nChikungunya (21): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170626.5132080\nChikungunya (20): Asia (Pakistan) 20170623.5127317\nChikungunya (19): Americas, Asia, observations, research Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) States most affected: Karnataka 8941 cases, Maharashtra 839, Andhra Pradesh 492.\nhttp://theindiasaga.com/saga-corner/national-capital-reeling-under-chikungunya-and-dengue-outbreaks\n\n[A 24-year-old woman from Delhi was reported to have been hospitalized presenting with dark purple-reddish rashes in multiple body parts, very low platelet count, and abnormal kidney function, among others. Her physicians indicated that this is the 1st case report of chikungunya fever presenting severe life-threatening clots in small blood vessels that they have seen (http://tinyurl.com/y7bdd85m).\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\nDate: October 2017 (ahead of print)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-0307_article\n\n\nRef: da Costa AC, Theze J, Komninakis SCV, et al. Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) "5310090", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (30): Americas, Europe, Asia, research", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5310090", "date": "2017-09-12 21:29:13", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (30): AMERICAS, EUROPE, ASIA, RESEARCH\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama (San Miguelito district, Panama City)\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department)\n\nEurope\n---\nItaly (Anzio, Lazio region)\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur): WHO\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia (national)\n\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\n\n******\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nWHO/PAHO report\n8 Sep 2017\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory - 2017 to EW 36 [week ending (w/e) 1 Sep 2017]. Cases before EW 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] are not given but are available at the URL above.\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week [w/e] / Local susp. / Local conf. / Imported conf / Deaths\n\nNorth America\n---\nMexico / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 0 / 24 / 0 / 0\nUSA / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 0 / 0 / 38 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nCosta Rica / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 300 / 0 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 407 / 0 / 0 / 0\nNicaragua / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 640 / 18 / 0 / 0\nPanama / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 1996 / 24 / 1 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean\n---\nPuerto Rico / week 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] / 0 / 8 / 0 / 0\n\nAndean Area\n---\nBolivia / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 3192 / 22 / 0 / 0\nColombia / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 852 / 6 / 0 / 0\nPeru / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 833 / 601 / 0 / 0\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nBrazil / week 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] / 21 784 / 112 963 / 86\n\nTotals (all of 2017) / 31 185 / 113 942 / 41 / 88\n[Interestingly, Brazil is the only one of 2 countries reporting deaths this year (2017). - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455;\nCaribbean http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama (San Miguelito district, Panama City). 31 Jul 2017. (conf.) 2 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/Contabilizan-dengue-chikungunya-San-Miguelito_0_1049595573.html [in Spanish]\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department). 17 Aug 2017. (registered) 7 cases.\nhttp://elmundo.com.bo/web2/index.php/noticias/index?id=confirman-que-bebe-nacio-con-microcefalia-a-raiz-del-zika [in Spanish]\n\nEurope\n---\nItaly (Anzio, Lazio region). 8 Sep 2017. (conf.) 3 cases, apparently locally acquired.\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41198774\n\n[Maps of Italy can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/italy_admin_06.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63107.\n\nThis is not the 1st time that there has been local transmission of chikungunya virus in Italy. There was a locally transmitted chikungunya outbreak in 2007 in Emilia Romagna, central Italy. That outbreak was initiated by a viremic individual traveling from India (see Chikungunya - Italy (Emilia Romagna) (04) 20070907.2957)\n\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur). 25 Aug 2017. WHO; as of 23 Aug 2017, (susp.) 8 cases, (probable) 1 case, (conf.) 4 cases.\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/25-august-2017-chikungunya-france/en/\n\n[The case count has increased from 2 in the previous August 2017 report to the number given above. The mosquito vector is not stated, but is likely to be _Aedes albopictus_.\n\nMaps of France can be accessed at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France#Administrative_divisions and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34151. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia (national). 4 Aug 2017. (reported) over 12 255 cases. States most affected: Karnataka 8941 cases, Maharashtra 839, Andhra Pradesh 492.\nhttp://theindiasaga.com/saga-corner/national-capital-reeling-under-chikungunya-and-dengue-outbreaks\n\n[A 24-year-old woman from Delhi was reported to have been hospitalized presenting with dark purple-reddish rashes in multiple body parts, very low platelet count, and abnormal kidney function, among others. Her physicians indicated that this is the 1st case report of chikungunya fever presenting severe life-threatening clots in small blood vessels that they have seen (http://tinyurl.com/y7bdd85m).\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\nDate: October 2017 (ahead of print)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-0307_article\n\n\nRef: da Costa AC, Theze J, Komninakis SCV, et al. Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 EUROPE, ASIA, RESEARCH\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama (San Miguelito district, Panama City)\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department)\n\nEurope\n---\nItaly (Anzio, Lazio region)\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur): WHO\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia (national)\n\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\n\n******\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nWHO/PAHO report\n8 Sep 2017\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory - 2017 to EW 36 [week ending (w/e) 1 Sep 2017]. Cases before EW 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] are not given but are available at the URL above.\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week [w/e] / Local susp. / Local conf. / Imported conf / Deaths\n\nNorth America\n---\nMexico / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 0 / 24 / 0 / 0\nUSA / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 0 / 0 / 38 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nCosta Rica / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 300 / 0 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 407 / 0 / 0 / 0\nNicaragua / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 640 / 18 / 0 / 0\nPanama / week 35 [w/e 1 Sep 2017] / 1996 / 24 / 1 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean\n---\nPuerto Rico / week 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] / 0 / 8 / 0 / 0\n\nAndean Area\n---\nBolivia / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 3192 / 22 / 0 / 0\nColombia / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 852 / 6 / 0 / 0\nPeru / week 34 [w/e 25 Aug 2017] / 833 / 601 / 0 / 0\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nBrazil / week 33 [w/e 18 Aug 2017] / 21 784 / 112 963 / 86\n\nTotals (all of 2017) / 31 185 / 113 942 / 41 / 88\n[Interestingly, Brazil is the only one of 2 countries reporting deaths this year (2017). - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455;\nCaribbean http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama (San Miguelito district, Panama City). 31 Jul 2017. (conf.) 2 cases.\nhttp://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/Contabilizan-dengue-chikungunya-San-Miguelito_0_1049595573.html [in Spanish]\n\nSouth America\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department). 17 Aug 2017. (registered) 7 cases.\nhttp://elmundo.com.bo/web2/index.php/noticias/index?id=confirman-que-bebe-nacio-con-microcefalia-a-raiz-del-zika [in Spanish]\n\nEurope\n---\nItaly (Anzio, Lazio region). 8 Sep 2017. (conf.) 3 cases, apparently locally acquired.\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41198774\n\n[Maps of Italy can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/italy_admin_06.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63107.\n\nThis is not the 1st time that there has been local transmission of chikungunya virus in Italy. There was a locally transmitted chikungunya outbreak in 2007 in Emilia Romagna, central Italy. That outbreak was initiated by a viremic individual traveling from India (see Chikungunya - Italy (Emilia Romagna) (04) 20070907.2957)\n\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur). 25 Aug 2017. WHO; as of 23 Aug 2017, (susp.) 8 cases, (probable) 1 case, (conf.) 4 cases.\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/25-august-2017-chikungunya-france/en/\n\n[The case count has increased from 2 in the previous August 2017 report to the number given above. The mosquito vector is not stated, but is likely to be _Aedes albopictus_.\n\nMaps of France can be accessed at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France#Administrative_divisions and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34151. - Mod.TY]\n\nAsia\n---\nIndia (national). 4 Aug 2017. (reported) over 12 255 cases. States most affected: Karnataka 8941 cases, Maharashtra 839, Andhra Pradesh 492.\nhttp://theindiasaga.com/saga-corner/national-capital-reeling-under-chikungunya-and-dengue-outbreaks\n\n[A 24-year-old woman from Delhi was reported to have been hospitalized presenting with dark purple-reddish rashes in multiple body parts, very low platelet count, and abnormal kidney function, among others. Her physicians indicated that this is the 1st case report of chikungunya fever presenting severe life-threatening clots in small blood vessels that they have seen (http://tinyurl.com/y7bdd85m).\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Brazil: genomic analysis\nDate: October 2017 (ahead of print)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-0307_article\n\n\nRef: da Costa AC, Theze J, Komninakis SCV, et al. Spread of chikungunya virus East/Central/South African genotype in Northeast Brazil. Emerg Infect Dis. 2017 [date cited]. https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2310.170307\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nWe investigated an outbreak of exanthematous illness in Maceio by using molecular surveillance; 76 percent of samples tested positive for chikungunya virus. Genetic analysis of 23 newly generated genomes identified the East/Central/South African [ECSA] genotype, suggesting that this lineage has persisted since mid-2014 in Brazil and may spread in the Americas and beyond.\n\n[Approach]\n----------\nAnalyzed samples were from patients who were on average 37 years of age (range 1-86 years); 175 (64 percent) were female, and 198 (73 percent) resided in Maceio municipality. Diagnostic tests for DENV [dengue virus], ZIKV [Zika virus], and CHIKV [chikungunya virus] confirmed that 208 (76 percent) were positive for CHIKV RNA. In addition, 36 (13.2 percent) were co-infected with CHIKV and ZIKV, consistent with Zika virus circulation in Northeast Brazil in mid-2016. We detected no DENV infections. Cycle threshold (Ct) values for CHIKV RNA-positive samples were lower (average Ct = 24.6) than those for ZIKV (average Ct = 33.5).\n\nWe applied a metagenomics next-generation sequencing protocol to 38 randomly chosen CHIKV RNA-positive samples. We recovered 23 CHIKV genomes (greater than 4000 bp) by using the MiSeq Sequencer (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, California, USA); mean genome coverage was 72x and mean depth coverage 207x. We also included 2 CHIKV RNA-positive samples from Joao Pessoa, Para\u00edba state. We did not detect the E1-A226V adaptive mutation associated with large outbreaks in Asia in the strains we analyzed. We then appended sequences to publicly available data (659 CHIKV isolates) and used maximum-likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic analysis to identify the origins of the outbreak.\n\n[Results and conclusion]\n------------------------\nOn the basis of available sequences of isolates from the Americas, the Maceio sequences we analyzed fell within a single strongly supported monophyletic clade (bootstrap support = 99 percent, posterior support = 1.00) that belongs to the ECSA. Genetic analysis suggests the outbreak most likely originated from transmission cycles not previously identified in northeast Brazil and not from a separate introduction into the Americas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Given active dengue virus transmission in this area at the time that samples for this study were collected, it is likely that the earliest cases of chikungunya virus infection were misdiagnosed as dengue fever. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Asia (Pakistan) 20170910.5306378\nChikungunya (28): Asia (Pakistan) "5268087", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (27): Americas, Europe, Asia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5268087", "date": "2017-07-11 12:00:12", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (23): ASIA (BANGLADESH), CASE NUMBERS\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Jul 2017 10 00:21:35.0 BdST\nSource: bdnews24.com [edited]\nhttp://bdnews24.com/health/2017/07/10/media-reports-on-chikungunya-not-correct-iedcr\n\n\nThe government's disease monitoring arm has refuted media reports on chikungunya saying 'confusion' has been created over the number of people suffering from the viral disease.\n\nThe IEDCR released a statement on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] saying the story of one in 11 people suffering from this Aedes Aegypti mosquito-borne disease being published in the media is \"not correct\". It pointed out that the report might have been picked up from an incomplete telephone-based survey of the IEDCR. It had conducted a telephone-based survey among 4775 people. Of them, 357 gave the information that they were suffering from fever and joint pain, the symptoms of chikungunya.\n\nBut they were not tested later for the confirmation of the disease. The IEDCR said the survey was still ongoing and data compilation and analysis incomplete. Based on that survey, none should come to any conclusion, the disease monitoring agency said.\n\nIt does not provide any information regarding the number of chikungunya patients but gives an idea about the presence of the disease, said the statement.\n\nChikungunya has struck so much fear into the people that a lawyer has even filed a writ petition in the court demanding proper actions.\n\nThe High Court on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] issued a rule asking why it will not order authorities to compensate patients diagnosed with chikungunya.\n\nHowever, IEDCR had advised the people from the beginning not to trouble themselves with running tests for the disease since it does not have any treatment.\n\nBoth dengue and chikungunya show some common symptoms such as fever and pain. But in chikungunya the pain is so severe that people cannot move. It involves all the joints, doctors say. It can be misdiagnosed, but both of them have no specific treatment. Treatment is mainly focused on relieving the symptoms. Paracetamol is the drug of choice for relieving both fever and pain. So there is no need to wait for testing, experts say.\n\nGeneral awareness is important as the Aedes mosquito usually breeds in a small collection of clean water in and around houses, such as inside a flower vase. Intermittent rains cause a proliferation of the breeding when water accumulates in different containers around homes.\n\nThe IEDCR advises removal of all open containers with stagnant water in and around the houses on a regular basis - flower plates and pots, used tires, tree holes and rock pools.\n\nHowever, the institute could not explain the reports of widespread fever in the capital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st identified chikungunya outbreak occurred in Bangladesh in 2008. Later in 2011, a major outbreak was reported from Dhaka district, which was later confirmed to be chikungunya (http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0003907). This indicates that both the virus and the vector are prevalent in the country, resulting in outbreaks in various geographical areas.\n\nEfforts to improve surveillance and identify outbreaks more quickly could provide an opportunity for public health actions, such as mosquito control, to reduce transmission. WHO guidelines suggest that environmental interventions, such as destroying natural and human-made mosquito breeding sites in and around homes, may be more cost-effective than chemical methods to kill larvae and adult mosquitoes [WHO Guidelines for Prevention and Control of Chikungunya Fever. 2009].\n\nIn the report above, as the available information on actual laboratory confirmed Chikungunya cases is not available, even though the data from the survey indicates that the case numbers might be lower, the factual situation can only be ascertained through sentinel or other surveillance initiatives supported by laboratory diagnostics. - Mod.UBA\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5240010", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (26): Asia (Pakistan) comment, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5240010", "date": "2017-07-11 12:00:12", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (23): ASIA (BANGLADESH), CASE NUMBERS\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Jul 2017 10 00:21:35.0 BdST\nSource: bdnews24.com [edited]\nhttp://bdnews24.com/health/2017/07/10/media-reports-on-chikungunya-not-correct-iedcr\n\n\nThe government's disease monitoring arm has refuted media reports on chikungunya saying 'confusion' has been created over the number of people suffering from the viral disease.\n\nThe IEDCR released a statement on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] saying the story of one in 11 people suffering from this Aedes Aegypti mosquito-borne disease being published in the media is \"not correct\". It pointed out that the report might have been picked up from an incomplete telephone-based survey of the IEDCR. It had conducted a telephone-based survey among 4775 people. Of them, 357 gave the information that they were suffering from fever and joint pain, the symptoms of chikungunya.\n\nBut they were not tested later for the confirmation of the disease. The IEDCR said the survey was still ongoing and data compilation and analysis incomplete. Based on that survey, none should come to any conclusion, the disease monitoring agency said.\n\nIt does not provide any information regarding the number of chikungunya patients but gives an idea about the presence of the disease, said the statement.\n\nChikungunya has struck so much fear into the people that a lawyer has even filed a writ petition in the court demanding proper actions.\n\nThe High Court on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] issued a rule asking why it will not order authorities to compensate patients diagnosed with chikungunya.\n\nHowever, IEDCR had advised the people from the beginning not to trouble themselves with running tests for the disease since it does not have any treatment.\n\nBoth dengue and chikungunya show some common symptoms such as fever and pain. But in chikungunya the pain is so severe that people cannot move. It involves all the joints, doctors say. It can be misdiagnosed, but both of them have no specific treatment. Treatment is mainly focused on relieving the symptoms. Paracetamol is the drug of choice for relieving both fever and pain. So there is no need to wait for testing, experts say.\n\nGeneral awareness is important as the Aedes mosquito usually breeds in a small collection of clean water in and around houses, such as inside a flower vase. Intermittent rains cause a proliferation of the breeding when water accumulates in different containers around homes.\n\nThe IEDCR advises removal of all open containers with stagnant water in and around the houses on a regular basis - flower plates and pots, used tires, tree holes and rock pools.\n\nHowever, the institute could not explain the reports of widespread fever in the capital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st identified chikungunya outbreak occurred in Bangladesh in 2008. Later in 2011, a major outbreak was reported from Dhaka district, which was later confirmed to be chikungunya (http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0003907). This indicates that both the virus and the vector are prevalent in the country, resulting in outbreaks in various geographical areas.\n\nEfforts to improve surveillance and identify outbreaks more quickly could provide an opportunity for public health actions, such as mosquito control, to reduce transmission. WHO guidelines suggest that environmental interventions, such as destroying natural and human-made mosquito breeding sites in and around homes, may be more cost-effective than chemical methods to kill larvae and adult mosquitoes [WHO Guidelines for Prevention and Control of Chikungunya Fever. 2009].\n\nIn the report above, as the available information on actual laboratory confirmed Chikungunya cases is not available, even though the data from the survey indicates that the case numbers might be lower, the factual situation can only be ascertained through sentinel or other surveillance initiatives supported by laboratory diagnostics. - Mod.UBA\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia 20170704.5149989\nChikungunya (21): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170626.5132080\nChikungunya (20): Asia (Pakistan) 20170623.5127317\nChikungunya (19): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170610.5096983\nChikungunya (19): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170610.5096983\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Bangladesh) 20170518.5044158\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Bangladesh) 20170515.5037500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) 20170511.5020435\nChikungunya (14): Asia (Pakistan) 20170507.5019416\nChikungunya (13): Asia (Pakistan) 20170429.5000142\nChikungunya (12): Asia (Pakistan) 20170420.4978219\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan) 20170316.4901816\nChikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO 20170302.4870168\nChikungunya (06): Americas, Asia, research 20170206.4817959\nChikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan) 20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n.................................................sb/uba/ec/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2008-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Dhaka", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5235254", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (25): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5235254", "date": "2017-07-11 12:00:12", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (23): ASIA (BANGLADESH), CASE NUMBERS\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Jul 2017 10 00:21:35.0 BdST\nSource: bdnews24.com [edited]\nhttp://bdnews24.com/health/2017/07/10/media-reports-on-chikungunya-not-correct-iedcr\n\n\nThe government's disease monitoring arm has refuted media reports on chikungunya saying 'confusion' has been created over the number of people suffering from the viral disease.\n\nThe IEDCR released a statement on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] saying the story of one in 11 people suffering from this Aedes Aegypti mosquito-borne disease being published in the media is \"not correct\". It pointed out that the report might have been picked up from an incomplete telephone-based survey of the IEDCR. It had conducted a telephone-based survey among 4775 people. Of them, 357 gave the information that they were suffering from fever and joint pain, the symptoms of chikungunya.\n\nBut they were not tested later for the confirmation of the disease. The IEDCR said the survey was still ongoing and data compilation and analysis incomplete. Based on that survey, none should come to any conclusion, the disease monitoring agency said.\n\nIt does not provide any information regarding the number of chikungunya patients but gives an idea about the presence of the disease, said the statement.\n\nChikungunya has struck so much fear into the people that a lawyer has even filed a writ petition in the court demanding proper actions.\n\nThe High Court on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] issued a rule asking why it will not order authorities to compensate patients diagnosed with chikungunya.\n\nHowever, IEDCR had advised the people from the beginning not to trouble themselves with running tests for the disease since it does not have any treatment.\n\nBoth dengue and chikungunya show some common symptoms such as fever and pain. But in chikungunya the pain is so severe that people cannot move. It involves all the joints, doctors say. It can be misdiagnosed, but both of them have no specific treatment. Treatment is mainly focused on relieving the symptoms. Paracetamol is the drug of choice for relieving both fever and pain. So there is no need to wait for testing, experts say.\n\nGeneral awareness is important as the Aedes mosquito usually breeds in a small collection of clean water in and around houses, such as inside a flower vase. Intermittent rains cause a proliferation of the breeding when water accumulates in different containers around homes.\n\nThe IEDCR advises removal of all open containers with stagnant water in and around the houses on a regular basis - flower plates and pots, used tires, tree holes and rock pools.\n\nHowever, the institute could not explain the reports of widespread fever in the capital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st identified chikungunya outbreak occurred in Bangladesh in 2008. Later in 2011, a major outbreak was reported from Dhaka district, which was later confirmed to be chikungunya (http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0003907). This indicates that both the virus and the vector are prevalent in the country, resulting in outbreaks in various geographical areas.\n\nEfforts to improve surveillance and identify outbreaks more quickly could provide an opportunity for public health actions, such as mosquito control, to reduce transmission. WHO guidelines suggest that environmental interventions, such as destroying natural and human-made mosquito breeding sites in and around homes, may be more cost-effective than chemical methods to kill larvae and adult mosquitoes [WHO Guidelines for Prevention and Control of Chikungunya Fever. 2009].\n\nIn the report above, as the available information on actual laboratory confirmed Chikungunya cases is not available, even though the data from the survey indicates that the case numbers might be lower, the factual situation can only be ascertained through sentinel or other surveillance initiatives supported by laboratory diagnostics. - Mod.UBA\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia "2017-07-11 12:00:12", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (23): ASIA (BANGLADESH), CASE NUMBERS\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Jul 2017 10 00:21:35.0 BdST\nSource: bdnews24.com [edited]\nhttp://bdnews24.com/health/2017/07/10/media-reports-on-chikungunya-not-correct-iedcr\n\n\nThe government's disease monitoring arm has refuted media reports on chikungunya saying 'confusion' has been created over the number of people suffering from the viral disease.\n\nThe IEDCR released a statement on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] saying the story of one in 11 people suffering from this Aedes Aegypti mosquito-borne disease being published in the media is \"not correct\". It pointed out that the report might have been picked up from an incomplete telephone-based survey of the IEDCR. It had conducted a telephone-based survey among 4775 people. Of them, 357 gave the information that they were suffering from fever and joint pain, the symptoms of chikungunya.\n\nBut they were not tested later for the confirmation of the disease. The IEDCR said the survey was still ongoing and data compilation and analysis incomplete. Based on that survey, none should come to any conclusion, the disease monitoring agency said.\n\nIt does not provide any information regarding the number of chikungunya patients but gives an idea about the presence of the disease, said the statement.\n\nChikungunya has struck so much fear into the people that a lawyer has even filed a writ petition in the court demanding proper actions.\n\nThe High Court on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] issued a rule asking why it will not order authorities to compensate patients diagnosed with chikungunya.\n\nHowever, IEDCR had advised the people from the beginning not to trouble themselves with running tests for the disease since it does not have any treatment.\n\nBoth dengue and chikungunya show some common symptoms such as fever and pain. But in chikungunya the pain is so severe that people cannot move. It involves all the joints, doctors say. It can be misdiagnosed, but both of them have no specific treatment. Treatment is mainly focused on relieving the symptoms. Paracetamol is the drug of choice for relieving both fever and pain. So there is no need to wait for testing, experts say.\n\nGeneral awareness is important as the Aedes mosquito usually breeds in a small collection of clean water in and around houses, such as inside a flower vase. Intermittent rains cause a proliferation of the breeding when water accumulates in different containers around homes.\n\nThe IEDCR advises removal of all open containers with stagnant water in and around the houses on a regular basis - flower plates and pots, used tires, tree holes and rock pools.\n\nHowever, the institute could not explain the reports of widespread fever in the capital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st identified chikungunya outbreak occurred in Bangladesh in 2008. Later in 2011, a major outbreak was reported from Dhaka district, which was later confirmed to be chikungunya (http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0003907). This indicates that both the virus and the vector are prevalent in the country, resulting in outbreaks in various geographical areas.\n\nEfforts to improve surveillance and identify outbreaks more quickly could provide an opportunity for public health actions, such as mosquito control, to reduce transmission. WHO guidelines suggest that environmental interventions, such as destroying natural and human-made mosquito breeding sites in and around homes, may be more cost-effective than chemical methods to kill larvae and adult mosquitoes [WHO Guidelines for Prevention and Control of Chikungunya Fever. 2009].\n\nIn the report above, as the available information on actual laboratory confirmed Chikungunya cases is not available, even though the data from the survey indicates that the case numbers might be lower, the factual situation can only be ascertained through sentinel or other surveillance initiatives supported by laboratory diagnostics. - Mod.UBA\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia cases is not available, even though the data from the survey indicates that the case numbers might be lower, the factual situation can only be ascertained through sentinel or other surveillance initiatives supported by laboratory diagnostics. - Mod.UBA\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia 20170704.5149989\nChikungunya (21): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170626.5132080\nChikungunya (20): Asia (Pakistan) 20170623.5127317\nChikungunya (19): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170610.5096983\nChikungunya (19): Americas, Asia, observations, research 20170610.5096983\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Bangladesh) 20170518.5044158\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Bangladesh) 20170515.5037500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) 20170511.5020435\nChikungunya (14): Asia (Pakistan) 20170507.5019416\nChikungunya (13): Asia (Pakistan) 20170429.5000142\nChikungunya (12): Asia (Pakistan) 20170420.4978219\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08):
