20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n.................................................sb/uba/ec/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2008-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Dhaka", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5132080", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (21): Americas, Asia, observations, research", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5132080", "date": "2017-07-11 12:00:12", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (23): ASIA (BANGLADESH), CASE NUMBERS\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Jul 2017 10 00:21:35.0 BdST\nSource: bdnews24.com [edited]\nhttp://bdnews24.com/health/2017/07/10/media-reports-on-chikungunya-not-correct-iedcr\n\n\nThe government's disease monitoring arm has refuted media reports on chikungunya saying 'confusion' has been created over the number of people suffering from the viral disease.\n\nThe IEDCR released a statement on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] saying the story of one in 11 people suffering from this Aedes Aegypti mosquito-borne disease being published in the media is \"not correct\". It pointed out that the report might have been picked up from an incomplete telephone-based survey of the IEDCR. It had conducted a telephone-based survey among 4775 people. Of them, 357 gave the information that they were suffering from fever and joint pain, the symptoms of chikungunya.\n\nBut they were not tested later for the confirmation of the disease. The IEDCR said the survey was still ongoing and data compilation and analysis incomplete. Based on that survey, none should come to any conclusion, the disease monitoring agency said.\n\nIt does not provide any information regarding the number of chikungunya patients but gives an idea about the presence of the disease, said the statement.\n\nChikungunya has struck so much fear into the people that a lawyer has even filed a writ petition in the court demanding proper actions.\n\nThe High Court on [Sun 9 Jul 2017] issued a rule asking why it will not order authorities to compensate patients diagnosed with chikungunya.\n\nHowever, IEDCR had advised the people from the beginning not to trouble themselves with running tests for the disease since it does not have any treatment.\n\nBoth dengue and chikungunya show some common symptoms such as fever and pain. But in chikungunya the pain is so severe that people cannot move. It involves all the joints, doctors say. It can be misdiagnosed, but both of them have no specific treatment. Treatment is mainly focused on relieving the symptoms. Paracetamol is the drug of choice for relieving both fever and pain. So there is no need to wait for testing, experts say.\n\nGeneral awareness is important as the Aedes mosquito usually breeds in a small collection of clean water in and around houses, such as inside a flower vase. Intermittent rains cause a proliferation of the breeding when water accumulates in different containers around homes.\n\nThe IEDCR advises removal of all open containers with stagnant water in and around the houses on a regular basis - flower plates and pots, used tires, tree holes and rock pools.\n\nHowever, the institute could not explain the reports of widespread fever in the capital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st identified chikungunya outbreak occurred in Bangladesh in 2008. Later in 2011, a major outbreak was reported from Dhaka district, which was later confirmed to be chikungunya (http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0003907). This indicates that both the virus and the vector are prevalent in the country, resulting in outbreaks in various geographical areas.\n\nEfforts to improve surveillance and identify outbreaks more quickly could provide an opportunity for public health actions, such as mosquito control, to reduce transmission. WHO guidelines suggest that environmental interventions, such as destroying natural and human-made mosquito breeding sites in and around homes, may be more cost-effective than chemical methods to kill larvae and adult mosquitoes [WHO Guidelines for Prevention and Control of Chikungunya Fever. 2009].\n\nIn the report above, as the available information on actual laboratory confirmed Chikungunya cases is not available, even though the data from the survey indicates that the case numbers might be lower, the factual situation can only be ascertained through sentinel or other surveillance initiatives supported by laboratory diagnostics. - Mod.UBA\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Americas, Asia ["2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2008-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5096983", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (19): Americas, Asia, observations, research", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5096983", "date": "2017-04-20 11:49:30", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (12): ASIA (PAKISTAN)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Apr 2017\nSource: The News [edited]\nhttps://www.thenews.com.pk/print/199163-840-cases-reported-in-April-198-test-positive-for-virus\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya was confirmed in city's [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. Its symptoms include high fever, severe pain in joints and muscles, headache, nausea, fatigue, and body rashes.\n\n\"In the 1st 15 days of April [2017] alone, 840 persons were brought to various public and private hospitals on suspicion of having chikungunya infection,\" Dr Taufiq said. Most of the cases were reported from areas known for having poor sanitary conditions, he added.\n\n\"Controlling the outbreak of the virus only lies in extensive fumigation of the areas by the municipal authorities. It is the Karachi Metropolitan Corporation's (KMC) job to improve sanitary conditions and keep the city clean to prevent an outbreak of such vector-borne diseases,\" the director health maintained.\n\nAnother official in the Sindh Health Department informed that a total of 1740 people have been brought to hospitals with chikungunya symptoms since [19 Dec 2016] -- an outbreak of the disease was reported in Malir after hundreds of people were confirmed to have contracted the infection.\n\n\"I have a list of around 1740 people who were brought to the hospitals, blood samples of around 260 of them were sent to the NIH, Islamabad,\" the official claimed. The highest number of cases, 664, were reported from Malir followed by 320 cases in Ibrahim Hyderi, 286 in Keamari, 260 from Bin Qasim Town, whereas 136 and 70 cases were reported from Orangi Town and Lyari respectively.\n\n\"Of the 1740, both the genders were found to have been affected in equal ratio. Most of the patients were aged between 30-39 years even though it is the children and elderly who are usually affected by the mosquito-borne infection,\" the health department official claimed.\n\nProvincial officials of the World Health Organization (WHO) also confirmed the virus's outbreak in Karachi. According to their data maintained till [14 Apr 2017], around 1419 cases of chikungunya had been reported; 215 blood samples were sent to the NIH Islamabad and out of them 169 were confirmed to have the mosquito-borne disease.\n\n\"WHO is in close coordination with the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU-Sindh) and is providing them with necessary support including setting up an advisory council, providing them with pamphlets and posters written in local languages,\" Dr Sara Salman, head of WHO Sindh, said in response to queries regarding the infection's outbreak.\n\nCiting WHO and [US] Centre for Disease Control (CDC) Atlanta's guidelines, renowned physician Dr Zeeshan Ansari said there was no specific antiviral drug treatment for chikungunya yet. \"Treatment is directed primarily at relieving the symptoms, such as administering paracetamol to patients for joint pains, anti-pyretics, optimal analgesics and fluids for other symptoms.\" Those infected with the disease were advised by Dr Ansari to have plenty of rest, fluids, and use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve acute pain and fever.\n\n[Byline: M Waqar Bhatti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on the recent report from the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU), from 19 Dec 2016 to 14 Apr 2017, 1419 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered, using the following WHO recommended case definition in the different towns of Karachi: \"A person with acute onset of fever (102 deg F/39 deg C) and severe arthralgia or arthritis not explained by other medical conditions, and who resides or has visited epidemic or endemic areas within 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.\"\n\nAccording to the available data (up to 16 Apr 2017), cases continue to be reported. A total of 245 samples have been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH), Islamabad from Sindh, for diagnostic Laboratory confirmation. Out of these, 179 samples were found positive for chikungunya virus on RT-PCR.\n\nThe numbers mentioned in the news report above are lower than the figures shared by RDSRU Sindh.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Muhammad Asif Syed, Provincial Technical Officer the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit, Karachi, Sindh, for the information above on the chikungunya outbreak. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/947.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan) 20170316.4901816\nChikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO 20170302.4870168\nChikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan) 20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n----\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. RFI 20161218.4706486\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09): Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (03): Americas, Asia {"location": "Malir", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5052540", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (18): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5052540", "date": "2017-04-20 11:49:30", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (12): ASIA (PAKISTAN)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Apr 2017\nSource: The News [edited]\nhttps://www.thenews.com.pk/print/199163-840-cases-reported-in-April-198-test-positive-for-virus\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya was confirmed in city's [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. Its symptoms include high fever, severe pain in joints and muscles, headache, nausea, fatigue, and body rashes.\n\n\"In the 1st 15 days of April [2017] alone, 840 persons were brought to various public and private hospitals on suspicion of having chikungunya infection,\" Dr Taufiq said. Most of the cases were reported from areas known for having poor sanitary conditions, he added.\n\n\"Controlling the outbreak of the virus only lies in extensive fumigation of the areas by the municipal authorities. It is the Karachi Metropolitan Corporation's (KMC) job to improve sanitary conditions and keep the city clean to prevent an outbreak of such vector-borne diseases,\" the director health maintained.\n\nAnother official in the Sindh Health Department informed that a total of 1740 people have been brought to hospitals with chikungunya symptoms since [19 Dec 2016] -- an outbreak of the disease was reported in Malir after hundreds of people were confirmed to have contracted the infection.\n\n\"I have a list of around 1740 people who were brought to the hospitals, blood samples of around 260 of them were sent to the NIH, Islamabad,\" the official claimed. The highest number of cases, 664, were reported from Malir followed by 320 cases in Ibrahim Hyderi, 286 in Keamari, 260 from Bin Qasim Town, whereas 136 and 70 cases were reported from Orangi Town and Lyari respectively.\n\n\"Of the 1740, both the genders were found to have been affected in equal ratio. Most of the patients were aged between 30-39 years even though it is the children and elderly who are usually affected by the mosquito-borne infection,\" the health department official claimed.\n\nProvincial officials of the World Health Organization (WHO) also confirmed the virus's outbreak in Karachi. According to their data maintained till [14 Apr 2017], around 1419 cases of chikungunya had been reported; 215 blood samples were sent to the NIH Islamabad and out of them 169 were confirmed to have the mosquito-borne disease.\n\n\"WHO is in close coordination with the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU-Sindh) and is providing them with necessary support including setting up an advisory council, providing them with pamphlets and posters written in local languages,\" Dr Sara Salman, head of WHO Sindh, said in response to queries regarding the infection's outbreak.\n\nCiting WHO and [US] Centre for Disease Control (CDC) Atlanta's guidelines, renowned physician Dr Zeeshan Ansari said there was no specific antiviral drug treatment for chikungunya yet. \"Treatment is directed primarily at relieving the symptoms, such as administering paracetamol to patients for joint pains, anti-pyretics, optimal analgesics and fluids for other symptoms.\" Those infected with the disease were advised by Dr Ansari to have plenty of rest, fluids, and use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve acute pain and fever.\n\n[Byline: M Waqar Bhatti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on the recent report from the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU), from 19 Dec 2016 to 14 Apr 2017, 1419 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered, using the following WHO recommended case definition in the different towns of Karachi: \"A person with acute onset of fever (102 deg F/39 deg C) and severe arthralgia or arthritis not explained by other medical conditions, and who resides or has visited epidemic or endemic areas within 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.\"\n\nAccording to the available data (up to 16 Apr 2017), cases continue to be reported. A total of 245 samples have been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH), Islamabad from Sindh, for diagnostic Laboratory confirmation. Out of these, 179 samples were found positive for chikungunya virus on RT-PCR.\n\nThe numbers mentioned in the news report above are lower than the figures shared by RDSRU Sindh.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Muhammad Asif Syed, Provincial Technical Officer the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit, Karachi, Sindh, for the information above on the chikungunya outbreak. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/947.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan) 20170316.4901816\nChikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO 20170302.4870168\nChikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan) 20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n----\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. RFI 20161218.4706486\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): [edited]\nhttps://www.thenews.com.pk/print/199163-840-cases-reported-in-April-198-test-positive-for-virus\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya was confirmed in city's [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. Its symptoms include high fever, severe pain in joints and muscles, headache, nausea, fatigue, and body rashes.\n\n\"In the 1st 15 days of April [2017] alone, 840 persons were brought to various public and private hospitals on suspicion of having chikungunya infection,\" Dr Taufiq said. Most of the cases were reported from areas known for having poor sanitary conditions, he added.\n\n\"Controlling the outbreak of the virus only lies in extensive fumigation of the areas by the municipal authorities. It is the Karachi Metropolitan Corporation's (KMC) job to improve sanitary conditions and keep the city clean to prevent an outbreak of such vector-borne diseases,\" the director health maintained.\n\nAnother official in the Sindh Health Department informed that a total of 1740 people have been brought to hospitals with chikungunya symptoms since [19 Dec 2016] -- an outbreak of the disease was reported in Malir after hundreds of people were confirmed to have contracted the infection.\n\n\"I have a list of around 1740 people who were brought to the hospitals, blood samples of around 260 of them were sent to the NIH, Islamabad,\" the official claimed. The highest number of cases, 664, were reported from Malir followed by 320 cases in Ibrahim Hyderi, 286 in Keamari, 260 from Bin Qasim Town, whereas 136 and 70 cases were reported from Orangi Town and Lyari respectively.\n\n\"Of the 1740, both the genders were found to have been affected in equal ratio. Most of the patients were aged between 30-39 years even though it is the children and elderly who are usually affected by the mosquito-borne infection,\" the health department official claimed.\n\nProvincial officials of the World Health Organization (WHO) also confirmed the virus's outbreak in Karachi. According to their data maintained till [14 Apr 2017], around 1419 cases of chikungunya had been reported; 215 blood samples were sent to the NIH Islamabad and out of them 169 were confirmed to have the mosquito-borne disease.\n\n\"WHO is in close coordination with the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU-Sindh) and is providing them with necessary support including setting up an advisory council, providing them with pamphlets and posters written in local languages,\" Dr Sara Salman, head of WHO Sindh, said in response to queries regarding the infection's outbreak.\n\nCiting WHO and [US] Centre for Disease Control (CDC) Atlanta's guidelines, renowned physician Dr Zeeshan Ansari said there was no specific antiviral drug treatment for chikungunya yet. \"Treatment is directed primarily at relieving the symptoms, such as administering paracetamol to patients for joint pains, anti-pyretics, optimal analgesics and fluids for other symptoms.\" Those infected with the disease were advised by Dr Ansari to have plenty of rest, fluids, and use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve acute pain and fever.\n\n[Byline: M Waqar Bhatti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on the recent report from the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU), from 19 Dec 2016 to 14 Apr 2017, 1419 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered, using the following WHO recommended case definition in the different towns of Karachi: \"A person with acute onset of fever (102 deg F/39 deg C) and severe arthralgia or arthritis not explained by other medical conditions, and who resides or has visited epidemic or endemic areas within 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.\"\n\nAccording to the available data (up to 16 Apr 2017), cases continue to be reported. A total of 245 samples have been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH), Islamabad from Sindh, for diagnostic Laboratory confirmation. Out of these, 179 samples were found positive for chikungunya virus on RT-PCR.\n\nThe numbers mentioned in the news report above are lower than the figures shared by RDSRU Sindh.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Muhammad Asif Syed, Provincial Technical Officer the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit, Karachi, Sindh, for the information above on the chikungunya outbreak. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/947.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan) 20170316.4901816\nChikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO 20170302.4870168\nChikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan) 20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n----\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. [edited]\nhttps://www.thenews.com.pk/print/199163-840-cases-reported-in-April-198-test-positive-for-virus\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya was confirmed in city's [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. Most of the cases were reported from areas known for having poor sanitary conditions, he added.\n\n\"Controlling the outbreak of the virus only lies in extensive fumigation of the areas by the municipal authorities. It is the Karachi Metropolitan Corporation's (KMC) job to improve sanitary conditions and keep the city clean to prevent an outbreak of such vector-borne diseases,\" the director health maintained.\n\nAnother official in the Sindh Health Department informed that a total of 1740 people have been brought to hospitals with chikungunya symptoms since [19 Dec 2016] -- an outbreak of the disease was reported in Malir after hundreds of people were confirmed to have contracted the infection.\n\n\"I have a list of around 1740 people who were brought to the hospitals, blood samples of around 260 of them were sent to the NIH, Islamabad,\" the official claimed. The highest number of cases, 664, were reported from Malir followed by 320 cases in Ibrahim Hyderi, 286 in Keamari, 260 from Bin Qasim Town, whereas 136 and 70 cases were reported from Orangi Town and Lyari respectively.\n\n\"Of the 1740, both the genders were found to have been affected in equal ratio. Most of the patients were aged between 30-39 years even though it is the children and elderly who are usually affected by the mosquito-borne infection,\" the health department official claimed.\n\nProvincial officials of the World Health Organization (WHO) also confirmed the virus's outbreak in Karachi. According to their data maintained till [14 Apr 2017], around 1419 cases of chikungunya had been reported; 215 blood samples were sent to the NIH Islamabad and out of them 169 were confirmed to have the mosquito-borne disease.\n\n\"WHO is in close coordination with the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU-Sindh) and is providing them with necessary support including setting up an advisory council, providing them with pamphlets and posters written in local languages,\" Dr Sara Salman, head of WHO Sindh, said in response to queries regarding the infection's outbreak.\n\nCiting WHO and [US] Centre for Disease Control (CDC) Atlanta's guidelines, renowned physician Dr Zeeshan Ansari said there was no specific antiviral drug treatment for chikungunya yet. \"Treatment is directed primarily at relieving the symptoms, such as administering paracetamol to patients for joint pains, anti-pyretics, optimal analgesics and fluids for other symptoms.\" Those infected with the disease were advised by Dr Ansari to have plenty of rest, fluids, and use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve acute pain and fever.\n\n[Byline: M Waqar Bhatti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on the recent report from the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU), from 19 Dec 2016 to 14 Apr 2017, 1419 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered, using the following WHO recommended case definition in the different towns of Karachi: \"A person with acute onset of fever (102 deg F/39 deg C) and severe arthralgia or arthritis not explained by other medical conditions, and who resides or has visited epidemic or endemic areas within 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.\"\n\nAccording to the available data (up to 16 Apr 2017), cases continue to be reported. {"location": "Malir", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5020435", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Chikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5020435", "date": "2017-04-20 11:49:30", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (12): ASIA (PAKISTAN)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Apr 2017\nSource: The News [edited]\nhttps://www.thenews.com.pk/print/199163-840-cases-reported-in-April-198-test-positive-for-virus\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya was confirmed in city's [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. Its symptoms include high fever, severe pain in joints and muscles, headache, nausea, fatigue, and body rashes.\n\n\"In the 1st 15 days of April [2017] alone, 840 persons were brought to various public and private hospitals on suspicion of having chikungunya infection,\" Dr Taufiq said. Most of the cases were reported from areas known for having poor sanitary conditions, he added.\n\n\"Controlling the outbreak of the virus only lies in extensive fumigation of the areas by the municipal authorities. It is the Karachi Metropolitan Corporation's (KMC) job to improve sanitary conditions and keep the city clean to prevent an outbreak of such vector-borne diseases,\" the director health maintained.\n\nAnother official in the Sindh Health Department informed that a total of 1740 people have been brought to hospitals with chikungunya symptoms since [19 Dec 2016] -- an outbreak of the disease was reported in Malir after hundreds of people were confirmed to have contracted the infection.\n\n\"I have a list of around 1740 people who were brought to the hospitals, blood samples of around 260 of them were sent to the NIH, Islamabad,\" the official claimed. The highest number of cases, 664, were reported from Malir followed by 320 cases in Ibrahim Hyderi, 286 in Keamari, 260 from Bin Qasim Town, whereas 136 and 70 cases were reported from Orangi Town and Lyari respectively.\n\n\"Of the 1740, both the genders were found to have been affected in equal ratio. Most of the patients were aged between 30-39 years even though it is the children and elderly who are usually affected by the mosquito-borne infection,\" the health department official claimed.\n\nProvincial officials of the World Health Organization (WHO) also confirmed the virus's outbreak in Karachi. According to their data maintained till [14 Apr 2017], around 1419 cases of chikungunya had been reported; 215 blood samples were sent to the NIH Islamabad and out of them 169 were confirmed to have the mosquito-borne disease.\n\n\"WHO is in close coordination with the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU-Sindh) and is providing them with necessary support including setting up an advisory council, providing them with pamphlets and posters written in local languages,\" Dr Sara Salman, head of WHO Sindh, said in response to queries regarding the infection's outbreak.\n\nCiting WHO and [US] Centre for Disease Control (CDC) Atlanta's guidelines, renowned physician Dr Zeeshan Ansari said there was no specific antiviral drug treatment for chikungunya yet. \"Treatment is directed primarily at relieving the symptoms, such as administering paracetamol to patients for joint pains, anti-pyretics, optimal analgesics and fluids for other symptoms.\" Those infected with the disease were advised by Dr Ansari to have plenty of rest, fluids, and use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve acute pain and fever.\n\n[Byline: M Waqar Bhatti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on the recent report from the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU), from 19 Dec 2016 to 14 Apr 2017, 1419 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered, using the following WHO recommended case definition in the different towns of Karachi: \"A person with acute onset of fever (102 deg F/39 deg C) and severe arthralgia or arthritis not explained by other medical conditions, and who resides or has visited epidemic or endemic areas within 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.\"\n\nAccording to the available data (up to 16 Apr 2017), cases continue to be reported. A total of 245 samples have been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH), Islamabad from Sindh, for diagnostic Laboratory confirmation. Out of these, 179 samples were found positive for chikungunya virus on RT-PCR.\n\nThe numbers mentioned in the news report above are lower than the figures shared by RDSRU Sindh.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Muhammad Asif Syed, Provincial Technical Officer the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit, Karachi, Sindh, for the information above on the chikungunya outbreak. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/947.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan) 20170316.4901816\nChikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO 20170302.4870168\nChikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan) 20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n----\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. RFI 20161218.4706486\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09): Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (03): Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia 20160108.3920697\n.................................................sb/uba/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1740-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "1740-03-15 00:00:00", "1740-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 {"location": "Malir", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5019416", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (14): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5019416", "date": "2017-04-20 11:49:30", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (12): ASIA (PAKISTAN)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Apr 2017\nSource: The News [edited]\nhttps://www.thenews.com.pk/print/199163-840-cases-reported-in-April-198-test-positive-for-virus\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya was confirmed in city's [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. Its symptoms include high fever, severe pain in joints and muscles, headache, nausea, fatigue, and body rashes.\n\n\"In the 1st 15 days of April [2017] alone, 840 persons were brought to various public and private hospitals on suspicion of having chikungunya infection,\" Dr Taufiq said. Most of the cases were reported from areas known for having poor sanitary conditions, he added.\n\n\"Controlling the outbreak of the virus only lies in extensive fumigation of the areas by the municipal authorities. It is the Karachi Metropolitan Corporation's (KMC) job to improve sanitary conditions and keep the city clean to prevent an outbreak of such vector-borne diseases,\" the director health maintained.\n\nAnother official in the Sindh Health Department informed that a total of 1740 people have been brought to hospitals with chikungunya symptoms since [19 Dec 2016] -- an outbreak of the disease was reported in Malir after hundreds of people were confirmed to have contracted the infection.\n\n\"I have a list of around 1740 people who were brought to the hospitals, blood samples of around 260 of them were sent to the NIH, Islamabad,\" the official claimed. The highest number of cases, 664, were reported from Malir followed by 320 cases in Ibrahim Hyderi, 286 in Keamari, 260 from Bin Qasim Town, whereas 136 and 70 cases were reported from Orangi Town and Lyari respectively.\n\n\"Of the 1740, both the genders were found to have been affected in equal ratio. Most of the patients were aged between 30-39 years even though it is the children and elderly who are usually affected by the mosquito-borne infection,\" the health department official claimed.\n\nProvincial officials of the World Health Organization (WHO) also confirmed the virus's outbreak in Karachi. According to their data maintained till [14 Apr 2017], around 1419 cases of chikungunya had been reported; 215 blood samples were sent to the NIH Islamabad and out of them 169 were confirmed to have the mosquito-borne disease.\n\n\"WHO is in close coordination with the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU-Sindh) and is providing them with necessary support including setting up an advisory council, providing them with pamphlets and posters written in local languages,\" Dr Sara Salman, head of WHO Sindh, said in response to queries regarding the infection's outbreak.\n\nCiting WHO and [US] Centre for Disease Control (CDC) Atlanta's guidelines, renowned physician Dr Zeeshan Ansari said there was no specific antiviral drug treatment for chikungunya yet. \"Treatment is directed primarily at relieving the symptoms, such as administering paracetamol to patients for joint pains, anti-pyretics, optimal analgesics and fluids for other symptoms.\" Those infected with the disease were advised by Dr Ansari to have plenty of rest, fluids, and use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve acute pain and fever.\n\n[Byline: M Waqar Bhatti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on the recent report from the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU), from 19 Dec 2016 to 14 Apr 2017, 1419 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered, using the following WHO recommended case definition in the different towns of Karachi: \"A person with acute onset of fever (102 deg F/39 deg C) and severe arthralgia or arthritis not explained by other medical conditions, and who resides or has visited epidemic or endemic areas within 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.\"\n\nAccording to the available data (up to 16 Apr 2017), cases continue to be reported. A total of 245 samples have been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH), Islamabad from Sindh, for diagnostic Laboratory confirmation. Out of these, 179 samples were found positive for chikungunya virus on RT-PCR.\n\nThe numbers mentioned in the news report above are lower than the figures shared by RDSRU Sindh.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Muhammad Asif Syed, Provincial Technical Officer the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit, Karachi, Sindh, for the information above on the chikungunya outbreak. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/947.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan) 20170316.4901816\nChikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO 20170302.4870168\nChikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan) 20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n----\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. {"location": "Malir", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4978219", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (12): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4978219", "date": "2017-04-20 11:49:30", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (12): ASIA (PAKISTAN)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Apr 2017\nSource: The News [edited]\nhttps://www.thenews.com.pk/print/199163-840-cases-reported-in-April-198-test-positive-for-virus\n\n\nAn outbreak of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya was confirmed in city's [Karachi] coastal areas after around 840 people were reported by health authorities to have contracted the virus in the first 15 days of April [2017] only. Of these, 198 patients were confirmed to have contracted the virus by the National Institute of Health in Islamabad.\n\nThe areas from where the highest numbers of cases were reported include Ibrahim Hyderi, Keamari, Malir and Lyari among others. \"The NIH, Islamabad tested 198 people positive for the mosquito-borne virus,\" Karachi Director Health Karachi Dr Muhammad Taufiq informed The News.\n\nThe disease is non-lethal and is [transmitted] by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, which also carries the dengue and Zika viruses. Its symptoms include high fever, severe pain in joints and muscles, headache, nausea, fatigue, and body rashes.\n\n\"In the 1st 15 days of April [2017] alone, 840 persons were brought to various public and private hospitals on suspicion of having chikungunya infection,\" Dr Taufiq said. Most of the cases were reported from areas known for having poor sanitary conditions, he added.\n\n\"Controlling the outbreak of the virus only lies in extensive fumigation of the areas by the municipal authorities. It is the Karachi Metropolitan Corporation's (KMC) job to improve sanitary conditions and keep the city clean to prevent an outbreak of such vector-borne diseases,\" the director health maintained.\n\nAnother official in the Sindh Health Department informed that a total of 1740 people have been brought to hospitals with chikungunya symptoms since [19 Dec 2016] -- an outbreak of the disease was reported in Malir after hundreds of people were confirmed to have contracted the infection.\n\n\"I have a list of around 1740 people who were brought to the hospitals, blood samples of around 260 of them were sent to the NIH, Islamabad,\" the official claimed. The highest number of cases, 664, were reported from Malir followed by 320 cases in Ibrahim Hyderi, 286 in Keamari, 260 from Bin Qasim Town, whereas 136 and 70 cases were reported from Orangi Town and Lyari respectively.\n\n\"Of the 1740, both the genders were found to have been affected in equal ratio. Most of the patients were aged between 30-39 years even though it is the children and elderly who are usually affected by the mosquito-borne infection,\" the health department official claimed.\n\nProvincial officials of the World Health Organization (WHO) also confirmed the virus's outbreak in Karachi. According to their data maintained till [14 Apr 2017], around 1419 cases of chikungunya had been reported; 215 blood samples were sent to the NIH Islamabad and out of them 169 were confirmed to have the mosquito-borne disease.\n\n\"WHO is in close coordination with the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU-Sindh) and is providing them with necessary support including setting up an advisory council, providing them with pamphlets and posters written in local languages,\" Dr Sara Salman, head of WHO Sindh, said in response to queries regarding the infection's outbreak.\n\nCiting WHO and [US] Centre for Disease Control (CDC) Atlanta's guidelines, renowned physician Dr Zeeshan Ansari said there was no specific antiviral drug treatment for chikungunya yet. \"Treatment is directed primarily at relieving the symptoms, such as administering paracetamol to patients for joint pains, anti-pyretics, optimal analgesics and fluids for other symptoms.\" Those infected with the disease were advised by Dr Ansari to have plenty of rest, fluids, and use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to relieve acute pain and fever.\n\n[Byline: M Waqar Bhatti]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Based on the recent report from the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit (RDSRU), from 19 Dec 2016 to 14 Apr 2017, 1419 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered, using the following WHO recommended case definition in the different towns of Karachi: \"A person with acute onset of fever (102 deg F/39 deg C) and severe arthralgia or arthritis not explained by other medical conditions, and who resides or has visited epidemic or endemic areas within 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.\"\n\nAccording to the available data (up to 16 Apr 2017), cases continue to be reported. A total of 245 samples have been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH), Islamabad from Sindh, for diagnostic Laboratory confirmation. Out of these, 179 samples were found positive for chikungunya virus on RT-PCR.\n\nThe numbers mentioned in the news report above are lower than the figures shared by RDSRU Sindh.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Muhammad Asif Syed, Provincial Technical Officer the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit, Karachi, Sindh, for the information above on the chikungunya outbreak. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/947.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (11): Asia (Pakistan) 20170405.4947304\nChikungunya (10): Asia (Nepal) 20170402.4942966\nChikungunya (09): Asia (Pakistan) 20170327.4929182\nChikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan) 20170316.4901816\nChikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO 20170302.4870168\nChikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan) 20170120.4774934\nChikungunya (04): Asia (Pakistan) spread 20170116.4767440\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n----\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. "2017-01-16 16:57:21", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (04): ASIA (PAKISTAN) SPREAD\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/01/14/chikungunya-viral-fever-moves-to-lyari/\n\n\nChikungunya viral fever cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He claimed that the situation in Lyari Town now is under control and informed that a total of 26 suspected chikungunya viral fever cases have been reported from Lyari Town from [29 Dec 2016], to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017].\n\nPanhwar said 480 suspected chikungunya fever cases had been reported in Saudabad and its adjoining areas to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017], 4 out of which tested positive. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/01/14/chikungunya-viral-fever-moves-to-lyari/\n\n\nChikungunya viral fever cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. SPREAD\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/01/14/chikungunya-viral-fever-moves-to-lyari/\n\n\nChikungunya viral fever cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He claimed that the situation in Lyari Town now is under control and informed that a total of 26 suspected chikungunya viral fever cases have been reported from Lyari Town from [29 Dec 2016], to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017].\n\nPanhwar said 480 suspected chikungunya fever cases had been reported in Saudabad and its adjoining areas to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017], 4 out of which tested positive. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (08): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4901816", "date": "2017-01-16 16:57:21", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (04): ASIA (PAKISTAN) SPREAD\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/01/14/chikungunya-viral-fever-moves-to-lyari/\n\n\nChikungunya viral fever cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He claimed that the situation in Lyari Town now is under control and informed that a total of 26 suspected chikungunya viral fever cases have been reported from Lyari Town from [29 Dec 2016], to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017].\n\nPanhwar said 480 suspected chikungunya fever cases had been reported in Saudabad and its adjoining areas to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017], 4 out of which tested positive. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (07): Asia (Pakistan) WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4870168", "date": "2017-01-16 16:57:21", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (04): ASIA (PAKISTAN) SPREAD\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/01/14/chikungunya-viral-fever-moves-to-lyari/\n\n\nChikungunya viral fever cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He claimed that the situation in Lyari Town now is under control and informed that a total of 26 suspected chikungunya viral fever cases have been reported from Lyari Town from [29 Dec 2016], to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017].\n\nPanhwar said 480 suspected chikungunya fever cases had been reported in Saudabad and its adjoining areas to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017], 4 out of which tested positive. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (05): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4774934", "date": "2017-01-16 16:57:21", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (04): ASIA (PAKISTAN) SPREAD\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/01/14/chikungunya-viral-fever-moves-to-lyari/\n\n\nChikungunya viral fever cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He claimed that the situation in Lyari Town now is under control and informed that a total of 26 suspected chikungunya viral fever cases have been reported from Lyari Town from [29 Dec 2016], to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017].\n\nPanhwar said 480 suspected chikungunya fever cases had been reported in Saudabad and its adjoining areas to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017], 4 out of which tested positive. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp.
