SPREAD\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Jan 2017\nSource: Pakistan Today [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/01/14/chikungunya-viral-fever-moves-to-lyari/\n\n\nChikungunya viral fever cases have also been reported from Lyari Town of Karachi for the last few weeks. The National Institute of Health (NIH) Islamabad has confirmed the presence of Chikungunya virus in Lyari as 7 people tested positive out of 9 samples sent to the NIH.\n\nTalking to PPI [Pakistan Press International], director [of] health services Dr Abdul Wahid Panhwar confirmed the presence of chikungunya viral fever in Lyari Town. He said that blood samples of 9 people had been sent to the National Institute of Health (NIH) for investigation and 7 of them had tested positive.\n\nHe added that monitoring teams have been formed and moved to Lyari Town to tackle the prevailing situation. He said the teams are visiting the private hospitals and clinics of Lyari Town to monitor the situation. He claimed that the situation in Lyari Town now is under control and informed that a total of 26 suspected chikungunya viral fever cases have been reported from Lyari Town from [29 Dec 2016], to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017].\n\nPanhwar said 480 suspected chikungunya fever cases had been reported in Saudabad and its adjoining areas to date [Sat 14 Jan 2017], 4 out of which tested positive. He further said a total of 510 chikungunya fever cases had been reported from Saudabad and Lyari areas so far.\n\nHowever, independent sources said that over 5000 patients were affected by chikungunya viral fever in Saudabad and Lyari in a month. They said that chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes.\n\nTo control mosquito breeding is the 1st step to control the chikungunya viral fever; however, the city administration is helpless to overcome leaking pipelines and overflowing gutters in almost all parts of the city.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From 19 Dec 2016 to 11 Jan 2017, a total of 480 suspected cases of chikungunya were identified and registered following WHO recommended case definition in the Malir town, district Korangi (Karachi), as reported by the Regional Disease Surveillance and Response Unit in Karachi (RDSRU). RDSRU has Field Epidemiology and Laboratory Training Programme trained field epidemiologists monitoring the ongoing outbreak.\n\nFrom the Lyari region, the National Institute of Health (NIH) of Islamabad has confirmed 5 chikungunya positive cases out of 7 samples forwarded from a total of 29 suspected cases that reported at the Lyari General Hospital. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/707.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan) 20170110.4754019\nChikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan) 20170107.4742890\nChikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan) 20170102.4731668\n2016\n---\nChikungunya (18): Pakistan (SD) IHR reporting, case update 20161229.4727442\nChikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India 20161226.4724577\nChikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed 20161222.4717500\nChikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf 20161221.4715533\nUndiagnosed illness - Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. RFI 20161218.4706486\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09): Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (03): Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia 20160108.3920697\n.................................................sb/uba/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "20161005.4539231", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "lyari", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Lyari", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Karachi", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Islamabad", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Saudabad", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Malir", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4754019", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Chikungunya (03): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4754019", "date": "2016-12-18 12:54:20", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. According to WHO information, Pakistan is also among countries having documented, endemic, or epidemic chikungunya disease http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/.\n\nFurther epidemiological data on individual cases and their laboratory confirmation (if conducted) will be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09) - Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas 20160223.4044850\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20160217.4027484\nChikungunya (03) - Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (02): Americas 20160126.3968082\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia 20160108.3920697\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "20161005.4539231", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Islamabad", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Khokhorapar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4742890", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (02): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4742890", "date": "2016-12-18 12:54:20", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. According to WHO information, Pakistan is also among countries having documented, endemic, or epidemic chikungunya disease http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/.\n\nFurther epidemiological data on individual cases and their laboratory confirmation (if conducted) will be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09) - Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas 20160223.4044850\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20160217.4027484\nChikungunya (03) - Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (02): Americas 20160126.3968082\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia 20160108.3920697\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "20161005.4539231", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Islamabad", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Khokhorapar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4731668", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (01): Asia (Pakistan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4731668", "date": "2016-12-18 12:54:20", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. According to WHO information, Pakistan is also among countries having documented, endemic, or epidemic chikungunya disease http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/.\n\nFurther epidemiological data on individual cases and their laboratory confirmation (if conducted) will be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09) - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. According to WHO information, Pakistan is also among countries having documented, endemic, or epidemic chikungunya disease http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/.\n\nFurther epidemiological data on individual cases and their laboratory confirmation (if conducted) will be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09) - Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas 20160223.4044850\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20160217.4027484\nChikungunya (03) - Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (02): Americas 20160126.3968082\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia 20160108.3920697\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "20161005.4539231", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Islamabad", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Khokhorapar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4724577", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Chikungunya (17): Asia (Pakistan) ex India", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4724577", "date": "2016-12-18 12:54:20", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. According to WHO information, Pakistan is also among countries having documented, endemic, or epidemic chikungunya disease http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/.\n\nFurther epidemiological data on individual cases and their laboratory confirmation (if conducted) will be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09) - Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas 20160223.4044850\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20160217.4027484\nChikungunya (03) - Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (02): Americas 20160126.3968082\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia 20160108.3920697\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "20161005.4539231", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Islamabad", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Khokhorapar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4717500", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (16): Asia (Pakistan), laboratory confirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4717500", "date": "2016-12-18 12:54:20", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. According to WHO information, Pakistan is also among countries having documented, endemic, or epidemic chikungunya disease http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/.\n\nFurther epidemiological data on individual cases and their laboratory confirmation (if conducted) will be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations 20161201.4667167\nZika & chikungunya viruses: comparative transmission 20161005.4539231\nChikungunya (13): Americas, Asia, Pacific, Africa, Europe 20160818.4426342\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Asia 20160730.4380775\nChikungunya (11): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160702.4323117\nChikungunya (10): Americas, Pacific, Asia, Africa 20160614.4285787\nChikungunya (09) - Americas, Asia 20160427.4186163\nChikungunya (08): Americas, Asia 20160330.412836\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas 20160223.4044850\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20160217.4027484\nChikungunya (03) - Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (02): Americas 20160126.3968082\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia 20160108.3920697\n.................................................sb/uba/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "20161005.4539231", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Islamabad", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Khokhorapar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Pacific", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "Croatia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4715533", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (15): Asia (Pakistan) conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4715533", "date": "2016-12-18 12:54:20", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. Pakistan: (SD) chikungunya susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4706486", "date": "2016-12-18 12:54:20", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED ILLNESS - PAKISTAN: (SINDH) CHIKUNGUNYA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 17 Dec 2016\nSource: Pakistan Khuda Hafiz [edited]\nhttp://www.pakistankakhudahafiz.com/news/provincial-health-dept-investigate-suspected-cases-viral-disease-chikungunya/\n\n\nThe provincial health department decided on Saturday [17 Dec 2016] to investigate cases of high-grade fever and acute joint pain being reported at a Malir health facility after its medical superintendent communicated to officials that some of these cases were of chikungunya, a viral disease caused by infected mosquitoes. The hospital in question is located in Khokhorapar No. 2.\n\nProgamme manager of dengue prevention and control Dr. Masood Solangi said that the medical superintendent of Al Mustafa Welfare Society hospital had informed him that his hospital had received some chikungunya cases. \"I asked him about this, since the hospital doesn't have the facilities to diagnose chikungunya,\" he explained, adding that symptoms of high-grade fever and acute joint pain might have led doctors to believe that patients had contracted chikungunya.\n\n\"However, we will investigate these cases on Monday [19 Dec 2016] with the help of experts arriving from Islamabad. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, for instance high-grade fever, body aches and rash, and can be misdiagnosed.\"\n\nThe disease, Dr. Solangi pointed out, was rarely fatal, and no other health facility in the city had reported a similar complaint with the surveillance centre. \"If cases were found positive, they will be the 1st cases of chikungunya in the country,\" he added.\n\nAccording to him, the city immediately needs vector control strategies, especially fumigation and waste disposal measures, to prevent outbreaks of diseases like malaria, typhoid and dengue.\n\n\"A decade ago, no dengue case was ever reported in winter, but now we have them. This shows that the virus has successfully adapted itself to the filthy conditions prevailing in the city. The theory that the dengue vector (a female mosquito) breeds only in clean water is no longer true, since we have found its larvae in dirty water, too.\"\n\nThe city, he said, hadn't seen a single fumigation drive this year [2016]. Upon contact, staff at the Al Mustafa hospital said that hundreds of patients with complaints of high-grade fever and body aches had reported at the facility since last month [November 2016].\n\n\"We don't know what exactly they have since we can't afford to test each and every case in the laboratory. Most patients are advised [to take] general medicines to alleviate pain and fever,\" a doctor said on condition of anonymity.\n\nSome patients were found to have dengue, others typhoid or malaria when their diagnosis was made, he added.\n\nCurrently, the facility to diagnose chikungunya in the city only exists at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH), health department sources say.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization's (WHO) website, chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain.\n\nOther symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. Joint pain is often debilitating and can vary in duration. There is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades, mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in a localised outbreak in northeastern Italy.\n\nOutbreaks have since been recorded in France and Croatia. Most patients recover fully in 2-3 weeks, but in some cases, joint pain may persist for several months, or even years.\n\nOccasional cases of eye, neurological and heart complications have been reported, as well as gastrointestinal complaints, the website says. Serious complications are not common, but in older people, the disease can contribute to the cause of death.\n\nOften, symptoms in infected individuals are mild, and the infection may go unrecognised, or be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue occurs.\n\nThe name chikungunya derives from a word in the Kimakonde language, meaning \"to become contorted,\" and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pain.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pakistan is one of the countries where dengue fever is now endemic, and chikungunya is also transmitted by the same mosquito vectors, _Aedes aegypti_, and _Aedes albopictus_. Therefore, the differential diagnosis of acute febrile viral illness may also include chikungunya as well.\n\nHowever, the report also states that the suspected cases are based on clinical picture and not on laboratory confirmation. A laboratory testing facility is currently available at the national public health laboratory at National Institute of Health, Islamabad.\n\nThe most common symptoms of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported from neighboring countries like India and Nepal and other countries in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. According to WHO information, Pakistan is also among countries having documented, endemic, or epidemic chikungunya disease http://www.who.int/denguecontrol/arbo-viral/other_arboviral_chikungunya/en/.\n\nFurther epidemiological data on individual cases and their laboratory confirmation (if conducted) will be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Americas, Asia, Pacific, research, observations Case numbers earlier than week 9 are not shown but can be seen on this URL.\n---------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / (Local Susp. / Local Conf. / Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America\nMexico / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 0 / 80 / 0 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nMexico / 09 [Week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 0 / 168 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / 10 [week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 3921 / 0 / 0 / 0\nHonduras / 09 [week ending 26 Feb 2016] / 6194 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean no recent reports\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean no recent reports\n\nAndean Area\n---\nColombia / week 09 [week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 8466 / 57 / 0 / 0\nEcuador / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 393 / 174 / 3 / 2\nVenezuela / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 1813 / 53 / 0 / 0\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nArgentina / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 0 / 37 / 36 / 0\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama. 21 Mar 2016. (susp.) 125 cases, (conf. clinically) 10 117 cases, (conf. laboratory) 63 cases; Cases reported in all departments, those most affected: Valle de Cauca 1935 cases, Tolima 1220 cases, Santander 911 cases, Cundinamarca 885 cases, Huila 729 cases, Meta 590 cases, Risaralda 516 cases, Antioquia 477 cases.\nBoletin Epidemiol\u00f3gico, Colombia National Institute of Health [provided by A.C. Jaramillo, MD]\n\nAsia\n---\nJapan ex Cuba. 21 Mar 2016. We describe a case of a chikungunya virus (CHIKV)-infected patient returning from Cuba, where no autochthonous transmission case has been reported, and the number of tourists has been increasing after the normalization between Cuba and the United States.\n\nA previously healthy 27-year-old Japanese man presented to our clinic with fever and rash at the end of February 2016. He had visited Habana and Santiago de Cuba in Cuba, via Toronto in Canada, for sightseeing and stayed for 11 days starting mid-February 2016. He complained of 1-day history of high-grade fever (39.8 C [103 F]), retro-orbital pain, malaise, congested bulbar conjunctivas, and rash on his anterior chest from the return date. He had also had mild arthralgia on his knee and ankle joints for a few days at presentation.\n\nOn examination, body temperature was 38.7 C [101 F], and he had congested bulbar conjunctivas, cervical lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and extremities at presentation. CHIKV RNA was detected in serum samples using real-time RT-PCR performed at the National Institute of Infectious Diseases in Japan. He was diagnosed with CHIK fever.\n\nAt the next day of the 1st visit to our clinic, rash on his extremities was getting worse and slightly itchy, and pain in the wrists and metacapophalangeal joints of hand followed by cervical pain and slight rigidity on distal and proximal interphalangeal joints of hand newly appeared, although congested bulbar conjunctivas and rash on his trunk was getting better. Shortly after that, all the symptoms were resolved.\n\nThe 1st autochthonous Zika virus (ZIKV) infection in Cuba was also reported in March 2016. CHIK fever, as well as dengue fever and ZIKV infection, should be considered as a differential diagnosis of febrile travellers with rash returning from Cuba.\n\n[This report was provided by Motoyuki Tsuboi, Satoshi Kutsuna , Yasuyuki Kato, Yuichi Katanami, Kei Yamamoto, Nozomi Takeshita, Kayoko Hayakaw, Shuzo Kanagawa, Norio Ohmagari, Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Japan. They are thanked for sending in this case report.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[Interestingly, reports of chikungunya virus infections have declined significantly in recent weeks. Perhaps the outbreak is declining in the Americas, or the focus on Zika virus infections has overshadowed case reporting. There is the risk that febrile cases diagnosed clinically as Zika or dengue virus infections are in some cases really chikungunya virus infections, since symptoms caused by these infections are similar. Laboratory confirmation is needed to be sure of the diagnosis. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4426342", "date": "2016-03-30 20:50:54", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (08): AMERICAS, ASIA\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case numbers.\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama\n\nSouth America\n---\nColombia\n\nAsia\n---\nJapan ex Cuba\n\n******\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nWHO/PAHO report\n18 Mar 2016\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8379&Itemid=40931&lang=en\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory - 2016 to EW 11 [week ending 18 Mar 2016]. Case numbers earlier than week 9 are not shown but can be seen on this URL.\n---------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / (Local Susp. / Local Conf. / Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America\nMexico / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 0 / 80 / 0 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nMexico / 09 [Week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 0 / 168 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / 10 [week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 3921 / 0 / 0 / 0\nHonduras / 09 [week ending 26 Feb 2016] / 6194 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean no recent reports\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean no recent reports\n\nAndean Area\n---\nColombia / week 09 [week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 8466 / 57 / 0 / 0\nEcuador / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 393 / 174 / 3 / 2\nVenezuela / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 1813 / 53 / 0 / 0\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nArgentina / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 0 / 37 / 36 / 0\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama. 21 Mar 2016. (conf.) 4 cases.\nhttp://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/salud/Aumentan-casos-virus-zika_0_4442555719.html\n\nSouth America\n---\nColombia. 19 Mar 2016. (susp.) 125 cases, (conf. clinically) 10 117 cases, (conf. laboratory) 63 cases; Cases reported in all departments, those most affected: Valle de Cauca 1935 cases, Tolima 1220 cases, Santander 911 cases, Cundinamarca 885 cases, Huila 729 cases, Meta 590 cases, Risaralda 516 cases, Antioquia 477 cases.\nBoletin Epidemiol\u00f3gico, Colombia National Institute of Health [provided by A.C. Jaramillo, MD]\n\nAsia\n---\nJapan ex Cuba. 21 Mar 2016. We describe a case of a chikungunya virus (CHIKV)-infected patient returning from Cuba, where no autochthonous transmission case has been reported, and the number of tourists has been increasing after the normalization between Cuba and the United States.\n\nA previously healthy 27-year-old Japanese man presented to our clinic with fever and rash at the end of February 2016. He had visited Habana and Santiago de Cuba in Cuba, via Toronto in Canada, for sightseeing and stayed for 11 days starting mid-February 2016. He complained of 1-day history of high-grade fever (39.8 C [103 F]), retro-orbital pain, malaise, congested bulbar conjunctivas, and rash on his anterior chest from the return date. He had also had mild arthralgia on his knee and ankle joints for a few days at presentation.\n\nOn examination, body temperature was 38.7 C [101 F], and he had congested bulbar conjunctivas, cervical lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and extremities at presentation. CHIKV RNA was detected in serum samples using real-time RT-PCR performed at the National Institute of Infectious Diseases in Japan. He was diagnosed with CHIK fever.\n\nAt the next day of the 1st visit to our clinic, rash on his extremities was getting worse and slightly itchy, and pain in the wrists and metacapophalangeal joints of hand followed by cervical pain and slight rigidity on distal and proximal interphalangeal joints of hand newly appeared, although congested bulbar conjunctivas and rash on his trunk was getting better. Shortly after that, all the symptoms were resolved.\n\nThe 1st autochthonous Zika virus (ZIKV) infection in Cuba was also reported in March 2016. CHIK fever, as well as dengue fever and ZIKV infection, should be considered as a differential diagnosis of febrile travellers with rash returning from Cuba.\n\n[This report was provided by Motoyuki Tsuboi, Satoshi Kutsuna , Yasuyuki Kato, Yuichi Katanami, Kei Yamamoto, Nozomi Takeshita, Kayoko Hayakaw, Shuzo Kanagawa, Norio Ohmagari, Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Japan. They are thanked for sending in this case report.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[Interestingly, reports of chikungunya virus infections have declined significantly in recent weeks. Perhaps the outbreak is declining in the Americas, or the focus on Zika virus infections has overshadowed case reporting. There is the risk that febrile cases diagnosed clinically as Zika or dengue virus infections are in some cases really chikungunya virus infections, since symptoms caused by these infections are similar. Laboratory confirmation is needed to be sure of the diagnosis. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas 20160223.4044850\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20160217.4027484\nChikungunya (03) - Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (02): Americas 20160126.3968082\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4285787", "date": "2016-03-30 20:50:54", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (08): AMERICAS, ASIA\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\nCases in various countries:\nRegional
