America\n---\nColombia\n\nAsia\n---\nJapan ex Cuba\n\n******\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nWHO/PAHO report\n18 Mar 2016\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8379&Itemid=40931&lang=en\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory - 2016 to EW 11 [week ending 18 Mar 2016]. Case numbers earlier than week 9 are not shown but can be seen on this URL.\n---------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / (Local Susp. / Local Conf. / Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America\nMexico / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 0 / 80 / 0 / 0\n\nCentral American Isthmus\n---\nMexico / 09 [Week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 0 / 168 / 0 / 0\nEl Salvador / 10 [week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 3921 / 0 / 0 / 0\nHonduras / 09 [week ending 26 Feb 2016] / 6194 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nLatin Caribbean no recent reports\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean no recent reports\n\nAndean Area\n---\nColombia / week 09 [week ending 4 Mar 2016] / 8466 / 57 / 0 / 0\nEcuador / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 393 / 174 / 3 / 2\nVenezuela / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 1813 / 53 / 0 / 0\n\nSouthern Cone\n---\nArgentina / week 10 [week ending 11 Mar 2016] / 0 / 37 / 36 / 0\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574;\nNorth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106;\nCentral America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455; and\nSouth America at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186. - Mod.TY]\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or with more recent case numbers.\n\nCentral America\n---\nPanama. 21 Mar 2016. (conf.) 4 cases.\nhttp://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/salud/Aumentan-casos-virus-zika_0_4442555719.html\n\nSouth America\n---\nColombia. 19 Mar 2016. (susp.) 125 cases, (conf. clinically) 10 117 cases, (conf. laboratory) 63 cases; Cases reported in all departments, those most affected: Valle de Cauca 1935 cases, Tolima 1220 cases, Santander 911 cases, Cundinamarca 885 cases, Huila 729 cases, Meta 590 cases, Risaralda 516 cases, Antioquia 477 cases.\nBoletin Epidemiol\u00f3gico, Colombia National Institute of Health [provided by A.C. Jaramillo, MD]\n\nAsia\n---\nJapan ex Cuba. 21 Mar 2016. We describe a case of a chikungunya virus (CHIKV)-infected patient returning from Cuba, where no autochthonous transmission case has been reported, and the number of tourists has been increasing after the normalization between Cuba and the United States.\n\nA previously healthy 27-year-old Japanese man presented to our clinic with fever and rash at the end of February 2016. He had visited Habana and Santiago de Cuba in Cuba, via Toronto in Canada, for sightseeing and stayed for 11 days starting mid-February 2016. He complained of 1-day history of high-grade fever (39.8 C [103 F]), retro-orbital pain, malaise, congested bulbar conjunctivas, and rash on his anterior chest from the return date. He had also had mild arthralgia on his knee and ankle joints for a few days at presentation.\n\nOn examination, body temperature was 38.7 C [101 F], and he had congested bulbar conjunctivas, cervical lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and extremities at presentation. CHIKV RNA was detected in serum samples using real-time RT-PCR performed at the National Institute of Infectious Diseases in Japan. He was diagnosed with CHIK fever.\n\nAt the next day of the 1st visit to our clinic, rash on his extremities was getting worse and slightly itchy, and pain in the wrists and metacapophalangeal joints of hand followed by cervical pain and slight rigidity on distal and proximal interphalangeal joints of hand newly appeared, although congested bulbar conjunctivas and rash on his trunk was getting better. Shortly after that, all the symptoms were resolved.\n\nThe 1st autochthonous Zika virus (ZIKV) infection in Cuba was also reported in March 2016. CHIK fever, as well as dengue fever and ZIKV infection, should be considered as a differential diagnosis of febrile travellers with rash returning from Cuba.\n\n[This report was provided by Motoyuki Tsuboi, Satoshi Kutsuna , Yasuyuki Kato, Yuichi Katanami, Kei Yamamoto, Nozomi Takeshita, Kayoko Hayakaw, Shuzo Kanagawa, Norio Ohmagari, Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Japan. They are thanked for sending in this case report.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[Interestingly, reports of chikungunya virus infections have declined significantly in recent weeks. Perhaps the outbreak is declining in the Americas, or the focus on Zika virus infections has overshadowed case reporting. There is the risk that febrile cases diagnosed clinically as Zika or dengue virus infections are in some cases really chikungunya virus infections, since symptoms caused by these infections are similar. Laboratory confirmation is needed to be sure of the diagnosis. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (07): Americas 20160320.4106646\nChikungunya (06): Americas 20160302.4062712\nChikungunya (05): Americas 20160223.4044850\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20160217.4027484\nChikungunya (03) - Americas, Asia 20160206.3998786\nChikungunya (02): Americas 20160126.3968082\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Asia He had also had mild arthralgia on his knee and ankle joints for a few days at presentation.\n\nOn examination, body temperature was 38.7 C [101 F], and he had congested bulbar conjunctivas, cervical lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and extremities at presentation. We describe a case of a chikungunya virus (CHIKV)-infected patient returning from Cuba, where no autochthonous transmission case has been reported, and the number of tourists has been increasing after the normalization between Cuba and the United States.\n\nA previously healthy 27-year-old Japanese man presented to our clinic with fever and rash at the end of February 2016. He had visited Habana and Santiago de Cuba in Cuba, via Toronto in Canada, for sightseeing and stayed for 11 days starting mid-February 2016. He complained of 1-day history of high-grade fever (39.8 C [103 F]), retro-orbital pain, malaise, congested bulbar conjunctivas, and rash on his anterior chest from the return date. He had also had mild arthralgia on his knee and ankle joints for a few days at presentation.\n\nOn examination, body temperature was 38.7 C [101 F], and he had congested bulbar conjunctivas, cervical lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and extremities at presentation. CHIKV RNA was detected in serum samples using real-time RT-PCR performed at the National Institute of Infectious Diseases in Japan. He was diagnosed with CHIK fever.\n\nAt the next day of the 1st visit to our clinic, rash on his extremities was getting worse and slightly itchy, and pain in the wrists and metacapophalangeal joints of hand followed by cervical pain and slight rigidity on distal and proximal interphalangeal joints of hand newly appeared, although congested bulbar conjunctivas and rash on his trunk was getting better. Shortly after that, all the symptoms were resolved.\n\nThe 1st autochthonous Zika virus (ZIKV) infection in Cuba was also reported in March 2016. CHIK fever, as well as dengue fever and ZIKV infection, should be considered as a differential diagnosis of febrile travellers with rash returning from Cuba.\n\n[This report was provided by Motoyuki Tsuboi, Satoshi Kutsuna , Yasuyuki Kato, Yuichi Katanami, Kei Yamamoto, Nozomi Takeshita, Kayoko Hayakaw, Shuzo Kanagawa, Norio Ohmagari, Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Japan. Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Nasal skin necrosis\nDate: Tue 29 Sep 2015\nSource: Clin Infect Dis. doi: 10.1093/cid/civ718 [edited]\nhttp://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2015/09/29/cid.civ718.abstract\n\n\nJaime R. Torres, Leopoldo G. Cordova, Victor Saravia, Joanne Arvelaez, Julio S. Castro. Nasal Skin Necrosis: An unexpected new finding in severe chikungunya fever.\n\nAbstract\nIn Venezuela, 3 adult patients with virologically confirmed chikungunya fever, who developed extensive acute nasal skin necrosis early in the course of a life-threatening illness characterized by shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, are discussed. One patient survived and fully recovered. Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Americas, Asia 20151005.3693195\nChikungunya (28): Americas, Asia, Africa 20150926.3671932\nChikungunya (27): Americas, Asia 20150906.3626991\nChikungunya (26): Americas, Asia 20150830.3611263\nChikungunya (25): Americas, Asia 20150825.3600044\nChikungunya (24): Americas, Asia, Europe 20150817.3583857\nChikungunya (23): Americas, Asia, Europe treatment 20150621.3454514\nChikungunya (15): Americas, Asia 20150530.3396435\nChikungunya (14): Americas 20150519.3370866\nChikungunya (13): Americas 20150511.3354217\nChikungunya (12): Americas, Torres, Leopoldo G. Cordova, Victor Saravia, Joanne Arvelaez, Julio S. Castro. Nasal Skin Necrosis: An unexpected new finding in severe chikungunya fever.\n\nAbstract\nIn Venezuela, 3 adult patients with virologically confirmed chikungunya fever, who developed extensive acute nasal skin necrosis early in the course of a life-threatening illness characterized by shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, are discussed. One patient survived and fully recovered. Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Americas, Asia 20151005.3693195\nChikungunya (28): Americas, Asia, Africa 20150926.3671932\nChikungunya (27): Americas, Asia 20150906.3626991\nChikungunya (26): Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Torres, Leopoldo G. Cordova, Victor Saravia, Joanne Arvelaez, Julio S. Castro. Nasal Skin Necrosis: An unexpected new finding in severe chikungunya fever.\n\nAbstract\nIn Venezuela, 3 adult patients with virologically confirmed chikungunya fever, who developed extensive acute nasal skin necrosis early in the course of a life-threatening illness characterized by shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, are discussed. One patient survived and fully recovered. Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Nasal skin necrosis\nDate: Tue 29 Sep 2015\nSource: Clin Infect Dis. doi: 10.1093/cid/civ718 [edited]\nhttp://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2015/09/29/cid.civ718.abstract\n\n\nJaime R. Torres, Leopoldo G. Cordova, Victor Saravia, Joanne Arvelaez, Julio S. Castro. Nasal Skin Necrosis: An unexpected new finding in severe chikungunya fever.\n\nAbstract\nIn Venezuela, 3 adult patients with virologically confirmed chikungunya fever, who developed extensive acute nasal skin necrosis early in the course of a life-threatening illness characterized by shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, are discussed. One patient survived and fully recovered. Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Torres, Leopoldo G. Cordova, Victor Saravia, Joanne Arvelaez, Julio S. Castro. Nasal Skin Necrosis: An unexpected new finding in severe chikungunya fever.\n\nAbstract\nIn Venezuela, 3 adult patients with virologically confirmed chikungunya fever, who developed extensive acute nasal skin necrosis early in the course of a life-threatening illness characterized by shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, are discussed. One patient survived and fully recovered. Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Torres, Leopoldo G. Cordova, Victor Saravia, Joanne Arvelaez, Julio S. Castro. Nasal Skin Necrosis: An unexpected new finding in severe chikungunya fever.\n\nAbstract\nIn Venezuela, 3 adult patients with virologically confirmed chikungunya fever, who developed extensive acute nasal skin necrosis early in the course of a life-threatening illness characterized by shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome, are discussed. One patient survived and fully recovered. Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Americas, Asia 20151005.3693195\nChikungunya (28): Americas, Asia, Africa 20150926.3671932\nChikungunya (27): Americas, Asia 20150906.3626991\nChikungunya (26): One patient survived and fully recovered. Nasal necrosis has not previously been associated with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[It would be interesting to know whether clinicians or pathologists have seen similar cases of nasal necrosis in cases of severe CHIK virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] Virus in saliva\nDate: Thu 8 Oct 2015\nSource: PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481 [edited]\n\n\nGardner J, Rudd PA, Prow NA, Belarbi E, Roques P, Larcher T, et al. Infectious chikungunya virus in the saliva of mice, monkeys and humans. PLoS ONE 10(10): e0139481. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0139481\n\nAbstract\nChikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a reemerging, ordinarily mosquito-transmitted, alphavirus that occasionally produces hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleed and bleeding gums, in human patients. Interferon response factor 3 and 7 deficient (IRF3/7-/-) mice, which are deficient for interferon alpha/Beta responses, reliably develop hemorrhagic manifestations after CHIKV infection. Here we show that infectious virus was present in the oral cavity of CHIKV infected IRF3/7-/- mice, likely due to hemorrhagic lesions in the olfactory epithelium that allow egress of infected blood into the nasal, and subsequently, oral cavities. In addition, IRF3/7-/- mice were more susceptible to infection with CHIKV via intranasal and oral routes, with IRF3/7-/- mice also able to transmit virus mouse-to-mouse without an arthropod vector. Cynomolgus macaques often show bleeding gums after CHIKV infection, and analysis of saliva from several infected monkeys also revealed the presence of viral RNA and infectious virus. Furthermore, saliva samples collected from several acute CHIKV patients with hemorrhagic manifestations were found to contain viral RNA and infectious virus. Oral fluids can, therefore, be infectious during acute CHIKV infections, likely due to hemorrhagic manifestations in the oral/nasal cavities.\n\nBackground (summarized)\nAlthough the primary disease manifestations of CHIKV infections in humans are acute fever and rash and acute and chronic polyarthralgia/polyarthritis, hemorrhagic manifestations are occasionally seen (in around 2-4 percent of patients) in both infected children and adults. Clinical signs of hemorrhage in CHIKV patients include purpura (bruising), hematemesis (vomiting blood), melena (pathognomonic of upper gastrointestinal bleeding), epistaxis (nose bleed), petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), hematuria (blood in urine), and gingivorrhagia (bleeding gums). The latter was reported in around one percent of adults; however, in CHIKV-infected dental patients, an Indian study showed the incidence can be much higher (over 50 per cent).\n\nDiscussion (summarized)\nTo our knowledge, this study represents the 1st report showing that oral fluids/saliva from CHIKV infected animals and humans can contain infectious CHIKV. The presence of infectious virus in oral fluids of IRF3/7-/- mice was associated with high viraemia and overt hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal cavities. In cynomolgus monkeys, CHIKV was isolated from saliva on or near the peak viraemia, with gingival bleeding noted previously in 50 percent of infected animals. The presence of infectious CHIKV in the saliva of several acute human patients with hemorrhagic manifestations provides further support for the contention that CHIKV in saliva is associated with hemorrhagic lesions in the nasal/oral cavities during the viraemic period. The safety implications of infectious saliva are perhaps most relevant for dentistry. Bites from CHIKV infected individuals with hemorrhagic manifestations might also be considered potentially infectious; however, for mice, this appears to be restricted to mice deficient in IFNalpha/Beta responses [6], with saliva from wild-type mice testing negative.\n\nOne might, nevertheless, speculate that individuals with a diminished capacity to mount IFNalpha/Beta responses might be at increased risk of infection via mucosal surfaces. Such individuals include the elderly, neonates, HIV patients, asthmatics and perhaps diabetics.\n\nAlthough the studies herein are hardly exhaustive, the lack of mouse-to-mouse transmission via aerosol is perhaps not surprising. Aerosol transmission of CHIKV has not been formally reported in the publically available literature. Suspected aerosol infections have been reported for CHIKV in humans; however, the circumstances were not described.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The epidemiological significance of CHIK virus in saliva or nasal secretions is not clear. The hundreds of instances of imported cases of CHIK virus into countries where vector mosquitoes are not present have not resulted in documented instances of ongoing transmission in the absence of those vectors (excluding transfusion of blood products). Risk of aerosol transmission apparently is low. This moderator knows firsthand of an example of a case of apparent aerosol transmission in a research laboratory 50 years ago, before negative pressure laminar flow hoods became available. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (29): Americas, Asia 20151005.3693195\nChikungunya (28): Americas, Asia, Africa 20150926.3671932\nChikungunya (27): Americas, Asia 20150906.3626991\nChikungunya (26): (reported since October 2014) 50 000 cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2015/07/25/a-200-mil-pueden-llegar-casos-de-chikungunya/ [in Spanish]\n\n[In a 28 Jul 2015 report (http://www.latribuna.hn/2015/07/28/chikungunya-afecta-al-40-por-ciento-de-la-poblacion-activa-a-nivel-nacional/ in Spanish), the Executive Director of the Chamber of Commerce stated that 40 per cent of the workforce is or has been affected by chikungunya virus infections. There is no indication of how this figure was arrived at.\n\nA 25 Jul 2015 report (http://www.laprensa.hn/honduras/862499-410/hondure\u00f1os-sufren-artritis-cronica-por-la-chikungunya in Spanish) indicates that 643 individuals have been hospitalized for chikungunya infections. However, this report does not indicate if that is the total for 2015 alone, or for 2014 plus 2015. - Mod.TY]\n\nCosta Rica (national). 25 Jul 2015. (conf.) 155 cases, since cases first appeared in country in 2014, 748 cases in all 7 provinces; 1st (conf.) 2015 cases in central Pacific cantons of Garabito and Jaco.\nhttp://www.ticotimes.net/2015/07/25/costa-rica-health-officials-report-first-cases-year-chikungunya-virus-central-pacific-cantons\n\nNicaragua (national). 28 Jul 2015. (conf.) as of 26 Jul 2015, 2456 cases.\nhttp://www.laprensa.com.ni/2015/07/28/nacionales/1873724-chikungunya-no-da-tregua-nicaragua [in Spanish]\n\nPanama (national). 26 Jul 2015. (reported) 155 cases.\nhttp://www.critica.com.pa/nacional/1528-casos-de-dengue-se-han-registrado-en-panama-399972 [in Spanish]\n\nSouth America\n---\nVenezuela (national). 27 Jul 2015. (reported) as of 1 Jul 2015, 13 616 cases. States most affected: Amazonas, Tachira, Merida, Lara.\nhttp://runrun.es/ss/salud/215425/virus-chikungunya-sigue-activo-en-venezuela.html [in Spanish]\n\nCountries with cases ex endemic areas but with no ongoing transmission.\n---\nUSA\n- USA states from ArboNET\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/pdfs/2015Table1-072815.pdf\nSummary report of laboratory confirmed imported cases as of 28 Jul States most affected: Guerrero 1101 cases, Oaxaca 503 cases, Chiapas 394 cases, to date 16 states have locally acquired cases.\nhttp://sipse.com/milenio/abarca-chikungunya-todo-sur-sureste-mexico-caso-mas-yucatan-163210.html [in Spanish]\n\n- Jalisco state. 27 Jul 2015. There is no indication of how this figure was arrived at.\n\nA 25 Jul 2015 report (http://www.laprensa.hn/honduras/862499-410/hondure\u00f1os-sufren-artritis-cronica-por-la-chikungunya in Spanish) indicates that 643 individuals have been hospitalized for chikungunya infections. There is no indication of how this figure was arrived at.\n\nA 25 Jul 2015 report (http://www.laprensa.hn/honduras/862499-410/hondure\u00f1os-sufren-artritis-cronica-por-la-chikungunya in Spanish) indicates that 643 individuals have been hospitalized for chikungunya infections. However, this report does not indicate if that is the total for 2015 alone, or for 2014 plus 2015. - Mod.TY]\n\nCosta Rica (national). 25 Jul 2015. (conf.) 155 cases, since cases first appeared in country in 2014, 748 cases in all 7 provinces; 1st (conf.) 2015 cases in central Pacific cantons of Garabito and Jaco.\nhttp://www.ticotimes.net/2015/07/25/costa-rica-health-officials-report-first-cases-year-chikungunya-virus-central-pacific-cantons\n\nNicaragua (national). 28 Jul 2015. (reported) 155 cases.\nhttp://www.critica.com.pa/nacional/1528-casos-de-dengue-se-han-registrado-en-panama-399972 [in Spanish]\n\nSouth America\n---\nVenezuela (national). 27 Jul 2015. (reported) as of 1 Jul 2015, 13 616 cases. States most affected: Guerrero 1101 cases, Oaxaca 503 cases, Chiapas 394 cases, to date 16 states have locally acquired cases.\nhttp://sipse.com/milenio/abarca-chikungunya-todo-sur-sureste-mexico-caso-mas-yucatan-163210.html [in Spanish]\n\n- Jalisco state. 27 Jul 2015. (reported since October 2014) 50 000 cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2015/07/25/a-200-mil-pueden-llegar-casos-de-chikungunya/ [in Spanish]\n\n[In a 28 Jul 2015 report (http://www.latribuna.hn/2015/07/28/chikungunya-afecta-al-40-por-ciento-de-la-poblacion-activa-a-nivel-nacional/ in Spanish), the Executive Director of the Chamber of Commerce stated that 40 per cent of the workforce is or has been affected by chikungunya virus infections. There is no indication of how this figure was arrived at.\n\nA 25 Jul 2015 report (http://www.laprensa.hn/honduras/862499-410/hondure\u00f1os-sufren-artritis-cronica-por-la-chikungunya in Spanish) indicates that 643 individuals have been hospitalized for chikungunya infections. Central America\n---\nMexico\n- National. 28 Jul 2015. (reported) 2646 cases. States most affected: Guerrero 1101 cases, Oaxaca 503 cases, Chiapas 394 cases, to date 16 states have locally acquired cases.\nhttp://sipse.com/milenio/abarca-chikungunya-todo-sur-sureste-mexico-caso-mas-yucatan-163210.html [in Spanish]\n\n- Jalisco state. 27 Jul 2015. (conf.) 14 cases locally acquired, 34 cases imported. Municipality affected: Guadalajara 4 locally acquired cases; other municipalities with locally acquired cases: Puerto Vallarta, La Huerta, Cuautitlan, and Tomatlan.\nhttp://www.informador.com.mx/jalisco/2015/605682/6/la-ssj-reporta-brote-de-chikungunya-en-guadalajara.htm [in Spanish]\n\n- Michoacan state. 28 Jul 2015. (conf.) 307 cases. Increasing.\nhttp://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/nacional/alerta-epidemiologica-en-michoacan-por-brote-de-chikungunya.html [in Spanish]\n\nHonduras (national). 25 Jul 2015. (reported since October 2014) 50 000 cases.\nhttp://www.latribuna.hn/2015/07/25/a-200-mil-pueden-llegar-casos-de-chikungunya/ [in Spanish]\n\n[In a 28 Jul 2015 report (http://www.latribuna.hn/2015/07/28/chikungunya-afecta-al-40-por-ciento-de-la-poblacion-activa-a-nivel-nacional/ in Spanish), the Executive Director of the Chamber of Commerce stated that 40 per cent of the workforce is or has been affected by chikungunya virus infections. There is no indication of how this figure was arrived at.\n\nA 25 Jul 2015 report (http://www.laprensa.hn/honduras/862499-410/hondure\u00f1os-sufren-artritis-cronica-por-la-chikungunya in Spanish) indicates that 643 individuals have been hospitalized for chikungunya infections. However, this report does not indicate if that is the total for 2015 alone, or for 2014 plus 2015. - Mod.TY]\n\nCosta Rica (national). 25 Jul 2015. (conf.) 155 cases, since cases first appeared in country in 2014, 748 cases in all 7 provinces; 1st (conf.) 2015 cases in central Pacific cantons of Garabito and Jaco.\nhttp://www.ticotimes.net/2015/07/25/costa-rica-health-officials-report-first-cases-year-chikungunya-virus-central-pacific-cantons\n\nNicaragua (national). 28 Jul 2015. (conf.) as of 26 Jul 2015, 2456 cases.\nhttp://www.laprensa.com.ni/2015/07/28/nacionales/1873724-chikungunya-no-da-tregua-nicaragua [in Spanish]\n\nPanama (national). 26 Jul 2015. (reported) 155 cases.\nhttp://www.critica.com.pa/nacional/1528-casos-de-dengue-se-han-registrado-en-panama-399972 [in Spanish]\n\nSouth America\n---\nVenezuela (national). 27 Jul 2015. (reported) as of 1 Jul 2015, 13 616 cases. "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3354217", "date": "2015-03-11 14:21:25", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (06): AMERICAS, PACIFIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional Viva Alfaro parroquia, Quevedo canton, Los Rios province\nParaguay (national)\nSuriname (national)\nVenezuela (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas 20150203.3138263\nChikungunya (02): Americas, Pacific 20150120.3105986\nChikungunya (01): Americas, Pacific 20150108.3079983\n2014\n----\nChikungunya (73): Americas 20141207.3016589\nChikungunya (70): "2015-03-11 14:21:25", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (06): AMERICAS, PACIFIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nHistorical overview\nWHO/PAHO report\nCARPHA\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case numbers.\nCaribbean locally acquired\n---\nDominica (national)\nHaiti (national)\nJamaica (national)\nTrinidad and (national)\nSuriname (national)\nVenezuela (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week countries not mentioned above or more recent case numbers\n\nCaribbean locally acquired\n---\nDominica (national). 26 Feb 2015. (reported) 3764 cases, (conf.) 173 cases. Outbreak officially declared over with no new cases in over 2 maximum incubation periods.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Dominica-CHIKV-epidemic-officially-over---Health-Ministry\n\nHaiti (national). 3 Mar 2015. (reported) 64 695 cases.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/303-cases-of-ChikV-in-TT-294931231.html\n\nJamaica (national). 3 Mar 2015. (reported) 39 new cases for 2015; for 2014 (reported) 4979; deaths 2014 to 19 Feb 2015 (susp.) 11, (conf.) 2.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Chik-V-not-through-with-Jamaica-yet\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 3 Mar 2015. (conf.) 43 cases. One hopes that control measures are effective to reduce the incidence and not discourage tourists from coming. - Mod.TY]\n\nCosta Rica (national). 26 Feb 2015. (reported) more than 100 cases, 70 of which are locally acquired.\nhttp://www.ticotimes.net/2015/02/26/honduras-registers-first-death-from-chikungunya-virus\n\nHonduras (national). 26 Feb 2015. (conf.) 12 090 cases; deaths 1, a 23-day-old infant from Olancho department.\nhttp://www.proceso.hn/salud-y-sociedad/item/97571-honduras-contabiliza-m%E1s-de-12-mil-casos-de-chikungunya.html\n\nThis report is confusing in that it states that the monthly average of cases for the 1st 2 months of 2015 is 3379 cases and the total so far for 2015 is more than 6758. Perhaps this represents the difference between confirmed and reported cases. A 6 Mar 2015 report indicates that there are at least 14 000 cases since the beginning of the outbreak and an average of 1000 cases weekly currently. (http://www.elheraldo.hn/pais/819133-331/piden-declara-alerta-por-dengue-y-chikungunya in Spanish). - Mod.TY]\n\nNicaragua (national). 26 Feb 2015. (conf.) nearly 4000 cases since July 2014.\nhttp://elmundo.com.sv/nicaragua-registra-casi-4-000-casos-positivos-de-virus-chikunguna/ [in Spanish]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nBolivia (Santa Cruz de la Sierra city, Santa Cruz department). 2 Mar 2015. (susp.) 418 cases, (conf.) 2768 cases. (reported) as of 25 Feb 2015, 2137 cases. One hopes that the epidemiological barriers being put in place around localities where cases have occurred is effective in halting further spread. - Mod.TY]\n\nParaguay (national). 9 Mar 2015. (conf.) 271 cases; deaths 1. Municipalities most affected: Asuncion 89 cases, Villa Elisa 73 cases, Luque 30 cases, Nemby 25 cases, 13 San Lorenzo 13 cases, Lambare 10 cases.\nhttp://www.sinembargo.mx/09-03-2015/1275646 [in Spanish]\n\nSuriname (national). 3 Mar 2015. (reported) 1210 cases.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/303-cases-of-ChikV-in-TT-294931231.html\n\nVenezuela (national). 4 Mar 2015. The Venezuela government Epidemiological Bulletin of week 07, ending 27 Feb 2015 reports (susp.) 34 642 cases, (conf.) 2303 cases since the beginning of the outbreak in 2014. However these are the same case numbers for Venezuela reported by PAHO as of 29 Dec 2014 and contradict projections made extra-officially by epidemiological experts in Venezuela.\nhttp://www.el-nacional.com/maria_yanes/meses-chikungunya-secuelas_0_584341667.html [in Spanish]\n\n[ProMED would appreciate receiving any updated case numbers that are available for Venezuela. The chikungunya outbreak continues in Colombia, and it seems likely that the outbreak continues in Venezuela as well. - Mod.TY]\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national). 5 Feb 2015. (conf.) 18 cases -- 2 ex French Polynesia, 1 ex Samoa.\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/267817/18-confirmed-chikungunya-cases-in-cooks\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the Cook Islands in the Pacific can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4035. - Mod.TY]\n\nSamoa (national). 27 Feb 2015. (reported) more than 4000 cases. Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas
