(Santa Cruz de la Sierra city, Santa Cruz department)\nBrazil\n- National (week 06 ending 14 Feb 2015)\n- Oiapoque, Amapa state\nColombia (Barranquilla, Atlantico department)\nEcuador\n- National\n- Esmeraldas city, Esmeraldas province\n- Quevedo, Los Rios province and Manabi province\n- Viva Alfaro parroquia, Quevedo canton, Los Rios province\nParaguay (national)\nSuriname (national)\nVenezuela (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week ending 13 Feb 2015] / 5280 / 793 / 0 / 3\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean\nAnguilla / week 07 [week ending 20 Feb 2015] / 67 / 52 / 2 / 0\nAntigua and Barbuda / week 07 [week ending 20 Feb 2015] / 1428 / 18 / 0 (conf.) 12 090 cases; deaths 1, a 23-day-old infant from Olancho department.\nhttp://www.proceso.hn/salud-y-sociedad/item/97571-honduras-contabiliza-m%E1s-de-12-mil-casos-de-chikungunya.html\n\nThis report is confusing in that it states that the monthly average of cases for the 1st 2 months of 2015 is 3379 cases and the total so far for 2015 is more than 6758. Perhaps this represents the difference between confirmed and reported cases. A 6 Mar 2015 report indicates that there are at least 14 000 cases since the beginning of the outbreak and an average of 1000 cases weekly currently. Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week ending 6 Mar 2015] / 0 / 355 / 20 / 0\nUSA /week 06 [week ending 13 Feb 2015] / 0 / 11 / 2524 / 0\n\nCentral America\nCosta Rica / week 06 [week ending 13 Feb 2015] / 0 / 233 / 89 / 0\nEl Salvador / (reported) more than 100 cases, 70 of which are locally acquired.\nhttp://www.ticotimes.net/2015/02/26/honduras-registers-first-death-from-chikungunya-virus\n\nHonduras (national). 26 Feb 2015. (conf.) 12 090 cases; deaths 1, a 23-day-old infant from Olancho department.\nhttp://www.proceso.hn/salud-y-sociedad/item/97571-honduras-contabiliza-m%E1s-de-12-mil-casos-de-chikungunya.html\n\nThis report is confusing in that it states that the monthly average of cases for the 1st 2 months of 2015 is 3379 cases and the total so far for 2015 is more than 6758. Perhaps this represents the difference between confirmed and reported cases. A 6 Mar 2015 report indicates that there are at least 14 000 cases since the beginning of the outbreak and an average of 1000 cases weekly currently. (http://www.elheraldo.hn/pais/819133-331/piden-declara-alerta-por-dengue-y-chikungunya in Spanish). - Mod.TY]\n\nNicaragua (national). 26 Feb 2015. Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas 14:21:25", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (06): AMERICAS, PACIFIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nHistorical overview\nWHO/PAHO report\nCARPHA\n\nCases in (Santa Cruz de la Sierra city, Santa Cruz department)\nBrazil\n- National (week 06 ending 14 Feb 2015)\n- Oiapoque, Amapa state\nColombia (Barranquilla, Atlantico department)\nEcuador\n- National\n- (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week (reported) 64 695 cases.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/303-cases-of-ChikV-in-TT-294931231.html\n\nJamaica (national). 3 Mar 2015. (reported) 39 new cases for 2015; for 2014 (reported) 4979; deaths 2014 to 19 Feb 2015 (susp.) 11, (conf.) 2.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Chik-V-not-through-with-Jamaica-yet\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 3 Mar 2015. (conf.) 43 cases. One hopes that control measures are effective to reduce the incidence and not discourage tourists from coming. - Mod.TY]\n\nCosta Rica (national). 26 Feb 2015. (reported) more than 100 cases, 70 of which are locally acquired.\nhttp://www.ticotimes.net/2015/02/26/honduras-registers-first-death-from-chikungunya-virus\n\nHonduras (national). 26 Feb 2015. (conf.) 12 090 cases; deaths 1, a 23-day-old infant from Olancho department.\nhttp://www.proceso.hn/salud-y-sociedad/item/97571-honduras-contabiliza-m%E1s-de-12-mil-casos-de-chikungunya.html\n\nThis report is confusing in that it states that the monthly average of cases for the 1st 2 months of 2015 is 3379 cases and the total so far for 2015 is more than 6758. Perhaps this represents the difference between confirmed and reported cases. A 6 Mar 2015 report indicates that there are at least 14 000 cases since the beginning of the outbreak and an average of 1000 cases weekly currently. (http://www.elheraldo.hn/pais/819133-331/piden-declara-alerta-por-dengue-y-chikungunya in Spanish). - Mod.TY]\n\nNicaragua (national). 26 Feb 2015. Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (06): AMERICAS, PACIFIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nHistorical overview\nWHO/PAHO report\nCARPHA\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case numbers.\nCaribbean locally acquired\n---\nDominica (national)\nHaiti (national)\nJamaica (national)\nTrinidad and Tobago (national)\n\nMexico and (Santa Cruz de la Sierra city, Santa Cruz department)\nBrazil\n- National (week 06 ending 14 Feb 2015)\n- Oiapoque, Amapa state\nColombia (Barranquilla, Atlantico department)\nEcuador\n- National\n- (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week (reported) as of 25 Feb 2015, 2137 cases. Municipal state of health emergency declared.\nhttp://g1.globo.com/ap/amapa/noticia/2015/03/centro-de-oiapoque-lidera-casos-de-chikungunya-vitimas-passam-de-2-mil.html [in Portuguese]\n\n[It is odd that a 5 Mar 2015 report in O Globo cites the most recent Ministry of Health Epidemiological Bulletin indicating that so far this year (2015) there are 689 suspected locally acquired cases and 82 confirmed ones, case numbers far fewer than those reported above for Amapa state. - Mod.TY]\n\nColombia (Barranquilla, Atlantico department. 3 Mar 2015. Manabi (registered) 25 cases in 2014, 50 cases in 2015.\nhttp://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/2015/03/03/nota/4615311/quevedo-10-casos-chikungunya [in Spanish]\n\n- Viva Alfaro parroquia, Quevedo canton, Los Rios province. 26 Feb 2015. (reported) more than 4000 cases. Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas 14:21:25", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (06): AMERICAS, PACIFIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nHistorical overview\nWHO/PAHO report\nCARPHA\n\nCases in (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week (conf.) 18 cases -- 2 ex French Polynesia, 1 ex Samoa.\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/267817/18-confirmed-chikungunya-cases-in-cooks\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the Cook Islands in the Pacific can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4035. - Mod.TY]\n\nSamoa (national). 27 Feb 2015. (reported) more than 4000 cases. The New Zealand rugby team is monitoring this situation because they have a test game there in July 2015.\nhttp://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2015/02/27/all-blacks-alert-samoa-mosquito-virus\n\n[This is an interesting example of how an outbreak could interfere with an important sporting event.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Samoa in the Pacific can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/41396. Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas 14:21:25", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (06): AMERICAS, PACIFIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\n---\nHistorical overview\nWHO/PAHO report\nCARPHA\n\nCases in (national)\n\nPacific\n---\nCook Islands (national)\nSamoa (national)\n\n[2] Treatment, comment\n\n******\n[1] Cases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n---\nAmericas\nHistorical overview\nDate: April 2015 (ahead of print, March 2015)\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [summ., edited]\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2104.141723\n\n\nRef: Halstead SB: Reappearance of chikungunya, formerly called dengue, in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(4)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAfter an absence of about 200 years, chikungunya returned to the American tropics in 2013. The virus is maintained in a complex African zoonotic cycle but escapes into an urban cycle at 40- to 50-year intervals, causing global pandemics. In 1823, classical chikungunya, a viral exanthem in humans, occurred on Zanzibar, and in 1827, it arrived in the Caribbean and spread to North and South America. In Zanzibar, the disease was known as kidenga pepo, Swahili for a sudden cramp-like seizure caused by an evil spirit; in Cuba, it was known as dengue, a Spanish homonym of denga. During the eighteenth century, dengue (present-day chikungunya) was distinguished from breakbone fever (present-day dengue), another febrile exanthem. In the 20th century, experiments resulted in the recovery and naming of present-day dengue viruses. In 1952, chikungunya virus was recovered during an outbreak in Tanzania, but by then, the virus had lost its original name to present-day dengue viruses.\n\n[This is a fascinating history of chikungunya with its previous appearance in the Americas, and the confusion due to its relationship clinically, to dengue fever. Given the widespread and continuing outbreak of chikungunya in the Americas, this report will be of interest to many ProMED-mail subscribers. - Mod.TY]\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n13 Feb 2015\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2015 to EW 09 (cumulative, updated 6 Mar 2015, reports earlier than week 06 of 2015 are not reported but are available in earlier reports)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCases by Country / Week / Local Susp. / Local Conf./ Imported Conf. / Deaths\nNorth America:\nMexico / week 09 [week (conf.) 12 090 cases; deaths 1, a 23-day-old infant from Olancho department.\nhttp://www.proceso.hn/salud-y-sociedad/item/97571-honduras-contabiliza-m%E1s-de-12-mil-casos-de-chikungunya.html\n\nThis report is confusing in that it states that the monthly average of cases for the 1st 2 months of 2015 is 3379 cases and the total so far for 2015 is more than 6758. Perhaps this represents the difference between confirmed and reported cases. A 6 Mar 2015 report indicates that there are at least 14 000 cases since the beginning of the outbreak and an average of 1000 cases weekly currently. Mod. TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nand\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Treatment, comment\nDate: Tue 17 Feb 2015\nFrom: Fabrice Simon <simon-f@wanadoo.fr> [edited]\n\n\nRe: French guidelines on case management of chikungunya-infected patients (acute, post-acute, and chronic stages)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA recent ProMED-mail post on chikungunya in the Americas (archive no 20150210.3156702) mentioned a recent paper on an uncontrolled therapeutic experiment. The moderator TY commented on it: \"One case is anecdotal but interesting, but will be of limited value until a statistically valid clinical trial is carried out.\" We totally agree with him about this kind of experimentation. To date, there is no drug available to heal all chikungunya [virus]-infected patients. Many drugs (vitamin C, phytotherapy, allopathy) have been tested in few regular trials and many empirical field experiments, unsuccessfully.\n\nHowever, physicians must always do their best to provide relief for their patients without adverse effects. We want to stress that it is possible to help most patients with appropriate use of some well-known drugs and physiotherapy.\n\nTo avoid such uncontrolled experiments due to the lack of knowledge, the Direction Generale de la Sante of the French Ministry of Health asked the Societe de Pathologie Infectieuse de Langue Francaise (the French Infectious Diseases Society) to produce guidelines for the case management of chikungunya [virus]-infected patients (acute stage and persisting forms). We directed a group of about 20 French experts (infectiologists, rheumatologists, GPs, reeducators, from mainland France, Reunion, Martinique, Guadeloupe, French Guiana) who worked on the topic for months. After having analysed the literature and debated their clinical experience, we produced a consensus among experts that is available online (free access) in French at http://www.infectiologie.com/site/medias/Recos/2014-Chikungunya-recommandations.pdf. We have answered the most frequently asked questions from GPs and listed the adequate practices for acute, post-acute, and chronic stages; some inefficient and/or potentially deleterious treatments are also mentioned.\n\nWe think that promoting this information about these French guidelines (English version coming soon) by ProMED could bring significant help for the patients and their physicians.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Fabrice Simon, MD, PhD, and Dr Emilie Javelle, MD\nDepartment of Infectious Diseases and Tropical Medicine, Laveran Military Teaching Hospital\nMarseille, France\n<simon-f@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[ProMED thanks Drs Simon and Javelle for this comment. The guidelines put together by this group of medical specialists will be very helpful. A version in English is awaited, and one hopes that in addition to French it will also become available in Spanish and Portuguese, because most of the cases in the Americas have occurred in the countries where those are the main languages spoken. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (05): Americas, Pacific 20150227.3195783\nChikungunya (04): Americas 20150210.3156702\nChikungunya (03): Americas Cruz", "country": "Bolivia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3105986", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (02): Americas, Pacific", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3105986", "date": "2014-12-12 09:30:40", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS (75): PACIFIC\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 10 Dec 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/french-polynesia-reports-an-estimated-9000-chikungunya-cases-during-past-week-14533/\n\n\nThe chikungunya outbreak in the Pacific Islands continue to balloon, particularly in French Polynesia, where health authorities report seeing an estimated 9000 new cases during the past week.\n\nAccording to numbers released by the Auckland Regional Public Health Service in New Zealand, as of [1 Dec 2014], the following island countries are battling an ongoing chikungunya outbreak: French Polynesia: 18 352 cases, American Samoa: 1148 cases, Samoa: more than 2500 suspected cases and Tokelau: 159 suspected cases.\n\nRadio New Zealand reported more up-to-date numbers today [10 Dec 2014] showing the French Polynesia outbreak is actually up to 27 000 cases and 5 deaths.\n\nChikungunya is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes such as _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_, the same mosquito vector that transmits dengue fever. It can cause high fever, joint and muscle pain, and headache.\n\nChikungunya does not often result in death, but the joint pain may last for months or years and may become a cause of chronic pain and disability. There is no specific treatment for chikungunya infection, nor any vaccine to prevent it.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pending the development of a new vaccine, the only effective means of prevention is to protect individuals against mosquito bites.\n\nThe chikungunya outbreak in the Pacific islands, especially in French Polynesia, continues with increasing numbers of cases. So far, attempts to halt transmission through mosquito vector control have not prevented the increase in case numbers. There is a dengue outbreak in French Polynesia as well, and those viruses are transmitted by the same mosquito vector. In the absence of available vaccines, mosquito vector control and avoidance of mosquitoes bites are the only preventive measures available. These measures would require active public collaboration through education.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the islands in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31048; maps showing the location of American Samoa and Samoa can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/wsnewz.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2; maps of Tokelau, a New Zealand territory, can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/tk.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6767. - and 5 deaths.\n\nChikungunya is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes such as _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_, the same mosquito vector that transmits dengue fever. It can cause high fever, joint and muscle pain, and headache.\n\nChikungunya does not often result in death, but the joint pain may last for months or years and may become a cause of chronic pain and disability. There is no specific treatment for chikungunya infection, nor any vaccine to prevent it.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pending the development of a new vaccine, the only effective means of prevention is to protect individuals against mosquito bites.\n\nThe chikungunya outbreak in the Pacific islands, especially in French Polynesia, continues with increasing numbers of cases. So far, attempts to halt transmission through mosquito vector control have not prevented the increase in case numbers. There is a dengue outbreak in French Polynesia as well, and those viruses are transmitted by the same mosquito vector. In the absence of available vaccines, mosquito vector control and avoidance of mosquitoes bites are the only preventive measures available. These measures would require active public collaboration through education.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the islands in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31048; maps showing the location of American Samoa and Samoa can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/wsnewz.gif and "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS (75): PACIFIC\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 10 Dec 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/french-polynesia-reports-an-estimated-9000-chikungunya-cases-during-past-week-14533/\n\n\nThe chikungunya outbreak in the Pacific Islands continue to balloon, particularly in French Polynesia, where health authorities report seeing an estimated 9000 new cases during the past week.\n\nAccording to numbers released by the Auckland Regional Public Health Service in New Zealand, as of [1 Dec 2014], the following island countries are battling an ongoing chikungunya outbreak: French Polynesia: 18 352 cases, American Samoa: 1148 cases, Samoa: more than 2500 suspected cases and Tokelau: 159 suspected cases.\n\nRadio New Zealand reported more up-to-date numbers today [10 Dec 2014] showing the French Polynesia outbreak is actually up to 27 000 cases and 5 deaths.\n\nChikungunya is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes such as _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_, the same mosquito vector that transmits dengue fever. It can cause high fever, joint and muscle pain, and headache.\n\nChikungunya does not often result in death, but the joint pain may last for months or years and may become a cause of chronic pain and disability. There is no specific treatment for chikungunya infection, nor any vaccine to prevent it.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pending the development of a new vaccine, the only effective means of prevention is to protect individuals against mosquito bites.\n\nThe chikungunya outbreak in the Pacific islands, especially in French Polynesia, continues with increasing numbers of cases. So far, attempts to halt transmission through mosquito vector control have not prevented the increase in case numbers. There is a dengue outbreak in French Polynesia as well, and those viruses are transmitted by the same mosquito vector. In the absence of available vaccines, mosquito vector control and avoidance of mosquitoes bites are the only preventive measures available. These measures would require active public collaboration through education.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the islands in French Polynesia can be accessed at Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://nouvellecaledonie.la1ere.fr/2014/11/19/deux-deces-lies-au-chikungunya-en-polynesie-208116.html\n\n\nIn French Polynesia, the office that monitors health has confirmed 2 deaths related to chikungunya [virus infections]. On the archipelago, 5000 cases of infection have been reported over the past few days.\n\nOn Wednesday [19 Nov 2014], the office manager for Public Health Surveillance in French Polynesia, Henri-Pierre Mallet, confirmed the deaths of 2 patients following their chikungunya virus infections. He said that 2 person's advanced age resulted in complications. These 2 deaths are the 1st currently recorded in Polynesia, which had its 1st outbreak of chikungunya a few weeks ago.\n\nThe epidemic has reached worrying proportions in the archipelago, where the Health Watch office said last week that there were 5000 possible cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak in French Polynesia is increasing rapidly and placing stress on medical services. Since the detection of the 1st cases on 10 Oct 2014, the virus has spread to several islands in French Polynesia, and the case number has now climbed to an estimated 5000, with the 2 deaths. In the absence of a commercially available vaccine, vector control is the only preventive measure available.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the islands in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/382. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (65): French Polynesia 20141115.2957255\nChikungunya (64): French Polynesia 20141107.2937752\nChikungunya (61): French Polynesia 20141017.2875482\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2065-03-15 00:00:00", "2064-03-15 00:00:00", "2061-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3016589", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (73): Americas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3016589", "date": "2014-11-19 17:57:33", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (67): FRENCH POLYNESIA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: Nouvelle Caladonie [in French, trans. On the archipelago, 5000 cases of infection have been reported over the past few days.\n\nOn Wednesday [19 Nov 2014], the office manager for Public Health Surveillance in French Polynesia, Henri-Pierre Mallet, confirmed the deaths of 2 patients following their chikungunya virus infections. He said that 2 person's advanced age resulted in complications. These 2 deaths are the 1st currently recorded in Polynesia, which had its 1st outbreak of chikungunya a few weeks ago.\n\nThe epidemic has reached worrying proportions in the archipelago, where the Health Watch office said last week that there were 5000 possible cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak in French Polynesia is increasing rapidly and placing stress on medical services. These 2 deaths are the 1st currently recorded in Polynesia, which had its 1st outbreak of chikungunya a few weeks ago.\n\nThe epidemic has reached worrying proportions in the archipelago, where the Health Watch office said last week that there were 5000 possible cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak in French Polynesia is increasing rapidly and placing stress on medical services. Since the detection of the 1st cases on 10 Oct 2014, the virus has spread to several islands in French Polynesia, and the case number has now climbed to an estimated 5000, with the 2 deaths. In the absence of a commercially available vaccine, vector control is the only preventive measure available.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the islands in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/382. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (65): French Polynesia 20141115.2957255\nChikungunya (64): French Polynesia 20141107.2937752\nChikungunya (61): French Polynesia 20141017.2875482\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2065-03-15 00:00:00", "2064-03-15 00:00:00", "2061-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2998621", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (70): Americas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2998621", "date": "2014-11-19 17:57:33", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (67): FRENCH POLYNESIA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Nov 2014\nSource: Nouvelle Caladonie [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://nouvellecaledonie.la1ere.fr/2014/11/19/deux-deces-lies-au-chikungunya-en-polynesie-208116.html\n\n\nIn French Polynesia, the office that monitors health has confirmed 2 deaths related to chikungunya [virus infections]. On the archipelago, 5000 cases of infection have been reported over the past few days.\n\nOn Wednesday [19 Nov 2014], the office manager for Public Health Surveillance in French Polynesia, Henri-Pierre Mallet, confirmed the deaths of 2 patients following their chikungunya virus infections. He said that 2 person's advanced age resulted in complications. These 2 deaths are the 1st currently recorded in Polynesia, which had its 1st outbreak of chikungunya a few weeks ago.\n\nThe epidemic has reached worrying proportions in the archipelago, where the Health Watch office said last week that there were 5000 possible cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak in French Polynesia is increasing rapidly and placing stress on medical services. Since the detection of the 1st cases on 10 Oct 2014, the virus has spread to several islands in French Polynesia, and the case number has now climbed to an estimated 5000, with the 2 deaths. Ed.LM, edited]\nhttp://fr.reuters.com/article/topNews/idFRKCN0I00BH20141011?rpc=401\n\n\nThe President of French Polynesia has announced that the chikungunya virus has made its appearance on the island of Tahiti.\n\nAn investigation was opened after the report of several people with joint pain and fever, sometimes accompanied by skin eruptions [rash].\n\nThe analyses confirmed it was chikungunya in 15 cases, mainly in the municipality of Teva I Uta. Further investigations are underway to determine the source and extent of the transmission.\n\nAccording to a statement from the President, mosquito control measures will be implemented, while the rainy season begins. Chikungunya, like dengue or zika, is a disease [virus] transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito, present in Polynesia [That is not correct. These viruses are not transmitted by _Anopheles_ mosquitoes. They are transmitted by _Aedes_ mosquitoes, in Tahiti most likely _Ae. aegypti_. - Mod.TY].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tahiti is part of the Society Island archipelago and capital of the collectivity that is French Polynesia. Although ProMED-mail has not received previous reports of chikungunya virus outbreaks on Tahiti, there were cases on New Caledonia in 2011. Given the inter-island movement within French Polynesia, it is not surprising to see chikungunya virus appear on Tahiti, the most populous of these islands, as Zika virus did in 2013. Since there are no commercially available vaccines available yet for chikungunya virus, the only preventive measures are vector control and avoidance of mosquito bites.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail showing the location of Tahiti in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22997. - Further investigations are underway to determine the source and extent of the transmission.\n\nAccording to a statement from the President, mosquito control measures will be implemented, while the rainy season begins. Chikungunya, like dengue or zika, is a disease [virus] transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito, present in Polynesia [That is not correct. These viruses are not transmitted by _Anopheles_ mosquitoes. Ed.LM, edited]\nhttp://fr.reuters.com/article/topNews/idFRKCN0I00BH20141011?rpc=401\n\n\nThe President of French Polynesia has announced that the chikungunya virus has made its appearance on the island of Tahiti.\n\nAn investigation was opened after the report of several people with joint pain and fever, sometimes accompanied by skin eruptions [rash].\n\nThe analyses confirmed it was chikungunya in 15 cases, mainly in the municipality of Teva I Uta. Further investigations are underway to determine the source and extent of the transmission.\n\nAccording to a statement from the President, mosquito control measures will be implemented, while the rainy season begins. Chikungunya, like dengue or zika, is a disease [virus] transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito, present in Polynesia [That is not correct. These viruses are not transmitted by _Anopheles_ mosquitoes. They are transmitted by _Aedes_ mosquitoes, in Tahiti most likely _Ae. aegypti_. - Mod.TY].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tahiti is part of the Society Island archipelago and capital of the collectivity that is French Polynesia. Although ProMED-mail has not received previous reports of chikungunya virus outbreaks on Tahiti, there were cases on New Caledonia in 2011. Given the inter-island movement within French Polynesia, it is not surprising to see chikungunya virus appear on Tahiti, the most populous of these islands, as Zika virus did in 2013. Since there are no commercially available vaccines available yet for chikungunya virus, the only preventive measures are vector control and avoidance of mosquito bites.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail showing the location of Tahiti in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22997. - Ed.LM, edited]\nhttp://fr.reuters.com/article/topNews/idFRKCN0I00BH20141011?rpc=401\n\n\nThe President of French Polynesia has announced that the chikungunya virus has made its appearance on the island of Tahiti.\n\nAn investigation was opened after the report of several people with joint pain and fever, sometimes accompanied by skin eruptions [rash].\n\nThe analyses confirmed it was chikungunya in 15 cases, mainly in the municipality of Teva I Uta. Further investigations are underway to determine the source and extent of the transmission.\n\nAccording to a statement from the President, mosquito control measures will be implemented, while the rainy season begins. Chikungunya, like dengue or zika, is a disease [virus] transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito, present in Polynesia [That is not correct. These viruses are not transmitted by _Anopheles_ mosquitoes. They are transmitted by _Aedes_ mosquitoes, in Tahiti most likely _Ae. aegypti_. - Mod.TY].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tahiti is part of the Society Island archipelago and capital of the collectivity that is French Polynesia. Although ProMED-mail has not received previous reports of chikungunya virus outbreaks on Tahiti, there were cases on New Caledonia in 2011. Given the inter-island movement within French Polynesia, it is not surprising to see chikungunya virus appear on Tahiti, the most populous of these islands, as Zika virus did in 2013. Since there are no commercially available vaccines available yet for chikungunya virus, the only preventive measures are vector control and avoidance of mosquito bites.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail showing the location of Tahiti in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22997. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nZika virus - New Caledonia (02): ex French Polynesia: 20131203.2089681\nChikungunya (38): New Caledonia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines 20130913.1943191\n2011\n----\nChikungunya (11): New Caledonia 20110507.1404\nChikungunya (09): New Caledonia 20110417.1203\nChikungunya (08): New Caledonia 20110327.0967\nChikungunya (07): New Caledonia, comment 20110309.0768\nChikungunya (06): New Caledonia 20110308.0759\nChikungunya (05): New Caledonia ex Indonesia 20110226.0631\n.................................................mpp/lm/mpp/ty/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "zika"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Polynesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tahiti", "country": "French Polynesia"}, {"location": "New Caledonia 20110507.1404", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "New Caledonia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2878897", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (62): Pacific, Tokelau Islands", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2878897", "date": "2014-10-13 22:50:37", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (60): TAHITI\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 Oct 2014\nSource: Reuters France [in French, trans. Ed.LM, edited]\nhttp://fr.reuters.com/article/topNews/idFRKCN0I00BH20141011?rpc=401\n\n\nThe President of French Polynesia has announced that the chikungunya virus has made its appearance on the island of Tahiti.\n\nAn investigation was opened after the report of several people with joint pain and fever, sometimes accompanied by skin eruptions [rash].\n\nThe analyses confirmed it was chikungunya in 15 cases, mainly in the municipality of Teva I Uta. Further investigations are underway to determine the source and extent of the transmission.\n\nAccording to a statement from the President, mosquito control measures will be implemented, while the rainy season begins. Chikungunya, like dengue or zika, is a disease [virus] transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito, present in Polynesia [That is not correct. These viruses are not transmitted by _Anopheles_ mosquitoes. They are transmitted by _Aedes_ mosquitoes, in Tahiti most likely _Ae. aegypti_. - Mod.TY].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tahiti is part of the Society Island archipelago and capital of the collectivity that is French Polynesia. Although ProMED-mail has not received previous reports of chikungunya virus outbreaks on Tahiti, there were cases on New Caledonia in 2011. Given the inter-island movement within French Polynesia, it is not surprising to see chikungunya virus appear on Tahiti, the most populous of these islands, as Zika virus did in 2013. Since there are no commercially available vaccines available yet for chikungunya virus, the only preventive measures are vector control and avoidance of mosquito bites.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail showing the location of Tahiti in French Polynesia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22997. - Further investigations are underway to determine the source and extent of the transmission.\n\nAccording to a statement from the President, mosquito control measures will be implemented, while the rainy season begins. Chikungunya, like dengue or zika, is a disease [virus] transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito, present in Polynesia [That is not correct. These viruses are not transmitted by _Anopheles_ mosquitoes. Given the inter-island movement within French Polynesia, it is not surprising to see chikungunya virus appear on Tahiti, the most populous of these islands, as Zika virus did in 2013. Ed.LM, edited]\nhttp://fr.reuters.com/article/topNews/idFRKCN0I00BH20141011?rpc=401\n\n\nThe President of French Polynesia has announced that the chikungunya virus has made its appearance on the island of Tahiti.\n\nAn investigation was opened after the report of several people with joint pain and fever, sometimes accompanied by skin eruptions [rash].\n\nThe analyses confirmed it was chikungunya in 15 cases, mainly in the municipality of Teva I Uta. Further investigations are underway to determine the source and extent of the transmission.\n\nAccording to a statement from the President, mosquito control measures will be implemented, while the rainy season begins. Chikungunya, like dengue or zika, is a disease [virus] transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito, present in Polynesia [That is not correct. These viruses are not transmitted by _Anopheles_ mosquitoes. Although ProMED-mail has not received previous reports of chikungunya virus outbreaks on Tahiti, there were cases on New Caledonia in 2011. Given the inter-island movement within French Polynesia, it is not surprising to see chikungunya virus appear on Tahiti, the most populous of these islands, as Zika virus did in 2013. "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (52): AMERICAN SAMOA\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Sep 2014\nSource: Radio New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/253977/chikungunya-related-cases-reach-over-700-in-american-samoa\n\n\nThe latest reports from American Samoa reveal that chikungunya-related [febrile] cases have now reached over 700, and there is now one probable case in Ofu, Manua. The virus was discovered in the territory in July 2014, but there have been no reported cases in Manua until now.\n\nHealth officials are urging residents not to travel to Manua if they have chikungunya, and testing is being done to determine whether the case in Ofu is due to the virus.\n\nSince July 2014, there have been 11 hospitalisations with the virus but no deaths.\n\nHealth officials continue to urge those with symptoms to drink plenty of fluids, get a lot of rest, and visit the emergency department if symptoms become serious.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 26 Jul 2014, it was reported that American Samoa had about 100 cases, with 3 laboratory confirmed as chikungunya virus infections (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20140727.2638925). This is a sharp outbreak, with over 700 cases in a little over one month. Once introduced into American Samoa, spread of the virus is not surprising, because it has had dengue virus transmission in the past, and the same mosquitoes that transmit dengue viruses can transmit chikungunya virus as well.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of American Samoa in the Pacific Ocean can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/380. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (42): American Samoa 20140727.2638925\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2052-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-07-15 00:00:00", "2014-07-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2042-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ofu", "country": "American Samoa"}, {"location": "Manua", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2825226", "headline": "PRO> Chikungunya (58): Americas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2825226", "date": "2014-09-08 17:08:35", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (52): AMERICAN SAMOA\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Sep 2014\nSource: Radio New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/253977/chikungunya-related-cases-reach-over-700-in-american-samoa\n\n\nThe latest reports from American Samoa reveal that chikungunya-related [febrile] cases have now reached over 700, and there is now one probable case in Ofu, Manua. The virus was discovered in the territory in July 2014, but there have been no reported cases in Manua until now.\n\nHealth officials are urging residents not to travel to Manua if they have chikungunya, and testing is being done to determine whether the case in Ofu is due to the virus.\n\nSince July 2014, there have been 11 hospitalisations with the virus but no deaths.\n\nHealth officials continue to urge those with symptoms to drink plenty of fluids, get a lot of rest, and visit the emergency department if symptoms become serious.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 26 Jul 2014, it was reported that American Samoa had about 100 cases, with 3 laboratory confirmed as chikungunya virus infections (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20140727.2638925). This is a sharp outbreak, with over 700 cases in a little over one month. The virus was discovered in the territory in July 2014, but there have been no reported cases in Manua until now.\n\nHealth officials are urging residents not to travel to Manua if they have chikungunya, and testing is being done to determine whether the case in Ofu is due to the virus.\n\nSince July 2014, there have been 11 hospitalisations with the virus but no deaths.\n\nHealth officials continue to urge those with symptoms to drink plenty of fluids, get a lot of rest, and visit the emergency department if symptoms become serious.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 26 Jul 2014, it was reported that American Samoa had about 100 cases, with 3 laboratory confirmed as chikungunya virus infections (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20140727.2638925). This is a sharp outbreak, with over 700 cases in a little over one month. The virus was discovered in the territory in July 2014, but there have been no reported cases in Manua until now.\n\nHealth officials are urging residents not to travel to Manua if they have chikungunya, and testing is being done to determine whether the case in Ofu is due to the virus.\n\nSince July 2014, there have been 11 hospitalisations with the virus but no deaths.\n\nHealth officials continue to urge those with symptoms to drink plenty of fluids, get a lot of rest, and visit the emergency department if symptoms become serious.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 26 Jul 2014, it was reported that American Samoa had about 100 cases, with 3 laboratory confirmed as chikungunya virus infections (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20140727.2638925). This is a sharp outbreak, with over 700 cases in a little over one month. Once introduced into American Samoa, spread of the virus is not surprising, because it has had dengue virus transmission in the past, and the same mosquitoes that transmit dengue viruses can transmit chikungunya virus as well.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of American Samoa in the Pacific Ocean can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/380. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (42): American Samoa 20140727.2638925\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2052-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-07-15 00:00:00", "2014-07-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2042-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ofu", "country": "American Samoa"}, {"location": "Manua", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2794035", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (55): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2794035", "date": "2014-09-08 17:08:35", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (52): AMERICAN SAMOA\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Sep 2014\nSource: Radio New Zealand [edited]\nhttp://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/253977/chikungunya-related-cases-reach-over-700-in-american-samoa\n\n\nThe latest reports from American Samoa reveal that chikungunya-related [febrile] cases have now reached over 700, and there is now one probable case in Ofu, Manua. (conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) 4 cases, of which 2 locally acquired, 2 imported.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Two-more-cases-of-chikungunya-confirmed-in-Jamaica\n\nPuerto Rico. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. Decreasing\nGuiana 1390, of which (conf and probable) 1194 cases.
