(conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) 4 cases, of which 2 locally acquired, 2 imported.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Two-more-cases-of-chikungunya-confirmed-in-Jamaica\n\nPuerto Rico. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 62 cases (case numbers doubled in past 2 weeks).\nhttp://www.stabroeknews.com/2014/news/stories/08/06/fears-grow-spread-chikungunya-berbice/\n\n[Maps of Guyana in northeastern South America can be accessed at http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/GUYANA-W2.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/40880. - Mod.TY]\n\nVenezuela\n- National. 3 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. Moderate transmission\nSt Barthelemy 800 cases. Increasing\nMartinique 52 560 cases; deaths 19. Decreasing\nGuadeloupe 69 740 cases; deaths 6. Decreasing\nGuiana 1390, of which (conf and probable) 1194 cases. Moderate but spreading.\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Cases in various countries:\nCaribbean countries with ongoing transmission not included in the WHO/PAHO report above or with more recent information.\n---\nAruba. 4 Aug 2014. (conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) 4 cases, of which 2 locally acquired, 2 imported.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Two-more-cases-of-chikungunya-confirmed-in-Jamaica\n\nPuerto Rico. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 62 cases (case numbers doubled in past 2 weeks).\nhttp://www.stabroeknews.com/2014/news/stories/08/06/fears-grow-spread-chikungunya-berbice/\n\n[Maps of Guyana in northeastern South America can be accessed at http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/GUYANA-W2.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/40880. - Mod.TY]\n\nVenezuela\n- National. 3 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. (conf) 19 cases. Municipalities most affected: Girardot 1717 cases, Zamora 1 case, Libertador 1 case.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/164987/Aragua-ocupa-el-primer-lugar-con-casos-de-chikungunya [in Spanish]\n\n- Turmero, Aragua state. 3 Aug 2014. (susp) 10 cases.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/165471/Sospechas-de-chikungunya-en-Ambulatorio-de-Turmero [in Spanish]\n\nCountries with cases ex Caribbean but no ongoing transmission\n---\nBrazil. 7 Aug 2014. (registered) 15 imported, including the 1st case in Sao Paulo state, all from affected countries.\nhttp://g1.globo.com/sao-paulo/sorocaba-jundiai/noticia/2014/08/missionario-e-diagnosticado-com-virus-chikungunya-em-aracoiaba.html [in Portuguese]\n\n[The 31 Jul 2014 edition of G1 Globo (http://g1.globo.com/ap/amapa/noticia/2014/07/amapa-tem-primeiro-caso-confirmado-de-chikungunya-diz-laboratorio.html in Portuguese) reported the 1st imported case in Amapa state.\n\nMaps of Brazil can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\n\nCayman Islands. 6 Aug 2014. (susp) 9 cases.\nhttp://www.amigoe.com/curacao/189256-verdelgingsmiddel-in-wijken-tegen-chikungunya\n\n[The 1 Aug 2014 edition of Nieuws (http://www.nieuws.nl/algemeen/20140801/Eerste-geval-van-chikungunya-op-Curacao in Dutch)\nindicated that there is (registered) 1 case locally acquired but there is no mention of ongoing transmission.\n\nFrance (by department) 1 Aug 2014. 1 May-1 Aug 2014. 2014\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous (http://www.nieuws-suriname.nl/al-39-geregistreerde-chikungunya-gevallen/ in Dutch) stated that there are 39 cases.\n\nFrench Caribbean\nDate: 14-27 Jul 2014\nSource: Institut de Veille Sanitaire (French Institute for Public Health Surveillance, InVS) [in French, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.invs.sante.fr/content/download/92696/336991/version/73/file/pe_chikungunya_antilles_310714.pdf\n\n\nLocally acquired cases (clinically compatible) / (conf) since December 2013:\nSt Martin 3760 cases; deaths 3. Moderate transmission\nSt Barthelemy 800 cases. Increasing\nMartinique 52 560 cases; deaths 19. Decreasing\nGuadeloupe 69 740 cases; deaths 6. Decreasing\nGuiana 1390, of which (conf and probable) 1194 cases. Moderate but spreading.\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Cases in various countries:\nCaribbean countries with ongoing transmission not included in the WHO/PAHO report above or with more recent information.\n---\nAruba. 4 Aug 2014. (conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) 4 cases, of which 2 locally acquired, 2 imported.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Two-more-cases-of-chikungunya-confirmed-in-Jamaica\n\nPuerto Rico. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 62 cases (case numbers doubled in past 2 weeks).\nhttp://www.stabroeknews.com/2014/news/stories/08/06/fears-grow-spread-chikungunya-berbice/\n\n[Maps of Guyana in northeastern South America can be accessed at http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/GUYANA-W2.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/40880. - Mod.TY]\n\nVenezuela\n- National. 3 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. (conf) 19 cases. Municipalities most affected: Girardot 1717 cases, Zamora 1 case, Libertador 1 case.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/164987/Aragua-ocupa-el-primer-lugar-con-casos-de-chikungunya [in Spanish]\n\n- Turmero, Aragua state. 3 Aug 2014. (susp) 10 cases.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/165471/Sospechas-de-chikungunya-en-Ambulatorio-de-Turmero [in Spanish]\n\nCountries with cases ex Caribbean but no ongoing transmission\n---\nBrazil. 7 Aug 2014. (registered) 15 imported, including the 1st case in Sao Paulo state, all from affected countries.\nhttp://g1.globo.com/sao-paulo/sorocaba-jundiai/noticia/2014/08/missionario-e-diagnosticado-com-virus-chikungunya-em-aracoiaba.html [in Portuguese]\n\n[The 31 Jul 2014 edition of G1 Globo (http://g1.globo.com/ap/amapa/noticia/2014/07/amapa-tem-primeiro-caso-confirmado-de-chikungunya-diz-laboratorio.html in Portuguese) reported the 1st imported case in Amapa state.\n\nMaps of Brazil can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\n\nCayman Islands. 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 5 cases of which 4 are imported and one locally acquired, but there is no evidence of ongoing transmission.\nhttp://www.caymannewsservice.com/health/2014/08/06/three-new-suspect-cases-chikungunya-reported\n\nCuracao. 8 Aug 2014. (susp) 9 cases.\nhttp://www.amigoe.com/curacao/189256-verdelgingsmiddel-in-wijken-tegen-chikungunya\n\n[The 1 Aug 2014 edition of Nieuws (http://www.nieuws.nl/algemeen/20140801/Eerste-geval-van-chikungunya-op-Curacao in Dutch)\nindicated that there is (registered) 1 case locally acquired but there is no mention of ongoing transmission.\n\nFrance (by department) 1 Aug 2014. 1 May-1 Aug 2014. Imported cases 221:\n- Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur 70 cases\n- Corse 2 cases\n- Languedoc-Roussillon 42 cases\n- Rhone-Alpes 48 cases\n- Aquitaine 31 cases\n- Midi-Pyrenees 28 cases\nhttp://bit.ly/1mQbRgF [in French]\n\n[Maps of France can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/france_admin91.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100. - Mod.TY]\n\nReunion Island. 1 Aug 2014. (conf ) 2 cases ex Antilles.\nhttp://bit.ly/1vqWgtr [in French]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38316. - Mod.TY]\n\nUSA states from ArboNET\nCases as of 5 Aug 2014, summarized (all imported except Florida, US Virgin Islands):\nStates:\nAlabama 1 case\nArizona 2 cases\nArkansas 3 cases\nCalifornia 19 cases\nConnecticut 13 cases\nDelaware 1 case\nDistrict of Columbia 2 cases\nFlorida 34 cases\nConnecticut 6 cases\nFlorida 127 cases imported 4 locally acquired\nGeorgia 8 cases\nHawaii 1 case\nIdaho 1 case\nIndiana 12 cases\nKansas 2 cases\nKentucky 7 cases\nLouisiana 6 cases\nMaine 2 cases\nMaryland 9 cases\nMassachusetts 22 cases\nMichigan 9 cases\nMinnesota 10 cases\nMississippi 5 cases\nMissouri 2 cases\nNebraska 4 cases\nNevada 1 case\nNew Hampshire 4 cases\nNew Jersey 25 cases\nNew Mexico 1 case\nNew York 72 cases\nNorth Carolina 15 cases\nOhio 13 cases\nOklahoma 7 cases\nOregon 3 cases\nPennsylvania 12 cases\nRhode Island 14 cases\nSouth Dakota 1 case\nTennessee 23 cases\nTexas 4 cases\nVirginia 12 cases\nWest Virginia 1 case\nWisconsin 3 cases\n\nTerritory\nUS Virgin Islands 2 cases locally acquired\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/geo/united-states.html\n\n[Maps showing the location of the states mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/usa-maps/us-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\nUSA cases not reported above in ArboNET or information more recently reported:\n- Florida. 2 Aug 2014. (conf) 137 imported cases (countries of origin: Dominica, Dominican Republic (40), Guyana (2), Haiti (85), Martinique (2), and Puerto Rico (7). (http://www.nieuws-suriname.nl/al-39-geregistreerde-chikungunya-gevallen/ in Dutch) stated that there are 39 cases.\n\nFrench Caribbean\nDate: 14-27 Jul 2014\nSource: Institut de Veille Sanitaire (French Institute for Public Health Surveillance, InVS) [in French, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.invs.sante.fr/content/download/92696/336991/version/73/file/pe_chikungunya_antilles_310714.pdf\n\n\nLocally acquired cases (clinically compatible) / (conf) since December 2013:\nSt Martin 3760 cases; deaths 3. Moderate transmission\nSt Barthelemy 800 cases. Increasing\nMartinique 52 560 cases; deaths 19. Decreasing\nGuadeloupe 69 740 cases; deaths 6. Decreasing\nGuiana 1390, of which (conf and probable) 1194 cases. Moderate but spreading.\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Cases in various countries:\nCaribbean countries with ongoing transmission not included in the WHO/PAHO report above or with more recent information.\n---\nAruba. 4 Aug 2014. (conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) 4 cases, of which 2 locally acquired, 2 imported.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Two-more-cases-of-chikungunya-confirmed-in-Jamaica\n\nPuerto Rico. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 62 cases (case numbers doubled in past 2 weeks).\nhttp://www.stabroeknews.com/2014/news/stories/08/06/fears-grow-spread-chikungunya-berbice/\n\n[Maps of Guyana in northeastern South America can be accessed at http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/GUYANA-W2.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/40880. - Mod.TY]\n\nVenezuela\n- National. 3 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. (conf) 19 cases. Municipalities most affected: Girardot 1717 cases, Zamora 1 case, Libertador 1 case.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/164987/Aragua-ocupa-el-primer-lugar-con-casos-de-chikungunya [in Spanish]\n\n- Turmero, Aragua state. 3 Aug 2014. (susp) 10 cases.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/165471/Sospechas-de-chikungunya-en-Ambulatorio-de-Turmero [in Spanish]\n\nCountries with cases ex Caribbean but no ongoing transmission\n---\nBrazil. 7 Aug 2014. (registered) 15 imported, including the 1st case in Sao Paulo state, all from affected countries.\nhttp://g1.globo.com/sao-paulo/sorocaba-jundiai/noticia/2014/08/missionario-e-diagnosticado-com-virus-chikungunya-em-aracoiaba.html [in Portuguese]\n\n[The 31 Jul 2014 edition of G1 Globo (http://g1.globo.com/ap/amapa/noticia/2014/07/amapa-tem-primeiro-caso-confirmado-de-chikungunya-diz-laboratorio.html in Portuguese) reported the 1st imported case in Amapa state.\n\nMaps of Brazil can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\n\nCayman Islands. 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 5 cases of which 4 are imported and one locally acquired, but there is no evidence of ongoing transmission.\nhttp://www.caymannewsservice.com/health/2014/08/06/three-new-suspect-cases-chikungunya-reported\n\nCuracao. 8 Aug 2014. (susp) 9 cases.\nhttp://www.amigoe.com/curacao/189256-verdelgingsmiddel-in-wijken-tegen-chikungunya\n\n[The 1 Aug 2014 edition of Nieuws (http://www.nieuws.nl/algemeen/20140801/Eerste-geval-van-chikungunya-op-Curacao in Dutch)\nindicated that there is (registered) 1 case locally acquired but there is no mention of ongoing transmission.\n\nFrance (by department) 1 Aug 2014. 1 May-1 Aug 2014. Imported cases 221:\n- Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur 70 cases\n- Corse 2 cases\n- Languedoc-Roussillon 42 cases\n- Rhone-Alpes 48 cases\n- Aquitaine 31 cases\n- Midi-Pyrenees 28 cases\nhttp://bit.ly/1mQbRgF [in French]\n\n[Maps of France can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/france_admin91.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100. - Mod.TY]\n\nReunion Island. 1 Aug 2014. (conf ) 2 cases ex Antilles.\nhttp://bit.ly/1vqWgtr [in French]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38316. - Mod.TY]\n\nUSA states from ArboNET\nCases as of 5 Aug 2014, summarized (all imported except Florida, US Virgin Islands):\nStates:\nAlabama 1 case\nArizona 2 cases\nArkansas 3 cases\nCalifornia 19 cases\nConnecticut 13 cases\nDelaware 1 case\nDistrict of Columbia 2 cases\nFlorida 34 cases\nConnecticut 6 cases\nFlorida 127 cases imported 4 locally acquired\nGeorgia 8 cases\nHawaii 1 case\nIdaho 1 case\nIndiana 12 cases\nKansas 2 cases\nKentucky 7 cases\nLouisiana 6 cases\nMaine 2 cases\nMaryland 9 cases\nMassachusetts 22 cases\nMichigan 9 cases\nMinnesota 10 cases\nMississippi 5 cases\nMissouri 2 cases\nNebraska 4 cases\nNevada 1 case\nNew Hampshire 4 cases\nNew Jersey 25 cases\nNew Mexico 1 case\nNew York 72 cases\nNorth Carolina 15 cases\nOhio 13 cases\nOklahoma 7 cases\nOregon 3 cases\nPennsylvania 12 cases\nRhode Island 14 cases\nSouth Dakota 1 case\nTennessee 23 cases\nTexas 4 cases\nVirginia 12 cases\nWest Virginia 1 case\nWisconsin 3 cases\n\nTerritory\nUS Virgin Islands 2 cases locally acquired\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/geo/united-states.html\n\n[Maps showing the location of the states mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/usa-maps/us-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\nUSA cases not reported above in ArboNET or information more recently reported:\n- Florida. 2 Aug 2014. (conf) 137 imported cases (countries of origin: Dominica, Dominican Republic (40), Guyana (2), Haiti (85), Martinique (2), and Puerto Rico (7). Locally acquired 4 cases in Palm Beach and St. Lucie Counties.\nhttp://www.floridahealth.gov/diseases-and-conditions/mosquito-borne-diseases/_documents/2014/week31arbovirusreport-8-2-14.pdf\n\n- South Carolina. 5 Aug 2014. 2014\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=article&id=343&Itemid=40931\n\n\nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or territory with autochthonous transmission -- 2013-2014 to EW 32 (cumulative, updated 8 Aug 2014)\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nCountry / Week / Local Susp/ Local Conf / Imported / (http://www.nieuws-suriname.nl/al-39-geregistreerde-chikungunya-gevallen/ in Dutch) stated that there are 39 cases.\n\nFrench Caribbean\nDate: 14-27 Jul 2014\nSource: Institut de Veille Sanitaire (French Institute for Public Health Surveillance, InVS) [in French, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.invs.sante.fr/content/download/92696/336991/version/73/file/pe_chikungunya_antilles_310714.pdf\n\n\nLocally acquired cases (clinically compatible) / (conf) since December 2013:\nSt Martin 3760 cases; deaths 3. Moderate transmission\nSt Barthelemy 800 cases. Increasing\nMartinique 52 560 cases; deaths 19. Decreasing\nGuadeloupe 69 740 cases; deaths 6. Decreasing\nGuiana 1390, of which (conf and probable) 1194 cases. Moderate but spreading.\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Cases in various countries:\nCaribbean countries with ongoing transmission not included in the WHO/PAHO report above or with more recent information.\n---\nAruba. 4 Aug 2014. (conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) 4 cases, of which 2 locally acquired, 2 imported.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Two-more-cases-of-chikungunya-confirmed-in-Jamaica\n\nPuerto Rico. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 62 cases (case numbers doubled in past 2 weeks).\nhttp://www.stabroeknews.com/2014/news/stories/08/06/fears-grow-spread-chikungunya-berbice/\n\n[Maps of Guyana in northeastern South America can be accessed at http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/GUYANA-W2.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/40880. - Mod.TY]\n\nVenezuela\n- National. 3 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. (conf) 19 cases. Municipalities most affected: Girardot 1717 cases, Zamora 1 case, Libertador 1 case.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/164987/Aragua-ocupa-el-primer-lugar-con-casos-de-chikungunya [in Spanish]\n\n- Turmero, Aragua state. 3 Aug 2014. (susp) 10 cases.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/165471/Sospechas-de-chikungunya-en-Ambulatorio-de-Turmero [in Spanish]\n\nCountries with cases ex Caribbean but no ongoing transmission\n---\nBrazil. 7 Aug 2014. (registered) 15 imported, including the 1st case in Sao Paulo state, all from affected countries.\nhttp://g1.globo.com/sao-paulo/sorocaba-jundiai/noticia/2014/08/missionario-e-diagnosticado-com-virus-chikungunya-em-aracoiaba.html [in Portuguese]\n\n[The 31 Jul 2014 edition of G1 Globo (http://g1.globo.com/ap/amapa/noticia/2014/07/amapa-tem-primeiro-caso-confirmado-de-chikungunya-diz-laboratorio.html in Portuguese) reported the 1st imported case in Amapa state.\n\nMaps of Brazil can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\n\nCayman Islands. 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 5 cases of which 4 are imported and one locally acquired, but there is no evidence of ongoing transmission.\nhttp://www.caymannewsservice.com/health/2014/08/06/three-new-suspect-cases-chikungunya-reported\n\nCuracao. 8 Aug 2014. (susp) 9 cases.\nhttp://www.amigoe.com/curacao/189256-verdelgingsmiddel-in-wijken-tegen-chikungunya\n\n[The 1 Aug 2014 edition of Nieuws (http://www.nieuws.nl/algemeen/20140801/Eerste-geval-van-chikungunya-op-Curacao in Dutch)\nindicated that there is (registered) 1 case locally acquired but there is no mention of ongoing transmission.\n\nFrance (by department) 1 Aug 2014. 1 May-1 Aug 2014. Imported cases 221:\n- Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur 70 cases\n- Corse 2 cases\n- Languedoc-Roussillon 42 cases\n- Rhone-Alpes 48 cases\n- Aquitaine 31 cases\n- Midi-Pyrenees 28 cases\nhttp://bit.ly/1mQbRgF [in French]\n\n[Maps of France can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/france_admin91.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/100. - Mod.TY]\n\nReunion Island. 1 Aug 2014. (conf ) 2 cases ex Antilles.\nhttp://bit.ly/1vqWgtr [in French]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38316. - Mod.TY]\n\nUSA states from ArboNET\nCases as of 5 Aug 2014, summarized (all imported except Florida, US Virgin Islands):\nStates:\nAlabama 1 case\nArizona 2 cases\nArkansas 3 cases\nCalifornia 19 cases\nConnecticut 13 cases\nDelaware 1 case\nDistrict of Columbia 2 cases\nFlorida 34 cases\nConnecticut 6 cases\nFlorida 127 cases imported 4 locally acquired\nGeorgia 8 cases\nHawaii 1 case\nIdaho 1 case\nIndiana 12 cases\nKansas 2 cases\nKentucky 7 cases\nLouisiana 6 cases\nMaine 2 cases\nMaryland 9 cases\nMassachusetts 22 cases\nMichigan 9 cases\nMinnesota 10 cases\nMississippi 5 cases\nMissouri 2 cases\nNebraska 4 cases\nNevada 1 case\nNew Hampshire 4 cases\nNew Jersey 25 cases\nNew Mexico 1 case\nNew York 72 cases\nNorth Carolina 15 cases\nOhio 13 cases\nOklahoma 7 cases\nOregon 3 cases\nPennsylvania 12 cases\nRhode Island 14 cases\nSouth Dakota 1 case\nTennessee 23 cases\nTexas 4 cases\nVirginia 12 cases\nWest Virginia 1 case\nWisconsin 3 cases\n\nTerritory\nUS Virgin Islands 2 cases locally acquired\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/geo/united-states.html\n\n[Maps showing the location of the states mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/usa-maps/us-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.TY]\n\nUSA cases not reported above in ArboNET or information more recently reported:\n- Florida. 2 Aug 2014. (conf) 137 imported cases (countries of origin: Dominica, Dominican Republic (40), Guyana (2), Haiti (85), Martinique (2), and Puerto Rico (7). (http://www.nieuws-suriname.nl/al-39-geregistreerde-chikungunya-gevallen/ in Dutch) stated that there are 39 cases.\n\nFrench Caribbean\nDate: 14-27 Jul 2014\nSource: Institut de Veille Sanitaire (French Institute for Public Health Surveillance, InVS) [in French, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.invs.sante.fr/content/download/92696/336991/version/73/file/pe_chikungunya_antilles_310714.pdf\n\n\nLocally acquired cases (clinically compatible) / (conf) since December 2013:\nSt Martin 3760 cases; deaths 3. Moderate transmission\nSt Barthelemy 800 cases. Increasing\nMartinique 52 560 cases; deaths 19. Decreasing\nGuadeloupe 69 740 cases; deaths 6. Decreasing\nGuiana 1390, of which (conf and probable) 1194 cases. Moderate but spreading.\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands mentioned above and below can be accessed at http://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/images/maps/CHIK_Caribbean_Map-060214.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Cases in various countries:\nCaribbean countries with ongoing transmission not included in the WHO/PAHO report above or with more recent information.\n---\nAruba. 4 Aug 2014. (conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) 4 cases, of which 2 locally acquired, 2 imported.\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Two-more-cases-of-chikungunya-confirmed-in-Jamaica\n\nPuerto Rico. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 62 cases (case numbers doubled in past 2 weeks).\nhttp://www.stabroeknews.com/2014/news/stories/08/06/fears-grow-spread-chikungunya-berbice/\n\n[Maps of Guyana in northeastern South America can be accessed at http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/GUYANA-W2.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/40880. - Mod.TY]\n\nVenezuela\n- National. 3 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. (conf) 19 cases. Municipalities most affected: Girardot 1717 cases, Zamora 1 case, Libertador 1 case.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/164987/Aragua-ocupa-el-primer-lugar-con-casos-de-chikungunya [in Spanish]\n\n- Turmero, Aragua state. 3 Aug 2014. (susp) 10 cases.\nhttp://www.elperiodiquito.com/article/165471/Sospechas-de-chikungunya-en-Ambulatorio-de-Turmero [in Spanish]\n\nCountries with cases ex Caribbean but no ongoing transmission\n---\nBrazil. 7 Aug 2014. (registered) 15 imported, including the 1st case in Sao Paulo state, all from affected countries.\nhttp://g1.globo.com/sao-paulo/sorocaba-jundiai/noticia/2014/08/missionario-e-diagnosticado-com-virus-chikungunya-em-aracoiaba.html [in Portuguese]\n\n[The 31 Jul 2014 edition of G1 Globo (http://g1.globo.com/ap/amapa/noticia/2014/07/amapa-tem-primeiro-caso-confirmado-de-chikungunya-diz-laboratorio.html in Portuguese) reported the 1st imported case in Amapa state.\n\nMaps of Brazil can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/brazil.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6. - Mod.TY]\n\nCayman Islands. 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 5 cases of which 4 are imported and one locally acquired, but there is no evidence of ongoing transmission.\nhttp://www.caymannewsservice.com/health/2014/08/06/three-new-suspect-cases-chikungunya-reported\n\nCuracao. 8 Aug 2014. (susp) 9 cases.\nhttp://www.amigoe.com/curacao/189256-verdelgingsmiddel-in-wijken-tegen-chikungunya\n\n[The 1 Aug 2014 edition of Nieuws (http://www.nieuws.nl/algemeen/20140801/Eerste-geval-van-chikungunya-op-Curacao in Dutch)\nindicated that there is (registered) 1 case locally acquired but there is no mention of ongoing transmission.\n\nFrance (by department) 1 Aug 2014. 1 May-1 Aug 2014. (conf) 15 cases of which 11 imported, 4 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.24ora.com/local-mainmenu-5/84060-na-aruba-a-confirma-caba-15-caso-di-chikungunya-te-cu-diabierna-ultimo [in Papiamento]\n\nCuracao. 1 Aug 2014. (conf) 9 cases, of which 1 locally acquired, _Aedes aegypti_ present in the island.\nhttp://www.kkcuracao.com/?p=74621 [in Dutch]\n\nDominican Republic. 6 Aug 2014. As of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], (susp) 370 141 cases, new (susp) in past week 23 730 cases, (conf) 71 cases; deaths (susp) 3. Provinces affected 19.\nhttp://www.digepisalud.gob.do/funciones/funciones/doc_download/390-.html\n\nJamaica. 7 Aug 2014. (conf) as of 15 Jul 2014 386 cases; Municipalities affected 22.\nhttp://www.metro.pr/locales/doce-nuevos-pueblos-reportan-casos-del-chikungunya/pGXnhg!PE1OTivnM8QQ/ [in Spanish]\n\nTrinidad and Tobago. 8 Aug 2014. (conf) 12 cases. The National Academy For the Performing Arts closed due to concern about spread.\nhttp://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/Chickungunya--risk-at-NAPA-270416521.html\n\n[It is not clear if all or some of these 12 cases are locally acquired or imported. Closure of the Performing Arts activities suggests that at least some may be local.\n\nMaps of the Caribbean area can be accessed at http://geology.com/world/caribbean-map.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574. - Mod.TY]\n\nCentral America local transmission\n---\nEl Salvador. 8 Aug 2014. (registered) 2778 cases, past week 433 cases. Municipalities affected: 51 in 9 departments. Increasing.\nhttp://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/08/08/433-casos-de-chikungunya-en-una-semana [in Spanish]\n\n[The 30 Jul 2014 of La Prensa (http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2014/07/30/minsal-reporta-incremento-del-virus-chikungunya in Spanish) indicated that there were 3345 reported cases as of week 30 [ending 25 Jul 2014], more than reported on 8 Aug 2014.\n\nMaps of El Salvador can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/centralamerica/political-map-of-El-Salvado.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21. - Mod.TY]\n\nSouth America with ongoing transmission\n---\nGuyana (Berbice region). 6 Aug 2014. (conf) 62 cases (case numbers doubled in past 2 weeks).\nhttp://www.stabroeknews.com/2014/news/stories/08/06/fears-grow-spread-chikungunya-berbice/\n\n[Maps of Guyana in northeastern South America can be accessed at http://media.maps.com/magellan/Images/GUYANA-W2.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/40880. - Mod.TY]\n\nVenezuela\n- National. 3 Aug 2014. (conf) 94 cases of which 59 are imported and 35 locally acquired.\nhttp://www.rcnradio.com/noticias/reportan-94-casos-de-chikungunya-en-venezuela-153093 [in Spanish]\n\n[The 4 Aug 2014 edition of El Nacional (http://www.el-nacional.com/sociedad/Casos-chikungunya-quintuplicarian-cifra-oficial_0_457754275.html in Spanish) quoted the Venezuelan Society for Public Health as indicating that there must have been nearly 500 cases in Maracay, placing in doubt the official figures of 94 cases.\n\nMaps of Venezuela can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/venezuela.gif and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/29. - Mod.TY]\n\n- Aragua state. 30 Jul 2014. Chikungunya (43): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2643340", "date": "2014-06-23 20:59:11", "main_text": "LEPTOSPIROSIS, DENGUE, CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIA: (TAMIL NADU)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 22 Jun 2014\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/City/Chennai/200-villagers-fall-ill-with-symptoms-of-dengue-rat-fever-near-Dharmapuri/articleshow/37006587.cms\n\n\nMore than 200 villagers have fallen ill with symptoms of dengue, chikungunya and rat fever at Jambukarankottai in Dharmapuri district since Saturday [21 Jun 2014].\n\nDharmapuri MP Dr Anbumani Ramadoss rushed to the spot on Sunday morning [22 Jun 2014] with a team of doctors from the district health department. Anbumani also took part in the medical camp and gave treatment to the patients.\n\n\"More than 200 people at Jambukarankottai are suffering from dengue, chikungunya, and rat fever. We have confirmed this by testing blood samples of [febrile patients],\" Anbumani told TOI.\n\nHe said rat fever or leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon. \"The zoonotic disease is caused largely by rats that are natural carriers of the disease-causing bacterium [_Leptospira interrogans_]. Human beings contract the disease through water and soil which [is contaminated by] the urine of infected animals,\" he said.\n\n\"People those who are affected with rat fever will have symptoms like high fever, headache, chills and nausea. More than 40 people with serious health conditions were rushed to Dharmapuri Government Medical College Hospital,\" Anbumani said.\n\n\"Leptospirosis or rat fever is a potentially serious bacterial infection that can affect many parts of the body. It is caused by _Leptospira interrogans_, a corkscrew-shaped bacterium. Since rats are the most common source of human infection by the bacteria, the disease is also called rat fever. It does not spread from person to person,\" said a medical officer who is part of the medical team.\n\nLeptospirosis bacteria can enter the body through wounds and mucous membranes, or when a person swallows contaminated food or water. Symptoms usually begin 10 days after infection. In severe cases, it can result in liver damage, jaundice, kidney failure, and internal bleeding.\n\nLeptospirosis should be treated with antibiotics. \"The disease can lead to life-threatening complications like renal failure, hypotension, and hemorrhage. Severe or untreated leptospirosis can lead to damage of the organs and, in rare cases, even death,\" he added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jambukarankottai is a village in the Dharmapuri district located in the northwestern portion of Tamil Nadu, India (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharmapuri). Tamil Nadu, one of the 29 states of India, is located in the southernmost part of the Indian Peninsula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu).\n\nLeptospirosis occurs worldwide and outbreaks frequently follow flooding after heavy rains. _Leptospira_ survive for weeks to months in warm, fresh water, or soil flooded with fresh water. After exposure to floodwater contaminated by infected animal urine, the bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes, especially if the skin is broken from a cut or scratch. Drinking contaminated water or food can also cause infection.\n\nTamil Nadu experiences heavy rain during the South West monsoon starting in June to September and during the North East monsoon from October to December; the dry season is from January to May. (The news report above confusingly says, \"leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon.\")\n\nBecause of the relatively nonspecific nature of the clinical presentation of leptospirosis, its diagnosis cannot be made confidently without laboratory confirmation and the exact number of patients with leptospirosis is not given in the news report above. However, the news report above says that the diagnosis of leptospirosis has been confirmed in these patients by blood testing. - Mod.ML]\n\n[Chikungunya & dengue have been reported from India for decades -- CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 (Myers RM, Carey DE. Concurrent isolation from patient of two arboviruses, chikungunya and dengue type 2. Science. 1967;157(3794):1307-8. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27665.]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (35): Americas, Asia 20140508.2459864\nChikungunya (30): Bangladesh (DA) 20140501.2443532 [includes India data\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - India (03): (GJ) 20110925.2912\nLeptospirosis, fatal - India (02): (KL) 20110924.2886\nLeptospirosis, fatal - India: (GJ) 20110829.2647\nLeptospirosis - India: (KA, KL) 20110709.2079\n2009\n----\nLeptospirosis - India (02) 20090404.1296\nLeptospirosis - India: (north), 2007 20090403.1292\n2006\n----\nLeptospirosis - India (Gujarat): not hantavirus 20060831.2476\nLeptospirosis - India (Maharashtra) 20060726.2058\nLeptospirosis - India (Kerala) 20060609.1612\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis", "chikungunya", "dengue", "hantavirus"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2014-06-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1967-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dharmapuri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "India"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Leptospira", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "india", "country": "India"}, {"location": "gujarat", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2638925", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (42): American Samoa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2638925", "date": "2014-06-23 20:59:11", "main_text": "LEPTOSPIROSIS, DENGUE, CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIA: (TAMIL NADU)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 22 Jun 2014\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/City/Chennai/200-villagers-fall-ill-with-symptoms-of-dengue-rat-fever-near-Dharmapuri/articleshow/37006587.cms\n\n\nMore than 200 villagers have fallen ill with symptoms of dengue, chikungunya and rat fever at Jambukarankottai in Dharmapuri district since Saturday [21 Jun 2014].\n\nDharmapuri MP Dr Anbumani Ramadoss rushed to the spot on Sunday morning [22 Jun 2014] with a team of doctors from the district health department. Anbumani also took part in the medical camp and gave treatment to the patients.\n\n\"More than 200 people at Jambukarankottai are suffering from dengue, chikungunya, and rat fever. We have confirmed this by testing blood samples of [febrile patients],\" Anbumani told TOI.\n\nHe said rat fever or leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon. \"The zoonotic disease is caused largely by rats that are natural carriers of the disease-causing bacterium [_Leptospira interrogans_]. Human beings contract the disease through water and soil which [is contaminated by] the urine of infected animals,\" he said.\n\n\"People those who are affected with rat fever will have symptoms like high fever, headache, chills and nausea. More than 40 people with serious health conditions were rushed to Dharmapuri Government Medical College Hospital,\" Anbumani said.\n\n\"Leptospirosis or rat fever is a potentially serious bacterial infection that can affect many parts of the body. It is caused by _Leptospira interrogans_, a corkscrew-shaped bacterium. Since rats are the most common source of human infection by the bacteria, the disease is also called rat fever. It does not spread from person to person,\" said a medical officer who is part of the medical team.\n\nLeptospirosis bacteria can enter the body through wounds and mucous membranes, or when a person swallows contaminated food or water. Symptoms usually begin 10 days after infection. In severe cases, it can result in liver damage, jaundice, kidney failure, and internal bleeding.\n\nLeptospirosis should be treated with antibiotics. \"The disease can lead to life-threatening complications like renal failure, hypotension, and hemorrhage. Severe or untreated leptospirosis can lead to damage of the organs and, in rare cases, even death,\" he added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jambukarankottai is a village in the Dharmapuri district located in the northwestern portion of Tamil Nadu, India (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharmapuri). Tamil Nadu, one of the 29 states of India, is located in the southernmost part of the Indian Peninsula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu).\n\nLeptospirosis occurs worldwide and outbreaks frequently follow flooding after heavy rains. _Leptospira_ survive for weeks to months in warm, fresh water, or soil flooded with fresh water. After exposure to floodwater contaminated by infected animal urine, the bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes, especially if the skin is broken from a cut or scratch. Drinking contaminated water or food can also cause infection.\n\nTamil Nadu experiences heavy rain during the South West monsoon starting in June to September and during the North East monsoon from October to December; the dry season is from January to May. (The news report above confusingly says, \"leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon.\")\n\nBecause of the relatively nonspecific nature of the clinical presentation of leptospirosis, its diagnosis cannot be made confidently without laboratory confirmation and the exact number of patients with leptospirosis is not given in the news report above. However, the news report above says that the diagnosis of leptospirosis has been confirmed in these patients by blood testing. - Mod.ML]\n\n[Chikungunya & dengue have been reported from India for decades -- CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 (Myers RM, Carey DE. Concurrent isolation from patient of two arboviruses, chikungunya and dengue type 2. Science. 1967;157(3794):1307-8. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27665.]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (35): Americas, Asia 20140508.2459864\nChikungunya (30): Bangladesh (DA) 20140501.2443532 [includes India data\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - India (Kerala) 20060609.1612\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis", "chikungunya", "dengue", "hantavirus"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2014-06-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1967-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dharmapuri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "India"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Leptospira", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "india", "country": "India"}, {"location": "gujarat", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2628054", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (41): Philippines (IS) susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2628054", "date": "2014-06-23 20:59:11", "main_text": "LEPTOSPIROSIS, DENGUE, CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIA: (TAMIL NADU)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 22 Jun 2014\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/City/Chennai/200-villagers-fall-ill-with-symptoms-of-dengue-rat-fever-near-Dharmapuri/articleshow/37006587.cms\n\n\nMore than 200 villagers have fallen ill with symptoms of dengue, chikungunya and rat fever at Jambukarankottai in Dharmapuri district since Saturday [21 Jun 2014].\n\nDharmapuri MP Dr Anbumani Ramadoss rushed to the spot on Sunday morning [22 Jun 2014] with a team of doctors from the district health department. Anbumani also took part in the medical camp and gave treatment to the patients.\n\n\"More than 200 people at Jambukarankottai are suffering from dengue, chikungunya, and rat fever. We have confirmed this by testing blood samples of [febrile patients],\" Anbumani told TOI.\n\nHe said rat fever or leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon. \"The zoonotic disease is caused largely by rats that are natural carriers of the disease-causing bacterium [_Leptospira interrogans_]. Human beings contract the disease through water and soil which [is contaminated by] the urine of infected animals,\" he said.\n\n\"People those who are affected with rat fever will have symptoms like high fever, headache, chills and nausea. More than 40 people with serious health conditions were rushed to Dharmapuri Government Medical College Hospital,\" Anbumani said.\n\n\"Leptospirosis or rat fever is a potentially serious bacterial infection that can affect many parts of the body. It is caused by _Leptospira interrogans_, a corkscrew-shaped bacterium. Since rats are the most common source of human infection by the bacteria, the disease is also called rat fever. It does not spread from person to person,\" said a medical officer who is part of the medical team.\n\nLeptospirosis bacteria can enter the body through wounds and mucous membranes, or when a person swallows contaminated food or water. Symptoms usually begin 10 days after infection. In severe cases, it can result in liver damage, jaundice, kidney failure, and internal bleeding.\n\nLeptospirosis should be treated with antibiotics. \"The disease can lead to life-threatening complications like renal failure, hypotension, and hemorrhage. Severe or untreated leptospirosis can lead to damage of the organs and, in rare cases, even death,\" he added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jambukarankottai is a village in the Dharmapuri district located in the northwestern portion of Tamil Nadu, India (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharmapuri). Tamil Nadu, one of the 29 states of India, is located in the southernmost part of the Indian Peninsula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu).\n\nLeptospirosis occurs worldwide and outbreaks frequently follow flooding after heavy rains. _Leptospira_ survive for weeks to months in warm, fresh water, or soil flooded with fresh water. After exposure to floodwater contaminated by infected animal urine, the bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes, especially if the skin is broken from a cut or scratch. Drinking contaminated water or food can also cause infection.\n\nTamil Nadu experiences heavy rain during the South West monsoon starting in June to September and during the North East monsoon from October to December; the dry season is from January to May. (The news report above confusingly says, \"leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon.\")\n\nBecause of the relatively nonspecific nature of the clinical presentation of leptospirosis, its diagnosis cannot be made confidently without laboratory confirmation and the exact number of patients with leptospirosis is not given in the news report above. However, the news report above says that the diagnosis of leptospirosis has been confirmed in these patients by blood testing. - Mod.ML]\n\n[Chikungunya & dengue have been reported from India for decades -- CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 (Myers RM, Carey DE. Symptoms usually begin 10 days after infection. In severe cases, it can result in liver damage, jaundice, kidney failure, and internal bleeding.\n\nLeptospirosis should be treated with antibiotics. \"The disease can lead to life-threatening complications like renal failure, hypotension, and hemorrhage. Severe or untreated leptospirosis can lead to damage of the organs and, in rare cases, even death,\" he added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jambukarankottai is a village in the Dharmapuri district located in the northwestern portion of Tamil Nadu, India (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharmapuri). Tamil Nadu, one of the 29 states of India, is located in the southernmost part of the Indian Peninsula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu).\n\nLeptospirosis occurs worldwide and outbreaks frequently follow flooding after heavy rains. _Leptospira_ survive for weeks to months in warm, fresh water, or soil flooded with fresh water. After exposure to floodwater contaminated by infected animal urine, the bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes, especially if the skin is broken from a cut or scratch. Drinking contaminated water or food can also cause infection.\n\nTamil Nadu experiences heavy rain during the South West monsoon starting in June to September and during the North East monsoon from October to December; the dry season is from January to May. (The news report above confusingly says, \"leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon.\")\n\nBecause of the relatively nonspecific nature of the clinical presentation of leptospirosis, its diagnosis cannot be made confidently without laboratory confirmation and the exact number of patients with leptospirosis is not given in the news report above. However, the news report above says that the diagnosis of leptospirosis has been confirmed in these patients by blood testing. - Mod.ML]\n\n[Chikungunya & dengue have been reported from India for decades -- CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 (Myers RM, Carey DE. Concurrent isolation from patient of two arboviruses, chikungunya and dengue type 2. Science. 1967;157(3794):1307-8. - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/27665.]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (35): Americas, Asia 20140508.2459864\nChikungunya (30): Bangladesh (DA) 20140501.2443532 [includes India data\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - India (Kerala) 20060609.1612\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis", "chikungunya", "dengue", "hantavirus"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2014-06-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1967-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dharmapuri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "India"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Leptospira", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "india", "country": "India"}, {"location": "gujarat", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2563740", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (37): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2563740", "date": "2014-06-23 20:59:11", "main_text": "LEPTOSPIROSIS, DENGUE, CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIA: (TAMIL NADU)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 22 Jun 2014\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/City/Chennai/200-villagers-fall-ill-with-symptoms-of-dengue-rat-fever-near-Dharmapuri/articleshow/37006587.cms\n\n\nMore than 200 villagers have fallen ill with symptoms of dengue, chikungunya and rat fever at Jambukarankottai in Dharmapuri district since Saturday [21 Jun 2014].\n\nDharmapuri MP Dr Anbumani Ramadoss rushed to the spot on Sunday morning [22 Jun 2014] with a team of doctors from the district health department. Anbumani also took part in the medical camp and gave treatment to the patients.\n\n\"More than 200 people at Jambukarankottai are suffering from dengue, chikungunya, and rat fever. We have confirmed this by testing blood samples of [febrile patients],\" Anbumani told TOI.\n\nHe said rat fever or leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon. \"The zoonotic disease is caused largely by rats that are natural carriers of the disease-causing bacterium [_Leptospira interrogans_]. Human beings contract the disease through water and soil which [is contaminated by] the urine of infected animals,\" he said.\n\n\"People those who are affected with rat fever will have symptoms like high fever, headache, chills and nausea. More than 40 people with serious health conditions were rushed to Dharmapuri Government Medical College Hospital,\" Anbumani said.\n\n\"Leptospirosis or rat fever is a potentially serious bacterial infection that can affect many parts of the body. It is caused by _Leptospira interrogans_, a corkscrew-shaped bacterium. Since rats are the most common source of human infection by the bacteria, the disease is also called rat fever. It does not spread from person to person,\" said a medical officer who is part of the medical team.\n\nLeptospirosis bacteria can enter the body through wounds and mucous membranes, or when a person swallows contaminated food or water. Symptoms usually begin 10 days after infection. In severe cases, it can result in liver damage, jaundice, kidney failure, and internal bleeding.\n\nLeptospirosis should be treated with antibiotics. \"The disease can lead to life-threatening complications like renal failure, hypotension, and hemorrhage. Severe or untreated leptospirosis can lead to damage of the organs and, in rare cases, even death,\" he added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Jambukarankottai is a village in the Dharmapuri district located in the northwestern portion of Tamil Nadu, India (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharmapuri). Tamil Nadu, one of the 29 states of India, is located in the southernmost part of the Indian Peninsula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu).\n\nLeptospirosis occurs worldwide and outbreaks frequently follow flooding after heavy rains. _Leptospira_ survive for weeks to months in warm, fresh water, or soil flooded with fresh water. After exposure to floodwater contaminated by infected animal urine, the bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes, especially if the skin is broken from a cut or scratch. Drinking contaminated water or food can also cause infection.\n\nTamil Nadu experiences heavy rain during the South West monsoon starting in June to September and during the North East monsoon from October to December; the dry season is from January to May. (The news report above confusingly says, \"leptospirosis would attack people just before the onset of the monsoon.\")\n\nBecause of the relatively nonspecific nature of the clinical presentation of leptospirosis, its diagnosis cannot be made confidently without laboratory confirmation and the exact number of patients with leptospirosis is not given in the news report above. However, the news report above says that the diagnosis of leptospirosis has been confirmed in these patients by blood testing. - Mod.ML]\n\n[Chikungunya & dengue have been reported from India for decades -- CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 (Myers RM, Carey DE. Tamil Nadu, one of the 29 states of India, is located in the southernmost part of the Indian Peninsula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu).\n\nLeptospirosis occurs worldwide and outbreaks frequently follow flooding after heavy rains. _Leptospira_ survive for weeks to months in warm, fresh water, or soil flooded with fresh water.
