"headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (30): Bangladesh (DA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2443532", "date": "2014-04-27 21:04:58", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (29): CARIBBEAN\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Dominican Republic\n[2] Antigua and the Grenadines\n[3] St. Lucia\n[4] PAHO/WHO report\n[5] French Antilles and Guiana\n\n******\n[1] Dominican Republic\nDate: Sat 26 Apr 2014\nSource: Listin Diario [in Spanish, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.listindiario.com.do/la-republica/2014/4/26/319616/La-fiebre-chikungunya-se-extiende-a-mas-provincias\n\n\nLast night [25 Apr 2014], the Minister of Health confirmed that chikungunya virus [CHKV] has expanded to other cities of the Dominican Republic other than the San Cristobal province, where [the outbreak] began, but not as outbreaks, rather as isolated cases. \"We are seeing isolated areas with isolated infected people, but not as outbreaks. We have not had currently another outbreak like the one in San Cristobal,\" said Freddy Hidalgo.\n\nHe indicated that isolated chikungunya cases have appeared in Puerto Plata ad San Pedro, because these cities have people who have come from Nigua in San Crisobal [province]. \"We expect that the virus can continue to move, but we continue working with the people in prevention tasks,\" he added. Freddy Hidalgo explained that to the extent that people move from one city to another, the virus can too, \"but we are alert to contain new outbreaks.\" The official explained that when a person has become infected with the virus and goes from one place to another, there is risk that the person will be bitten by a mosquito that will then bite another person and infect them.\n\n\"The mosquito is present in different localities to which one might move, and because of this, we are working to avoid dissemination of the virus, that [in turn], moves with the [infected] people. We are not immune, nor is there a vaccine, so we are susceptible to being affected by the virus,\" he said.\n\nHe stressed to the public that water stored on the patios of their houses should be in containers previously treated with bleach. He also asked for general collaboration by the populace for the elimination of water catchments that could contain clean water from their patios.\n\n[Byline: Adriana Peguero]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[New cases are appearing in various parts of the Dominican Republic, especially on the south coast. The 25 Apr 2014 edition of Entorno Inteligente (http://www.entornointeligente.com/articulo/2421878/REPUBLICA-DOMINICANA-La-chikungunya-provoca-188-casos-por-dia-en-Nigua-25042014) quotes the Ministry of Public Health as stating that there are no outbreaks, just isolated cases, outside of the main focus of infection in Nigua, San Cristobal and Haina, where there is an average of 188 new cases per day. However, the 25 Apr 2014 edition of Sierra Vision (http://sierravision.com.do/alcanza-a-4-provincias-virus-de-chikungunya/) indicated that there are outbreaks of chikungunya virus infections in 4 provinces. The localities with the most cases are: San Pedro, Nigua, Haina and Boca Chica (which had 76 cases in the past 72 hours). The 25 Apr 2014 edition of Dominican Today (http://www.dominicantoday.com/dr/local/2014/4/25/51271/Public-Healths-cavalry-battles-chikungunya-fever-at-Boca-Chica) stated that the Public Health Ministry has deployed as of Friday [25 Apr 2014] its entire \"cavalry\" to fumigate Boca Chica, as the rising cases of chikungunya fever have panicked the resort town's population. Fumigation will have limited effect on transmission unless vector mosquito breeding sites are treated or eliminated. Barahona province has also had \"dozens of suspected cases,\" according to a 26 Apr 2014 report in Al Momento (http://www.almomento.net/articulo/161688/BARAHONA-Casos-sospechosos-de-fiebre-Chikungunya), although the occurrence of suspected cases in Barahona is denied in another report (http://www.resumendesalud.com/do/index.php/categoria-infectologia/7893-en-algunas-localidades-no-se-han-registrado-casos-de-chikungunya). Ironically, there has been a cluster of cases in the Robert Reid Cabral Children's Hospital in Santo Domingo, where medical personnel, nurses and other public health workers have been affected. Apparently, _Aedes aegypti_ vector mosquitoes are breeding on the hospital grounds (http://www.alanterd.com/2014/04/salud-publica-se-rehusa-dar-total-casos.html and http://elnuevodiario.com.do/mobile/article.aspx?id=371961).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the Dominican Republic can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/24. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Antigua and the Grenadines\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2015\nSource: Jamaica Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Chikungunya-virus-recorded-in-Antigua\n\n\nLess than 24 hours after St Vincent and the Grenadines confirmed an outbreak of the chikungunya virus, another Caribbean Community (CARICOM) country is reporting its 1st case of the mosquito-borne disease. Antigua and Barbuda health officials on Friday [25 Apr 2014] held a news conference to confirm that an individual in his mid 60s had become the island's 1st case.\n\nMedical Officer of Health Dr Orita Zachariah told reporters that the case had been detected on 22 Apr [2014], and the victim, between the ages of 60 and 65, works in the capital, St John's.\n\nThe health authorities say they are also awaiting results of 4 other suspected cases from the Trinidad-based Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) [laboratories].\n\nDr Zachariah said that persons should remain home if they suspect they have the disease, while Chief health Inspector Lionel Michael said the Department of Health would increase vector control in a bid to prevent a spread of the disease.\n\nOn Thu 24 Apr 2014, the Ministry of Health in St Vincent and the Grenadines declared an outbreak of the virus after 3 cases were confirmed on the northern Grenadine island of Bequia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The 24 Apr 2014 edition of I-Witness News (http://www.iwnsvg.com/2014/04/24/update-health-minister-declares-outbreak-of-chikungunya-in-st-vincent/) indicated that cases of chikungunya on Bequia were 1st suspected last week, Mon 14 Apr 2014. Of the 4 samples sent to the Trinidad laboratory, 3 tested positive for chikungunya virus. An additional 14 samples are ready to send to the Trinidad Laboratory.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Bequia in the Grenadines can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38717. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] St. Lucia\nDate: Wed 23 Apr 2014\nSource: St. Lucia News [edited]\nhttp://www.stlucianewsonline.com/health-officials-investigate-more-suspected-cases-of-chikungunya/\n\n\nThere are no new confirmed cases of chikungunya on the island; however, health officials suspect there may be at least 10 more. The Ministry of Health announced the 1st and only confirmed case of the disease earlier this month [April 2014].\n\nChief Epidemiologist Nahum Jn Baptiste told Saint Lucia News Online (SNO) in an interview that as of today, 23 Apr 2014, 10 suspected cases have surfaced -- one as recent as yesterday -- involving a foreigner, but none have been confirmed.\n\nA 63-year-old fisherman, who was the 1st individual confirmed to have contracted the virus, has been treated and is fully recovered. He is now back on the job, Jn Baptiste said.\n\n\"So far, we have done the investigations. We have not yet confirmed any other case that has been transmitted from that imported case. We also have another suspected case of a foreigner, someone who started to present signs and symptoms yesterday [22 Apr 2014],\" he said.\n\nJn Baptiste said the ministry continues to strengthen its surveillance system and will continue to send samples to the Caribbean Public Health Agency for testing every week.\n\nFollowing the announcement of the 1st confirmed case of chikungunya [virus infection] a few weeks ago, the Ministry of Health said it had intensified mosquito-control efforts to lessen the impact of a chikungunya outbreak on the island. Officials say the impact of the disease all depends on whether suitable conditions exist for _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes to breed, since they transmit the disease [virus].\n\nPeople suffering with the illness will mainly feel chronic pain in the joints, and although it will not require being admitted to a hospital, there will be prolonged pain or swelling in the joints.\n\n\"As long as we have an infected person and the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito is around and they can bite this infected person whereupon they get infected themselves and then bite someone else, there is possibility for transmission. We of course are zooming in on our index case and looking at his surroundings and the persons in his household and places he frequents to ensure we have some focus intervention there as well,\" Chief Medical Officer Dr. Merlene Fredericks said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[A map showing the location of St. Lucia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[4] PAHO/WHO report\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: PAHO/WHO [edited]\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=25294&Itemid=\u3008=en\n\n\nCountry / Week / Suspected cases / Confirmed cases / Deaths\nLatin Caribbean\nDominican Republic / 14 / 3015 / 17 / 0\nFrench Guiana / 16 / 0 / 52 / 0\nGuadeloupe / 16 / 6000 / 1328 / 1\nMartinique / 16 / 17 630 / 1515 / 2\nSt Barthelemy / 16 / 480 / 135 / 0\nSt Martin / 16 / 3030 / 793 / 3\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean\nAnguilla / 13 / 0 / 33 / 0\nAruba / 6 / 0 / 1 / 0\nDominica / 16 / 1252 / 105 / 0\nSt Kitts and Nevis / 8 / 0 / 1 / 0\nSt Lucia 13 / 0 / 1 / 0\nSt Vincent & the Grenadines 17 / 24 / 3 / 0\nSt Maarten / 12 / 0 / 123 / 0\nBritish Virgin Islands / 11 / 0 / 9 / 0\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/caribnew.gif, and at http://healthmap.org/promed/?p=35575. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[5] French Antilles and Guiana\nDate: 14-20 Apr 2014\nSource: InVS Point Epidemiologique No. 15 [in French, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.invs.sante.fr/fr/content/download/87447/320771/version/62/file/pe_chikungunya_antilles_240414.pdf\n\n\nCases since the beginning of the outbreak in December, 2013:\n- St. Martin: (susp.) 3030 cases, (probable and conf.) 793 cases; Deaths 3; Stable.\n- St. Barthelemy: (susp.) 480 cases, (probable or confirmed) 135 cases; Stable.\n- Martinique: (susp.) 17 630, (probable or confirmed) 1515 cases; Deaths 2; Decreasing.\n- Guadeloupe: (susp.) 6000 cases, (probable or confirmed) 1328 cases; Deaths 1; Increasing.\n- French Guiana: (susp. cases from Kourou and Matoury) not available, (probable or confirmed) 54 cases with 36 locally acquired cases and 18 imported cases; Slightly increasing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[Maps showing case distributions on Guadeloupe can be accessed at the above URL. "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (29): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2433880", "date": "2014-04-27 21:04:58", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (29): CARIBBEAN\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Dominican Republic\n[2] Antigua and the Grenadines\n[3] St. Lucia\n[4] PAHO/WHO report\n[5] French Antilles and Guiana\n\n******\n[1] Dominican Republic\nDate: Sat 26 Apr 2014\nSource: Listin Diario [in Spanish, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.listindiario.com.do/la-republica/2014/4/26/319616/La-fiebre-chikungunya-se-extiende-a-mas-provincias\n\n\nLast night [25 Apr 2014], the Minister of Health confirmed that chikungunya virus [CHKV] has expanded to other cities of the Dominican Republic other than the San Cristobal province, where [the outbreak] began, but not as outbreaks, rather as isolated cases. \"We are seeing isolated areas with isolated infected people, but not as outbreaks. We have not had currently another outbreak like the one in San Cristobal,\" said Freddy Hidalgo.\n\nHe indicated that isolated chikungunya cases have appeared in Puerto Plata ad San Pedro, because these cities have people who have come from Nigua in San Crisobal [province]. \"We expect that the virus can continue to move, but we continue working with the people in prevention tasks,\" he added. Freddy Hidalgo explained that to the extent that people move from one city to another, the virus can too, \"but we are alert to contain new outbreaks.\" The official explained that when a person has become infected with the virus and goes from one place to another, there is risk that the person will be bitten by a mosquito that will then bite another person and infect them.\n\n\"The mosquito is present in different localities to which one might move, and because of this, we are working to avoid dissemination of the virus, that [in turn], moves with the [infected] people. We are not immune, nor is there a vaccine, so we are susceptible to being affected by the virus,\" he said.\n\nHe stressed to the public that water stored on the patios of their houses should be in containers previously treated with bleach. He also asked for general collaboration by the populace for the elimination of water catchments that could contain clean water from their patios.\n\n[Byline: Adriana Peguero]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[New cases are appearing in various parts of the Dominican Republic, especially on the south coast. The 25 Apr 2014 edition of Entorno Inteligente (http://www.entornointeligente.com/articulo/2421878/REPUBLICA-DOMINICANA-La-chikungunya-provoca-188-casos-por-dia-en-Nigua-25042014) quotes the Ministry of Public Health as stating that there are no outbreaks, just isolated cases, outside of the main focus of infection in Nigua, San Cristobal and Haina, where there is an average of 188 new cases per day. However, the 25 Apr 2014 edition of Sierra Vision (http://sierravision.com.do/alcanza-a-4-provincias-virus-de-chikungunya/) indicated that there are outbreaks of chikungunya virus infections in 4 provinces. The localities with the most cases are: San Pedro, Nigua, Haina and Boca Chica (which had 76 cases in the past 72 hours). The 25 Apr 2014 edition of Dominican Today (http://www.dominicantoday.com/dr/local/2014/4/25/51271/Public-Healths-cavalry-battles-chikungunya-fever-at-Boca-Chica) stated that the Public Health Ministry has deployed as of Friday [25 Apr 2014] its entire \"cavalry\" to fumigate Boca Chica, as the rising cases of chikungunya fever have panicked the resort town's population. Fumigation will have limited effect on transmission unless vector mosquito breeding sites are treated or eliminated. Barahona province has also had \"dozens of suspected cases,\" according to a 26 Apr 2014 report in Al Momento (http://www.almomento.net/articulo/161688/BARAHONA-Casos-sospechosos-de-fiebre-Chikungunya), although the occurrence of suspected cases in Barahona is denied in another report (http://www.resumendesalud.com/do/index.php/categoria-infectologia/7893-en-algunas-localidades-no-se-han-registrado-casos-de-chikungunya). Ironically, there has been a cluster of cases in the Robert Reid Cabral Children's Hospital in Santo Domingo, where medical personnel, nurses and other public health workers have been affected. Apparently, _Aedes aegypti_ vector mosquitoes are breeding on the hospital grounds (http://www.alanterd.com/2014/04/salud-publica-se-rehusa-dar-total-casos.html and http://elnuevodiario.com.do/mobile/article.aspx?id=371961).\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of the Dominican Republic can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/24. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2] Antigua and the Grenadines\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2015\nSource: Jamaica Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Chikungunya-virus-recorded-in-Antigua\n\n\nLess than 24 hours after St Vincent and the Grenadines confirmed an outbreak of the chikungunya virus, another Caribbean Community (CARICOM) country is reporting its 1st case of the mosquito-borne disease. Antigua and Barbuda health officials on Friday [25 Apr 2014] held a news conference to confirm that an individual in his mid 60s had become the island's 1st case.\n\nMedical Officer of Health Dr Orita Zachariah told reporters that the case had been detected on 22 Apr [2014], and the victim, between the ages of 60 and 65, works in the capital, St John's.\n\nThe health authorities say they are also awaiting results of 4 other suspected cases from the Trinidad-based Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) [laboratories].\n\nDr Zachariah said that persons should remain home if they suspect they have the disease, while Chief health Inspector Lionel Michael said the Department of Health would increase vector control in a bid to prevent a spread of the disease.\n\nOn Thu 24 Apr 2014, the Ministry of Health in St Vincent and the Grenadines declared an outbreak of the virus after 3 cases were confirmed on the northern Grenadine island of Bequia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[The 24 Apr 2014 edition of I-Witness News (http://www.iwnsvg.com/2014/04/24/update-health-minister-declares-outbreak-of-chikungunya-in-st-vincent/) indicated that cases of chikungunya on Bequia were 1st suspected last week, Mon 14 Apr 2014. Of the 4 samples sent to the Trinidad laboratory, 3 tested positive for chikungunya virus. An additional 14 samples are ready to send to the Trinidad Laboratory.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Bequia in the Grenadines can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38717. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[3] St. Lucia\nDate: Wed 23 Apr 2014\nSource: St. Lucia News [edited]\nhttp://www.stlucianewsonline.com/health-officials-investigate-more-suspected-cases-of-chikungunya/\n\n\nThere are no new confirmed cases of chikungunya on the island; however, health officials suspect there may be at least 10 more. The Ministry of Health announced the 1st and only confirmed case of the disease earlier this month [April 2014].\n\nChief Epidemiologist Nahum Jn Baptiste told Saint Lucia News Online (SNO) in an interview that as of today, 23 Apr 2014, 10 suspected cases have surfaced -- one as recent as yesterday -- involving a foreigner, but none have been confirmed.\n\nA 63-year-old fisherman, who was the 1st individual confirmed to have contracted the virus, has been treated and is fully recovered. He is now back on the job, Jn Baptiste said.\n\n\"So far, we have done the investigations. We have not yet confirmed any other case that has been transmitted from that imported case. We also have another suspected case of a foreigner, someone who started to present signs and symptoms yesterday [22 Apr 2014],\" he said.\n\nJn Baptiste said the ministry continues to strengthen its surveillance system and will continue to send samples to the Caribbean Public Health Agency for testing every week.\n\nFollowing the announcement of the 1st confirmed case of chikungunya [virus infection] a few weeks ago, the Ministry of Health said it had intensified mosquito-control efforts to lessen the impact of a chikungunya outbreak on the island. Officials say the impact of the disease all depends on whether suitable conditions exist for _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes to breed, since they transmit the disease [virus].\n\nPeople suffering with the illness will mainly feel chronic pain in the joints, and although it will not require being admitted to a hospital, there will be prolonged pain or swelling in the joints.\n\n\"As long as we have an infected person and the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito is around and they can bite this infected person whereupon they get infected themselves and then bite someone else, there is possibility for transmission. We of course are zooming in on our index case and looking at his surroundings and the persons in his household and places he frequents to ensure we have some focus intervention there as well,\" Chief Medical Officer Dr. Merlene Fredericks said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[A map showing the location of St. Lucia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[4] PAHO/WHO report\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nSource: PAHO/WHO [edited]\nhttp://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=25294&Itemid=\u3008=en\n\n\nCountry / Week / Suspected cases / Confirmed cases / Deaths\nLatin Caribbean\nDominican Republic / 14 / 3015 / 17 / 0\nFrench Guiana / 16 / 0 / 52 / 0\nGuadeloupe / 16 / 6000 / 1328 / 1\nMartinique / 16 / 17 630 / 1515 / 2\nSt Barthelemy / 16 / 480 / 135 / 0\nSt Martin / 16 / 3030 / 793 / 3\n\nNon-Latin Caribbean\nAnguilla / 13 / 0 / 33 / 0\nAruba / 6 / 0 / 1 / 0\nDominica / 16 / 1252 / 105 / 0\nSt Kitts and Nevis / 8 / 0 / 1 / 0\nSt Lucia 13 / 0 / 1 / 0\nSt Vincent & the Grenadines 17 / 24 / 3 / 0\nSt Maarten / 12 / 0 / 123 / 0\nBritish Virgin Islands / 11 / 0 / 9 / 0\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps showing the location of the affected islands can be accessed at http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/caribnew.gif, and at http://healthmap.org/promed/?p=35575. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[5] French Antilles and Guiana\nDate: 14-20 Apr 2014\nSource: InVS Point Epidemiologique No. 15 [in French, trans. Mod.TY, edited]\nhttp://www.invs.sante.fr/fr/content/download/87447/320771/version/62/file/pe_chikungunya_antilles_240414.pdf\n\n\nCases since the beginning of the outbreak in December, 2013:\n- St. Martin: (susp.) 3030 cases, (probable and conf.) 793 cases; Deaths 3; Stable.\n- St. Barthelemy: (susp.) 480 cases, (probable or confirmed) 135 cases; Stable.\n- Martinique: (susp.) 17 630, (probable or confirmed) 1515 cases; Deaths 2; Decreasing.\n- Guadeloupe: (susp.) 6000 cases, (probable or confirmed) 1328 cases; Deaths 1; Increasing.\n- French Guiana: (susp. cases from Kourou and Matoury) not available, (probable or confirmed) 54 cases with 36 locally acquired cases and 18 imported cases; Slightly increasing.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n\n[Maps showing case distributions on Guadeloupe can be accessed at the above URL. "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-04-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-04-15 00:00:00", "2013-12-15 00:00:00", "1515-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (28): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2416502", "date": "2014-03-17 20:09:13", "main_text": "DENGUE & CHIKUNGUNYA CO-INFECTION - PORTUGAL ex ANGOLA\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Mar 2014\nSource: Eurosurveillance Volume 19, Issue 10 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20730\n\n\nParreira R, Centeno-Lima S, Lopes A, Portugal-Calisto D, Constantino A, Nina J. Dengue virus serotype 4 and chikungunya virus coinfection in a traveller returning from Luanda, Angola, January 2014. Euro Surveill. 2014;19(10):pii=20730\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSummary:\nA concurrent dengue virus [DENV] serotype 4 and chikungunya virus [CHIKV] infection was detected in a woman in her early 50s returning to Portugal from Luanda, Angola, in January 2014. The clinical, laboratory and molecular findings, involving phylogenetic analyses of partial viral genomic sequences amplified by RT-PCR, are described. Although the circulation of both dengue and chikungunya viruses in Angola has been previously reported, to our knowledge this is the 1st time coinfection with both viruses has been detected there.\n\nBackground [summarized]:\nAlthough CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 [13] and later confirmed in Sri Lanka (2008), Malaysia (2010) and Gabon (2007) [14-16], these coinfections are rarely notified.\n\nDiscussion:\nSerological reports from the 1960s, the detection of DENV in travellers returning from Angola in the 1980s, and the detection of DENV1 and DENV2 in travellers in the 1980s and in 1999-2002 suggest endemic DENV activity in Angola. As far as CHIKV is concerned, the situation is a lot less clear. However, serological studies from the 1960s not only identified the presence of anti-CHIKV neutralising antibodies in the north of the country, but also allowed the isolation of 2 strains from a viraemic individual and wild-caught mosquitoes during an outbreak of Katolu Tolu (Kimbundu dialect for 'break-bone disease'), a dengue-like disease caused by the CHIKV, which occurred in Luanda in 1970.\n\nThe detection of DENV4 in the recent traveller is of interest, given that on 1 Apr 2013, the Angolan health authorities reported a dengue outbreak in the country, which was later shown to have been caused by DENV1, and the current description of DENV4 in Luanda may indicate the circulation of multiple DENV subtypes in the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The occurrence of dual DENV and CHIKV infections in an individual is clearly a rare event. With the infected woman's return to Portugal in January, a time of no vector activity, there was little chance of her being a virus source for ongoing transmission. Had either or both infections occurred during the warm season, the consequences might have been different had the infected individual landed in a locality where _Aedes_ mosquitoes were abundant and active, as happened with the introduction of dengue virus into Madeira Island in 2013 (see ProMED-mail archives cited below).\n\nMaps of Angola can be accessed at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/angola.pdf and http://healthmap.org/r/1iGj. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nDengue/DHF update (64): Asia, Africa 20130805.1863726\nDengue/DHF update (54): Asia, Africa 20130701.1800463\nDengue/DHF update (52): Asia, Indian Ocean, Africa 20130624.1788185\nDengue/DHF update (46): Asia, Africa 20130603.1751357\nDengue/DHF update (44): Asia, Africa 20130527.1739445\nDengue/DHF update (40): Asia, Africa 20130521.1727082\nDengue/DHF update (38): Asia, Africa, Middle East, Pacific 20130512.1707139\nDengue/DHF update (31): Asia, Africa, Pacific 20130420.1660193\nDengue/DHF update (30): Asia, Africa, Pacific 20130415.1645892\n.................................................mpp/ty/je/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1967-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "1970-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2064-03-15 00:00:00", "2054-03-15 00:00:00", "2052-03-15 00:00:00", "2046-03-15 00:00:00", "2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Angolan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Angola", "country": "Angola"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Luanda", "country": "Angola"}, {"location": "Sri Lanka", "country": "Sri Lanka"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2409660", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (27): Tonga, New Caledonia ex Tonga", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2409660", "date": "2014-03-17 20:09:13", "main_text": "DENGUE & CHIKUNGUNYA CO-INFECTION - PORTUGAL ex ANGOLA\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Mar 2014\nSource: Eurosurveillance Volume 19, Issue 10 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20730\n\n\nParreira R, Centeno-Lima S, Lopes A, Portugal-Calisto D, Constantino A, Nina J. Euro Surveill. 2014;19(10):pii=20730\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSummary:\nA concurrent dengue virus [DENV] serotype 4 and chikungunya virus [CHIKV] infection was detected in a woman in her early 50s returning to Portugal from Luanda, Angola, in January 2014. The clinical, laboratory and molecular findings, involving phylogenetic analyses of partial viral genomic sequences amplified by RT-PCR, are described. Although the circulation of both dengue and chikungunya viruses in Angola has been previously reported, to our knowledge this is the 1st time coinfection with both viruses has been detected there.\n\nBackground [summarized]:\nAlthough CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 [13] and later confirmed in Sri Lanka (2008), Malaysia (2010) and Gabon (2007) [14-16], these coinfections are rarely notified.\n\nDiscussion:\nSerological reports from the 1960s, the detection of DENV in travellers returning from Angola in the 1980s, and the detection of DENV1 and DENV2 in travellers in the 1980s and in 1999-2002 suggest endemic DENV activity in Angola. Dengue virus serotype 4 and chikungunya virus coinfection in a traveller returning from Luanda, Angola, January 2014. Euro Surveill. 2014;19(10):pii=20730\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSummary:\nA concurrent dengue virus [DENV] serotype 4 and chikungunya virus [CHIKV] infection was detected in a woman in her early 50s returning to Portugal from Luanda, Angola, in January 2014. The clinical, laboratory and molecular findings, involving phylogenetic analyses of partial viral genomic sequences amplified by RT-PCR, are described. Although the circulation of both dengue and chikungunya viruses in Angola has been previously reported, to our knowledge this is the 1st time coinfection with both viruses has been detected there.\n\nBackground [summarized]:\nAlthough CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 [13] and later confirmed in Sri Lanka (2008), Malaysia (2010) and Gabon (2007) [14-16], these coinfections are rarely notified.\n\nDiscussion:\nSerological reports from the 1960s, the detection of DENV in travellers returning from Angola in the 1980s, and the detection of DENV1 and DENV2 in travellers in the 1980s and in 1999-2002 suggest endemic DENV activity in Angola. With the infected woman's return to Portugal in January, a time of no vector activity, there was little chance of her being a virus source for ongoing transmission. Had either or both infections occurred during the warm season, the consequences might have been different had the infected individual landed in a locality where _Aedes_ mosquitoes were abundant and active, as happened with the introduction of dengue virus into Madeira Island in 2013 (see ProMED-mail archives cited below).\n\nMaps of Angola can be accessed at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/angola.pdf and http://healthmap.org/r/1iGj. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nDengue/DHF update (64): Asia, Africa 20130805.1863726\nDengue/DHF update (54): Asia, Africa 20130701.1800463\nDengue/DHF update (52): Asia, Indian Ocean, Africa 20130624.1788185\nDengue/DHF update (46): Asia, Africa 20130603.1751357\nDengue/DHF update (44): Asia, Africa 20130527.1739445\nDengue/DHF update (40): Asia, Africa 20130521.1727082\nDengue/DHF update (38): Asia, Africa, Middle East, Pacific 20130512.1707139\nDengue/DHF update (31): Asia, Africa, Pacific 20130420.1660193\nDengue/DHF update (30): Asia, Africa, Pacific 20130415.1645892\n.................................................mpp/ty/je/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1967-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "1970-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2064-03-15 00:00:00", "2054-03-15 00:00:00", "2052-03-15 00:00:00", "2046-03-15 00:00:00", "2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Angolan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Angola", "country": "Angola"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Luanda", "country": "Angola"}, {"location": "Sri Lanka", "country": "Sri Lanka"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2381750", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (24): Indonesia (JB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2381750", "date": "2014-03-17 20:09:13", "main_text": "DENGUE & CHIKUNGUNYA CO-INFECTION - PORTUGAL ex ANGOLA\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Mar 2014\nSource: Eurosurveillance Volume 19, Issue 10 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=20730\n\n\nParreira R, Centeno-Lima S, Lopes A, Portugal-Calisto D, Constantino A, Nina J. Dengue virus serotype 4 and chikungunya virus coinfection in a traveller returning from Luanda, Angola, January 2014. Euro Surveill. 2014;19(10):pii=20730\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSummary:\nA concurrent dengue virus [DENV] serotype 4 and chikungunya virus [CHIKV] infection was detected in a woman in her early 50s returning to Portugal from Luanda, Angola, in January 2014. The clinical, laboratory and molecular findings, involving phylogenetic analyses of partial viral genomic sequences amplified by RT-PCR, are described. Although the circulation of both dengue and chikungunya viruses in Angola has been previously reported, to our knowledge this is the 1st time coinfection with both viruses has been detected there.\n\nBackground [summarized]:\nAlthough CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 [13] and later confirmed in Sri Lanka (2008), Malaysia (2010) and Gabon (2007) [14-16], these coinfections are rarely notified.\n\nDiscussion:\nSerological reports from the 1960s, the detection of DENV in travellers returning from Angola in the 1980s, and the detection of DENV1 and DENV2 in travellers in the 1980s and in 1999-2002 suggest endemic DENV activity in Angola. As far as CHIKV is concerned, the situation is a lot less clear. However, serological studies from the 1960s not only identified the presence of anti-CHIKV neutralising antibodies in the north of the country, but also allowed the isolation of 2 strains from a viraemic individual and wild-caught mosquitoes during an outbreak of Katolu Tolu (Kimbundu dialect for 'break-bone disease'), a dengue-like disease caused by the CHIKV, which occurred in Luanda in 1970.\n\nThe detection of DENV4 in the recent traveller is of interest, given that on 1 Apr 2013, the Angolan health authorities reported a dengue outbreak in the country, which was later shown to have been caused by DENV1, and the current description of DENV4 in Luanda may indicate the circulation of multiple DENV subtypes in the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The occurrence of dual DENV and CHIKV infections in an individual is clearly a rare event. With the infected woman's return to Portugal in January, a time of no vector activity, there was little chance of her being a virus source for ongoing transmission. Had either or both infections occurred during the warm season, the consequences might have been different had the infected individual landed in a locality where _Aedes_ mosquitoes were abundant and active, as happened with the introduction of dengue virus into Madeira Island in 2013 (see ProMED-mail archives cited below).\n\nMaps of Angola can be accessed at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/angola.pdf and http://healthmap.org/r/1iGj. - Euro Surveill. 2014;19(10):pii=20730\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSummary:\nA concurrent dengue virus [DENV] serotype 4 and chikungunya virus [CHIKV] infection was detected in a woman in her early 50s returning to Portugal from Luanda, Angola, in January 2014. Although the circulation of both dengue and chikungunya viruses in Angola has been previously reported, to our knowledge this is the 1st time coinfection with both viruses has been detected there.\n\nBackground [summarized]:\nAlthough CHIKV/DENV coinfections were 1st reported in India in 1967 [13] and later confirmed in Sri Lanka (2008), Malaysia (2010) and Gabon (2007) [14-16], these coinfections are rarely notified.\n\nDiscussion:\nSerological reports from the 1960s, the detection of DENV in travellers returning from Angola in the 1980s, and the detection of DENV1 and DENV2 in travellers in the 1980s and in 1999-2002 suggest endemic DENV activity in Angola. However, serological studies from the 1960s not only identified the presence of anti-CHIKV neutralising antibodies in the north of the country, but also allowed the isolation of 2 strains from a viraemic individual and wild-caught mosquitoes during an outbreak of Katolu Tolu (Kimbundu dialect for 'break-bone disease'), a dengue-like disease caused by the CHIKV, which occurred in Luanda in 1970.\n\nThe detection of DENV4 in the recent traveller is of interest, given that on 1 Apr 2013, the Angolan health authorities reported a dengue outbreak in the country, which was later shown to have been caused by DENV1, and the current description of DENV4 in Luanda may indicate the circulation of multiple DENV subtypes in the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The occurrence of dual DENV and CHIKV infections in an individual is clearly a rare event. (54): Asia, Africa 20130701.1800463\nDengue/DHF update (52): Asia, Indian Ocean, Africa 20130624.1788185\nDengue/DHF update (46): Asia, Africa 20130603.1751357\nDengue/DHF update (44): Asia, Africa 20130420.1660193\nDengue/DHF update (30): Asia, Africa, Pacific 20130415.1645892\n.................................................mpp/ty/je/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1967-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2335886", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (21): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2335886", "date": "2014-02-07 18:06:44", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (15): CARIBBEAN\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Virus strain\n[2] Dominica\n[3] Caribbean update\n\n******\n[1] Virus strain\nDate: Sat 8 Feb 2014\nSource: The Lancet 838 (9916):514 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2814%2960185-9/fulltext#sec1\n\n\nChikungunya in the Americas\n---------------------------\n[authors: Isabelle Leparc-Goffart, Antoine Nougairede, Sylvie Cassadou, Christine Prat, Xavier de Lamballerie]\n\nOn 5 Dec 2013, the French National Reference Centre for arboviruses confirmed autochthonous chikungunya cases on Saint Martin Island, French West Indies (appendix). On 20 Dec 2013, about 50 confirmed cases were reported with additional evidence for autochthonous transmission on Martinique island. In January 2014, autochthonous cases have been reported also from Guadeloupe, Saint Barthelemy, Dominica, and the British Virgin Islands.\n\n_Aedes aegypti_ is the unique potential vector locally. The full-length viral RNA genome was characterised directly from the serum of 2 viraemic patients using next-generation sequencing methods. The virus does not belong to the ECSA genotype but to the Asian genotype, identified in late 1950s in southeast Asian countries. It is phylogenetically related to strains recently identified in Asia (in Indonesia in 2007, in China in 2012, and in the Philippines in 2013), most of them sharing a specific 4-amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene. The virus is only distantly related to the Asian genotype virus that recently circulated in New Caledonia, which harbours different amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene.\n\nThis episode represents the 1st evidence for the emergence of autochthonous chikungunya cases in the Americas. It is likely that the chikungunya epidemic will extend to other Caribbean islands, and it also has substantial potential for spreading from this region visited yearly by millions of tourists to the American mainland where _A. aegypti_ is endemic. Assuming that this strain will be transmitted efficiently by _A. albopictus_ mosquitoes, its persistence in the Caribbean would also represent, as a consequence of seasonal synchronicity, a great threat for southern European countries where the mosquito has recently dispersed. This situation warrants reinforced epidemiological surveillance and specific preparedness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Dominica\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: Dominica News [edited]\nhttp://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/health/thirteen-cases-chikungunya-dominica/\n\n\nThere are now a total of 13 confirmed cases of the mosquitoborne [virus] disease, chikungunya, in Dominica. Senior environmental health officer, Sylvester St Ville, made the announcement on state-owned DBS Radio on Friday [7 Feb 2014] and said the matter is disturbing. \"It's a major concern for the health care system, but it's something that we are trying to manage,\" he said. \"As of our latest report, there are 13 confirmed cases.\" He said the cases are mainly in the Woodfordhill and Bath Estate areas. \"They are confined to those 2 communities,\" he remarked.\n\nSt Ville pointed out that the environmental health department is currently undertaking preventative measures to reduce the spread the disease. \"Presently we are in Bath Estate doing some source reduction and vector control activities ... this evening (Friday [7 Feb 2014]) we will be doing some fogging operations to reduce the population of adults in these communities,\" he pointed out.\n\nHe said the department will also be removing discarded white goods [stoves, fridges, washing machines and other household appliances] in the Bath Estate area since they provide breeding areas for mosquitos. St Ville is calling on residents to play their part by covering water sources, emptying water containers, among other things, in efforts to control the breeding of mosquitos.\n\nChikungunya is a viral disease, carried mainly by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, that causes a dengue-like sickness. Symptoms include a sudden high fever, severe pain in the wrists, ankles or knuckles, muscle pain, headache, nausea and rash. Joint pain and stiffness are more common with chikungunya than with dengue. Persons who have these symptoms are advised to report to the nearest health centre or their personal health care provider.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[3] Caribbean update\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control Epidemiological Update [edited]\nhttp://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/_layouts/forms/News_DispForm.aspx?List=8db7286c%2Dfe2d%2D476c%2D9133%2D18ff4cb1b568&ID=951&RootFolder=%2Fen%2Fpress%2Fnews%2FLists%2FNews&Source=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Eecdc%2Eeuropa%2Eeu%2Fen%2FPages%2Fhome%2Easpx&Web=86661a14%2Dfb61%2D43e0%2D9663%2D0d514841605d\n\n\nAn ECDC risk assessment of the outbreak published on 12 Dec 2013 concluded that the risk of the disease spreading to other islands in the Caribbean region was high. Since then, autochthonous transmission and imported cases of chikungunya have been reported from several islands in the Caribbean.\n\nThe systematic laboratory confirmation of cases from the islands Saint Martin, Martinique, Saint Barthelemy and Guadeloupe was stopped because of the ongoing outbreak situation. As of 7 Feb 2014, the following number of cases have been reported:\n- St Martin (France): 601 probable or confirmed cases;\n- St Maarten (Netherlands): 60 confirmed cases\n- Saint Barthelemy: 83 probable or confirmed cases\n- Martinique: 518 probable or confirmed cases\n- Guadeloupe: 175 probable or confirmed cases\n- British Virgin Islands, Jost Van Dyke islands: 6 confirmed cases\n- Dominica: 3 confirmed cases and 1 imported confirmed case probably originating from St Martin [now 13 confirmed cases per above report, so the local transmission continues - Mod.TY]\n\nIslands and countries from where imported cases were reported:\n- French Guiana: 4 confirmed imported cases (3 from Martinique and 1 from St Martin, with no evidence of local transmission)\n- One imported confirmed case on the island of Anguilla, probably originating from St Martin\n- One imported case reported on the island Aruba\n\nThis overview indicates that the chikungunya outbreak in the Caribbean is still ongoing and spreading.\n\nThe chikungunya transmission was detected during an ongoing dengue outbreak in the Caribbean. Both arboviruses are transmitted by the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito species. The naive population, the presence of an effective vector in the region and the movement of people in and between islands are factors that make it likely that the outbreak will continue to spread geographically and increase in numbers. Clinicians and travel medicine clinics should remain vigilant regarding imported dengue and chikungunya cases from the Caribbean.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[As the above reports indicate, chikungunya virus infections continue to spread in the Caribbean area. So far, there are no outbreaks reported on the mainland of the Americas.\n\nA map of the Caribbean that indicates the location of all the islands mentioned and French Guiana can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8vcv. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Caribbean 20140205.2257138\nChikungunya (12): Australia, imported 20140202.2250560\nChikungunya (11): Caribbean 20140202.2248906\nChikungunya (10): Caribbean 20140129.2240929\nChikungunya (09): Caribbean 20140126.2231647\nChikungunya (08): Caribbean (St Maarten) 20140122.2224929\nChikungunya (06): Caribbean, corr 20140121.2219548\nChikungunya (07): Caribbean 20140120.2184116\nChikungunya (06): Caribbean 20140118.2181292\nChikungunya (05): Caribbean (British Virgin Islands) 20140114.2172714\nChikungunya (04): Micronesia (YA) 2013 20140114.2171369\nChikungunya (03): Caribbean 20140111.2165563\nChikungunya (02): Caribbean 20140105.2153134\nChikungunya (01): Caribbean 20140102.2148245\n.................................................ty/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Aruba", "country": "Aruba"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Martinique", "country": "Martinique"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Guadeloupe", "country": "Guadeloupe"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Anguilla", "country": "Anguilla"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "British Virgin Islands", "country": "British Virgin Islands"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "New Caledonia", "country": "New Caledonia"}, {"location": "West Indies", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "Dominica"}, {"location": "Saint Martin Island", "country": "Saint Martin"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2323168", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (21): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2323168", "date": "2014-02-07 18:06:44", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (15): CARIBBEAN\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Virus strain\n[2] Dominica\n[3] Caribbean update\n\n******\n[1] Virus strain\nDate: Sat 8 Feb 2014\nSource: The Lancet 838 (9916):514 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2814%2960185-9/fulltext#sec1\n\n\nChikungunya in the Americas\n---------------------------\n[authors: Isabelle Leparc-Goffart, Antoine Nougairede, Sylvie Cassadou, Christine Prat, Xavier de Lamballerie]\n\nOn 5 Dec 2013, the French National Reference Centre for arboviruses confirmed autochthonous chikungunya cases on Saint Martin Island, French West Indies (appendix). On 20 Dec 2013, about 50 confirmed cases were reported with additional evidence for autochthonous transmission on Martinique island. In January 2014, autochthonous cases have been reported also from Guadeloupe, Saint Barthelemy, Dominica, and the British Virgin Islands.\n\n_Aedes aegypti_ is the unique potential vector locally. The full-length viral RNA genome was characterised directly from the serum of 2 viraemic patients using next-generation sequencing methods. The virus does not belong to the ECSA genotype but to the Asian genotype, identified in late 1950s in southeast Asian countries. It is phylogenetically related to strains recently identified in Asia (in Indonesia in 2007, in China in 2012, and in the Philippines in 2013), most of them sharing a specific 4-amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene. The virus is only distantly related to the Asian genotype virus that recently circulated in New Caledonia, which harbours different amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene.\n\nThis episode represents the 1st evidence for the emergence of autochthonous chikungunya cases in the Americas. It is likely that the chikungunya epidemic will extend to other Caribbean islands, and it also has substantial potential for spreading from this region visited yearly by millions of tourists to the American mainland where _A. aegypti_ is endemic. Assuming that this strain will be transmitted efficiently by _A. albopictus_ mosquitoes, its persistence in the Caribbean would also represent, as a consequence of seasonal synchronicity, a great threat for southern European countries where the mosquito has recently dispersed. This situation warrants reinforced epidemiological surveillance and specific preparedness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Dominica\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: Dominica News [edited]\nhttp://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/health/thirteen-cases-chikungunya-dominica/\n\n\nThere are now a total of 13 confirmed cases of the mosquitoborne [virus] disease, chikungunya, in Dominica. Senior environmental health officer, Sylvester St Ville, made the announcement on state-owned DBS Radio on Friday [7 Feb 2014] and said the matter is disturbing. \"It's a major concern for the health care system, but it's something that we are trying to manage,\" he said. \"As of our latest report, there are 13 confirmed cases.\" He said the cases are mainly in the Woodfordhill and Bath Estate areas. \"They are confined to those 2 communities,\" he remarked.\n\nSt Ville pointed out that the environmental health department is currently undertaking preventative measures to reduce the spread the disease. \"Presently we are in Bath Estate doing some source reduction and vector control activities ... this evening (Friday [7 Feb 2014]) we will be doing some fogging operations to reduce the population of adults in these communities,\" he pointed out.\n\nHe said the department will also be removing discarded white goods [stoves, fridges, washing machines and other household appliances] in the Bath Estate area since they provide breeding areas for mosquitos. St Ville is calling on residents to play their part by covering water sources, emptying water containers, among other things, in efforts to control the breeding of mosquitos.\n\nChikungunya is a viral disease, carried mainly by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, that causes a dengue-like sickness. Symptoms include a sudden high fever, severe pain in the wrists, ankles or knuckles, muscle pain, headache, nausea and rash. Joint pain and stiffness are more common with chikungunya than with dengue. Persons who have these symptoms are advised to report to the nearest health centre or their personal health care provider.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[3] Caribbean update\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control Epidemiological Update [edited]\nhttp://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/_layouts/forms/News_DispForm.aspx?List=8db7286c%2Dfe2d%2D476c%2D9133%2D18ff4cb1b568&ID=951&RootFolder=%2Fen%2Fpress%2Fnews%2FLists%2FNews&Source=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Eecdc%2Eeuropa%2Eeu%2Fen%2FPages%2Fhome%2Easpx&Web=86661a14%2Dfb61%2D43e0%2D9663%2D0d514841605d\n\n\nAn ECDC risk assessment of the outbreak published on 12 Dec 2013 concluded that the risk of the disease spreading to other islands in the Caribbean region was high. Since then, autochthonous transmission and imported cases of chikungunya have been reported from several islands in the Caribbean.\n\nThe systematic laboratory confirmation of cases from the islands Saint Martin, Martinique, Saint Barthelemy and Guadeloupe was stopped because of the ongoing outbreak situation. As of 7 Feb 2014, the following number of cases have been reported:\n- St Martin (France): 601 probable or confirmed cases;\n- St Maarten (Netherlands): 60 confirmed cases\n- Saint Barthelemy: 83 probable or confirmed cases\n- Martinique: 518 probable or confirmed cases\n- Guadeloupe: 175 probable or confirmed cases\n- British Virgin Islands, Jost Van Dyke islands: 6 confirmed cases\n- Dominica: 3 confirmed cases and 1 imported confirmed case probably originating from St Martin [now 13 confirmed cases per above report, so the local transmission continues - Mod.TY]\n\nIslands and countries from where imported cases were reported:\n- French Guiana: 4 confirmed imported cases (3 from Martinique and 1 from St Martin, with no evidence of local transmission)\n- One imported confirmed case on the island of Anguilla, probably originating from St Martin\n- One imported case reported on the island Aruba\n\nThis overview indicates that the chikungunya outbreak in the Caribbean is still ongoing and spreading.\n\nThe chikungunya transmission was detected during an ongoing dengue outbreak in the Caribbean. Both arboviruses are transmitted by the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito species. The naive population, the presence of an effective vector in the region and the movement of people in and between islands are factors that make it likely that the outbreak will continue to spread geographically and increase in numbers. Clinicians and travel medicine clinics should remain vigilant regarding imported dengue and chikungunya cases from the Caribbean.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[As the above reports indicate, chikungunya virus infections continue to spread in the Caribbean area. http://healthmap.org/r/8vcv. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Caribbean 20140205.2257138\nChikungunya (12): Australia, imported 20140202.2250560\nChikungunya (11): Caribbean edited]\nhttp://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2814%2960185-9/fulltext#sec1\n\n\nChikungunya in the Americas\n---------------------------\n[authors: Isabelle Leparc-Goffart, Antoine Nougairede, Sylvie Cassadou, Christine Prat, Xavier de Lamballerie]\n\nOn 5 Dec 2013, the French National Reference Centre for arboviruses confirmed autochthonous chikungunya cases on Saint Martin Island, French West Indies (appendix). On 20 Dec 2013, about 50 confirmed cases were reported with additional evidence for autochthonous transmission on Martinique island. In January 2014, autochthonous cases have been reported also from Guadeloupe, Saint Barthelemy, Dominica, and the British Virgin Islands.\n\n_Aedes aegypti_ is the unique potential vector locally. The full-length viral RNA genome was characterised directly from the serum of 2 viraemic patients using next-generation sequencing methods. The virus does not belong to the ECSA genotype but to the Asian genotype, identified in late 1950s in southeast Asian countries. It is phylogenetically related to strains recently identified in Asia (in Indonesia in 2007, in China in 2012, and in the Philippines in 2013), most of them sharing a specific 4-amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene. The virus is only distantly related to the Asian genotype virus that recently circulated in New Caledonia, which harbours different amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene.\n\nThis episode represents the 1st evidence for the emergence of autochthonous chikungunya cases in the Americas. It is likely that the chikungunya epidemic will extend to other Caribbean islands, and it also has substantial potential for spreading from this region visited yearly by millions of tourists to the American mainland where _A. aegypti_ is endemic. Assuming that this strain will be transmitted efficiently by _A. albopictus_ mosquitoes, its persistence in the Caribbean would also represent, as a consequence of seasonal synchronicity, a great threat for southern European countries where the mosquito has recently dispersed. This situation warrants reinforced epidemiological surveillance and specific preparedness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Dominica\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: Dominica News [edited]\nhttp://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/health/thirteen-cases-chikungunya-dominica/\n\n\nThere are now a total of 13 confirmed cases of the mosquitoborne [virus] disease, chikungunya, in Dominica. Senior environmental health officer, Sylvester St Ville, made the announcement on state-owned DBS Radio on Friday [7 Feb 2014] and said the matter is disturbing. \"It's a major concern for the health care system, but it's something that we are trying to manage,\" he said. \"As of our latest report, there are 13 confirmed cases.\" He said the cases are mainly in the Woodfordhill and Bath Estate areas. \"They are confined to those 2 communities,\" he remarked.\n\nSt Ville pointed out that the environmental health department is currently undertaking preventative measures to reduce the spread the disease. \"Presently we are in Bath Estate doing some source reduction and vector control activities ... this evening (Friday [7 Feb 2014]) we will be doing some fogging operations to reduce the population of adults in these communities,\" he pointed out.\n\nHe said the department will also be removing discarded white goods [stoves, fridges, washing machines and other household appliances] in the Bath Estate area since they provide breeding areas for mosquitos. St Ville is calling on residents to play their part by covering water sources, emptying water containers, among other things, in efforts to control the breeding of mosquitos.\n\nChikungunya is a viral disease, carried mainly by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, that causes a dengue-like sickness. Symptoms include a sudden high fever, severe pain in the wrists, ankles or knuckles, muscle pain, headache, nausea and rash. Joint pain and stiffness are more common with chikungunya than with dengue. Persons who have these symptoms are advised to report to the nearest health centre or their personal health care provider.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[3] Caribbean update\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control Epidemiological Update [edited]\nhttp://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/_layouts/forms/News_DispForm.aspx?List=8db7286c%2Dfe2d%2D476c%2D9133%2D18ff4cb1b568&ID=951&RootFolder=%2Fen%2Fpress%2Fnews%2FLists%2FNews&Source=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Eecdc%2Eeuropa%2Eeu%2Fen%2FPages%2Fhome%2Easpx&Web=86661a14%2Dfb61%2D43e0%2D9663%2D0d514841605d\n\n\nAn ECDC risk assessment of the outbreak published on 12 Dec 2013 concluded that the risk of the disease spreading to other islands in the Caribbean region was high. Since then, autochthonous transmission and imported cases of chikungunya have been reported from several islands in the Caribbean.\n\nThe systematic laboratory confirmation of cases from the islands Saint Martin, Martinique, Saint Barthelemy and Guadeloupe was stopped because of the ongoing outbreak situation. As of 7 Feb 2014, the following number of cases have been reported:\n- St Martin (France): 601 probable or confirmed cases;\n- St Maarten (Netherlands): 60 confirmed cases\n- Saint Barthelemy: 83 probable or confirmed cases\n- Martinique: 518 probable or confirmed cases\n- Guadeloupe: 175 probable or confirmed cases\n- British Virgin Islands, Jost Van Dyke islands: 6 confirmed cases\n- Dominica: 3 confirmed cases and 1 imported confirmed case probably originating from St Martin [now 13 confirmed cases per above report, so the local transmission continues - Mod.TY]\n\nIslands and countries from where imported cases were reported:\n- French Guiana: 4 confirmed imported cases (3 from Martinique and 1 from St Martin, with no evidence of local transmission)\n- One imported confirmed case on the island of Anguilla, probably originating from St Martin\n- One imported case reported on the island Aruba\n\nThis overview indicates that the chikungunya outbreak in the Caribbean is still ongoing and spreading.\n\nThe chikungunya transmission was detected during an ongoing dengue outbreak in the Caribbean. Both arboviruses are transmitted by the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito species. The naive population, the presence of an effective vector in the region and the movement of people in and between islands are factors that make it likely that the outbreak will continue to spread geographically and increase in numbers. Clinicians and travel medicine clinics should remain vigilant regarding imported dengue and chikungunya cases from the Caribbean.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[As the above reports indicate, chikungunya virus infections continue to spread in the Caribbean area. So far, there are no outbreaks reported on the mainland of the Americas.\n\nA map of the Caribbean that indicates the location of all the islands mentioned and French Guiana can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8vcv. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Caribbean 20140205.2257138\nChikungunya (12): Australia, imported 20140202.2250560\nChikungunya (11): Caribbean corr 20140121.2219548\nChikungunya (07): Caribbean 20140120.2184116\nChikungunya (06): Caribbean 20140118.2181292\nChikungunya (05): Caribbean (British Virgin Islands) 20140114.2172714\nChikungunya (04): Micronesia (YA) 2013 20140114.2171369\nChikungunya (03): Caribbean 20140111.2165563\nChikungunya (02): Caribbean 20140105.2153134\nChikungunya (01): Caribbean Antoine Nougairede, Sylvie Cassadou, Christine Prat, Xavier de Lamballerie]\n\nOn 5 Dec 2013, the French National Reference Centre for arboviruses confirmed autochthonous chikungunya cases on Saint (04): Micronesia (YA) 2013 20140114.2171369\nChikungunya (03): Caribbean 20140111.2165563\nChikungunya (02): Caribbean 20140105.2153134\nChikungunya (01): Caribbean 20140102.2148245\n.................................................ty/je/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-01-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Aruba", "country": "Aruba"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Martinique", "country": "Martinique"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Guadeloupe", "country": "Guadeloupe"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Brussels", "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "Dominica"}, {"location": "Saint Martin Island", "country": "Saint Martin"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2273650", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (16): Caribbean (Anguilla)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2273650", "date": "2014-02-07 18:06:44", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (15): CARIBBEAN\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Virus strain\n[2] Dominica\n[3] Caribbean update\n\n******\n[1] Virus strain\nDate: Sat 8 Feb 2014\nSource: The Lancet 838 (9916):514 [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736%2814%2960185-9/fulltext#sec1\n\n\nChikungunya in the Americas\n---------------------------\n[authors: Isabelle Leparc-Goffart, Antoine Nougairede, Sylvie Cassadou, Christine Prat, Xavier de Lamballerie]\n\nOn 5 Dec 2013, the French National Reference Centre for arboviruses confirmed autochthonous chikungunya cases on Saint Martin Island, French West Indies (appendix). On 20 Dec 2013, about 50 confirmed cases were reported with additional evidence for autochthonous transmission on Martinique island. In January 2014, autochthonous cases have been reported also from Guadeloupe, Saint Barthelemy, Dominica, and the British Virgin Islands.\n\n_Aedes aegypti_ is the unique potential vector locally. The full-length viral RNA genome was characterised directly from the serum of 2 viraemic patients using next-generation sequencing methods. The virus does not belong to the ECSA genotype but to the Asian genotype, identified in late 1950s in southeast Asian countries. It is phylogenetically related to strains recently identified in Asia (in Indonesia in 2007, in China in 2012, and in the Philippines in 2013), most of them sharing a specific 4-amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene. The virus is only distantly related to the Asian genotype virus that recently circulated in New Caledonia, which harbours different amino acid deletion in the NSP3 gene.\n\nThis episode represents the 1st evidence for the emergence of autochthonous chikungunya cases in the Americas. It is likely that the chikungunya epidemic will extend to other Caribbean islands, and it also has substantial potential for spreading from this region visited yearly by millions of tourists to the American mainland where _A. aegypti_ is endemic. Assuming that this strain will be transmitted efficiently by _A. albopictus_ mosquitoes, its persistence in the Caribbean would also represent, as a consequence of seasonal synchronicity, a great threat for southern European countries where the mosquito has recently dispersed. This situation warrants reinforced epidemiological surveillance and specific preparedness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[2] Dominica\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: Dominica News [edited]\nhttp://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/news/health/thirteen-cases-chikungunya-dominica/\n\n\nThere are now a total of 13 confirmed cases of the mosquitoborne [virus] disease, chikungunya, in Dominica. Senior environmental health officer, Sylvester St Ville, made the announcement on state-owned DBS Radio on Friday [7 Feb 2014] and said the matter is disturbing. \"It's a major concern for the health care system, but it's something that we are trying to manage,\" he said. \"As of our latest report, there are 13 confirmed cases.\" He said the cases are mainly in the Woodfordhill and Bath Estate areas. \"They are confined to those 2 communities,\" he remarked.\n\nSt Ville pointed out that the environmental health department is currently undertaking preventative measures to reduce the spread the disease. \"Presently we are in Bath Estate doing some source reduction and vector control activities ... this evening (Friday [7 Feb 2014]) we will be doing some fogging operations to reduce the population of adults in these communities,\" he pointed out.\n\nHe said the department will also be removing discarded white goods [stoves, fridges, washing machines and other household appliances] in the Bath Estate area since they provide breeding areas for mosquitos. St Ville is calling on residents to play their part by covering water sources, emptying water containers, among other things, in efforts to control the breeding of mosquitos.\n\nChikungunya is a viral disease, carried mainly by the _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito, that causes a dengue-like sickness. Symptoms include a sudden high fever, severe pain in the wrists, ankles or knuckles, muscle pain, headache, nausea and rash. Joint pain and stiffness are more common with chikungunya than with dengue. Persons who have these symptoms are advised to report to the nearest health centre or their personal health care provider.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n******\n[3] Caribbean update\nDate: Fri 7 Feb 2014\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control Epidemiological Update [edited]\nhttp://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/press/news/_layouts/forms/News_DispForm.aspx?List=8db7286c%2Dfe2d%2D476c%2D9133%2D18ff4cb1b568&ID=951&RootFolder=%2Fen%2Fpress%2Fnews%2FLists%2FNews&Source=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Eecdc%2Eeuropa%2Eeu%2Fen%2FPages%2Fhome%2Easpx&Web=86661a14%2Dfb61%2D43e0%2D9663%2D0d514841605d\n\n\nAn ECDC risk assessment of the outbreak published on 12 Dec 2013 concluded that the risk of the disease spreading to other islands in the Caribbean region was high. Since then, autochthonous transmission and imported cases of chikungunya have been reported from several islands in the Caribbean.\n\nThe systematic laboratory confirmation of cases from the islands Saint Martin, Martinique, Saint Barthelemy and Guadeloupe was stopped because of the ongoing outbreak situation. As of 7 Feb 2014, the following number of cases have been reported:\n- St Martin (France): 601 probable or confirmed cases;\n- St Maarten (Netherlands): 60 confirmed cases\n- Saint Barthelemy: 83 probable or confirmed cases\n- Martinique: 518 probable or confirmed cases\n- Guadeloupe: 175 probable or confirmed cases\n- British Virgin Islands, Jost Van Dyke islands: 6 confirmed cases\n- Dominica: 3 confirmed cases and 1 imported confirmed case probably originating from St Martin [now 13 confirmed cases per above report, so the local transmission continues - Mod.TY]\n\nIslands and countries from where imported cases were reported:\n- French Guiana: 4 confirmed imported cases (3 from Martinique and 1 from St Martin, with no evidence of local transmission)\n- One imported confirmed case on the island of Anguilla, probably originating from St Martin\n- One imported case reported on the island Aruba\n\nThis overview indicates that the chikungunya outbreak in the Caribbean is still ongoing and spreading.\n\nThe chikungunya transmission was detected during an ongoing dengue outbreak in the Caribbean. Both arboviruses are transmitted by the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito species. The naive population, the presence of an effective vector in the region and the movement of people in and between islands are factors that make it likely that the outbreak will continue to spread geographically and increase in numbers. Clinicians and travel medicine clinics should remain vigilant regarding imported dengue and chikungunya cases from the Caribbean.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nRoland Hubner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n<roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be>\n\n[As the above reports indicate, chikungunya virus infections continue to spread in the Caribbean area. So far, there are no outbreaks reported on the mainland of the Americas.\n\nA map of the Caribbean that indicates the location of all the islands mentioned and French Guiana can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8vcv. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (14): Caribbean 20140205.2257138\nChikungunya (12): Australia, imported 20140202.2250560\nChikungunya (11): Caribbean corr 20140121.2219548\nChikungunya (07): Caribbean 20140120.2184116\nChikungunya (06): Caribbean 20140118.2181292\nChikungunya (05): Caribbean (British Virgin Islands) 20140114.2172714\nChikungunya (04): Micronesia (YA) 2013 20140114.2171369\nChikungunya (03): Caribbean 20140111.2165563\nChikungunya (02): Caribbean 20140105.2153134\nChikungunya (01): Caribbean "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2014-02-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promedmail.org>\n\n\nThe number of cases (7) listed for Martinique in the ProMED-mail post of 18 Jan 2014 (archive no 20140118.2181292) is incorrect. The case numbers (340 suspected, 127 confirmed) in the post of 20 Jan 2014 (archive no. 20140120.2184116) are correct.\n\nProMED-mail regrets the error and any inconvenience it may have caused. - Mod.TY]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/9Pud.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (07): Caribbean 20140120.2184116\nChikungunya (06): Caribbean 20140118.2181292\nChikungunya (05): Caribbean (British Virgin Islands) 20140114.2172714\nChikungunya (03): Caribbean 20140111.2165563\nChikungunya (02): Caribbean 20140105.2153134\nChikungunya (01): Caribbean 20140102.2148245\n.................................................ty/dk/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2014-01-20 00:00:00", "2014-01-18 00:00:00", "2014-01-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Virgin Islands", "country": "British Virgin Islands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2252615", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (13): Uganda, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2252615", "date": "2014-01-21 12:06:30", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (06): CARIBBEAN, CORRECTION\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promedmail.org>\n\n\nThe number of cases (7) listed for Martinique in the ProMED-mail post of 18 Jan 2014 (archive no 20140118.2181292) is incorrect. It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue, and rash. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common.\n\nThere is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms.\n\nThe proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya [virus infections].\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in Europe, in a localized outbreak in north-eastern Italy.\n\nThe CDC notes there is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent chikungunya [disease]. People can protect themselves by preventing mosquito bites.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak on Yap island first reported on 14 Nov 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20131114.2055640) continues, with 340 suspected cases. These reports do not indicate the mosquito vector involved in this outbreak.\n\nMod.CP provided a good summary of the virus and the disease it causes in that earlier report.\n\nMaps of Micronesia can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/1tB5\nhttp://www.dankainmicronesia.com/images/Micronesia.jpg. - Mod.TY]\nSee "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2049-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-11-14 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00", "2048-03-15 00:00:00", "2046-03-15 00:00:00",
