States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2130000", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (55): Caribbean", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2130000", "date": "2013-11-29 09:49:16", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (49): MICRONESIA (YAP)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Nov 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/chikungunya-outbreak-reported-on-the-island-of-yap-57291/\n\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has been advised by the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) of an outbreak of the mosquito borne viral disease, chikungunya fever, in the State of Yap.\n\nAccording to health officials, more than 340 suspected cases have been identified on the main island of Yap and several of the smaller islands.\n\nAccording to a World Health Organization (WHO) fact sheet, chikungunya is a viral disease that is spread by mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue, and rash. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common.\n\nThere is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms.\n\nThe proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya [virus infections].\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in Europe, in a localized outbreak in north-eastern Italy.\n\nThe CDC notes there is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent chikungunya [disease]. People can protect themselves by preventing mosquito bites.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak on Yap island first reported on 14 Nov 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20131114.2055640) continues, with 340 suspected cases. These reports do not indicate the mosquito vector involved in this outbreak.\n\nMod.CP provided a good summary of the virus and the disease it causes in that earlier report.\n\nMaps of Micronesia can "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (49): MICRONESIA (YAP)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Nov 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/chikungunya-outbreak-reported-on-the-island-of-yap-57291/\n\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has been advised by the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) of an outbreak of the mosquito borne viral disease, chikungunya fever, in the State of Yap.\n\nAccording to health officials, more than 340 suspected cases have been identified on the main island of Yap and several of the smaller islands.\n\nAccording to a World Health Organization (WHO) fact sheet, chikungunya is a viral disease that is spread by mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue, and rash. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common.\n\nThere is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms.\n\nThe proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya [virus infections].\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in Europe, in a localized outbreak in north-eastern Italy.\n\nThe CDC notes there is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent chikungunya [disease]. People can protect themselves by preventing mosquito bites.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak on Yap island first reported on 14 Nov 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20131114.2055640) continues, with 340 suspected cases. of Micronesia (FSM) of an outbreak of the mosquito borne viral disease, chikungunya fever, in the State of Yap.\n\nAccording to health officials, more than 340 suspected cases have been identified on the main island of Yap and several of the smaller islands.\n\nAccording to a World Health Organization (WHO) fact sheet, chikungunya is a viral disease that is spread by mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue, and rash. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common.\n\nThere is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms.\n\nThe proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya [virus infections].\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in Europe, in a localized outbreak in north-eastern Italy.\n\nThe CDC notes there is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent chikungunya [disease]. Yap.\n\nAccording to health officials, more than 340 suspected cases have been identified on the main island of Yap and several of the smaller islands.\n\nAccording to a World Health Organization It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue, and rash. In recent decades mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in Europe, in a localized outbreak in north-eastern Italy.\n\nThe CDC notes there is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent chikungunya [disease]. States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2081433", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (49): Micronesia (YA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2081433", "date": "2013-11-29 09:49:16", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (49): MICRONESIA (YAP)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 24 Nov 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/chikungunya-outbreak-reported-on-the-island-of-yap-57291/\n\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has been advised by the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) of an outbreak of the mosquito borne viral disease, chikungunya fever, in the State of Yap.\n\nAccording to health officials, more than 340 suspected cases have been identified on the main island of Yap and several of the smaller islands.\n\nAccording to a World Health Organization (WHO) fact sheet, chikungunya is a viral disease that is spread by mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue, and rash. The disease shares some clinical signs with dengue, and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common.\n\nThere is no cure for the disease. Treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms.\n\nThe proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya [virus infections].\n\nThe disease occurs in Africa, Asia and the Indian subcontinent. In recent decades mosquito vectors of chikungunya have spread to Europe and the Americas. In 2007, disease transmission was reported for the 1st time in Europe, in a localized outbreak in north-eastern Italy.\n\nThe CDC notes there is currently no vaccine or medicine to prevent chikungunya [disease]. People can protect themselves by preventing mosquito bites.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The chikungunya virus outbreak on Yap island first reported on 14 Nov 2013 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20131114.2055640) continues, with 340 suspected cases. These reports do not indicate the mosquito vector involved in this outbreak.\n\nMod.CP provided a good summary of the virus and the disease it causes in that earlier report.\n\nMaps of Micronesia can be accessed at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/islands_oceans_poles/micronesia_pol99.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/1tB5\nhttp://www.dankainmicronesia.com/images/Micronesia.jpg. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (47): Micronesia (YA) alert 20131114.2055640\nChikungunya (48): India (GJ) 20131120.2065840\nChikungunya (46): Indonesia (JI) 20131111.2050030\nChikungunya (42): Philippines (BA) 20131002.1980717\nChikungunya (41): Australia ex Papua New Guinea 20130929.1974825\nChikungunya (38): New Caledonia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines 20130913.1943191\nChikungunya & dengue - Japan: ex Cambodia (KM) 20130829.1909917\nChikungunya (32): Taiwan ex Southeast Asian countries 20130818.1887387\nChikungunya (31): Singapore 20130813.1877862\nChikungunya (11): Papua New Guinea "CHIKUNGUNYA (48): INDIA (GUJARAT)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Chikungunya-cases-on-rise-in-Ahmedabad/articleshow/26038235.cms\n\n\nAccording to the latest data released by the health department of the AMC [Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation], Ahmedabad city has recorded an increase of more than 350 in the cases of chikungunya [virus infection] from Sep 2013 to 16 Nov 2013 compared with Sep-Nov 2012.\n\nCompared with 24 cases from Sep-Nov 2012, 369 cases of chikungunya [virus infection] were reported from Sep to 16 Nov 2013.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of reported infections from chikungunya virus in Ahmedabad has increased from 39 as of July 2013 to the 350 cases reported above. Chikungunya virus is endemic in India and causes sporadic outbreaks in various parts of the country. Not surprisingly, Ahmedabad is having a mixed outbreak of chikungunya and dengue virus infections since both viruses are transmitted by the same vector mosquito. If the chikungunya virus vector mosquitoes, _Aedes aegypti_, are relatively abundant as is likely, the occurrence of additional cases can be expected unless the vector control efforts are effective. Although the fatality rate is low to nil, morbidity can be high with persistent arthralgia that can last weeks to months. There is no commercially available chikungunya virus vaccine.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Gujarat state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/27Ix. - Mod.TY]\nSee [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Chikungunya-cases-on-rise-in-Ahmedabad/articleshow/26038235.cms\n\n\nAccording to the latest data released by the health department of the 2012.\n\nCompared with 24 cases from Sep-Nov 2012, 369 cases of chikungunya [virus infection] were reported from Sep to 16 Nov 2013.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of reported infections from chikungunya virus in Ahmedabad has increased from 39 as of July 2013 to the 350 cases reported above. Chikungunya virus is endemic in India and causes sporadic outbreaks in various parts of the country. Not surprisingly, Ahmedabad is having a mixed outbreak of chikungunya and dengue virus infections since both viruses are transmitted by the same vector mosquito. If the chikungunya virus vector mosquitoes, _Aedes aegypti_, are relatively abundant as is likely, the occurrence of additional cases can be expected unless the vector control efforts are effective. Although the fatality rate is low to nil, morbidity can be high with persistent arthralgia that can last weeks to months. "2013-11-20 15:12:39", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (48): INDIA (GUJARAT)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Chikungunya-cases-on-rise-in-Ahmedabad/articleshow/26038235.cms\n\n\nAccording to the latest data released by the health department of the AMC [Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation], Ahmedabad city has recorded an increase of more than 350 in the cases of chikungunya [virus infection] from Sep 2013 to 16 Nov 2013 compared with Sep-Nov 2012.\n\nCompared with 24 cases from Sep-Nov 2012, 369 cases of chikungunya [virus infection] were reported from Sep to 16 Nov 2013.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of reported infections from chikungunya virus in Ahmedabad has increased from 39 as of July 2013 to the 350 cases reported above. Chikungunya virus is endemic in India and causes sporadic outbreaks in various parts of the country. Not surprisingly, Ahmedabad is having a mixed outbreak of chikungunya and dengue virus infections since both viruses are transmitted by the same vector mosquito. If the chikungunya virus vector mosquitoes, _Aedes aegypti_, are relatively abundant as is likely, the occurrence of additional cases can be expected unless the vector control efforts are effective. Although the fatality rate is low to nil, morbidity can be high with persistent arthralgia that can last weeks to months. There is no commercially available chikungunya virus vaccine.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Gujarat state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/27Ix. - Mod.TY]\nSee Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of reported infections from chikungunya virus in Ahmedabad has increased from 39 as of July 2013 to the 350 cases reported above. Chikungunya virus is endemic in India and causes sporadic outbreaks in various parts of the country. Not surprisingly, Ahmedabad is having a mixed outbreak of chikungunya and dengue virus infections since both viruses are transmitted by the same vector mosquito. If the chikungunya virus vector mosquitoes, _Aedes aegypti_, are relatively abundant as is likely, the occurrence of additional cases can be expected unless the vector control efforts are effective. Although the fatality rate is low to nil, morbidity can be high with persistent arthralgia that can last weeks to months. There is no commercially available chikungunya virus vaccine.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Gujarat state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/27Ix. - Mod.TY]\nSee "2013-11-20 15:12:39", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (48): INDIA (GUJARAT)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Chikungunya-cases-on-rise-in-Ahmedabad/articleshow/26038235.cms\n\n\nAccording to the latest data released by the health department of the AMC [Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation], Ahmedabad city has recorded an increase of more than 350 in the cases of chikungunya [virus infection] from Sep 2013 to 16 Nov 2013 compared with Sep-Nov 2012.\n\nCompared with 24 cases from Sep-Nov 2012, 369 cases of chikungunya [virus infection] were reported from Sep to 16 Nov 2013.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of reported infections from chikungunya virus in Ahmedabad has increased from 39 as of July 2013 to the 350 cases reported above. Chikungunya virus is endemic in India and causes sporadic outbreaks in various parts of the country. Not surprisingly, Ahmedabad is having a mixed outbreak of chikungunya and dengue virus infections since both viruses are transmitted by the same vector mosquito. If the chikungunya virus vector mosquitoes, _Aedes aegypti_, are relatively abundant as is likely, the occurrence of additional cases can be expected unless the vector control efforts are effective. Although the fatality rate is low to nil, morbidity can be high with persistent arthralgia that can last weeks to months. There is no commercially available chikungunya virus vaccine.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Gujarat state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/27Ix. - Mod.TY]\nSee "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1974825", "date": "2013-11-20 15:12:39", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (48): INDIA (GUJARAT)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 19 Nov 2013\nSource: The Times of India, Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Chikungunya-cases-on-rise-in-Ahmedabad/articleshow/26038235.cms\n\n\nAccording to the latest data released by the health department of the AMC [Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation], Ahmedabad city has recorded an increase of more than 350 in the cases of chikungunya [virus infection] from Sep 2013 to 16 Nov 2013 compared with Sep-Nov 2012.\n\nCompared with 24 cases from Sep-Nov 2012, 369 cases of chikungunya [virus infection] were reported from Sep to 16 Nov 2013.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of reported infections from chikungunya virus in Ahmedabad has increased from 39 as of July 2013 to the 350 cases reported above. Chikungunya virus is endemic in India and causes sporadic outbreaks in various parts of the country. Not surprisingly, Ahmedabad is having a mixed outbreak of chikungunya and dengue virus infections since both viruses are transmitted by the same vector mosquito. If the chikungunya virus vector mosquitoes, _Aedes aegypti_, are relatively abundant as is likely, the occurrence of additional cases can be expected unless the vector control efforts are effective. Although the fatality rate is low to nil, morbidity can be high with persistent arthralgia that can last weeks to months. There is no commercially available chikungunya virus vaccine.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Gujarat state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/27Ix. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (45): India (OR) susp. 20131110.2048315\nChikungunya (44): India (GJ) 20131029.2028239\nChikungunya (43): India (TN) 20131016.2003740\nChikungunya (37): India (GJ) 20130912.1939793\nChikungunya (35): India (KL) 20130905.1926193\nChikungunya (30): India (GU) 20130813.1870987\nChikungunya (18): India (KA) susp 20130603.1751840\nChikungunya (17): India (KA) susp 20130602.1750761\nChikungunya (01): India (OD) 20130107.1484993\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2048-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-09-15 00:00:00", "2013-07-15 00:00:00", "2045-03-15 00:00:00", "2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2043-03-15 00:00:00", "2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Ahmedabad", "country": "India"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Ahmedabad city", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1962092", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (40): Philippines (BA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1962092", "date": "2013-08-29 10:02:17", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - JAPAN: ex CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2013\nFrom: Yasuko Honma <honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nA dengue fever case and a chikungunya fever case were simultaneously detected in the same tour group returning from Cambodia by quarantine screening at Narita international airport in Japan.\n\nThe tour group participants, 8 junior high school students and a staff member, traveled to Cambodia from 2-11 Aug [2013]. Each member stayed with a host family in a village of Kampong Cham province from 4-8 Aug 2013. The participants used mosquito repellent but could not avoid some bites. On 12 Aug [2013], returning from Cambodia to Japan, a 12-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy visited the health consultation room of Narita quarantine station because of fever. They were examined and blood samples were tested for dengue fever, chikungunya fever, and malaria.\n\nCase 1: a girl (12 years old) had fever, headache, arthralgia, general fatigue, and postorbital pain on 9 Aug 2013 and diarrhea on 12 Aug 2013. From the blood sample, dengue NS-1 antigen was detected by immunochromatographic test [Bio-Rad Dengue NS1 Antigen Strip test] and virus specific gene by RT-PCR (TaqMan; both types 1 and 4 dengue virus). Chikungunya virus or malaria microparasite were not detected. Diagnosed as dengue fever, suspected type 1 and 4 virus coinfection, she was immediately hospitalized and received supportive care. She recovered on 17 Aug 2013.\n\nCase 2: a boy (14 years old) got sick with fever, headache, arthralgia, and general fatigue beginning 10 Aug [2013]. He also had an episode of diarrhea and abdominal pain on the previous day. From his blood sample, chikungunya virus gene was detected by TaqMan RT-PCR, but neither dengue nor malaria was negative [positive?] He responded to outpatient therapy.\n\nIn Japan, both dengue fever and chikungunya fever are quarantinable and notifiable diseases because the potential vector, _Aedes albopictus_, is ubiquitous in the country. In 2012, 220 cases of dengue fever and 9 cases of chikungunya fever were reported among international travelers. This is the 1st report of simultaneous detection of both infections in a tour group in Japan.\n\n--\nYasuko Honma MD\nChief of Quarantine Division, Narita Airport Quarantine Station\nJapan\n<honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp>\n\n[This is an excellent example of long distance movement of pathogens, where there is a risk of ongoing transmission. It is fortunate that these 2 cases were detected early in their infections and quickly diagnosed. It would be of interest to know the opinion of the Japanese authorities concerning the risk of viremic incoming travelers initiating an outbreak in Japan.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Yasuko Honma MD for this first-hand report. Reports from the field are very valuable.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8azs. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (47): Asia, Pacific 20130611.1764198\n2012\n----\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n.................................................dk/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-11 00:00:00", "2004-08-08 20:13:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CAMBODIA", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1944858", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (39): Philippines (IS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1944858", "date": "2013-08-29 10:02:17", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - JAPAN: ex CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2013\nFrom: Yasuko Honma <honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nA dengue fever case and a chikungunya fever case were simultaneously detected in the same tour group returning from Cambodia by quarantine screening at Narita international airport in Japan.\n\nThe tour group participants, 8 junior high school students and a staff member, traveled to Cambodia from 2-11 Aug [2013]. Each member stayed with a host family in a village of Kampong Cham province from 4-8 Aug 2013. The participants used mosquito repellent but could not avoid some bites. On 12 Aug [2013], returning from Cambodia to Japan, a 12-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy visited the health consultation room of Narita quarantine station because of fever. They were examined and blood samples were tested for dengue fever, chikungunya fever, and malaria.\n\nCase 1: a girl (12 years old) had fever, headache, arthralgia, general fatigue, and postorbital pain on 9 Aug 2013 and diarrhea on 12 Aug 2013. Chikungunya virus or malaria microparasite were not detected. Diagnosed as dengue fever, suspected type 1 and 4 virus coinfection, she was immediately hospitalized and received supportive care. She recovered on 17 Aug 2013.\n\nCase 2: a boy (14 years old) got sick with fever, headache, arthralgia, and general fatigue beginning 10 Aug [2013]. He also had an episode of diarrhea and abdominal pain on the previous day. From his blood sample, chikungunya virus gene was detected by TaqMan RT-PCR, but neither dengue nor malaria was negative [positive?] He responded to outpatient therapy.\n\nIn Japan, both dengue fever and chikungunya fever are quarantinable and notifiable diseases because the potential vector, _Aedes albopictus_, is ubiquitous in the country. In 2012, 220 cases of dengue fever and 9 cases of chikungunya fever were reported among international travelers. This is the 1st report of simultaneous detection of both infections in a tour group in Japan.\n\n--\nYasuko Honma MD\nChief of Quarantine Division, Narita Airport Quarantine Station\nJapan\n<honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp>\n\n[This is an excellent example of long distance movement of pathogens, where there is a risk of ongoing transmission. It is fortunate that these 2 cases were detected early in their infections and quickly diagnosed. It would be of interest to know the opinion of the Japanese authorities concerning the risk of viremic incoming travelers initiating an outbreak in Japan.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Yasuko Honma MD for this first-hand report. Reports from the field are very valuable.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8azs. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (47): Asia, Pacific 20130611.1764198\n2012\n----\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n.................................................dk/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-11 00:00:00", "2004-08-08 20:13:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CAMBODIA", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1943191", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (38): New Caledonia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1943191", "date": "2013-08-29 10:02:17", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - JAPAN: ex CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2013\nFrom: Yasuko Honma <honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nA dengue fever case and a chikungunya fever case were simultaneously detected in the same tour group returning from Cambodia by quarantine screening at Narita international airport in Japan.\n\nThe tour group participants, 8 junior high school students and a staff member, traveled to Cambodia from 2-11 Aug [2013]. On 12 Aug [2013], returning from Cambodia to Japan, a 12-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy visited the health consultation room of Narita quarantine station because of fever. It is fortunate that these 2 cases were detected early in their infections and quickly diagnosed. It would be of interest to know the opinion of the Japanese authorities concerning the risk of viremic incoming travelers initiating an outbreak in Japan.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Yasuko Honma MD for this first-hand report. Reports from the field are very valuable.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8azs. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (47): Asia, Pacific 20130611.1764198\n2012\n----\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n.................................................dk/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-11 00:00:00", "2004-08-08 20:13:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CAMBODIA", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1926193", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (35): India (KL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1926193", "date": "2013-08-29 10:02:17", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - JAPAN: ex CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2013\nFrom: Yasuko Honma <honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nA dengue fever case and a chikungunya fever case were simultaneously detected in the same tour group returning from Cambodia by quarantine screening at Narita international airport in Japan.\n\nThe tour group participants, 8 junior high school students and a staff member, traveled to Cambodia from 2-11 Aug [2013]. Each member stayed with a host family in a village of Kampong Cham province from 4-8 Aug 2013. The participants used mosquito repellent but could not avoid some bites. On 12 Aug [2013], returning from Cambodia to Japan, a 12-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy visited the health consultation room of Narita quarantine station because of fever. They were examined and blood samples were tested for dengue fever, chikungunya fever, and malaria.\n\nCase 1: a girl (12 years old) had fever, headache, arthralgia, general fatigue, and postorbital pain on 9 Aug 2013 and diarrhea on 12 Aug 2013. From the blood sample, dengue NS-1 antigen was detected by immunochromatographic test [Bio-Rad Dengue NS1 Antigen Strip test] and virus specific gene by RT-PCR (TaqMan; both types 1 and 4 dengue virus). Chikungunya virus or malaria microparasite were not detected. Diagnosed as dengue fever, suspected type 1 and 4 virus coinfection, she was immediately hospitalized and received supportive care. She recovered on 17 Aug 2013.\n\nCase 2: a boy (14 years old) got sick with fever, headache, arthralgia, and general fatigue beginning 10 Aug [2013]. He also had an episode of diarrhea and abdominal pain on the previous day. From his blood sample, chikungunya virus gene was detected by TaqMan RT-PCR, but neither dengue nor malaria was negative [positive?] He responded to outpatient therapy.\n\nIn Japan, both dengue fever and chikungunya fever are quarantinable and notifiable diseases because the potential vector, _Aedes albopictus_, is ubiquitous in the country. In 2012, 220 cases of dengue fever and 9 cases of chikungunya fever were reported among international travelers. This is the 1st report of simultaneous detection of both infections in a tour group in Japan.\n\n--\nYasuko Honma MD\nChief of Quarantine Division, Narita Airport Quarantine Station\nJapan\n<honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp>\n\n[This is an excellent example of long distance movement of pathogens, where there is a risk of ongoing transmission. It is fortunate that these 2 cases were detected early in their infections and quickly diagnosed. It would be of interest to know the opinion of the Japanese authorities concerning the risk of viremic incoming travelers initiating an outbreak in Japan.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Yasuko Honma MD for this first-hand report. Reports from the field are very valuable.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8azs. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (47): Asia, Pacific 20130611.1764198\n2012\n----\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n.................................................dk/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-11 00:00:00", "2004-08-08 20:13:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CAMBODIA", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1923385", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (34): Philippines (AQ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1923385", "date": "2013-08-29 10:02:17", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - JAPAN: ex CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2013\nFrom: Yasuko Honma <honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nA dengue fever case and a chikungunya fever case were simultaneously detected in the same tour group returning from Cambodia by quarantine screening at Narita international airport in Japan.\n\nThe tour group participants, 8 junior high school students and a staff member, traveled to Cambodia from 2-11 Aug [2013]. Each member stayed with a host family in a village of Kampong Cham province from 4-8 Aug 2013. The participants used mosquito repellent but could not avoid some bites. On 12 Aug [2013], returning from Cambodia to Japan, a 12-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy visited the health consultation room of Narita quarantine station because of fever. They were examined and blood samples were tested for dengue fever, chikungunya fever, and malaria.\n\nCase 1: a girl (12 years old) had fever, headache, arthralgia, general fatigue, and postorbital pain on 9 Aug 2013 and diarrhea on 12 Aug 2013. From the blood sample, dengue NS-1 antigen was detected by immunochromatographic test [Bio-Rad Dengue NS1 Antigen Strip test] and virus specific gene by RT-PCR (TaqMan; both types 1 and 4 dengue virus). Chikungunya virus or malaria microparasite were not detected. Diagnosed as dengue fever, suspected type 1 and 4 virus coinfection, she was immediately hospitalized and received supportive care. She recovered on 17 Aug 2013.\n\nCase 2: a boy (14 years old) got sick with fever, headache, arthralgia, and general fatigue beginning 10 Aug [2013]. He also had an episode of diarrhea and abdominal pain on the previous day. From his blood sample, chikungunya virus gene was detected by TaqMan RT-PCR, but neither dengue nor malaria was negative [positive?] He responded to outpatient therapy.\n\nIn Japan, both dengue fever and chikungunya fever are quarantinable and notifiable diseases because the potential vector, _Aedes albopictus_, is ubiquitous in the country. In 2012, 220 cases of dengue fever and 9 cases of chikungunya fever were reported among international travelers. This is the 1st report of simultaneous detection of both infections in a tour group in Japan.\n\n--\nYasuko Honma MD\nChief of Quarantine Division, Narita Airport Quarantine Station\nJapan\n<honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp>\n\n[This is an excellent example of long distance movement of pathogens, where there is a risk of ongoing transmission. It is fortunate that these 2 cases were detected early in their infections and quickly diagnosed. It would be of interest to know the opinion of the Japanese authorities concerning the risk of viremic incoming travelers initiating an outbreak in Japan.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Yasuko Honma MD for this first-hand report. Reports from the field are very valuable.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8azs. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (47): Asia, Pacific 20130611.1764198\n2012\n----\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n.................................................dk/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-11 00:00:00", "2004-08-08 20:13:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CAMBODIA", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1909917", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya & dengue - Japan: ex Cambodia (KM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1909917", "date": "2013-08-29 10:02:17", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - JAPAN: ex CAMBODIA (KAMPONG CHAM)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2013\nFrom: Yasuko Honma <honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp> [edited]\n\n\nA dengue fever case and a chikungunya fever case were simultaneously detected in the same tour group returning from Cambodia by quarantine screening at Narita international airport in Japan.\n\nThe tour group participants, 8 junior high school students and a staff member, traveled to Cambodia from 2-11 Aug [2013]. Each member stayed with a host family in a village of Kampong Cham province from 4-8 Aug 2013. The participants used mosquito repellent but could not avoid some bites. On 12 Aug [2013], returning from Cambodia to Japan, a 12-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy visited the health consultation room of Narita quarantine station because of fever. They were examined and blood samples were tested for dengue fever, chikungunya fever, and malaria.\n\nCase 1: a girl (12 years old) had fever, headache, arthralgia, general fatigue, and postorbital pain on 9 Aug 2013 and diarrhea on 12 Aug 2013. From the blood sample, dengue NS-1 antigen was detected by immunochromatographic test [Bio-Rad Dengue NS1 Antigen Strip test] and virus specific gene by RT-PCR (TaqMan; both types 1 and 4 dengue virus). Chikungunya virus or malaria microparasite were not detected. Diagnosed as dengue fever, suspected type 1 and 4 virus coinfection, she was immediately hospitalized and received supportive care. She recovered on 17 Aug 2013.\n\nCase 2: a boy (14 years old) got sick with fever, headache, arthralgia, and general fatigue beginning 10 Aug [2013]. He also had an episode of diarrhea and abdominal pain on the previous day. From his blood sample, chikungunya virus gene was detected by TaqMan RT-PCR, but neither dengue nor malaria was negative [positive?] He responded to outpatient therapy.\n\nIn Japan, both dengue fever and chikungunya fever are quarantinable and notifiable diseases because the potential vector, _Aedes albopictus_, is ubiquitous in the country. In 2012, 220 cases of dengue fever and 9 cases of chikungunya fever were reported among international travelers. This is the 1st report of simultaneous detection of both infections in a tour group in Japan.\n\n--\nYasuko Honma MD\nChief of Quarantine Division, Narita Airport Quarantine Station\nJapan\n<honma-yasuko@keneki.go.jp>\n\n[This is an excellent example of long distance movement of pathogens, where there is a risk of ongoing transmission. It is fortunate that these 2 cases were detected early in their infections and quickly diagnosed. It would be of interest to know the opinion of the Japanese authorities concerning the risk of viremic incoming travelers initiating an outbreak in Japan.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Yasuko Honma MD for this first-hand report. Reports from the field are very valuable.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Cambodia can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8azs. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nDengue/DHF update (47): Asia, Pacific 20130611.1764198\n2012\n----\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n.................................................dk/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-11 00:00:00", "2004-08-08 20:13:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CAMBODIA", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Kampong Cham", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1889602", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (33): Indonesia (East Jakarta)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1889602", "date": "2013-07-21 16:05:37", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (26): PHILIPPINES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Negros Occidental province\n[2] Camarines Norte province\n\n******\n[1] Negros Occidental province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2013/July/20/topstory5.htm\n\n\nIn Negros Occidental, 56 cases of chikungunya fever, which is often accompanied by very debilitating joint pains, have been reported, 50 of which were in Kabankalan City and 6 in Cadiz City, the Provincial Health Office reported yesterday [19 Jul 2013].\n\nChikungunya fever is a viral illness transmitted through the bite of infected _Aedes_ mosquitoes, the same carrier of dengue fever, Dr. Ernell Tumimbang, Negros Occidental provincial health officer, said.\n\nThe illness resembles dengue fever as it usually co-occurs and is often misdiagnosed.\n\nThe symptoms of chikungunya fever include sudden onset of fever, severe headache, chills, nausea, vomiting, accompanied by severe and sometimes persistent joint pains, but it is generally not fatal unlike dengue, Tumimbang said.\n\nOf the 50 cases of Chikungunya in Kabankalan City, 44 were in Barangay Magballo, 4 in Barangay Bantayan, and one each in barangays Locotan and Balicotoc.\n\nIn Cadiz City, the 6 cases reported were in Barangay Jerusalem.\n\nSome chikungunya patients have reported incapacitating joint pains, or arthritis, that may last for weeks or months. The areas around the joints become swollen and painful to touch, a Center for Health Development - Western Visayas advisory said.\n\nSuch prolonged joint pain and fatigue associated with chikungunya fever are not typical of dengue. A rash may sometimes occur but hemorrhaging is rare, it added.\n\nTime from the infected bite to the onset of illness can be 2 to 12 days, but usually it is 3 to 7 days, the advisory said.\n\nIf you have chikungunya fever symptoms, see a doctor, it advised.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific drug treatment against chikungunya fever but proper and early treatment with bed rest and sufficient intake of fluids is recommended, the advisory said. Aspirin and ibuprofen should be avoided as they are known to increase the risk of bleeding, while paracetamol can be given on medical advice, the advisory added.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites, one should wear full-sleeve clothes and long dresses to cover the limbs, and use repellants, but care should be taken in using them on small children and the elderly, it added.\n\nIt also advised the use of mosquito nets to protect babies and old people, who may rest during the day.\n\nMosquito nets and coils will effectively prevent mosquitoes from biting sick people and help stop the spread of chikungunya fever [virus], the advisory also said.\n\nTumimbang reiterated the call for the public to remove possible mosquito breeding places such as containers with stagnant water to prevent the spread of dengue and Chikungunya.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gomez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Camarines Norte province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSources: Balita [edited]\nhttp://balita.ph/2013/07/20/doh-warns-public-on-chikungunya-dengue-this-rainy-season/\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) regional office in Bicol has warned the public against chikungunya and dengue diseases.\n\nDOH Regional Director Gloria Balboa issued the warning after an outbreak of chikungunya occurred in Sta. Elena, Camarines Norte, with a total of 300 infected persons brought to hospitals.\n\n\"We have already deployed our surveillance team in the areas believed to be with high number of chikungunya cases to conduct an assessment and evaluation,\" Balboa said.\n\nShe urged the public to observe cleanliness, especially this rainy season, and remove all potential mosquito breeding sites.\n\nThe DOH official advised the public to consult doctors or bring their patients to a clinic or hospital if they observe symptoms of chikungunya. \"It is a viral disease which is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes -- including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Symptoms appear between 4 and 7 days after the patient has been bitten by the infected mosquito,\" Balboa explained.\n\nShe urged barangay and school officials to conduct a massive clean-up drive. \"This is the immediate counter-measure to prevent possible chikungunya outbreak,\" Balboa added.\n\nAccording to her, chikungunya [virus infection] symptoms are generally self-limiting and last for 2-3 days. The virus remains in the human system for 5-7 days and mosquitoes feeding on an infected person during this period can also become infected, Balboa said.\n\nChikungunya shares some clinical signs with dengue and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. Dengue is also another threat to public this rainy season, Balboa said. \"Both dengue and chikungunya are fatal, and we need a strong counter-measure to prevent the spread of these diseases brought by mosquitoes,\" she stressed. [The fatality rate from chikungunya virus infections is extremely low to nil. - Mod.TY]\n\nBalboa said immediate family members must be aware of the symptoms of chikungunya and dengue. \"Do not hesitate to consult your doctor, or respective rural health units in order to prevent human fatality,\" she advised.\n\n[Byline: Mike de la Rama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya outbreaks continue to pop up around various Philippines islands this year (2013), with new ones reported above. One can expect these outbreaks to continue as long as the vector mosquito populations are abundant. Unless vector control measures are quickly implemented, these outbreaks are likely to continue. There is no commercially available vaccine to prevent chikungunya virus infections, so the only effective measure to prevent transmission of the virus is through timely control of mosquito vectors.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg, Negros Occidental province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_W, and Camarines Norte province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_X. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (25): Philippines (SC) 20130719.1834183\nChikungunya (24): Philippines 20130715.1826121\nChikungunya (23): Philippines 20130712.1822393\nChikungunya (22): Philippines 20130705.1809572\nChikungunya (21): Philippines (KA) susp., RFI 20130704.1807686\nChikungunya (20): Philippines 20130702.1803947\nChikungunya (05): Philippines (CA) susp 20130208.1534203\nChikungunya (04): Philippines (SA) 20130128.1518853\nChikungunya (03): Philippines (SA) 20130126.1516209\nChikungunya (02): Philippines (EV) 20130113.1494945\n.................................................sb/lm/ty/je", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cadiz City", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Bicol", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "PHILIPPINES", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Barangay Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": 20130113.1494945\n.................................................sb/lm/ty/je", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cadiz City", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Bicol", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "PHILIPPINES", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Barangay Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kabankalan City", "country": "Philippines"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1877862", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (31): Singapore", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1877862", "date": "2013-07-21 16:05:37", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (26): PHILIPPINES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Negros Occidental province\n[2] Camarines Norte province\n\n******\n[1] Negros Occidental province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2013/July/20/topstory5.htm\n\n\nIn Negros Occidental, 56 cases of chikungunya fever, which is often accompanied by very debilitating joint pains, have been reported, 50 of which were in Kabankalan City and 6 in Cadiz City, the Provincial Health Office reported yesterday [19 Jul 2013].\n\nChikungunya fever is a viral illness transmitted through the bite of infected _Aedes_ mosquitoes, the same carrier of dengue fever, Dr. Ernell Tumimbang, Negros Occidental provincial health officer, said.\n\nThe illness resembles dengue fever as it usually co-occurs and is often misdiagnosed.\n\nThe symptoms of chikungunya fever include sudden onset of fever, severe headache, chills, nausea, vomiting, accompanied by severe and sometimes persistent joint pains, but it is generally not fatal unlike dengue, Tumimbang said.\n\nOf the 50 cases of Chikungunya in Kabankalan City, 44 were in Barangay Magballo, 4 in Barangay Bantayan, and one each in barangays Locotan and Balicotoc.\n\nIn Cadiz City, the 6 cases reported were in Barangay Jerusalem.\n\nSome chikungunya patients have reported incapacitating joint pains, or arthritis, that may last for weeks or months. The areas around the joints become swollen and painful to touch, a Center for Health Development - Western Visayas advisory said.\n\nSuch prolonged joint pain and fatigue associated with chikungunya fever are not typical of dengue. A rash may sometimes occur but hemorrhaging is rare, it added.\n\nTime from the infected bite to the onset of illness can be 2 to 12 days, but usually it is 3 to 7 days, the advisory said.\n\nIf you have chikungunya fever symptoms, see a doctor, it advised.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific drug treatment against chikungunya fever but proper and early treatment with bed rest and sufficient intake of fluids is recommended, the advisory said. Aspirin and ibuprofen should be avoided as they are known to increase the risk of bleeding, while paracetamol can be given on medical advice, the advisory added.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites, one should wear full-sleeve clothes and long dresses to cover the limbs, and use repellants, but care should be taken in using them on small children and the elderly, it added.\n\nIt also advised the use of mosquito nets to protect babies and old people, who may rest during the day.\n\nMosquito nets and coils will effectively prevent mosquitoes from biting sick people and help stop the spread of chikungunya fever [virus], the advisory also said.\n\nTumimbang reiterated the call for the public to remove possible mosquito breeding places such as containers with stagnant water to prevent the spread of dengue and Chikungunya.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gomez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Camarines Norte province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSources: Balita [edited]\nhttp://balita.ph/2013/07/20/doh-warns-public-on-chikungunya-dengue-this-rainy-season/\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) regional office in Bicol has warned the public against chikungunya and dengue diseases.\n\nDOH Regional Director Gloria Balboa issued the warning after an outbreak of chikungunya occurred in Sta. Elena, Camarines Norte, with a total of 300 infected persons brought to hospitals.\n\n\"We have already deployed our surveillance team in the areas believed to be with high number of chikungunya cases to conduct an assessment and evaluation,\" Balboa said.\n\nShe urged the public to observe cleanliness, especially this rainy season, and remove all potential mosquito breeding sites.\n\nThe DOH official advised the public to consult doctors or bring their patients to a clinic or hospital if they observe symptoms of chikungunya. \"It is a viral disease which is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes -- including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Symptoms appear between 4 and 7 days after the patient has been bitten by the infected mosquito,\" Balboa explained.\n\nShe urged barangay and school officials to conduct a massive clean-up drive. \"This is the immediate counter-measure to prevent possible chikungunya outbreak,\" Balboa added.\n\nAccording to her, chikungunya [virus infection] symptoms are generally self-limiting and last for 2-3 days. The virus remains in the human system for 5-7 days and mosquitoes feeding on an infected person during this period can also become infected, Balboa said.\n\nChikungunya shares some clinical signs with dengue and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. Dengue is also another threat to public this rainy season, Balboa said. \"Both dengue and chikungunya are fatal, and we need a strong counter-measure to prevent the spread of these diseases brought by mosquitoes,\" she stressed. [The fatality rate from chikungunya virus infections is extremely low to nil. - Mod.TY]\n\nBalboa said immediate family members must be aware of the symptoms of chikungunya and dengue. \"Do not hesitate to consult your doctor, or respective rural health units in order to prevent human fatality,\" she advised.\n\n[Byline: Mike de la Rama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya outbreaks continue to pop up around various Philippines islands this year (2013), with new ones reported above. One can expect these outbreaks to continue as long as the vector mosquito populations are abundant. Unless vector control measures are quickly implemented, these outbreaks are likely to continue. There is no commercially available vaccine to prevent chikungunya virus infections, so the only effective measure to prevent transmission of the virus is through timely control of mosquito vectors.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg, Negros Occidental province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_W, and Camarines Norte province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_X. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (25): Philippines (SC) 20130719.1834183\nChikungunya (24): Philippines 20130715.1826121\nChikungunya (23): Philippines 20130712.1822393\nChikungunya (22): Philippines 20130705.1809572\nChikungunya (21): Philippines (KA) susp., RFI 20130704.1807686\nChikungunya (20): Philippines 20130702.1803947\nChikungunya (05): Philippines (CA) susp 20130208.1534203\nChikungunya (04): Philippines (SA) 20130128.1518853\nChikungunya (03): Philippines (SA) 20130126.1516209\nChikungunya (02): Philippines (EV) 20130113.1494945\n.................................................sb/lm/ty/je", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2044-03-15 00:00:00", (GU)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1870987", "date": "2013-07-21 16:05:37", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (26): PHILIPPINES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Negros Occidental province\n[2] Camarines Norte province\n\n******\n[1] Negros Occidental province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2013/July/20/topstory5.htm\n\n\nIn Negros Occidental, 56 cases of chikungunya fever, which is often accompanied by very debilitating joint pains, have been reported, 50 of which were in Kabankalan City and 6 in Cadiz City, the Provincial Health Office reported yesterday [19 Jul 2013].\n\nChikungunya fever is a viral illness transmitted through the bite of infected _Aedes_ mosquitoes, the same carrier of dengue fever, Dr. Ernell Tumimbang, Negros Occidental provincial health officer, said.\n\nThe illness resembles dengue fever as it usually co-occurs and is often misdiagnosed.\n\nThe symptoms of chikungunya fever include sudden onset of fever, severe headache, chills, nausea, vomiting, accompanied by severe and sometimes persistent joint pains, but it is generally not fatal unlike dengue, Tumimbang said.\n\nOf the 50 cases of Chikungunya in Kabankalan City, 44 were in Barangay Magballo, 4 in Barangay Bantayan, and one each in barangays Locotan and Balicotoc.\n\nIn Cadiz City, the 6 cases reported were in Barangay Jerusalem.\n\nSome chikungunya patients have reported incapacitating joint pains, or arthritis, that may last for weeks or months. The areas around the joints become swollen and painful to touch, a Center for Health Development - Western Visayas advisory said.\n\nSuch prolonged joint pain and fatigue associated with chikungunya fever are not typical of dengue. A rash may sometimes occur but hemorrhaging is rare, it added.\n\nTime from the infected bite to the onset of illness can be 2 to 12 days, but usually it is 3 to 7 days, the advisory said.\n\nIf you have chikungunya fever symptoms, see a doctor, it advised.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific drug treatment against chikungunya fever but proper and early treatment with bed rest and sufficient intake of fluids is recommended, the advisory said. Aspirin and ibuprofen should be avoided as they are known to increase the risk of bleeding, while paracetamol can be given on medical advice, the advisory added.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites, one should wear full-sleeve clothes and long dresses to cover the limbs, and use repellants, but care should be taken in using them on small children and the elderly, it added.\n\nIt also advised the use of mosquito nets to protect babies and old people, who may rest during the day.\n\nMosquito nets and coils will effectively prevent mosquitoes from biting sick people and help stop the spread of chikungunya fever [virus], the advisory also said.\n\nTumimbang reiterated the call for the public to remove possible mosquito breeding places such as containers with stagnant water to prevent the spread of dengue and Chikungunya.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gomez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Camarines Norte province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSources: Balita [edited]\nhttp://balita.ph/2013/07/20/doh-warns-public-on-chikungunya-dengue-this-rainy-season/\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) regional office in Bicol has warned the public against chikungunya and dengue diseases.\n\nDOH Regional Director Gloria Balboa issued the warning after an outbreak of chikungunya occurred in Sta. Elena, Camarines Norte, with a total of 300 infected persons brought to hospitals.\n\n\"We have already deployed our surveillance team in the areas believed to be with high number of chikungunya cases to conduct an assessment and evaluation,\" Balboa said.\n\nShe urged the public to observe cleanliness, especially this rainy season, and remove all potential mosquito breeding sites.\n\nThe DOH official advised the public to consult doctors or bring their patients to a clinic or hospital if they observe symptoms of chikungunya. \"It is a viral disease which is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes -- including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Symptoms appear between 4 and 7 days after the patient has been bitten by the infected mosquito,\" Balboa explained.\n\nShe urged barangay and school officials to conduct a massive clean-up drive. \"This is the immediate counter-measure to prevent possible chikungunya outbreak,\" Balboa added.\n\nAccording to her, chikungunya [virus infection] symptoms are generally self-limiting and last for 2-3 days. The virus remains in the human system for 5-7 days and mosquitoes feeding on an infected person during this period can also become infected, Balboa said.\n\nChikungunya shares some clinical signs with dengue and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. Dengue is also another threat to public this rainy season, Balboa said. \"Both dengue and chikungunya are fatal, and we need a strong counter-measure to prevent the spread of these diseases brought by mosquitoes,\" she stressed. [The fatality rate from chikungunya virus infections is extremely low to nil. - Mod.TY]\n\nBalboa said immediate family members must be aware of the symptoms of chikungunya and dengue. \"Do not hesitate to consult your doctor, or respective rural health units in order to prevent human fatality,\" she advised.\n\n[Byline: Mike de la Rama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya outbreaks continue to pop up around various Philippines islands this year (2013), with new ones reported above. One can expect these outbreaks to continue as long as the vector mosquito populations are abundant. Unless vector control measures are quickly implemented, these outbreaks are likely to continue. There is no commercially available vaccine to prevent chikungunya virus infections, so the only effective measure to prevent transmission of the virus is through timely control of mosquito vectors.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg, Negros Occidental province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_W, and Camarines Norte province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_X. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (25): Philippines (SC) 20130719.1834183\nChikungunya (24): Philippines 20130715.1826121\nChikungunya (23): Philippines Norte province\n\n******\n[1] Negros Occidental province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2013/July/20/topstory5.htm\n\n\nIn Negros Occidental, 56 cases of chikungunya fever, which is often accompanied by very debilitating joint pains, have been reported, 50 of which were in Kabankalan City and 6 in Cadiz City, the Provincial Health Office reported yesterday [19 Jul 2013].\n\nChikungunya fever is a viral illness transmitted through the bite of infected _Aedes_ mosquitoes, the same carrier of dengue fever, Dr. Ernell Tumimbang, Negros Occidental provincial health officer, said.\n\nThe illness resembles dengue fever as it usually co-occurs and is often misdiagnosed.\n\nThe symptoms of chikungunya fever include sudden onset of fever, severe headache, chills, nausea, vomiting, accompanied by severe and sometimes persistent joint pains, but it is generally not fatal unlike dengue, Tumimbang said.\n\nOf the 50 cases of Chikungunya in Kabankalan City, 44 were in Barangay Magballo, 4 in Barangay Bantayan, and one each in barangays Locotan and Balicotoc.\n\nIn Cadiz City, the 6 cases reported were in Barangay Jerusalem.\n\nSome chikungunya patients have reported incapacitating joint pains, or arthritis, that may last for weeks or months. The areas around the joints become swollen and painful to touch, a Center for Health Development - Western Visayas advisory said.\n\nSuch prolonged joint pain and fatigue associated with chikungunya fever are not typical of dengue. A rash may sometimes occur but hemorrhaging is rare, it added.\n\nTime from the infected bite to the onset of illness can be 2 to 12 days, but usually it is 3 to 7 days, the advisory said.\n\nIf you have chikungunya fever symptoms, see a doctor, it advised.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific drug treatment against chikungunya fever but proper and early treatment with bed rest and sufficient intake of fluids is recommended, the advisory said. Aspirin and ibuprofen should be avoided as they are known to increase the risk of bleeding, while paracetamol can be given on medical advice, the advisory added.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites, one should wear full-sleeve clothes and long dresses to cover the limbs, and use repellants, but care should be taken in using them on small children and the elderly, it added.\n\nIt also advised the use of mosquito nets to protect babies and old people, who may rest during the day.\n\nMosquito nets and coils will effectively prevent mosquitoes from biting sick people and help stop the spread of chikungunya fever [virus], the advisory also said.\n\nTumimbang reiterated the call for the public to remove possible mosquito breeding places such as containers with stagnant water to prevent the spread of dengue and Chikungunya.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gomez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Camarines Norte province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSources: Balita [edited]\nhttp://balita.ph/2013/07/20/doh-warns-public-on-chikungunya-dengue-this-rainy-season/\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) regional office in Bicol has warned the public against chikungunya and dengue diseases.\n\nDOH Regional Director Gloria Balboa issued the warning after an outbreak of chikungunya occurred in Sta. Elena, Camarines Norte, with a total of 300 infected persons brought to hospitals.\n\n\"We have already deployed our surveillance team in the areas believed to be with high number of chikungunya cases to conduct an assessment and evaluation,\" Balboa said.\n\nShe urged the public to observe cleanliness, especially this rainy season, and remove all potential mosquito breeding sites.\n\nThe DOH official advised the public to consult doctors or bring their patients to a clinic or hospital if they observe symptoms of chikungunya. \"It is a viral disease which is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes -- including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Symptoms appear between 4 and 7 days after the patient has been bitten by the infected mosquito,\" Balboa explained.\n\nShe urged barangay and school officials to conduct a massive clean-up drive. \"This is the immediate counter-measure to prevent possible chikungunya outbreak,\" Balboa added.\n\nAccording to her, chikungunya [virus infection] symptoms are generally self-limiting and last for 2-3 days. The virus remains in the human system for 5-7 days and mosquitoes feeding on an infected person during this period can also become infected, Balboa said.\n\nChikungunya shares some clinical signs with dengue and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. Dengue is also another threat to public this rainy season, Balboa said. \"Both dengue and chikungunya are fatal, and we need a strong counter-measure to prevent the spread of these diseases brought by mosquitoes,\" she stressed. [The fatality rate from chikungunya virus infections is extremely low to nil. - Mod.TY]\n\nBalboa said immediate family members must be aware of the symptoms of chikungunya and dengue. \"Do not hesitate to consult your doctor, or respective rural health units in order to prevent human fatality,\" she advised.\n\n[Byline: Mike de la Rama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya outbreaks continue to pop up around various Philippines islands this year (2013), with new ones reported above. One can expect these outbreaks to continue as long as the vector mosquito populations are abundant. Unless vector control measures are quickly implemented, these outbreaks are likely to continue. There is no commercially available vaccine to prevent chikungunya virus infections, so the only effective measure to prevent transmission of the virus is through timely control of mosquito Philippines (IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1850812", "date": "2013-07-21 16:05:37", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (26): PHILIPPINES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Negros Occidental province\n[2] Camarines Norte province\n\n******\n[1] Negros Occidental province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2013/July/20/topstory5.htm\n\n\nIn Negros Occidental, 56 cases of chikungunya fever, which is often accompanied by very debilitating joint pains, have been reported, 50 of which were in Kabankalan City and 6 in Cadiz City, the Provincial Health Office reported yesterday [19 Jul 2013].\n\nChikungunya fever is a viral illness transmitted through the bite of infected _Aedes_ mosquitoes, the same carrier of dengue fever, Dr. Ernell Tumimbang, Negros Occidental provincial health officer, said.\n\nThe illness resembles dengue fever as it usually co-occurs and is often misdiagnosed.\n\nThe symptoms of chikungunya fever include sudden onset of fever, severe headache, chills, nausea, vomiting, accompanied by severe and sometimes persistent joint pains, but it is generally not fatal unlike dengue, Tumimbang said.\n\nOf the 50 cases of Chikungunya in Kabankalan City, 44 were in Barangay Magballo, 4 in Barangay Bantayan, and one each in barangays Locotan and Balicotoc.\n\nIn Cadiz City, the 6 cases reported were in Barangay Jerusalem.\n\nSome chikungunya patients have reported incapacitating joint pains, or arthritis, that may last for weeks or months. The areas around the joints become swollen and painful to touch, a Center for Health Development - Western Visayas advisory said.\n\nSuch prolonged joint pain and fatigue associated with chikungunya fever are not typical of dengue. A rash may sometimes occur but hemorrhaging is rare, it added.\n\nTime from the infected bite to the onset of illness can be 2 to 12 days, but usually it is 3 to 7 days, the advisory said.\n\nIf you have chikungunya fever symptoms, see a doctor, it advised.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific drug treatment against chikungunya fever but proper and early treatment with bed rest and sufficient intake of fluids is recommended, the advisory said. Aspirin and ibuprofen should be avoided as they are known to increase the risk of bleeding, while paracetamol can be given on medical advice, the advisory added.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites, one should wear full-sleeve clothes and long dresses to cover the limbs, and use repellants, but care should be taken in using them on small children and the elderly, it added.\n\nIt also advised the use of mosquito nets to protect babies and old people, who may rest during the day.\n\nMosquito nets and coils will effectively prevent mosquitoes from biting sick people and help stop the spread of chikungunya fever [virus], the advisory also said.\n\nTumimbang reiterated the call for the public to remove possible mosquito breeding places such as containers with stagnant water to prevent the spread of dengue and Chikungunya.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gomez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Camarines Norte province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSources: Balita [edited]\nhttp://balita.ph/2013/07/20/doh-warns-public-on-chikungunya-dengue-this-rainy-season/\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) regional office in Bicol has warned the public against chikungunya and dengue diseases.\n\nDOH Regional Director Gloria Balboa issued the warning after an outbreak of chikungunya occurred in Sta. Elena, Camarines Norte, with a total of 300 infected persons brought to hospitals.\n\n\"We have already deployed our surveillance team in the areas believed to be with high number of chikungunya cases to conduct an assessment and evaluation,\" Balboa said.\n\nShe urged the public to observe cleanliness, especially this rainy season, and remove all potential mosquito breeding sites.\n\nThe DOH official advised the public to consult doctors or bring their patients to a clinic or hospital if they observe symptoms of chikungunya. \"It is a viral disease which is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes -- including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Symptoms appear between 4 and 7 days after the patient has been bitten by the infected mosquito,\" Balboa explained.\n\nShe urged barangay and school officials to conduct a massive clean-up drive. \"This is the immediate counter-measure to prevent possible chikungunya outbreak,\" Balboa added.\n\nAccording to her, chikungunya [virus infection] symptoms are generally self-limiting and last for 2-3 days. The virus remains in the human system for 5-7 days and mosquitoes feeding on an infected person during this period can also become infected, Balboa said.\n\nChikungunya shares some clinical signs with dengue and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. Dengue is also another threat to public this rainy season, Balboa said. \"Both dengue and chikungunya are fatal, and we need a strong counter-measure to prevent the spread of these diseases brought by mosquitoes,\" she stressed. [The fatality rate from chikungunya virus infections is extremely low to nil. - Mod.TY]\n\nBalboa said immediate family members must be aware of the symptoms of chikungunya and dengue. \"Do not hesitate to consult your doctor, or respective rural health units in order to prevent human fatality,\" she advised.\n\n[Byline: Mike de la Rama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya outbreaks continue to pop up around various Philippines islands this year (2013), with new ones reported above. One can expect these outbreaks to continue as long as the vector mosquito populations are abundant. Unless vector control measures are quickly implemented, these outbreaks are likely to continue. There is no commercially available vaccine to prevent chikungunya virus infections, so the only effective measure to prevent transmission of the virus is through timely control of mosquito vectors.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg, Negros Occidental province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_W, and Camarines Norte province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_X. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (25): Philippines (SC) 20130719.1834183\nChikungunya (24): Philippines 20130715.1826121\nChikungunya (23): Philippines 20130712.1822393\nChikungunya (22): Philippines 20130705.1809572\nChikungunya (21): Philippines (KA) susp., RFI 20130704.1807686\nChikungunya (20): Philippines 20130702.1803947\nChikungunya (05): Philippines (CA) susp 20130208.1534203\nChikungunya (04): Philippines (SA) 20130128.1518853\nChikungunya (03): Philippines (SA) 20130126.1516209\nChikungunya (02): Philippines (EV) "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03
