Philippines", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1845826", "date": "2013-07-21 16:05:37", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (26): PHILIPPINES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Negros Occidental province\n[2] Camarines Norte province\n\n******\n[1] Negros Occidental province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2013/July/20/topstory5.htm\n\n\nIn Negros Occidental, 56 cases of chikungunya fever, which is often accompanied by very debilitating joint pains, have been reported, 50 of which were in Kabankalan City and 6 in Cadiz City, the Provincial Health Office reported yesterday [19 Jul 2013].\n\nChikungunya fever is a viral illness transmitted through the bite of infected _Aedes_ mosquitoes, the same carrier of dengue fever, Dr. Ernell Tumimbang, Negros Occidental provincial health officer, said.\n\nThe illness resembles dengue fever as it usually co-occurs and is often misdiagnosed.\n\nThe symptoms of chikungunya fever include sudden onset of fever, severe headache, chills, nausea, vomiting, accompanied by severe and sometimes persistent joint pains, but it is generally not fatal unlike dengue, Tumimbang said.\n\nOf the 50 cases of Chikungunya in Kabankalan City, 44 were in Barangay Magballo, 4 in Barangay Bantayan, and one each in barangays Locotan and Balicotoc.\n\nIn Cadiz City, the 6 cases reported were in Barangay Jerusalem.\n\nSome chikungunya patients have reported incapacitating joint pains, or arthritis, that may last for weeks or months. The areas around the joints become swollen and painful to touch, a Center for Health Development - Western Visayas advisory said.\n\nSuch prolonged joint pain and fatigue associated with chikungunya fever are not typical of dengue. A rash may sometimes occur but hemorrhaging is rare, it added.\n\nTime from the infected bite to the onset of illness can be 2 to 12 days, but usually it is 3 to 7 days, the advisory said.\n\nIf you have chikungunya fever symptoms, see a doctor, it advised.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific drug treatment against chikungunya fever but proper and early treatment with bed rest and sufficient intake of fluids is recommended, the advisory said. Aspirin and ibuprofen should be avoided as they are known to increase the risk of bleeding, while paracetamol can be given on medical advice, the advisory added.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites, one should wear full-sleeve clothes and long dresses to cover the limbs, and use repellants, but care should be taken in using them on small children and the elderly, it added.\n\nIt also advised the use of mosquito nets to protect babies and old people, who may rest during the day.\n\nMosquito nets and coils will effectively prevent mosquitoes from biting sick people and help stop the spread of chikungunya fever [virus], the advisory also said.\n\nTumimbang reiterated the call for the public to remove possible mosquito breeding places such as containers with stagnant water to prevent the spread of dengue and Chikungunya.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gomez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Camarines Norte province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSources: Balita [edited]\nhttp://balita.ph/2013/07/20/doh-warns-public-on-chikungunya-dengue-this-rainy-season/\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) regional office in Bicol has warned the public against chikungunya and dengue diseases.\n\nDOH Regional Director Gloria Balboa issued the warning after an outbreak of chikungunya occurred in Sta. Elena, Camarines Norte, with a total of 300 infected persons brought to hospitals.\n\n\"We have already deployed our surveillance team in the areas believed to be with high number of chikungunya cases to conduct an assessment and evaluation,\" Balboa said.\n\nShe urged the public to observe cleanliness, especially this rainy season, and remove all potential mosquito breeding sites.\n\nThe DOH official advised the public to consult doctors or bring their patients to a clinic or hospital if they observe symptoms of chikungunya. \"It is a viral disease which is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes -- including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Symptoms appear between 4 and 7 days after the patient has been bitten by the infected mosquito,\" Balboa explained.\n\nShe urged barangay and school officials to conduct a massive clean-up drive. \"This is the immediate counter-measure to prevent possible chikungunya outbreak,\" Balboa added.\n\nAccording to her, chikungunya [virus infection] symptoms are generally self-limiting and last for 2-3 days. The virus remains in the human system for 5-7 days and mosquitoes feeding on an infected person during this period can also become infected, Balboa said.\n\nChikungunya shares some clinical signs with dengue and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. Dengue is also another threat to public this rainy season, Balboa said. \"Both dengue and chikungunya are fatal, and we need a strong counter-measure to prevent the spread of these diseases brought by mosquitoes,\" she stressed. [The fatality rate from chikungunya virus infections is extremely low to nil. - Mod.TY]\n\nBalboa said immediate family members must be aware of the symptoms of chikungunya and dengue. \"Do not hesitate to consult your doctor, or respective rural health units in order to prevent human fatality,\" she advised.\n\n[Byline: Mike de la Rama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya outbreaks continue to pop up around various Philippines islands this year (2013), with new ones reported above. One can expect these outbreaks to continue as long as the vector mosquito populations are abundant. Unless vector control measures are quickly implemented, these outbreaks are likely to continue. There is no commercially available vaccine to prevent chikungunya virus infections, so the only effective measure to prevent transmission of the virus is through timely control of mosquito vectors.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg, Negros Occidental province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_W, and Camarines Norte province\n\n******\n[1] Negros Occidental province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2013/July/20/topstory5.htm\n\n\nIn Negros Occidental, 56 cases of chikungunya fever, which is often accompanied by very debilitating joint pains, have been reported, 50 of which were in Kabankalan City and 6 in Cadiz City, the Provincial Health Office reported yesterday [19 Jul 2013].\n\nChikungunya fever is a viral illness transmitted through the bite of infected _Aedes_ mosquitoes, the same carrier of dengue fever, Dr. Ernell Tumimbang, Negros Occidental provincial health officer, said.\n\nThe illness resembles dengue fever as it usually co-occurs and is often misdiagnosed.\n\nThe symptoms of chikungunya fever include sudden onset of fever, severe headache, chills, nausea, vomiting, accompanied by severe and sometimes persistent joint pains, but it is generally not fatal unlike dengue, Tumimbang said.\n\nOf the 50 cases of Chikungunya in Kabankalan City, 44 were in Barangay Magballo, 4 in Barangay Bantayan, and one each in barangays Locotan and Balicotoc.\n\nIn Cadiz City, the 6 cases reported were in Barangay Jerusalem.\n\nSome chikungunya patients have reported incapacitating joint pains, or arthritis, that may last for weeks or months. The areas around the joints become swollen and painful to touch, a Center for Health Development - Western Visayas advisory said.\n\nSuch prolonged joint pain and fatigue associated with chikungunya fever are not typical of dengue. A rash may sometimes occur but hemorrhaging is rare, it added.\n\nTime from the infected bite to the onset of illness can be 2 to 12 days, but usually it is 3 to 7 days, the advisory said.\n\nIf you have chikungunya fever symptoms, see a doctor, it advised.\n\nCurrently, there is no specific drug treatment against chikungunya fever but proper and early treatment with bed rest and sufficient intake of fluids is recommended, the advisory said. Aspirin and ibuprofen should be avoided as they are known to increase the risk of bleeding, while paracetamol can be given on medical advice, the advisory added.\n\nTo avoid mosquito bites, one should wear full-sleeve clothes and long dresses to cover the limbs, and use repellants, but care should be taken in using them on small children and the elderly, it added.\n\nIt also advised the use of mosquito nets to protect babies and old people, who may rest during the day.\n\nMosquito nets and coils will effectively prevent mosquitoes from biting sick people and help stop the spread of chikungunya fever [virus], the advisory also said.\n\nTumimbang reiterated the call for the public to remove possible mosquito breeding places such as containers with stagnant water to prevent the spread of dengue and Chikungunya.\n\n[Byline: Carla Gomez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Camarines Norte province\nDate: Sat 20 Jul 2013\nSources: Balita [edited]\nhttp://balita.ph/2013/07/20/doh-warns-public-on-chikungunya-dengue-this-rainy-season/\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) regional office in Bicol has warned the public against chikungunya and dengue diseases.\n\nDOH Regional Director Gloria Balboa issued the warning after an outbreak of chikungunya occurred in Sta. Elena, Camarines Norte, with a total of 300 infected persons brought to hospitals.\n\n\"We have already deployed our surveillance team in the areas believed to be with high number of chikungunya cases to conduct an assessment and evaluation,\" Balboa said.\n\nShe urged the public to observe cleanliness, especially this rainy season, and remove all potential mosquito breeding sites.\n\nThe DOH official advised the public to consult doctors or bring their patients to a clinic or hospital if they observe symptoms of chikungunya. \"It is a viral disease which is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes -- including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Symptoms appear between 4 and 7 days after the patient has been bitten by the infected mosquito,\" Balboa explained.\n\nShe urged barangay and school officials to conduct a massive clean-up drive. \"This is the immediate counter-measure to prevent possible chikungunya outbreak,\" Balboa added.\n\nAccording to her, chikungunya [virus infection] symptoms are generally self-limiting and last for 2-3 days. The virus remains in the human system for 5-7 days and mosquitoes feeding on an infected person during this period can also become infected, Balboa said.\n\nChikungunya shares some clinical signs with dengue and can be misdiagnosed in areas where dengue is common. Dengue is also another threat to public this rainy season, Balboa said. \"Both dengue and chikungunya are fatal, and we need a strong counter-measure to prevent the spread of these diseases brought by mosquitoes,\" she stressed. [The fatality rate from chikungunya virus infections is extremely low to nil. - Mod.TY]\n\nBalboa said immediate family members must be aware of the symptoms of chikungunya and dengue. \"Do not hesitate to consult your doctor, or respective rural health units in order to prevent human fatality,\" she advised.\n\n[Byline: Mike de la Rama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya outbreaks continue to pop up around various Philippines islands this year (2013), with new ones reported above. One can expect these outbreaks to continue as long as the vector mosquito populations are abundant. Unless vector control measures are quickly implemented, these outbreaks are likely to continue. There is no commercially available vaccine to prevent chikungunya virus infections, so the only effective measure to prevent transmission of the virus is through timely control of mosquito vectors.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg, Negros Occidental province at http://healthmap.org/r/7H_W, and Camarines 20130113.1494945\n.................................................sb/lm/ty/je", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cadiz City", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Bicol", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "PHILIPPINES", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Barangay Jerusalem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kabankalan City", "country": "Philippines"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1834183", "headline": "PRO> Chikungunya (25): Philippines (SC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1834183", "date": "2013-06-28 21:53:05", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (19): PHILIPPINES, AUSTRALIA ex PAPUA NEW GUINEA, INDONESIA\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\n\n******\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Philippine Information Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.pia.gov.ph/news/index.php?article=1611372306004\n\n\nThe chikungunya virus, another mosquito-borne disease similar to dengue, has found its way to South Cotabato province.\n\nDr. Rogelio Aturdido Jr., head of the Integrated Provincial Health Office (IPHO), told Philippine Information Agency 12 yesterday that 2 cases of the disease were found in Sitio Bukang-liwayway, Barangay Kipalbig in nearby Tampakan town and validated by the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM) in Metro Manila.\n\n\"The other week, we sent several serum samples to RITM. Of these, 2 were found positive of the chikungunya virus,\" Dr. Aturdido said.\n\nAturdido said although the disease is not deadly like dengue, it remains a major concern because victims could suffer from severe joint pains for up to 6 months or longer.\n\nInformation from the website of the World Health Organization (WHO) says chikungunya is a mosquito-borne disease [virus] which was 1st described in an outbreak in southern Tanzania in 1954.\n\nLike dengue, the virus is transmitted via bites of infected female mosquitoes, mostly _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Illness usually occurs between 2-12 days from [initial] infection.\n\n\"Chikungunya is characterized by an abrupt onset of fever frequently accompanied by joint pain. Other common signs and symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. The joint pain is often very debilitating, but usually ends within a few days or weeks. Most patients recover fully, but in some cases joint pain may persist for several months, or even years,\" the article continues.\n\n\"The name 'chikungunya' derives from a root verb in the Kimakonde language, meaning 'to become contorted,' and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pains.\"\n\nAturdido said that although the responsibility to address this concern rests primarily on the local government unit of Tampakan, the IPHO is ready to extend help.\n\nHe emphasized, however, that since the disease's source and means of transmission is similar to dengue, prevention of its spread is also largely dependent on community efforts.\n\n\"What is required is to strictly follow the 4S strategy,\" Aturdido said.\n\n4S anti-dengue strategy consists of the following: Search and destroy; Self-protection measures; Seek early consultation; and Say no to indiscriminate fogging.\n\nIn January this year [2013], Department of Health (DOH) 12 reported that 57 cases were clinically diagnosed from Sarangani Province. The number consisted of 35 cases from Kiamba and 22 from Maitum.\n\nAccording to DOH, Chikungunya cases have also been reported in Metro Manila, Laguna, Pangasinan and other parts of Mindanao.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya virus is endemic in the Philippines, so this type of small outbreak, and the one below, are not surprising. Because there is no commercially available vaccine for chikungunya virus, the only preventive action is elimination of _Aedes_ vector mosquito breeding sites and avoidance of mosquito bites per the 4S strategy mentioned above.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Philippines is at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4l. - Mod.TY]\n\n\n******\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\nDate: Wed 26 Jun 2013\nSource: ABS-CBN news [edited]\nhttp://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/06/26/13/chikungunya-outbreak-3-antique-barangays\n\n\nHealth officials have declared a chikungunya outbreak in 3 barangays in Patnongon, Antique province -- Mabasa, Magsaysay Tamayok and Poblacion, where 6 people tested positive for the disease and nearly 100 more are being monitored.\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) has extended its monitoring and probe of other possible cases in nearby areas.\n\nLike dengue, chikungunya [virus] is contracted through mosquitoes and also has similar symptoms.\n\nHealth officials reminded the public to keep their surroundings clean [to eliminate mosquito breeding sites] and not to self-medicate if they start exhibiting symptoms of chikungunya.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Brisbane Times, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/mosquito-virus-fears-in-north-queensland-20130627-2oyag.html\n\n\nHealth authorities fear a dengue-like mosquito-borne virus could spread through far north Queensland following a massive outbreak in Papua New Guinea (PNG).\n\nSince the start of the year [2013], 11 people in Queensland have been diagnosed with chikungunya [virus infection], which causes fever, rashes and prolonged joint pain.\n\n[Of these 11,] 10 of the people contracted the virus in PNG, where more than 3000 people have been hit by the virus. Another person was bitten by a mosquito in Indonesia before flying to Queensland.\n\nThe majority of the 11 affected are Australian citizens but almost half of them live outside far north Queensland.\n\nTropical Public Health Services director Dr Richard Gair says the PNG outbreak is recent and could lead to an outbreak in far north Queensland.\n\nHe says this is because the same type of mosquitoes that carry the virus live in both areas.\n\n\"Every import is a potential outbreak,\" he said. \"If you get bitten when you're still infectious, that mosquito can go and bite someone else.\"\n\nNo one has been infected by chikungunya [virus] while in Australia.\n\nThose who have chikungunya [virus infections] experience the same symptoms as [those with] dengue fever, and both diseases are spread by the same mosquitoes.\n\n\"The difference between them is that with chikungunya we might well see the transmission happening quite a bit faster,\" Mr Gair said. \"There is less time between cases so it is harder to control.\"\n\nSince January [2013] there have been about 170 cases of dengue in the Cairns region.\n\nChikungunya [virus] was 1st found in East Africa about 50 years ago but has only recently spread to countries close to Australia.\n\nMr Gair says the best way to eliminate both chikungunya and dengue is to get rid of mosquito breeding sites, such as pots of water around properties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a very real risk of ongoing chikungunya virus transmission in northern Queensland. As the above report mentions, the mosquito vectors of the virus are present there and transmitting dengue virus.\n\nImportation of chikungunya virus into Australia is not surprising. There is an ongoing chikungunya virus outbreak on Papua New Guinea this year (2013) and there was a significant outbreak on the main island of Papua New Guinea last year (2012). From June to October 2012, a total of 633 patients suspected of having symptoms of chikungunya were reported from Vanimo hospital. The outbreak was localized to the town vicinity and its satellite communities (see ProMED-mail archive no 20121010.1335814).\n\nThe above report does not indicate where in Indonesia the single chikungunya virus infection was acquired. However, Bali is a popular tourist destination. Bali has had sporadic outbreaks.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Queensland can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJr. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Papua New Guinea can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1KlS and one of Bali, Indonesia at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4m. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (15): Indonesia (JK) 20130509.1700484\nChikungunya (06): Germany ex Indonesia (Bali) 2012 20130227.1562598\nChikungunya (05): Philippines (CA) susp 20130208.1534203\n2012\n----\nChikungunya (20): Papua New Guinea: 20121010.1335814\n.................................................sb/mpp/ty/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1954-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "bali", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Laguna", "country": "Guatemala"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "PHILIPPINES", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Pangasinan", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Antique province", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Sarangani Province", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "Bali", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Patnongon", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Manila", "country": "Philippines"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1826121", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (24): Philippines", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1826121", "date": "2013-06-28 21:53:05", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (19): PHILIPPINES, AUSTRALIA ex PAPUA NEW GUINEA, INDONESIA\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\n\n******\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Philippine Information Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.pia.gov.ph/news/index.php?article=1611372306004\n\n\nThe chikungunya virus, another mosquito-borne disease similar to dengue, has found its way to South Cotabato province.\n\nDr. Rogelio Aturdido Jr., head of the Integrated Provincial Health Office (IPHO), told Philippine Information Agency 12 yesterday that 2 cases of the disease were found in Sitio Bukang-liwayway, Barangay Kipalbig in nearby Tampakan town and validated by the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM) in Metro Manila.\n\n\"The other week, we sent several serum samples to RITM. Of these, 2 were found positive of the chikungunya virus,\" Dr. Aturdido said.\n\nAturdido said although the disease is not deadly like dengue, it remains a major concern because victims could suffer from severe joint pains for up to 6 months or longer.\n\nInformation from the website of the World Health Organization (WHO) says chikungunya is a mosquito-borne disease [virus] which was 1st described in an outbreak in southern Tanzania in 1954.\n\nLike dengue, the virus is transmitted via bites of infected female mosquitoes, mostly _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Illness usually occurs between 2-12 days from [initial] infection.\n\n\"Chikungunya is characterized by an abrupt onset of fever frequently accompanied by joint pain. Other common signs and symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. The joint pain is often very debilitating, but usually ends within a few days or weeks. Most patients recover fully, but in some cases joint pain may persist for several months, or even years,\" the article continues.\n\n\"The name 'chikungunya' derives from a root verb in the Kimakonde language, meaning 'to become contorted,' and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pains.\"\n\nAturdido said that although the responsibility to address this concern rests primarily on the local government unit of Tampakan, the IPHO is ready to extend help.\n\nHe emphasized, however, that since the disease's source and means of transmission is similar to dengue, prevention of its spread is also largely dependent on community efforts.\n\n\"What is required is to strictly follow the 4S strategy,\" Aturdido said.\n\n4S anti-dengue strategy consists of the following: Search and destroy; Self-protection measures; Seek early consultation; and Say no to indiscriminate fogging.\n\nIn January this year [2013], Department of Health (DOH) 12 reported that 57 cases were clinically diagnosed from Sarangani Province. The number consisted of 35 cases from Kiamba and 22 from Maitum.\n\nAccording to DOH, Chikungunya cases have also been reported in Metro Manila, Laguna, Pangasinan and other parts of Mindanao.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya virus is endemic in the Philippines, so this type of small outbreak, and the one below, are not surprising. Because there is no commercially available vaccine for chikungunya virus, the only preventive action is elimination of _Aedes_ vector mosquito breeding sites and avoidance of mosquito bites per the 4S strategy mentioned above.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Philippines is at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4l. - Mod.TY]\n\n\n******\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\nDate: Wed 26 Jun 2013\nSource: ABS-CBN news [edited]\nhttp://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/06/26/13/chikungunya-outbreak-3-antique-barangays\n\n\nHealth officials have declared a chikungunya outbreak in 3 barangays in Patnongon, Antique province -- Mabasa, Magsaysay Tamayok and Poblacion, where 6 people tested positive for the disease and nearly 100 more are being monitored.\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) has extended its monitoring and probe of other possible cases in nearby areas.\n\nLike dengue, chikungunya [virus] is contracted through mosquitoes and also has similar symptoms.\n\nHealth officials reminded the public to keep their surroundings clean [to eliminate mosquito breeding sites] and not to self-medicate if they start exhibiting symptoms of chikungunya.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Brisbane Times, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/mosquito-virus-fears-in-north-queensland-20130627-2oyag.html\n\n\nHealth authorities fear a dengue-like mosquito-borne virus could spread through far north Queensland following a massive outbreak in Papua New Guinea (PNG).\n\nSince the start of the year [2013], 11 people in Queensland have been diagnosed with chikungunya [virus infection], which causes fever, rashes and prolonged joint pain.\n\n[Of these 11,] 10 of the people contracted the virus in PNG, where more than 3000 people have been hit by the virus. Another person was bitten by a mosquito in Indonesia before flying to Queensland.\n\nThe majority of the 11 affected are Australian citizens but almost half of them live outside far north Queensland.\n\nTropical Public Health Services director Dr Richard Gair says the PNG outbreak is recent and could lead to an outbreak in far north Queensland.\n\nHe says this is because the same type of mosquitoes that carry the virus live in both areas.\n\n\"Every import is a potential outbreak,\" he said. \"If you get bitten when you're still infectious, that mosquito can go and bite someone else.\"\n\nNo one has been infected by chikungunya [virus] while in Australia.\n\nThose who have chikungunya [virus infections] experience the same symptoms as [those with] dengue fever, and both diseases are spread by the same mosquitoes.\n\n\"The difference between them is that with chikungunya we might well see the transmission happening quite a bit faster,\" Mr Gair said. \"There is less time between cases so it is harder to control.\"\n\nSince January [2013] there have been about 170 cases of dengue in the Cairns region.\n\nChikungunya [virus] was 1st found in East Africa about 50 years ago but has only recently spread to countries close to Australia.\n\nMr Gair says the best way to eliminate both chikungunya and dengue is to get rid of mosquito breeding sites, such as pots of water around properties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a very real risk of ongoing chikungunya virus transmission in northern Queensland. As the above report mentions, the mosquito vectors of the virus are present there and transmitting dengue virus.\n\nImportation of chikungunya virus into Australia is not surprising. There is an ongoing chikungunya virus outbreak on Papua New Guinea this year (2013) and there was a significant outbreak on the main island of Papua New Guinea last year (2012). From June to October 2012, a total of 633 patients suspected of having symptoms of chikungunya were reported from Vanimo hospital. The outbreak was localized to the town vicinity and its satellite communities (see ProMED-mail archive no 20121010.1335814).\n\nThe above report does not indicate where in Indonesia the single chikungunya virus infection was acquired. However, Bali is a popular tourist destination. Bali has had sporadic outbreaks.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Queensland can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJr. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Papua New Guinea can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1KlS and one of Bali, Indonesia at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4m. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (15): Indonesia (JK) 20130509.1700484\nChikungunya Philippines", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1809572", "date": "2013-06-28 21:53:05", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (19): PHILIPPINES, AUSTRALIA ex PAPUA NEW GUINEA, INDONESIA\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\n\n******\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Philippine Information Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.pia.gov.ph/news/index.php?article=1611372306004\n\n\nThe chikungunya virus, another mosquito-borne disease similar to dengue, has found its way to South Cotabato province.\n\nDr. Rogelio Aturdido Jr., head of the Integrated Provincial Health Office (IPHO), told Philippine Information Agency 12 yesterday that 2 cases of the disease were found in Sitio Bukang-liwayway, Barangay Kipalbig in nearby Tampakan town and validated by the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM) in Metro Manila.\n\n\"The other week, we sent several serum samples to RITM. Of these, 2 were found positive of the chikungunya virus,\" Dr. Aturdido said.\n\nAturdido said although the disease is not deadly like dengue, it remains a major concern because victims could suffer from severe joint pains for up to 6 months or longer.\n\nInformation from the website of the World Health Organization (WHO) says chikungunya is a mosquito-borne disease [virus] which was 1st described in an outbreak in southern Tanzania in 1954.\n\nLike dengue, the virus is transmitted via bites of infected female mosquitoes, mostly _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Illness usually occurs between 2-12 days from [initial] infection.\n\n\"Chikungunya is characterized by an abrupt onset of fever frequently accompanied by joint pain. Other common signs and symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. The joint pain is often very debilitating, but usually ends within a few days or weeks. Most patients recover fully, but in some cases joint pain may persist for several months, or even years,\" the article continues.\n\n\"The name 'chikungunya' derives from a root verb in the Kimakonde language, meaning 'to become contorted,' and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pains.\"\n\nAturdido said that although the responsibility to address this concern rests primarily on the local government unit of Tampakan, the IPHO is ready to extend help.\n\nHe emphasized, however, that since the disease's source and means of transmission is similar to dengue, prevention of its spread is also largely dependent on community efforts.\n\n\"What is required is to strictly follow the 4S strategy,\" Aturdido said.\n\n4S anti-dengue strategy consists of the following: Search and destroy; Self-protection measures; Seek early consultation; and Say no to indiscriminate fogging.\n\nIn January this year [2013], Department of Health (DOH) 12 reported that 57 cases were clinically diagnosed from Sarangani Province. The number consisted of 35 cases from Kiamba and 22 from Maitum.\n\nAccording to DOH, Chikungunya cases have also been reported in Metro Manila, Laguna, Pangasinan and other parts of Mindanao.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya virus is endemic in the Philippines, so this type of small outbreak, and the one below, are not surprising. Because there is no commercially available vaccine for chikungunya virus, the only preventive action is elimination of _Aedes_ vector mosquito breeding sites and avoidance of mosquito bites per the 4S strategy mentioned above.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Philippines is at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4l. - Mod.TY]\n\n\n******\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\nDate: Wed 26 Jun 2013\nSource: ABS-CBN news [edited]\nhttp://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/06/26/13/chikungunya-outbreak-3-antique-barangays\n\n\nHealth officials have declared a chikungunya outbreak in 3 barangays in Patnongon, Antique province -- Mabasa, Magsaysay Tamayok and Poblacion, where 6 people tested positive for the disease and nearly 100 more are being monitored.\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) has extended its monitoring and probe of other possible cases in nearby areas.\n\nLike dengue, chikungunya [virus] is contracted through mosquitoes and also has similar symptoms.\n\nHealth officials reminded the public to keep their surroundings clean [to eliminate mosquito breeding sites] and not to self-medicate if they start exhibiting symptoms of chikungunya.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Brisbane Times, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/mosquito-virus-fears-in-north-queensland-20130627-2oyag.html\n\n\nHealth authorities fear a dengue-like mosquito-borne virus could spread through far north Queensland following a massive outbreak in Papua New Guinea (PNG).\n\nSince the start of the year [2013], 11 people in Queensland have been diagnosed with chikungunya [virus infection], which causes fever, rashes and prolonged joint pain.\n\n[Of these 11,] 10 of the people contracted the virus in PNG, where more than 3000 people have been hit by the virus. Another person was bitten by a mosquito in Indonesia before flying to Queensland.\n\nThe majority of the 11 affected are Australian citizens but almost half of them live outside far north Queensland.\n\nTropical Public Health Services director Dr Richard Gair says the PNG outbreak is recent and could lead to an outbreak in far north Queensland.\n\nHe says this is because the same type of mosquitoes that carry the virus live in both areas.\n\n\"Every import is a potential outbreak,\" he said. \"If you get bitten when you're still infectious, that mosquito can go and bite someone else.\"\n\nNo one has been infected by chikungunya [virus] while in Australia.\n\nThose who have chikungunya [virus infections] experience the same symptoms as [those with] dengue fever, and both diseases are spread by the same mosquitoes.\n\n\"The difference between them is that with chikungunya we might well see the transmission happening quite a bit faster,\" Mr Gair said. \"There is less time between cases so it is harder to control.\"\n\nSince January [2013] there have been about 170 cases of dengue in the Cairns region.\n\nChikungunya [virus] was 1st found in East Africa about 50 years ago but has only recently spread to countries close to Australia.\n\nMr Gair says the best way to eliminate both chikungunya and dengue is to get rid of mosquito breeding sites, such as pots of water around properties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a very real risk of ongoing chikungunya virus transmission in northern Queensland. As the above report mentions, the mosquito vectors of the virus are present there and transmitting dengue virus.\n\nImportation of chikungunya virus into Australia is not surprising. There is an ongoing chikungunya virus outbreak on Papua New Guinea this year (2013) and there was a significant outbreak on the main island of Papua New Guinea last year (2012). From June to October 2012, a total of 633 patients suspected of having symptoms of chikungunya were reported from Vanimo hospital. The outbreak was localized to the town vicinity and its satellite communities (see ProMED-mail archive no 20121010.1335814).\n\nThe above report does not indicate where in Indonesia the single chikungunya virus infection was acquired. However, Bali is a popular tourist destination. Bali has had sporadic outbreaks.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Queensland can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJr. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Papua New Guinea can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1KlS and one of Bali, Indonesia at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4m. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (15): Indonesia (JK) 20130509.1700484\nChikungunya (06): Germany ex Indonesia (Bali) 2012 20130227.1562598\nChikungunya (05): Philippines (CA) susp 20130208.1534203\n2012\n----\nChikungunya (20): Papua New Guinea: 20121010.1335814\n.................................................sb/mpp/ty/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 Philippines (KA) susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1807686", "date": "2013-06-28 21:53:05", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (19): PHILIPPINES, AUSTRALIA ex PAPUA NEW GUINEA, INDONESIA\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\n\n******\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Philippine Information Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.pia.gov.ph/news/index.php?article=1611372306004\n\n\nThe chikungunya virus, another mosquito-borne disease similar to dengue, has found its way to South Cotabato province.\n\nDr. Rogelio Aturdido Jr., head of the Integrated Provincial Health Office (IPHO), told Philippine Information Agency 12 yesterday that 2 cases of the disease were found in Sitio Bukang-liwayway, Barangay Kipalbig in nearby Tampakan town and validated by the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM) in Metro Manila.\n\n\"The other week, we sent several serum samples to RITM. Of these, 2 were found positive of the chikungunya virus,\" Dr. Aturdido said.\n\nAturdido said although the disease is not deadly like dengue, it remains a major concern because victims could suffer from severe joint pains for up to 6 months or longer.\n\nInformation from the website of the World Health Organization (WHO) says chikungunya is a mosquito-borne disease [virus] which was 1st described in an outbreak in southern Tanzania in 1954.\n\nLike dengue, the virus is transmitted via bites of infected female mosquitoes, mostly _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Illness usually occurs between 2-12 days from [initial] infection.\n\n\"Chikungunya is characterized by an abrupt onset of fever frequently accompanied by joint pain. Other common signs and symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. The joint pain is often very debilitating, but usually ends within a few days or weeks. Most patients recover fully, but in some cases joint pain may persist for several months, or even years,\" the article continues.\n\n\"The name 'chikungunya' derives from a root verb in the Kimakonde language, meaning 'to become contorted,' and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pains.\"\n\nAturdido said that although the responsibility to address this concern rests primarily on the local government unit of Tampakan, the IPHO is ready to extend help.\n\nHe emphasized, however, that since the disease's source and means of transmission is similar to dengue, prevention of its spread is also largely dependent on community efforts.\n\n\"What is required is to strictly follow the 4S strategy,\" Aturdido said.\n\n4S anti-dengue strategy consists of the following: Search and destroy; Self-protection measures; Seek early consultation; and Say no to indiscriminate fogging.\n\nIn January this year [2013], Department of Health (DOH) 12 reported that 57 cases were clinically diagnosed from Sarangani Province. The number consisted of 35 cases from Kiamba and 22 from Maitum.\n\nAccording to DOH, Chikungunya cases have also been reported in Metro Manila, Laguna, Pangasinan and other parts of Mindanao.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya virus is endemic in the Philippines, so this type of small outbreak, and the one below, are not surprising. Because there is no commercially available vaccine for chikungunya virus, the only preventive action is elimination of _Aedes_ vector mosquito breeding sites and avoidance of mosquito bites per the 4S strategy mentioned above.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Philippines is at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4l. - Mod.TY]\n\n\n******\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\nDate: Wed 26 Jun 2013\nSource: ABS-CBN news [edited]\nhttp://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/06/26/13/chikungunya-outbreak-3-antique-barangays\n\n\nHealth officials have declared a chikungunya outbreak in 3 barangays in Patnongon, Antique province -- Mabasa, Magsaysay Tamayok and Poblacion, where 6 people tested positive for the disease and nearly 100 more are being monitored.\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) has extended its monitoring and probe of other possible cases in nearby areas.\n\nLike dengue, chikungunya [virus] is contracted through mosquitoes and also has similar symptoms.\n\nHealth officials reminded the public to keep their surroundings clean [to eliminate mosquito breeding sites] and not to self-medicate if they start exhibiting symptoms of chikungunya.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Brisbane Times, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/mosquito-virus-fears-in-north-queensland-20130627-2oyag.html\n\n\nHealth authorities fear a dengue-like mosquito-borne virus could spread through far north Queensland following a massive outbreak in Papua New Guinea (PNG).\n\nSince the start of the year [2013], 11 people in Queensland have been diagnosed with chikungunya [virus infection], which causes fever, rashes and prolonged joint pain.\n\n[Of these 11,] 10 of the people contracted the virus in PNG, where more than 3000 people have been hit by the virus. Another person was bitten by a mosquito in Indonesia before flying to Queensland.\n\nThe majority of the 11 affected are Australian citizens but almost half of them live outside far north Queensland.\n\nTropical Public Health Services director Dr Richard Gair says the PNG outbreak is recent and could lead to an outbreak in far north Queensland.\n\nHe says this is because the same type of mosquitoes that carry the virus live in both areas.\n\n\"Every import is a potential outbreak,\" he said. \"If you get bitten when you're still infectious, that mosquito can go and bite someone else.\"\n\nNo one has been infected by chikungunya [virus] while in Australia.\n\nThose who have chikungunya [virus infections] experience the same symptoms as [those with] dengue fever, and both diseases are spread by the same mosquitoes.\n\n\"The difference between them is that with chikungunya we might well see the transmission happening quite a bit faster,\" Mr Gair said. \"There is less time between cases so it is harder to control.\"\n\nSince January [2013] there have been about 170 cases of dengue in the Cairns region.\n\nChikungunya [virus] was 1st found in East Africa about 50 years ago but has only recently spread to countries close to Australia.\n\nMr Gair says the best way to eliminate both chikungunya and dengue is to get rid of mosquito breeding sites, such as pots of water around properties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a very real risk of ongoing chikungunya virus transmission in northern Queensland. As the above report mentions, the mosquito vectors of the virus are present there and transmitting dengue virus.\n\nImportation of chikungunya virus into Australia is not surprising. There is an ongoing chikungunya virus outbreak on Papua New Guinea this year (2013) and there was a significant outbreak on the main island of Papua New Guinea last year (2012). Philippines, Australia ex Papua New Guinea, Indonesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1798136", "date": "2013-06-28 21:53:05", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (19): PHILIPPINES, AUSTRALIA ex PAPUA NEW GUINEA, INDONESIA\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\n\n******\n[1] Philippines (South Cotabato)\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Philippine Information Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.pia.gov.ph/news/index.php?article=1611372306004\n\n\nThe chikungunya virus, another mosquito-borne disease similar to dengue, has found its way to South Cotabato province.\n\nDr. Rogelio Aturdido Jr., head of the Integrated Provincial Health Office (IPHO), told Philippine Information Agency 12 yesterday that 2 cases of the disease were found in Sitio Bukang-liwayway, Barangay Kipalbig in nearby Tampakan town and validated by the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM) in Metro Manila.\n\n\"The other week, we sent several serum samples to RITM. Of these, 2 were found positive of the chikungunya virus,\" Dr. Aturdido said.\n\nAturdido said although the disease is not deadly like dengue, it remains a major concern because victims could suffer from severe joint pains for up to 6 months or longer.\n\nInformation from the website of the World Health Organization (WHO) says chikungunya is a mosquito-borne disease [virus] which was 1st described in an outbreak in southern Tanzania in 1954.\n\nLike dengue, the virus is transmitted via bites of infected female mosquitoes, mostly _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Illness usually occurs between 2-12 days from [initial] infection.\n\n\"Chikungunya is characterized by an abrupt onset of fever frequently accompanied by joint pain. Other common signs and symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. The joint pain is often very debilitating, but usually ends within a few days or weeks. Most patients recover fully, but in some cases joint pain may persist for several months, or even years,\" the article continues.\n\n\"The name 'chikungunya' derives from a root verb in the Kimakonde language, meaning 'to become contorted,' and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pains.\"\n\nAturdido said that although the responsibility to address this concern rests primarily on the local government unit of Tampakan, the IPHO is ready to extend help.\n\nHe emphasized, however, that since the disease's source and means of transmission is similar to dengue, prevention of its spread is also largely dependent on community efforts.\n\n\"What is required is to strictly follow the 4S strategy,\" Aturdido said.\n\n4S anti-dengue strategy consists of the following: Search and destroy; Self-protection measures; Seek early consultation; and Say no to indiscriminate fogging.\n\nIn January this year [2013], Department of Health (DOH) 12 reported that 57 cases were clinically diagnosed from Sarangani Province. The number consisted of 35 cases from Kiamba and 22 from Maitum.\n\nAccording to DOH, Chikungunya cases have also been reported in Metro Manila, Laguna, Pangasinan and other parts of Mindanao.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya virus is endemic in the Philippines, so this type of small outbreak, and the one below, are not surprising. Because there is no commercially available vaccine for chikungunya virus, the only preventive action is elimination of _Aedes_ vector mosquito breeding sites and avoidance of mosquito bites per the 4S strategy mentioned above.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Philippines is at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4l. - Mod.TY]\n\n\n******\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\nDate: Wed 26 Jun 2013\nSource: ABS-CBN news [edited]\nhttp://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/06/26/13/chikungunya-outbreak-3-antique-barangays\n\n\nHealth officials have declared a chikungunya outbreak in 3 barangays in Patnongon, Antique province -- Mabasa, Magsaysay Tamayok and Poblacion, where 6 people tested positive for the disease and nearly 100 more are being monitored.\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) has extended its monitoring and probe of other possible cases in nearby areas.\n\nLike dengue, chikungunya [virus] is contracted through mosquitoes and also has similar symptoms.\n\nHealth officials reminded the public to keep their surroundings clean [to eliminate mosquito breeding sites] and not to self-medicate if they start exhibiting symptoms of chikungunya.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Brisbane Times, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/mosquito-virus-fears-in-north-queensland-20130627-2oyag.html\n\n\nHealth authorities fear a dengue-like mosquito-borne virus could spread through far north Queensland following a massive outbreak in Papua New Guinea (PNG).\n\nSince the start of the year [2013], 11 people in Queensland have been diagnosed with chikungunya [virus infection], which causes fever, rashes and prolonged joint pain.\n\n[Of these 11,] 10 of the people contracted the virus in PNG, where more than 3000 people have been hit by the virus. Another person was bitten by a mosquito in Indonesia before flying to Queensland.\n\nThe majority of the 11 affected are Australian citizens but almost half of them live outside far north Queensland.\n\nTropical Public Health Services director Dr Richard Gair says the PNG outbreak is recent and could lead to an outbreak in far north Queensland.\n\nHe says this is because the same type of mosquitoes that carry the virus live in both areas.\n\n\"Every import is a potential outbreak,\" he said. \"If you get bitten when you're still infectious, that mosquito can go and bite someone else.\"\n\nNo one has been infected by chikungunya [virus] while in Australia.\n\nThose who have chikungunya [virus infections] experience the same symptoms as [those with] dengue fever, and both diseases are spread by the same mosquitoes.\n\n\"The difference between them is that with chikungunya we might well see the transmission happening quite a bit faster,\" Mr Gair said. \"There is less time between cases so it is harder to control.\"\n\nSince January [2013] there have been about 170 cases of dengue in the Cairns region.\n\nChikungunya [virus] was 1st found in East Africa about 50 years ago but has only recently spread to countries close to Australia.\n\nMr Gair says the best way to eliminate both chikungunya and dengue is to get rid of mosquito breeding sites, such as pots of water around properties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a very real risk of ongoing chikungunya virus transmission in northern Queensland. As the above report mentions, the mosquito vectors of the virus are present there and transmitting dengue virus.\n\nImportation of chikungunya virus into Australia is not surprising. There is an ongoing chikungunya virus outbreak on Papua New Guinea this year (2013) and there was a significant outbreak on the main island of Papua New Guinea last year (2012). From June to October 2012, a total of 633 patients suspected of having symptoms of chikungunya were reported from Vanimo hospital. The outbreak was localized to the town vicinity and its satellite communities (see ProMED-mail archive no 20121010.1335814).\n\nThe above report does not indicate where in Indonesia the single chikungunya virus infection was acquired. However, Bali is a popular tourist destination. Bali has had sporadic outbreaks.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Queensland can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1kJr. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Papua New Guinea can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1KlS and one of Bali, Indonesia at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4m. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (15): Indonesia (JK) 20130509.1700484\nChikungunya (06): Germany ex Indonesia (Bali) 2012 20130227.1562598\nChikungunya (05): Philippines (CA) susp 20130208.1534203\n2012\n----\nChikungunya (20): Papua New Guinea: Cotabato)\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Philippine Information Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.pia.gov.ph/news/index.php?article=1611372306004\n\n\nThe chikungunya virus, another mosquito-borne disease similar to dengue, has found its way to South Cotabato province.\n\nDr. Rogelio Aturdido Jr., head of the Integrated Provincial Health Office (IPHO), told Philippine Information Agency 12 yesterday that 2 cases of the disease were found in Sitio Bukang-liwayway, Barangay Kipalbig in nearby Tampakan town and validated by the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM) in Metro Manila.\n\n\"The other week, we sent several serum samples to RITM. Of these, 2 were found positive of the chikungunya virus,\" Dr. Aturdido said.\n\nAturdido said although the disease is not deadly like dengue, it remains a major concern because victims could suffer from severe joint pains for up to 6 months or longer.\n\nInformation from the website of the World Health Organization (WHO) says chikungunya is a mosquito-borne disease [virus] which was 1st described in an outbreak in southern Tanzania in 1954.\n\nLike dengue, the virus is transmitted via bites of infected female mosquitoes, mostly _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes albopictus_. Illness usually occurs between 2-12 days from [initial] infection.\n\n\"Chikungunya is characterized by an abrupt onset of fever frequently accompanied by joint pain. Other common signs and symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rash. The joint pain is often very debilitating, but usually ends within a few days or weeks. Most patients recover fully, but in some cases joint pain may persist for several months, or even years,\" the article continues.\n\n\"The name 'chikungunya' derives from a root verb in the Kimakonde language, meaning 'to become contorted,' and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with joint pains.\"\n\nAturdido said that although the responsibility to address this concern rests primarily on the local government unit of Tampakan, the IPHO is ready to extend help.\n\nHe emphasized, however, that since the disease's source and means of transmission is similar to dengue, prevention of its spread is also largely dependent on community efforts.\n\n\"What is required is to strictly follow the 4S strategy,\" Aturdido said.\n\n4S anti-dengue strategy consists of the following: Search and destroy; Self-protection measures; Seek early consultation; and Say no to indiscriminate fogging.\n\nIn January this year [2013], Department of Health (DOH) 12 reported that 57 cases were clinically diagnosed from Sarangani Province. The number consisted of 35 cases from Kiamba and 22 from Maitum.\n\nAccording to DOH, Chikungunya cases have also been reported in Metro Manila, Laguna, Pangasinan and other parts of Mindanao.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Chikungunya virus is endemic in the Philippines, so this type of small outbreak, and the one below, are not surprising. Because there is no commercially available vaccine for chikungunya virus, the only preventive action is elimination of _Aedes_ vector mosquito breeding sites and avoidance of mosquito bites per the 4S strategy mentioned above.\n\nA map of the Philippines can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/philippines/maps/Philippines-Location.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Philippines is at http://healthmap.org/r/7r4l. - Mod.TY]\n\n\n******\n[2] Philippines (Antique)\nDate: Wed 26 Jun 2013\nSource: ABS-CBN news [edited]\nhttp://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/regions/06/26/13/chikungunya-outbreak-3-antique-barangays\n\n\nHealth officials have declared a chikungunya outbreak in 3 barangays in Patnongon, Antique province -- Mabasa, Magsaysay Tamayok and Poblacion, where 6 people tested positive for the disease and nearly 100 more are being monitored.\n\nThe Department of Health (DOH) has extended its monitoring and probe of other possible cases in nearby areas.\n\nLike dengue, chikungunya [virus] is contracted through mosquitoes and also has similar symptoms.\n\nHealth officials reminded the public to keep their surroundings clean [to eliminate mosquito breeding sites] and not to self-medicate if they start exhibiting symptoms of chikungunya.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Australia ex Papua New Guinea and Indonesia\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nSource: Brisbane Times, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/mosquito-virus-fears-in-north-queensland-20130627-2oyag.html\n\n\nHealth authorities fear a dengue-like mosquito-borne virus could spread through far north Queensland following a massive outbreak in Papua New Guinea (PNG).\n\nSince the start of the year [2013], 11 people in Queensland have been diagnosed with chikungunya [virus infection], which causes fever, rashes and prolonged joint pain.\n\n[Of these 11,] 10 of the people contracted the virus in PNG, where more than 3000 people have been hit by the virus. (KA) susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1750761", "date": "2013-05-09 08:34:55", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (15): INDONESIA (JAKARTA SPECIAL DISTRICT)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 May 2013\nSource: Berita Jakarta [edited]\nhttp://beritajakarta.com/2008/en/newsview.aspx?idwil=0&id=27908\n\n\nAside from the dangers of dengue fever, during changing season such as this one, the citizens were asked to be vigilant with other diseases such as chikungunya [virus infection], because in East Jakarta, based on the local Health Sub Department, there are 165 citizens who suffered from that disease.\n\nThose 165 chikungunya sufferers consist of 10 citizens in Palmeriam Urban Village, 22 citizens in Cakungbarat, 15 citizens in Jatinegara, 20 citizens in Pondokkelapa, 11 citizens in Rawaterate, 16 citizens in Pondokbambu, 6 citizens in Cipinangmelayu, 16 citizens in Halim Perdanakusumah, 25 citizens in Makasar, and 24 citizens in Pondokkopi. \"From this number, there are no dead people,\" said Safarudin, Head of East Jakarta Health Sub Department, Tuesday (7 May 2013).\n\nProbably, such data will change by the end of this year [2013]. However, citizens are urged to remain calm and need not worry, because chikungunya disease is not [more] dangerous than dengue fever.\n\nHe said the number of chikungunya sufferers in East Jakarta is relatively high, caused by low citizen awareness to [maintain] hygiene and [a] healthy lifestyle. \"With anti-mosquito campaigns and \"Hygiene and Health Lifestyle Behavior\" [these] are the best solutions to handle dengue fever and chikungunya,\" he said.\n\nEspecially for chikungunya, sufferers will feel weak and sore in their bodies. \"Especially in their joints, but it is not too dangerous. For those who had fever accompanied by sore and rheumatic pain in the joints, they must be taken to the nearest community health center,\" he concluded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Within the past 7 months in Indonesia, there have been cases of chikungunya virus infection in Bali, West Sumatra, Central Java, and West Java. A cleanup of water catchment breeding sites should help reduce the population of _Aedes aegypti_, the likely vector of chikungunya virus in these areas. There is no vaccine available to prevent chikungunya virus infections. Control of vector mosquito populations and avoidance of their bites are the only feasible preventive measures.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Jakarta can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/6QcT. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (08): Papua New Guinea, Australia ex Indonesia (Bali) 20130320.1594512\nChikungunya (06): Germany ex Indonesia (Bali) 2012 DISTRICT)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 May 2013\nSource: Berita Jakarta [edited]\nhttp://beritajakarta.com/2008/en/newsview.aspx?idwil=0&id=27908\n\n\nAside from the dangers of dengue fever, during changing season such as this one, the citizens were asked to be vigilant with other diseases such as chikungunya [virus infection], because in East Jakarta, based on the local Health Sub Department, there are 165 citizens who suffered from that disease.\n\nThose 165 chikungunya sufferers consist of 10 citizens in Palmeriam Urban Village, 22 citizens in Cakungbarat, 15 citizens in Jatinegara, 20 citizens in Pondokkelapa, 11 citizens in Rawaterate, 16 citizens in Pondokbambu, 6 citizens in Cipinangmelayu, 16 citizens in Halim Perdanakusumah, 25 citizens in Makasar, and 24 citizens in Pondokkopi. \"From this number, there are no dead people,\" said Safarudin, Head of East Jakarta Health Sub Department, Tuesday (7 May 2013).\n\nProbably, such data will change by the end of this year [2013]. However, citizens are urged to remain calm and need not worry, because chikungunya disease is not [more] dangerous than dengue fever.\n\nHe said the number of chikungunya sufferers in East Jakarta is relatively high, caused by low citizen awareness to [maintain] hygiene and [a] healthy lifestyle. \"With anti-mosquito campaigns and \"Hygiene and Health Lifestyle Behavior\" [these] are the best solutions to handle dengue fever and chikungunya,\" he said.\n\nEspecially for chikungunya, sufferers will feel weak and sore in their bodies. \"Especially in their joints, but it is not too dangerous. For those who had fever accompanied by sore and rheumatic pain in the joints, they must be taken to the nearest community health center,\" he concluded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Within the past 7 months in Indonesia, there have been cases of chikungunya virus infection in Bali, West Sumatra, Central Java, and West Java. A cleanup of water catchment breeding sites should help reduce the population of _Aedes aegypti_, the likely vector of chikungunya virus in these areas. There is no vaccine available to prevent chikungunya virus infections. Control of vector mosquito populations and avoidance of their bites are the only feasible preventive measures.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Jakarta can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/6QcT. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (08): Papua New Guinea, Australia ex Indonesia (Bali) 20130320.1594512\nChikungunya (06): Germany ex Indonesia (Bali) 2012 DISTRICT)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 May 2013\nSource: Berita Jakarta [edited]\nhttp://beritajakarta.com/2008/en/newsview.aspx?idwil=0&id=27908\n\n\nAside from the dangers of dengue fever, during changing season such as this one, the citizens were asked to be vigilant with other diseases such as chikungunya [virus infection], because in East Jakarta, based on the local Health Sub Department, there are 165 citizens who suffered from that disease.\n\nThose 165 chikungunya sufferers consist of 10 citizens in Palmeriam Urban Village, 22 citizens in Cakungbarat, 15 citizens in Jatinegara, 20 citizens in Pondokkelapa, 11 citizens in Rawaterate, 16 citizens in Pondokbambu, 6 citizens in Cipinangmelayu, 16 citizens in Halim Perdanakusumah, 25 citizens in Makasar, and 24 citizens in Pondokkopi. \"From this number, there are no dead people,\" said Safarudin, Head of East Jakarta Health Sub Department, Tuesday (7 May 2013).\n\nProbably, such data will change by the end of this year [2013]. However, citizens are urged to remain calm and need not worry, because chikungunya disease is not [more] dangerous than dengue fever.\n\nHe said the number of chikungunya sufferers in East Jakarta is relatively high, caused by low citizen awareness to [maintain] hygiene and [a] healthy lifestyle. \"With anti-mosquito campaigns and \"Hygiene and Health Lifestyle Behavior\" [these] are the best solutions to handle dengue fever and chikungunya,\" he said.\n\nEspecially for chikungunya, sufferers will feel weak and sore in their bodies. \"Especially in their joints, but it is not too dangerous. For those who had fever accompanied by sore and rheumatic pain in the joints, they must be taken to the nearest community health center,\" he concluded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Within the past 7 months in Indonesia, there have been cases of chikungunya virus infection in Bali, West Sumatra, Central Java, and West Java. A cleanup of water catchment breeding sites should help reduce the population of _Aedes aegypti_, the likely vector of chikungunya virus in these areas. There is no vaccine available to prevent chikungunya virus infections. Control of vector mosquito populations and avoidance of their bites are the only feasible preventive measures.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Jakarta can be accessed at of this year [2013]. However, citizens are urged to remain calm and need not worry, because chikungunya disease is not [more] dangerous than dengue fever.\n\nHe said the number of chikungunya sufferers in East Jakarta is relatively high, caused by low citizen awareness to [maintain] hygiene and [a] healthy lifestyle. \"With anti-mosquito campaigns and \"Hygiene and Health Lifestyle Behavior\" [these] are the best solutions to handle dengue fever and chikungunya,\" he said.\n\nEspecially for chikungunya, sufferers will feel weak and sore in their bodies. \"Especially in their joints, but it is not too dangerous. For those who had fever accompanied by sore and rheumatic pain in the joints, they must be taken to the nearest community health center,\" he concluded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Within the past 7 months in Indonesia, there have been cases of chikungunya virus infection in Bali, West Sumatra, Central Java, and West Java. of this year [2013]. However, citizens are urged to remain calm and need not worry, because chikungunya disease is not [more] dangerous than dengue fever.\n\nHe said the number of chikungunya sufferers in East Jakarta is relatively high, caused by low citizen awareness to [maintain] hygiene and [a] healthy lifestyle. \"With anti-mosquito campaigns and \"Hygiene and Health Lifestyle Behavior\" [these] are the best solutions to handle dengue fever and chikungunya,\" he said.\n\nEspecially for chikungunya, sufferers will feel weak and sore in their bodies. \"Especially in their joints, but it is not too dangerous. However, citizens are urged to remain calm and need not worry, because chikungunya disease is not [more] dangerous than dengue fever.\n\nHe said the number of chikungunya sufferers in East Jakarta is relatively high, caused by low citizen awareness to [maintain] hygiene and [a] healthy lifestyle. \"With anti-mosquito campaigns and \"Hygiene and Health Lifestyle Behavior\" [these] are the best solutions to handle dengue fever and chikungunya,\" he said.\n\nEspecially for chikungunya, sufferers will feel weak and sore in their bodies. \"Especially in their joints, but it is not too dangerous. Guinea, comment, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1597913", "date": "2013-01-13 11:19:11", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (02): PHILIPPINES (EASTERN VISAYAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Jan 2013\nSource: Business World [edited]\nhttp://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=Nation&title=Chikungunya-afflicts-Samar-residents&id=64143\n\n\nOver 250 individuals in Villareal town in Samar [Eastern Visayas region] are believed to have been afflicted with chikungunya, a mosquito-borne viral disease with symptoms similar to those of dengue fever.\n\nThe Department of Health (DoH) in Eastern Visayas has deployed Regional Prevention and Control Program (RPCP) teams to investigate the spread of the disease in Villareal as well as in Catarman, Northern Samar, and San Juan, Southern Leyte, where cases were also reported early this week.\n\nRoderick Boyd S. Cerro, DoH-8 regional sentinel nurse, said 235 people in Barangay Banquil and 28 in Guintarcan Island in Samar showed symptoms of the disease.\n\n\"The disease was reported by the municipal health office in November [2012]. They raised an alarm over the quick spread of the disease in December last year [2012] and early this month [January 2013],\" he said.\n\nHe said 12 of the 28 cases reported in Guintarcan Island were confirmed to be chikungunya [virus infections] based on laboratory results from the Regional Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM).\n\nChikungunya, a dengue-like disease, has also been reported in Northern Mindanao, Ilocos, Cagayan Valley, National Capital Region, Calabarzon, Bicol, Western Visayas, Davao and Caraga.\n\nMr. Cerro said chikungunya causes fever and a skin rash similar to dengue and mostly affects adults. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), chikungunya is a viral disease spread by mosquitoes that causes fever and severe joint pain. Its symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rashes.\n\nSigns and symptoms include an abrupt onset of fever, frequently accompanied by joint pain. Illness usually occurs 4-8 days after a mosquito bite and can range from 2-12 days.\n\n\"There is no cure for the disease, and treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. Although it is not as deadly as dengue, patients are advised to seek immediate medical help,\" Mr. Cerro said.\n\n[Byline: Reyan L. Arinto]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak appears to have been going on for over 2 months. There were sporadic outbreaks of chikungunya virus infections last year (2012) in various parts of the Philippines. Chikungunya virus is doubtless endemic in the Philippines, having caused sporadic outbreaks in 1954, 1956, 1968, and 1985 to 1986 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20120929.1315954), mainly in the center and south areas of the country. Since there is no commercially available vaccine, the only preventive measures are mosquito vector control and avoidance of mosquito bites.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Philippines can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/3AV9 and Samar in Eastern Visayas region at http://www.ugo.cn/admin2/en/1290903.htm. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nChikungunya (24): Philippines "CHIKUNGUNYA (02): PHILIPPINES (EASTERN VISAYAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Jan 2013\nSource: Business World [edited]\nhttp://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=Nation&title=Chikungunya-afflicts-Samar-residents&id=64143\n\n\nOver 250 individuals in Villareal town in Samar [Eastern Visayas region] are believed to have been afflicted with chikungunya, a mosquito-borne viral disease with symptoms similar to those of dengue fever.\n\nThe Department of Health (DoH) in Eastern Visayas has deployed Regional Prevention and Control Program (RPCP) teams to investigate the spread of the disease in Villareal as well as in Catarman, Northern Samar, and San Juan, Southern Leyte, where cases were also reported early this week.\n\nRoderick Boyd S. Cerro, DoH-8 regional sentinel nurse, said 235 people in Barangay Banquil and 28 in Guintarcan Island in Samar showed symptoms of the disease.\n\n\"The disease was reported by the municipal health office in November [2012]. They raised an alarm over the quick spread of the disease in December last year [2012] and early this month [January 2013],\" he said.\n\nHe said 12 of the 28 cases reported in Guintarcan Island were confirmed to be chikungunya [virus infections] based on laboratory results from the Regional Institute for Tropical Medicine (RITM).\n\nChikungunya, a dengue-like disease, has also been reported in Northern Mindanao, Ilocos, Cagayan Valley, National Capital Region, Calabarzon, Bicol, Western Visayas, Davao and Caraga.\n\nMr. Cerro said chikungunya causes fever and a skin rash similar to dengue and mostly affects adults. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), chikungunya is a viral disease spread by mosquitoes that causes fever and severe joint pain. Its symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue and rashes.\n\nSigns and symptoms include an abrupt onset of fever, frequently accompanied by joint pain. Illness usually occurs 4-8 days after a mosquito bite and can range from 2-12 days.\n\n\"There is no cure for the disease, and treatment is focused on relieving the symptoms. Although it is not as deadly as dengue, patients are advised to seek immediate medical help,\" Mr. Cerro said.\n\n[Byline: Reyan L. Arinto]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak appears to have been going on for over 2 months. There were sporadic outbreaks of chikungunya virus infections last year (2012) in various parts of the Philippines. Chikungunya virus is doubtless endemic in the Philippines, having caused sporadic outbreaks in 1954, 1956, 1968, and 1985 to 1986 (see ProMED-mail archive no 20120929.1315954), mainly in the center and south areas of the country.
