CAMBODIA (02) COMMENT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nFrom: Fabio Napoletano [edited]\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n\n[Responding to ProMED/MBDS Dengue - Cambodia (04) 20120516.1119 posted on 16 May, identical to report published on this list today, 19 May. - ProMED]\n\nAs a non-medic travelling in Cambodia's countryside, I think the\nreports of infections are completely underestimating the pandemic\ncurrently going on.\n\nIn one village alone in the province of Preah Vihear I have counted at\nleast 700 cases of infections since January 2012.\n\nExtrapolate this to the whole province and you easily have 40 000 or\nmore cases of infections that will very soon occur also in the rest of\nthe country thanks to the newly built roads and increased movement of\npeople.\n\nMany strong men are unable to work due to month-long severe arthritis.\n\nPeople have died directly or indirectly.\n\n--\nFabio Napoletano\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Fabio Napoletano for providing his 1st-hand\nobservations. There is a clear need for health authorities to follow\nup on the outbreak that is going on, with epidemiological surveillance\nand good laboratory support.\n\nAlthough persistent athralgia is typical of chikungunya virus\ninfections, because the acute clinical signs of dengue and chikungunya\nare otherwise similar, laboratory diagnosis will be essential,\nespecially if fatalities are occurring. Reports of fatalities from\nchikungunya virus infections are very rare, so one hopes that the\ncause of deaths in this outbreak in Cambodia are determined. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]\nSee Also\nsee also:\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n2009\n----\nChikungunya (13): Thailand (PU) 20090515.1818\nChikungunya (09): Thailand (SG) 20090429.1615\n.................................................jw/ty/ejp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1225107", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (09): France ex Africa (DRC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1225107", "date": "2012-05-19 17:13:32", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - CAMBODIA (02) COMMENT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nFrom: Fabio Napoletano [edited]\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n\n[Responding to ProMED/MBDS Dengue - Cambodia (04) 20120516.1119 posted on 16 May, identical to report published on this list today, 19 May. - ProMED]\n\nAs a non-medic travelling in Cambodia's countryside, I think the\nreports of infections are completely underestimating the pandemic\ncurrently going on.\n\nIn one village alone in the province of Preah Vihear I have counted at\nleast 700 cases of infections since January 2012.\n\nExtrapolate this to the whole province and you easily have 40 000 or\nmore cases of infections that will very soon occur also in the rest of\nthe country thanks to the newly built roads and increased movement of\npeople.\n\nMany strong men are unable to work due to month-long severe arthritis.\n\nPeople have died directly or indirectly.\n\n--\nFabio Napoletano\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Fabio Napoletano for providing his 1st-hand\nobservations. There is a clear need for health authorities to follow\nup on the outbreak that is going on, with epidemiological surveillance\nand good laboratory support.\n\nAlthough persistent athralgia is typical of chikungunya virus\ninfections, because the acute clinical signs of dengue and chikungunya\nare otherwise similar, laboratory diagnosis will be essential,\nespecially if fatalities are occurring. Reports of fatalities from\nchikungunya virus infections are very rare, so one hopes that the\ncause of deaths in this outbreak in Cambodia are determined. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]\nSee Also\nsee also:\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n2009\n----\nChikungunya (13): Thailand (PU) 20090515.1818\nChikungunya (09): Thailand (SG) 20090429.1615\n.................................................jw/ty/ejp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1209257", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (08): Sierra Leone, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1209257", "date": "2012-05-19 17:13:32", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - CAMBODIA (02) COMMENT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nFrom: Fabio Napoletano [edited]\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n\n[Responding to ProMED/MBDS Dengue - Cambodia (04) 20120516.1119 posted on 16 May, identical to report published on this list today, 19 May. - ProMED]\n\nAs a non-medic travelling in Cambodia's countryside, I think the\nreports of infections are completely underestimating the pandemic\ncurrently going on.\n\nIn one village alone in the province of Preah Vihear I have counted at\nleast 700 cases of infections since January 2012.\n\nExtrapolate this to the whole province and you easily have 40 000 or\nmore cases of infections that will very soon occur also in the rest of\nthe country thanks to the newly built roads and increased movement of\npeople.\n\nMany strong men are unable to work due to month-long severe arthritis.\n\nPeople have died directly or indirectly.\n\n--\nFabio Napoletano\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Fabio Napoletano for providing his 1st-hand\nobservations. There is a clear need for health authorities to follow\nup on the outbreak that is going on, with epidemiological surveillance\nand good laboratory support.\n\nAlthough persistent athralgia is typical of chikungunya virus\ninfections, because the acute clinical signs of dengue and chikungunya\nare otherwise similar, laboratory diagnosis will be essential,\nespecially if fatalities are occurring. Reports of fatalities from\nchikungunya virus infections are very rare, so one hopes that the\ncause of deaths in this outbreak in Cambodia are determined. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]\nSee Also\nsee also:\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n2009\n----\nChikungunya (13): Thailand (PU) 20090515.1818\nChikungunya (09): Thailand (SG) 20090429.1615\n.................................................jw/ty/ejp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1203694", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (07): India (RA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1203694", "date": "2012-05-19 17:13:32", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - CAMBODIA (02) COMMENT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nFrom: Fabio Napoletano [edited]\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n\n[Responding to ProMED/MBDS Dengue - Cambodia (04) 20120516.1119 posted on 16 May, identical to report published on this list today, 19 May. - ProMED]\n\nAs a non-medic travelling in Cambodia's countryside, I think the\nreports of infections are completely underestimating the pandemic\ncurrently going on.\n\nIn one village alone in the province of Preah Vihear I have counted at\nleast 700 cases of infections since January 2012.\n\nExtrapolate this to the whole province and you easily have 40 000 or\nmore cases of infections that will very soon occur also in the rest of\nthe country thanks to the newly built roads and increased movement of\npeople.\n\nMany strong men are unable to work due to month-long severe arthritis.\n\nPeople have died directly or indirectly.\n\n--\nFabio Napoletano\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Fabio Napoletano for providing his 1st-hand\nobservations. There is a clear need for health authorities to follow\nup on the outbreak that is going on, with epidemiological surveillance\nand good laboratory support.\n\nAlthough persistent athralgia is typical of chikungunya virus\ninfections, because the acute clinical signs of dengue and chikungunya\nare otherwise similar, laboratory diagnosis will be essential,\nespecially if fatalities are occurring. Reports of fatalities from\nchikungunya virus infections are very rare, so one hopes that the\ncause of deaths in this outbreak in Cambodia are determined. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]\nSee Also\nsee also:\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n2009\n----\nChikungunya (13): Thailand (PU) 20090515.1818\nChikungunya (09): Thailand (SG) 20090429.1615\n.................................................jw/ty/ejp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1186683", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (06): India (West Bengal)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1186683", "date": "2012-05-19 17:13:32", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - CAMBODIA (02) COMMENT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nFrom: Fabio Napoletano [edited]\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n\n[Responding to ProMED/MBDS Dengue - Cambodia (04) 20120516.1119 posted on 16 May, identical to report published on this list today, 19 May. - ProMED]\n\nAs a non-medic travelling in Cambodia's countryside, I think the\nreports of infections are completely underestimating the pandemic\ncurrently going on.\n\nIn one village alone in the province of Preah Vihear I have counted at\nleast 700 cases of infections since January 2012.\n\nExtrapolate this to the whole province and you easily have 40 000 or\nmore cases of infections that will very soon occur also in the rest of\nthe country thanks to the newly built roads and increased movement of\npeople.\n\nMany strong men are unable to work due to month-long severe arthritis.\n\nPeople have died directly or indirectly.\n\n--\nFabio Napoletano\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Fabio Napoletano for providing his 1st-hand\nobservations. There is a clear need for health authorities to follow\nup on the outbreak that is going on, with epidemiological surveillance\nand good laboratory support.\n\nAlthough persistent athralgia is typical of chikungunya virus\ninfections, because the acute clinical signs of dengue and chikungunya\nare otherwise similar, laboratory diagnosis will be essential,\nespecially if fatalities are occurring. Reports of fatalities from\nchikungunya virus infections are very rare, so one hopes that the\ncause of deaths in this outbreak in Cambodia are determined. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]\nSee Also\nsee also:\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n2009\n----\nChikungunya (13): Thailand (PU) 20090515.1818\nChikungunya (09): Thailand (SG) 20090429.1615\n.................................................jw/ty/ejp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1138358", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya & dengue - Cambodia (02) comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1138358", "date": "2012-05-19 17:13:32", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA AND DENGUE - CAMBODIA (02) COMMENT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 May 2012\nFrom: Fabio Napoletano [edited]\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n\n[Responding to ProMED/MBDS Dengue - Cambodia (04) 20120516.1119 posted on 16 May, identical to report published on this list today, 19 May. - ProMED]\n\nAs a non-medic travelling in Cambodia's countryside, I think the\nreports of infections are completely underestimating the pandemic\ncurrently going on.\n\nIn one village alone in the province of Preah Vihear I have counted at\nleast 700 cases of infections since January 2012.\n\nExtrapolate this to the whole province and you easily have 40 000 or\nmore cases of infections that will very soon occur also in the rest of\nthe country thanks to the newly built roads and increased movement of\npeople.\n\nMany strong men are unable to work due to month-long severe arthritis.\n\nPeople have died directly or indirectly.\n\n--\nFabio Napoletano\n<fabio.napoletano@runbox.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Fabio Napoletano for providing his 1st-hand\nobservations. There is a clear need for health authorities to follow\nup on the outbreak that is going on, with epidemiological surveillance\nand good laboratory support.\n\nAlthough persistent athralgia is typical of chikungunya virus\ninfections, because the acute clinical signs of dengue and chikungunya\nare otherwise similar, laboratory diagnosis will be essential,\nespecially if fatalities are occurring. Reports of fatalities from\nchikungunya virus infections are very rare, so one hopes that the\ncause of deaths in this outbreak in Cambodia are determined. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1iGB.]\nSee Also\nsee also:\nChikungunya & dengue - Cambodia 20120519.1138336\n2009\n----\nChikungunya (13): Thailand (PU) 20090515.1818\nChikungunya (09): Thailand (SG) 20090429.1615\n.................................................jw/ty/ejp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1138336", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya & dengue - Cambodia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1138336", "date": "2012-01-11 20:10:51", "main_text": "DENGUE-CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS CO-INFECTIONS - INDIA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Jan 2012\nSource: Deccan Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/dengue-chikungunya-difficult-diagnosis-081\n\n\nCases of dengue-chikungunya [virus] co-infection are on the rise, causing concern to health planners and doctors. About 3 per cent of dengue-chikungunya cases fall under the co-infection category, with the patient suffering from both the diseases at the same time.\n\nIncidentally, the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito transmits both the dengue and the chikunguniya virus; chances of co-infection are higher if the mosquito carries the viruses of both the diseases. A detailed analysis of dengue and chikungunya cases by the department of microbiology, Sri Venkate-swara Institute of Medical Sciences, Tirupati has revealed that the problem of co-infection is more pronounced in areas where both viruses co-circulate.\n\nWhere co-infection strikes, doctors find it hard to diagnose the problem. Though symptoms of these diseases are common, their outcome differs. Tests for both dengue and chikungunya [virus infections] will help in finding whether a patient is suffering from one disease or both of them. Chikungunya is non-fatal, while dengue may lead to severe complications including death. The common symptoms of both the diseases include fever, joint and bone pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, and fatigue [However, acute joint pain that may persist for weeks or months is more characteristic of chikungunya virus infections. - Mod.TY].\n\nA team of researchers comprising Usha Kalawat, Krishna K. Sharma and G. Satishkumar Reddy analysed 331 samples for dengue and 170 samples for chikungunya [antibodies]. About 12 per cent of dengue samples and 20 per cent of chikungunya samples were positive. The team tested 72 samples for the presence of both dengue and chikungunya antibodies. About 3 per cent of these samples tested positive for both the diseases [virus infections].\n\n\"Areas affected by the chikungunya virus overlap with dengue fever-endemic areas and provide opportunities for mosquitoes to become infected with both the viruses,\" the team pointed out. They added that missing out signs of one disease is always plausible if diagnostic tests for both are not performed, and the presence of one does not rule out the other.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if individuals residing in areas where both dengue and chikungunya outbreaks are occurring were infected with both viruses as the authors of this study indicate. However, this study is based on the results of tests with commercial kits that measure IgM antibodies (see original article cited below).\n\nFirstly, it is necessary to show that the serological reactions observed were specific for dengue and chikungunya viruses. Serological tests with ELISA kits alone, without demonstration of virus presence by isolation or RT-PCR or confirmation by other, more specific serological tests, should be interpreted with caution. Serological cross reactions among different flaviviruses such as dengue, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus and others can further complicate interpretation of results. The USA CDC always confirms these types of positive serological test results with more virus-specific, 90 per cent plaque-reduction neutralization tests, which were not done in the above study.\n\nSecondly, IgM can persist for months or even beyond a year in some individuals following an acute dengue or chikungunya virus infection. The authors presume that because IgM was detected that reacted with both dengue and chikungunya virus antigens, those individuals were simultaneously infected with both viruses. That may not necessarily have been the case in all or even most of them. It is possible that some of these individuals in the above study were, in fact, infected with both dengue and chikungunya viruses but serially, not simultaneously. The authors of the study are correct in that both viruses should be considered when the clinical picture that they mention is observed. Mixed outbreaks can and do occur.\n\nReference for the original above report:\nKalawat U, Sharma KK, Reddy SG. Prevalence of dengue and chickungunya fever and their co-infection. Indian J Path Microbiol 2011. 54 (4):844-6. http://www.ijpmonline.org/article.asp?issn=0377-4929;year=2011;volume=54;issue=4;spage=844;epage=846;aulast=Kalawat.\n\nReferences for IgM persistence provided by Dr. Charles Calisher:\n\nDengue:\nPrince HE, Matud JL. Estimation of dengue virus IgM persistence using regression analysis. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2011 18(12):2183-5.\n\nNogueira RM, Miagostovich MP, Cavalcanti SM, Marzochi KB, Schatzmayr HG. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nOther flaviviruses:\nRoehrig JT, Nash D, Maldin B, Labowitz A, Martin DA, Lanciotti RS, Campbell GL. Persistence of virus-reactive serum immunoglobulin m antibody in confirmed West Nile virus encephalitis cases. Emerg Infect Dis. 2003 9(3):376-9.\n\nChikungunya:\nMalvy D, Ezzedine K, Mamani-Matsuda M, Autran B, Tolou H, Receveur MC, Pistone T, Rambert J, Moynet D, Mossalayi D. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nCalisher, C.H., A.O. El Kafrawi, M.I. Al D. Mahmud, A.P.A. Travassos da Rosa, C.R. Bartz, M. Brummer Korvenkontio, S. Haksohusodo, and W. Suharyono. Complex specific immunoglobulin M antibody patterns in humans infected with alphaviruses. J Clin Microbiol 1986 23:155-9.\n- Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH, http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH]\n\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2012-01-09 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "C.H.", "country": "Greenland"}, {"location": "El Kafrawi", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "M.I.", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "A.O.", "country": "Haiti"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Pistone", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1137577", "headline": "PRO> Chikungunya, dengue - Cambodia (02) comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1137577", "date": "2012-01-11 20:10:51", "main_text": "DENGUE-CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS CO-INFECTIONS - INDIA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Jan 2012\nSource: Deccan Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/dengue-chikungunya-difficult-diagnosis-081\n\n\nCases of dengue-chikungunya [virus] co-infection are on the rise, causing concern to health planners and doctors. About 3 per cent of dengue-chikungunya cases fall under the co-infection category, with the patient suffering from both the diseases at the same time.\n\nIncidentally, the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito transmits both the dengue and the chikunguniya virus; chances of co-infection are higher if the mosquito carries the viruses of both the diseases. A detailed analysis of dengue and chikungunya cases by the department of microbiology, Sri Venkate-swara Institute of Medical Sciences, Tirupati has revealed that the problem of co-infection is more pronounced in areas where both viruses co-circulate.\n\nWhere co-infection strikes, doctors find it hard to diagnose the problem. Though symptoms of these diseases are common, their outcome differs. Tests for both dengue and chikungunya [virus infections] will help in finding whether a patient is suffering from one disease or both of them. Chikungunya is non-fatal, while dengue may lead to severe complications including death. The common symptoms of both the diseases include fever, joint and bone pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, and fatigue [However, acute joint pain that may persist for weeks or months is more characteristic of chikungunya virus infections. - Mod.TY].\n\nA team of researchers comprising Usha Kalawat, Krishna K. Sharma and G. Satishkumar Reddy analysed 331 samples for dengue and 170 samples for chikungunya [antibodies]. About 12 per cent of dengue samples and 20 per cent of chikungunya samples were positive. The team tested 72 samples for the presence of both dengue and chikungunya antibodies. About 3 per cent of these samples tested positive for both the diseases [virus infections].\n\n\"Areas affected by the chikungunya virus overlap with dengue fever-endemic areas and provide opportunities for mosquitoes to become infected with both the viruses,\" the team pointed out. They added that missing out signs of one disease is always plausible if diagnostic tests for both are not performed, and the presence of one does not rule out the other.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if individuals residing in areas where both dengue and chikungunya outbreaks are occurring were infected with both viruses as the authors of this study indicate. However, this study is based on the results of tests with commercial kits that measure IgM antibodies (see original article cited below).\n\nFirstly, it is necessary to show that the serological reactions observed were specific for dengue and chikungunya viruses. Serological tests with ELISA kits alone, without demonstration of virus presence by isolation or RT-PCR or confirmation by other, more specific serological tests, should be interpreted with caution. Serological cross reactions among different flaviviruses such as dengue, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus and others can further complicate interpretation of results. The USA CDC always confirms these types of positive serological test results with more virus-specific, 90 per cent plaque-reduction neutralization tests, which were not done in the above study.\n\nSecondly, IgM can persist for months or even beyond a year in some individuals following an acute dengue or chikungunya virus infection. The authors presume that because IgM was detected that reacted with both dengue and chikungunya virus antigens, those individuals were simultaneously infected with both viruses. That may not necessarily have been the case in all or even most of them. It is possible that some of these individuals in the above study were, in fact, infected with both dengue and chikungunya viruses but serially, not simultaneously. The authors of the study are correct in that both viruses should be considered when the clinical picture that they mention is observed. Mixed outbreaks can and do occur.\n\nReference for the original above report:\nKalawat U, Sharma KK, Reddy SG. Prevalence of dengue and chickungunya fever and their co-infection. Indian J Path Microbiol 2011. 54 (4):844-6. http://www.ijpmonline.org/article.asp?issn=0377-4929;year=2011;volume=54;issue=4;spage=844;epage=846;aulast=Kalawat.\n\nReferences for IgM persistence provided by Dr. Charles Calisher:\n\nDengue:\nPrince HE, Matud JL. Estimation of dengue virus IgM persistence using regression analysis. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2011 18(12):2183-5.\n\nNogueira RM, Miagostovich MP, Cavalcanti SM, Marzochi KB, Schatzmayr HG. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nOther flaviviruses:\nRoehrig JT, Nash D, Maldin B, Labowitz A, Martin DA, Lanciotti RS, Campbell GL. Persistence of virus-reactive serum immunoglobulin m antibody in confirmed West Nile virus encephalitis cases. Emerg Infect Dis. 2003 9(3):376-9.\n\nChikungunya:\nMalvy D, Ezzedine K, Mamani-Matsuda M, Autran B, Tolou H, Receveur MC, Pistone T, Rambert J, Moynet D, Mossalayi D. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nCalisher, C.H., A.O. El Kafrawi, M.I. Al D. Mahmud, A.P.A. Travassos da Rosa, C.R. Bartz, M. Brummer Korvenkontio, S. Haksohusodo, and W. Suharyono. Complex specific immunoglobulin M antibody patterns in humans infected with alphaviruses. J Clin Microbiol 1986 23:155-9.\n- Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH, http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH]\n\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2012-01-09 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "C.H.", "country": "Greenland"}, {"location": "El Kafrawi", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "M.I.", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "A.O.", "country": "Haiti"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Pistone", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1134161", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Chikungunya & dengue - Cambodia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1134161", "date": "2012-01-11 20:10:51", "main_text": "DENGUE-CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS CO-INFECTIONS - INDIA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Jan 2012\nSource: Deccan Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/dengue-chikungunya-difficult-diagnosis-081\n\n\nCases of dengue-chikungunya [virus] co-infection are on the rise, causing concern to health planners and doctors. About 3 per cent of dengue-chikungunya cases fall under the co-infection category, with the patient suffering from both the diseases at the same time.\n\nIncidentally, the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito transmits both the dengue and the chikunguniya virus; chances of co-infection are higher if the mosquito carries the viruses of both the diseases. A detailed analysis of dengue and chikungunya cases by the department of microbiology, Sri Venkate-swara Institute of Medical Sciences, Tirupati has revealed that the problem of co-infection is more pronounced in areas where both viruses co-circulate.\n\nWhere co-infection strikes, doctors find it hard to diagnose the problem. Though symptoms of these diseases are common, their outcome differs. Tests for both dengue and chikungunya [virus infections] will help in finding whether a patient is suffering from one disease or both of them. Chikungunya is non-fatal, while dengue may lead to severe complications including death. The common symptoms of both the diseases include fever, joint and bone pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, and fatigue [However, acute joint pain that may persist for weeks or months is more characteristic of chikungunya virus infections. - Mod.TY].\n\nA team of researchers comprising Usha Kalawat, Krishna K. Sharma and G. Satishkumar Reddy analysed 331 samples for dengue and 170 samples for chikungunya [antibodies]. About 12 per cent of dengue samples and 20 per cent of chikungunya samples were positive. The team tested 72 samples for the presence of both dengue and chikungunya antibodies. About 3 per cent of these samples tested positive for both the diseases [virus infections].\n\n\"Areas affected by the chikungunya virus overlap with dengue fever-endemic areas and provide opportunities for mosquitoes to become infected with both the viruses,\" the team pointed out. They added that missing out signs of one disease is always plausible if diagnostic tests for both are not performed, and the presence of one does not rule out the other.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if individuals residing in areas where both dengue and chikungunya outbreaks are occurring were infected with both viruses as the authors of this study indicate. However, this study is based on the results of tests with commercial kits that measure IgM antibodies (see original article cited below).\n\nFirstly, it is necessary to show that the serological reactions observed were specific for dengue and chikungunya viruses. Serological tests with ELISA kits alone, without demonstration of virus presence by isolation or RT-PCR or confirmation by other, more specific serological tests, should be interpreted with caution. Serological cross reactions among different flaviviruses such as dengue, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus and others can further complicate interpretation of results. The USA CDC always confirms these types of positive serological test results with more virus-specific, 90 per cent plaque-reduction neutralization tests, which were not done in the above study.\n\nSecondly, IgM can persist for months or even beyond a year in some individuals following an acute dengue or chikungunya virus infection. The authors presume that because IgM was detected that reacted with both dengue and chikungunya virus antigens, those individuals were simultaneously infected with both viruses. That may not necessarily have been the case in all or even most of them. It is possible that some of these individuals in the above study were, in fact, infected with both dengue and chikungunya viruses but serially, not simultaneously. The authors of the study are correct in that both viruses should be considered when the clinical picture that they mention is observed. Mixed outbreaks can and do occur.\n\nReference for the original above report:\nKalawat U, Sharma KK, Reddy SG. Prevalence of dengue and chickungunya fever and their co-infection. Indian J Path Microbiol 2011. 54 (4):844-6. http://www.ijpmonline.org/article.asp?issn=0377-4929;year=2011;volume=54;issue=4;spage=844;epage=846;aulast=Kalawat.\n\nReferences for IgM persistence provided by Dr. Charles Calisher:\n\nDengue:\nPrince HE, Matud JL. Estimation of dengue virus IgM persistence using regression analysis. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2011 18(12):2183-5.\n\nNogueira RM, Miagostovich MP, Cavalcanti SM, Marzochi KB, Schatzmayr HG. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nOther flaviviruses:\nRoehrig JT, Nash D, Maldin B, Labowitz A, Martin DA, Lanciotti RS, Campbell GL. Persistence of virus-reactive serum immunoglobulin m antibody in confirmed West Nile virus encephalitis cases. Emerg Infect Dis. 2003 9(3):376-9.\n\nChikungunya:\nMalvy D, Ezzedine K, Mamani-Matsuda M, Autran B, Tolou H, Receveur MC, Pistone T, Rambert J, Moynet D, Mossalayi D. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nCalisher, C.H., A.O. El Kafrawi, M.I. Al D. Mahmud, A.P.A. Travassos da Rosa, C.R. Bartz, M. Brummer Korvenkontio, S. Haksohusodo, and W. Suharyono. Complex specific immunoglobulin M antibody patterns in humans infected with alphaviruses. J Clin Microbiol 1986 23:155-9.\n- Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH, http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH]\n\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2012-01-09 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "C.H.", "country": "Greenland"}, {"location": "El Kafrawi", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "M.I.", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "A.O.", "country": "Haiti"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Pistone", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1132124", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (05): India (OR):", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1132124", "date": "2012-01-11 20:10:51", "main_text": "DENGUE-CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS CO-INFECTIONS - INDIA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Jan 2012\nSource: Deccan Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/dengue-chikungunya-difficult-diagnosis-081\n\n\nCases of dengue-chikungunya [virus] co-infection are on the rise, causing concern to health planners and doctors. About 3 per cent of dengue-chikungunya cases fall under the co-infection category, with the patient suffering from both the diseases at the same time.\n\nIncidentally, the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito transmits both the dengue and the chikunguniya virus; chances of co-infection are higher if the mosquito carries the viruses of both the diseases. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nCalisher, C.H., A.O. El Kafrawi, M.I. Al D. Mahmud, A.P.A. Travassos da Rosa, C.R. Bartz, M. Brummer Korvenkontio, S. Haksohusodo, and W. Suharyono. Complex specific immunoglobulin M antibody patterns in humans infected with alphaviruses. J Clin Microbiol 1986 23:155-9.\n- Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH, http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH]\n\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2012-01-09 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "C.H.", "country": "Greenland"}, {"location": "El Kafrawi", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "M.I.", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "A.O.", "country": "Haiti"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Pistone", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1015835", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (02): Mauritius", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1015835", "date": "2012-01-11 20:10:51", "main_text": "DENGUE-CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS CO-INFECTIONS - INDIA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Jan 2012\nSource: Deccan Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/dengue-chikungunya-difficult-diagnosis-081\n\n\nCases of dengue-chikungunya [virus] co-infection are on the rise, causing concern to health planners and doctors. About 3 per cent of dengue-chikungunya cases fall under the co-infection category, with the patient suffering from both the diseases at the same time.\n\nIncidentally, the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito transmits both the dengue and the chikunguniya virus; chances of co-infection are higher if the mosquito carries the viruses of both the diseases. A detailed analysis of dengue and chikungunya cases by the department of microbiology, Sri Venkate-swara Institute of Medical Sciences, Tirupati has revealed that the problem of co-infection is more pronounced in areas where both viruses co-circulate.\n\nWhere co-infection strikes, doctors find it hard to diagnose the problem. Though symptoms of these diseases are common, their outcome differs. Tests for both dengue and chikungunya [virus infections] will help in finding whether a patient is suffering from one disease or both of them. Chikungunya is non-fatal, while dengue may lead to severe complications including death. The common symptoms of both the diseases include fever, joint and bone pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, and fatigue [However, acute joint pain that may persist for weeks or months is more characteristic of chikungunya virus infections. - Mod.TY].\n\nA team of researchers comprising Usha Kalawat, Krishna K. Sharma and G. Satishkumar Reddy analysed 331 samples for dengue and 170 samples for chikungunya [antibodies]. About 12 per cent of dengue samples and 20 per cent of chikungunya samples were positive. The team tested 72 samples for the presence of both dengue and chikungunya antibodies. About 3 per cent of these samples tested positive for both the diseases [virus infections].\n\n\"Areas affected by the chikungunya virus overlap with dengue fever-endemic areas and provide opportunities for mosquitoes to become infected with both the viruses,\" the team pointed out. They added that missing out signs of one disease is always plausible if diagnostic tests for both are not performed, and the presence of one does not rule out the other.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if individuals residing in areas where both dengue and chikungunya outbreaks are occurring were infected with both viruses as the authors of this study indicate. However, this study is based on the results of tests with commercial kits that measure IgM antibodies (see original article cited below).\n\nFirstly, it is necessary to show that the serological reactions observed were specific for dengue and chikungunya viruses. Serological tests with ELISA kits alone, without demonstration of virus presence by isolation or RT-PCR or confirmation by other, more specific serological tests, should be interpreted with caution. Serological cross reactions among different flaviviruses such as dengue, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus and others can further complicate interpretation of results. The USA CDC always confirms these types of positive serological test results with more virus-specific, 90 per cent plaque-reduction neutralization tests, which were not done in the above study.\n\nSecondly, IgM can persist for months or even beyond a year in some individuals following an acute dengue or chikungunya virus infection. The authors presume that because IgM was detected that reacted with both dengue and chikungunya virus antigens, those individuals were simultaneously infected with both viruses. That may not necessarily have been the case in all or even most of them. It is possible that some of these individuals in the above study were, in fact, infected with both dengue and chikungunya viruses but serially, not simultaneously. The authors of the study are correct in that both viruses should be considered when the clinical picture that they mention is observed. Mixed outbreaks can and do occur.\n\nReference for the original above report:\nKalawat U, Sharma KK, Reddy SG. Prevalence of dengue and chickungunya fever and their co-infection. Indian J Path Microbiol 2011. 54 (4):844-6. http://www.ijpmonline.org/article.asp?issn=0377-4929;year=2011;volume=54;issue=4;spage=844;epage=846;aulast=Kalawat.\n\nReferences for IgM persistence provided by Dr. Charles Calisher:\n\nDengue:\nPrince HE, Matud JL. Estimation of dengue virus IgM persistence using regression analysis. Clin Vaccine Immunol. 2011 18(12):2183-5.\n\nNogueira RM, Miagostovich MP, Cavalcanti SM, Marzochi KB, Schatzmayr HG. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nOther flaviviruses:\nRoehrig JT, Nash D, Maldin B, Labowitz A, Martin DA, Lanciotti RS, Campbell GL. Persistence of virus-reactive serum immunoglobulin m antibody in confirmed West Nile virus encephalitis cases. Emerg Infect Dis. 2003 9(3):376-9.\n\nChikungunya:\nMalvy D, Ezzedine K, Mamani-Matsuda M, Autran B, Tolou H, Receveur MC, Pistone T, Rambert J, Moynet D, Mossalayi D. Levels of IgM antibodies against dengue virus in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Res Virol. 1992 143(6):423-7.\n\nCalisher, C.H., A.O. El Kafrawi, M.I. Al D. Mahmud, A.P.A. Travassos da Rosa, C.R. Bartz, M. Brummer Korvenkontio, S. Haksohusodo, and W. Suharyono. Complex specific immunoglobulin M antibody patterns in humans infected with alphaviruses. J Clin Microbiol 1986 23:155-9.\n- Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH, http://healthmap.org/r/1pSH]\n\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2012-01-09 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "C.H.", "country": "Greenland"}, {"location": "El Kafrawi", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "M.I.", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "A.O.", "country": "Haiti"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Pistone", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Rio de Janeiro", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1007483", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Dengue-chikungunya virus co-infections - India", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1007483", "date": "2012-01-11 20:10:51", "main_text": "DENGUE-CHIKUNGUNYA VIRUS CO-INFECTIONS - INDIA\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Jan 2012\nSource: Deccan Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/hyderabad/dengue-chikungunya-difficult-diagnosis-081\n\n\nCases of dengue-chikungunya [virus] co-infection are on the rise, causing concern to health planners and doctors. About 3 per cent of dengue-chikungunya cases fall under the co-infection category, with the patient suffering from both the diseases at the same time.\n\nIncidentally, the same _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito transmits both the dengue and the chikunguniya virus; chances of co-infection are higher if the mosquito carries the viruses of both the diseases. A detailed analysis of dengue and chikungunya cases by the department of microbiology, Sri Venkate-swara Institute of Medical Sciences, Tirupati has revealed that the problem of co-infection is more pronounced in areas where both viruses co-circulate.\n\nWhere co-infection strikes, doctors find it hard to diagnose the problem. Tests for both dengue and chikungunya [virus infections] will help in finding whether a patient is suffering from one disease or both of them. Chikungunya is non-fatal, while dengue may lead to severe complications including death. The common symptoms of both the diseases include fever, joint and bone pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, and fatigue [However, acute joint pain that may persist for weeks or months is more characteristic of chikungunya virus infections. - Mod.TY].\n\nA team of researchers comprising Usha Kalawat, Krishna K. Sharma and G. Satishkumar Reddy analysed 331 samples for dengue and 170 samples for chikungunya [antibodies]. About 12 per cent of dengue samples and 20 per cent of chikungunya samples were positive. The team tested 72 samples for the presence of both dengue and chikungunya antibodies. About 3 per cent of these samples tested positive for both the diseases [virus infections].\n\n\"Areas affected by the chikungunya virus overlap with dengue fever-endemic areas and provide opportunities for mosquitoes to become infected with both the viruses,\" the team pointed out. They added that missing out signs of one disease is always plausible if diagnostic tests for both are not performed, and the presence of one does not rule out the other.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It would not be surprising if individuals residing in areas where both dengue and chikungunya outbreaks are occurring were infected with both viruses as the authors of this study indicate. Serological tests with ELISA kits alone, without demonstration of virus presence by isolation or RT-PCR or confirmation by other, more specific serological tests, should be interpreted with caution. Serological cross reactions among different flaviviruses such as dengue, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus and others can further complicate interpretation of results. The USA CDC always confirms these types of positive serological test results with more virus-specific, 90 per cent plaque-reduction neutralization tests, which were not done in the above study.\n\nSecondly, IgM can persist for months or even beyond a year in some individuals following an acute dengue or chikungunya virus infection. The authors presume that because IgM was detected that reacted with both dengue and chikungunya virus antigens, those individuals were simultaneously infected with both viruses. That may not necessarily have been the case in all or even most of them. It is possible that some of these individuals in the above study were, in fact, infected with both dengue and chikungunya viruses but serially, not simultaneously. It is the\n[virus that] causes chikungunya where the sufferer is almost\nparalyzed. As of the date of this news release [11 Nov 2011], there\nare 2 people who suffer from this disease in the area immediately\nadjacent to the City of Bukittinggi. \"But thanks to the infected\nindividuals having been rapidly brought to Achmad Mochtar Hospital\n(RSAM) Bukittinggi, the threat of paralysis had been anticipated.\nReportedly the victim is recovering,\" said Pakoan Youth Chairman, Jon\nSutan Longhouse, to Padang Express, yesterday (10 Nov 2011). He said\nthe Agam District Health Office went to the field to conduct spraying\nfogging last Tuesday (8 Nov 2011).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There was an apparent (but later not confirmed), significant focal\noutbreak of chikungunya virus infection in Central Java province. Not\nsurprisingly, no fatalities are reported in that outbreak or in the\none above, as is the case in nearly all chikungunya outbreaks.\nMorbidity may be significant, and incapacitating arthralgia may\npersist for weeks or months in convalescent individuals. Reports of\nchikungunya infections often indicate that the patient is paralyzed.\nIn reality, rather than paralysis, the patient may have arthralgia so\nsevere that they are reluctant to move because of this joint pain. The\noriginal report above indicated that this area is having a mixed\noutbreak involving both dengue and chikungunya viruses.\n\nAgam is a regency of West Sumatra, Indonesia. It has an area of\n2232.30 sq km (862 sq mi) and a population of approximately 419 800\npeople. Tilatang Kamang is one of 15 subdistricts in this regency. A\nmap of the Agam regency can be accessed at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Sumatra.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of West\nSumatra can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1r3h. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Indonesia (CJ) 20111023.3158\nChikungunya (05): New Caledonia ex Indonesia 20110226.0631\n2010\n----\nChikungunya (33): Brazil ex "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (33): India (KE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=986625", "date": "2011-11-16 11:18:54", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (27): INDONESIA (WEST SUMATRA)\n******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: Padang Express [in Indonesian, machine trans.; summ., &\nedited]\nhttp://padangekspres.co.id/?news=berita&id=16666\n\n\nIn the area of Pakoan, Gulaibancah, Kenagarian Gadut, Tilatang Kamang\nsubdistrict, Agam regency, a disease attacked the area. It is the\n[virus that] causes chikungunya where the sufferer is almost\nparalyzed. As of the date of this news release [11 Nov 2011], there\nare 2 people who suffer from this disease in the area immediately\nadjacent to the City of Bukittinggi. \"But thanks to the infected\nindividuals having been rapidly brought to Achmad Mochtar Hospital\n(RSAM) Bukittinggi, the threat of paralysis had been anticipated.\nReportedly the victim is recovering,\" said Pakoan Youth Chairman, Jon\nSutan Longhouse, to Padang Express, yesterday (10 Nov 2011). He said\nthe Agam District Health Office went to the field to conduct spraying\nfogging last Tuesday (8 Nov 2011).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There was an apparent (but later not confirmed), significant focal\noutbreak of chikungunya virus infection in Central Java province. Not\nsurprisingly, no fatalities are reported in that outbreak or in the\none above, as is the case in nearly all chikungunya outbreaks.\nMorbidity may be significant, and incapacitating arthralgia may\npersist for weeks or months in convalescent individuals. Reports of\nchikungunya infections often indicate that the patient is paralyzed.\nIn reality, rather than paralysis, the patient may have arthralgia so\nsevere that they are reluctant to move because of this joint pain. The\noriginal report above indicated that this area is having a mixed\noutbreak involving both dengue and chikungunya viruses.\n\nAgam is a regency of West Sumatra, Indonesia. It has an area of\n2232.30 sq km (862 sq mi) and a population of approximately 419 800\npeople. Tilatang Kamang is one of 15 subdistricts in this regency. A\nmap of the Agam regency can be accessed at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Sumatra.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of West\nSumatra can be accessed at "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2011-11-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "RSAM", "country": "Yemen"}, {"location": "Pakoan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gulaibancah", "country": "unknown"}, "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (31): India (GA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=962863", "date": "2011-11-16 11:18:54", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (27): INDONESIA (WEST SUMATRA)\n******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: Padang Express [in Indonesian, machine trans.; summ., &\nedited]\nhttp://padangekspres.co.id/?news=berita&id=16666\n\n\nIn the area of Pakoan, Gulaibancah, Kenagarian Gadut, Tilatang Kamang\nsubdistrict, Agam regency, a disease attacked the area. It is the\n[virus that] causes chikungunya where the sufferer is almost\nparalyzed. As of the date of this news release [11 Nov 2011], there\nare 2 people who suffer from this disease in the area immediately\nadjacent to the City of Bukittinggi. \"But thanks to the infected\nindividuals having been rapidly brought to Achmad Mochtar Hospital\n(RSAM) Bukittinggi, the threat of paralysis had been anticipated.\nReportedly the victim is recovering,\" said Pakoan Youth Chairman, Jon\nSutan Longhouse, to Padang Express, yesterday (10 Nov 2011). He said\nthe Agam District Health Office went to the field to conduct spraying\nfogging last Tuesday (8 Nov 2011).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There was an apparent (but later not confirmed), significant focal\noutbreak of chikungunya virus infection in Central Java province. Not\nsurprisingly, no fatalities are reported in that outbreak or in the\none above, as is the case in nearly all chikungunya outbreaks.\nMorbidity may be significant, and incapacitating arthralgia may\npersist for weeks or months in convalescent individuals. Reports of\nchikungunya infections often indicate that the patient is paralyzed.\nIn reality, rather than paralysis, the patient may have arthralgia so\nsevere that they are reluctant to move because of this joint pain. The\noriginal report above indicated that this area is having a mixed\noutbreak involving both dengue and chikungunya viruses.\n\nAgam is a regency of West Sumatra, Indonesia. It has an area of\n2232.30 sq km (862 sq mi) and a population of approximately 419 800\npeople. Tilatang Kamang is one of 15 subdistricts in this regency. A\nmap of the Agam regency can be accessed at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Sumatra.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of West\nSumatra can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1r3h. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (22): Indonesia (CJ) 20111023.3158\nChikungunya (05): New Caledonia ex Indonesia 20110226.0631\n2010\n----\nChikungunya (33): Brazil ex "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (53): Malaysia (Kedah)"}, {"archive_id": "137304", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (52): Malaysia (KH)"}, {"archive_id": "136657", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (51): Malaysia (KH), susp"}, {"archive_id": "135505", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (50): Indonesia: (JT)"}, {"archive_id": "130583", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (49): Indonesia (RI)"}, {"archive_id": "128724", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya (48): Indonesia (JT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=128724", "date": "2008-10-02 23:57:34", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (41): INDIA (WEST BENGAL)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Oct 2008\nSource: The Statesman [edited]\n<http://www.thestatesman.net/page.arcview.php?clid=22&id=251793&usrsess=1>\n\n\nHowrah district [West Bengal state] health administration have\ndetected chikungunya virus in the blood samples of 8 people in\nBaigachi of Howrah district today [1 Oct 2008]. More than 200\nresidents of Baigachi and its adjacent villages have been suffering\nfrom fever and severe throat pain since 18 Sep [2008].\n\nAccording to the district health department officials, following the\nspread of the disease, experts from the state health administration\nvisited the affected areas and collected blood samples and serum from\nneighbours of the affected people.\n\nAccording to the chief medical officer, health (CMOH), Howrah, Dr\nDilip Deb: \"Blood samples of 10 people in Baigachi were taken and the\ndistrict health officials have confirmed that chikungunya [virus?\nantibody? - Mod.TY] has been found in the blood samples of 8 people.\nAll sorts of medical aid are being provided.\" He further added that\nthe health department has set up a temporary health care centre at\nBaigachi and have started an awareness programme in the area.\n\nThe block administration has initiated a drive to control the\nbreeding of mosquitoes. Medicines are also being distributed among\nthe villagers. The local primary health centre has been asked to stay\non alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Satadal Das, MD, DCP\nConsultant Microbiologist\nPeerless Hospital & BK Roy Research Centre\n76 Satyen Roy Road\nKolkata 700034\nIndia\n<drsatdas@hotmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Das for forwarding this article. Interestingly, the\narticle also states that there were a few dengue virus infections\noccurring at the same time, illustrating the need for laboratory\ndiagnosis to distinguish between these 2 arthropod-borne virus\ninfections.\n\nA map of India showing the location of West Bengal state can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>\nand a map of West Bengal state showing the location of Howrah\nDistrict can be accessed at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howrah_District>\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=1270396&v=22.9,79.6,5>. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (40): India 20080923.3010\nChikungunya (32): India (Karnataka) 20080810.2463\nChikungunya (27): India (Kerala), susp., RFI 20080711.2114\nChikungunya (25): India (Karataka, Kerala) 20080628.1986\nChikungunya (24): India (Karnataka) 20080626.1969\nChikungunya (21): India (Karnataka), RFI 20080527.1723\nChikungunya (20): India (Karnataka) 20080523.1697\nChikungunya (19): India (Karnataka) 20080520.1673\nChikungunya (18): Singapore ex Indonesia, India (Kerala) 20080508.1576\nChikungunya (16): India (Karnataka), Sri Lanka RFI 20080504.1524\nChikungunya (12): India (Karnataka) 20080417.1377\nChikungunya (11): India (Kerala) 20080409.1307\nChikungunya, 2006 - India, excess deaths 20080304.0895\nChikungunya - India: (West Bengal) 20080102.0013\n2007\n----\nChikungunya (05): India (KA), RFI 20071222.4113\n........................................jw/ty/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. BENGAL)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Oct 2008\nSource: The Statesman [edited]\n<http://www.thestatesman.net/page.arcview.php?clid=22&id=251793&usrsess=1>\n\n\nHowrah district [West Bengal state] health administration have\ndetected chikungunya virus in the blood samples of 8 people in\nBaigachi of Howrah district today [1 Oct 2008]. More than 200\nresidents of Baigachi and its adjacent villages have been suffering\nfrom fever and severe throat pain since 18 Sep [2008].\n\nAccording to the district health department officials, following the\nspread of the disease, experts from the state health administration\nvisited the affected areas and collected blood samples and serum from\nneighbours of the affected people.\n\nAccording to the chief medical officer, health (CMOH), Howrah, Dr\nDilip Deb: \"Blood samples of 10 people in Baigachi were taken and the\ndistrict health officials have confirmed that chikungunya [virus?\nantibody? - Mod.TY] has been found in the blood samples of 8 people.\nAll sorts of medical aid are being provided.\" He further added that\nthe health department has set up a temporary health care centre at\nBaigachi and have started an awareness programme in the area.\n\nThe block administration has initiated a drive to control the\nbreeding of mosquitoes. Medicines are also being distributed among\nthe villagers. The local primary health centre has been asked to stay\non alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Satadal Das, MD, DCP\nConsultant Microbiologist\nPeerless Hospital & BK Roy Research Centre\n76 Satyen Roy Road\nKolkata 700034\nIndia\n<drsatdas@hotmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Das for forwarding this article. Interestingly, the\narticle also states that there were a few dengue virus infections\noccurring at the same time, illustrating the need for laboratory\ndiagnosis to distinguish between these 2 arthropod-borne virus\ninfections.\n\nA map of India showing the location of West Bengal state can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>\nand a map of West Bengal state showing the location of Howrah\nDistrict can be accessed at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howrah_District>\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=1270396&v=22.9,79.6,5>. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya (40): India 20080923.3010\nChikungunya (32): India (Karnataka) 20080810.2463\nChikungunya (27): India (Kerala), susp., RFI 20080711.2114\nChikungunya (25): India (Karataka, Kerala) 20080628.1986\nChikungunya (24): India (Karnataka) 20080626.1969\nChikungunya (21): India (Karnataka), RFI 20080527.1723\nChikungunya (20): India (Karnataka) 20080523.1697\nChikungunya (19): India (Karnataka) 20080520.1673\nChikungunya (18): Singapore ex Indonesia, India (Kerala) 20080508.1576\nChikungunya (16): India (Karnataka), Sri Lanka RFI 20080504.1524\nChikungunya (12): India (Karnataka) 20080417.1377\nChikungunya (11): India (Kerala) 20080409.1307\nChikungunya, 2006 - India, excess deaths 20080304.0895\nChikungunya - India: (West Bengal) 20080102.0013\n2007\n----\nChikungunya (05): India (KA), RFI 20071222.4113\n........................................jw/ty/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Sumatra), India (W. Bengal)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=120008", "date": "2008-10-02 23:57:34", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (41): INDIA (WEST BENGAL)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Oct 2008\nSource: The Statesman [edited]\n<http://www.thestatesman.net/page.arcview.php?clid=22&id=251793&usrsess=1>\n\n\nHowrah district [West Bengal state] health administration have\ndetected chikungunya virus in the blood samples of 8 people in\nBaigachi of Howrah district today [1 Oct 2008]. More than 200\nresidents of Baigachi and its adjacent villages have been suffering\nfrom fever and severe throat pain since 18 Sep [2008].\n\nAccording to the district health department officials, following the\nspread of the disease, experts from the state health administration\nvisited the affected areas and collected blood samples and serum from\nneighbours of the affected people.\n\nAccording to the chief medical officer, health (CMOH), Howrah, Dr\nDilip Deb: \"Blood samples of 10 people in Baigachi were taken and the\ndistrict health officials have confirmed that chikungunya [virus?\nantibody? - Mod.TY] has been found in the blood samples of 8 people.\nAll sorts of medical aid are being provided.\" He further added that\nthe health department has set up a temporary health care centre at\nBaigachi and have started an awareness programme in the area.\n\nThe block administration has initiated a drive to control the\nbreeding of mosquitoes. Medicines are also being distributed among\nthe villagers. The local primary health centre has been asked to stay\non alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Satadal Das, MD, DCP\nConsultant Microbiologist\nPeerless Hospital & BK Roy Research Centre\n76 Satyen Roy Road\nKolkata 700034\nIndia\n<drsatdas@hotmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Das for forwarding this article. Medicines are also being distributed among\nthe villagers. Chikungunya (41): India (WB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=116298", "date": "2008-10-02 23:57:34", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA (41): INDIA (WEST BENGAL)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Oct 2008\nSource: The Statesman [edited]\n<http://www.thestatesman.net/page.arcview.php?clid=22&id=251793&usrsess=1>\n\n\nHowrah district [West Bengal state] health administration have\ndetected chikungunya virus in the blood samples of 8 people in\nBaigachi of Howrah district today [1 Oct 2008]. More than 200\nresidents of Baigachi and its adjacent villages have been suffering\nfrom fever and severe throat pain since 18 Sep [2008].\n\nAccording to the district health department officials, following the\nspread of the disease, experts from the state health administration\nvisited the affected areas and collected blood samples and serum from\nneighbours of the affected people.\n\nAccording to the chief medical officer, health (CMOH), Howrah, Dr\nDilip Deb: \"Blood samples of 10 people in Baigachi were taken and the\ndistrict health officials have confirmed that chikungunya [virus?\nantibody? - Mod.TY] has been found in the blood samples of 8 people.\nAll sorts of medical aid are being provided.\" He further added that\nthe health department has set up a temporary health care centre at\nBaigachi and have started an awareness programme in the area.\n\nThe block administration has initiated a drive to control the\nbreeding of mosquitoes. Medicines are also being distributed among\nthe villagers. The local primary health centre has been asked to stay\non alert.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Satadal Das, MD, DCP\nConsultant Microbiologist\nPeerless Hospital & BK Roy Research Centre\n76 Satyen Roy Road\nKolkata 700034\nIndia\n<drsatdas@hotmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Das for forwarding this article. INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (24): INDIA (JAIPUR), SUSPECTED,\nREQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 3 Sep 2007\nSource: Newindpress.com [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/NewsItems.asp?ID=IEQ20070902214600&Title=ORISSA&rLink=0>\n\nWith 8 more cases reported on Sunday [2 Sep 2007], the number of\nchikungunya cases in Mugpal Kelasahi village in Jaipur district has reached 91.\nOver 50 affected persons are still undergoing treatment in various\nhospitals. However, no deaths have been reported so far.\nOn Saturday [1 Sep 2007], a team of doctors rushed to the village to\ncollect the blood sample of those affected. The samples have been\nsent to Indian Council of Medical Research, Bhubaneswar for examination.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[If this outbreak is confirmed as due to chikungunya virus infection,\nthen the outbreak of this viral disease continues in India. There is\nno indication of mosquito vector control measures being taken in this\nbrief report. ProMED-mail requests further information as laboratory\ntest results become available.\nAn interactive map of the Jaipur District, showing location of\nvillages and the location of the district within India can be accessed at:\n<http://maps.google.com/maps?q=Jaipur,+Rajasthan,+India&sa=X&oi=map&ct=title>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (22): India (West Bengal) 20070815.2671\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (21): India (Calcutta) 20070807.2568\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (20): India (Kerala) 20070804.2536\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (19): India (Kerala) 20070724.2380\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (18): India (Kerala): confirmed 20070723.2365\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (17): India (Delhi) 20070722.2355\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (16): India (Kerala) 20070718.2305\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (15): India (Kerala) 20070717.2296\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (14): India (Kerala) 20070712.2235\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (13): India (Kerala) 20070621.2008\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (11): India (Kerala) 20070531.1757\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Orissa): susp. 20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vadodara) susp. 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India, Islands 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\n...................................dk/ty/mj/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Other reports\ncame in from Kesavappuram, Manamboor, Vizhinjam, Perumkadavila,\nVellarada, Neyyattinkara and Nedumangad. Suspected chikungunya cases\nare being reported frequently from Peroorkada area.\nThe outpatient clinic at Peroorkada Government hospital has been very\ncrowded in the past few weeks [8-21 Jul 2007] with fever patients.\nHowever, the hospital authorities had not been sending the stipulated\nnumber of blood samples daily for analysis. The Central team members\nwho had visited the hospital sought an explanation for this from the\ndistrict health administration. Blood samples are now being sent from\nthe hospital and a few suspected and confirmed cases of chikungunya\nhave been reported from Peroorkada.\nA section of the doctors are worried about the sustained pattern of\nviral fever incidence and the fact that chicken pox cases are also\nbeing reported now, during the rainy season.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previous reports of febrile cases of chikungunya, as well as fevers\ncaused by other etiological agents, continues with this report.\nChikungunya virus transmission can be reduced by vigorous _Aedes_\nmosquito control. Confirmed laboratory diagnosis is critical to know\nto what extent chikungunya virus infection is responsible for these\ncases, in order to mount an effective control campaign.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand a map of Kerala, showing districts, at:\n<http://www.naturemagics.com/kerala-maps/kerala-map.shtm>. - Mod.TY.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (18): India (Kerala):\nconfirmed 20070723.2365\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (17): India (Delhi) 20070722.2355\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (16): India (Kerala) 20070718.2305\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (15): India (Kerala) 20070717.2296\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (14): India (Kerala) 20070712.2235\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (13): India (Kerala) 20070621.2008\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (11): India (Kerala) 20070531.1757\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Orissa): susp. 20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vadodara) susp. 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India, Islands 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\n...................................dk/ty/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Other reports\ncame in from Kesavappuram, Manamboor, Vizhinjam, Perumkadavila,\nVellarada, Neyyattinkara and Nedumangad. Suspected chikungunya cases\nare being reported frequently from Peroorkada area.\nThe outpatient clinic at Peroorkada Government hospital has been very\ncrowded in the past few weeks [8-21 Jul 2007] with fever patients.\nHowever, the hospital authorities had not been sending the stipulated\nnumber of blood samples daily for analysis. The Central team members\nwho had visited the hospital sought an explanation for this from the\ndistrict health administration. Blood samples are now being sent from\nthe hospital and a few suspected and confirmed cases of chikungunya\nhave been reported from Peroorkada.\nA section of the doctors are worried about the sustained pattern of\nviral fever incidence and the fact that chicken pox cases are also\nbeing reported now, during the rainy season.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previous reports of febrile cases of chikungunya, as well as fevers\ncaused by other etiological agents, continues with this report.\nChikungunya virus transmission can be reduced by vigorous _Aedes_\nmosquito control. Confirmed laboratory diagnosis is critical to know\nto what extent chikungunya virus infection is responsible for these\ncases, in order to mount an effective control campaign.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand a map of Kerala, showing districts, at:\n<http://www.naturemagics.com/kerala-maps/kerala-map.shtm>. - Mod.TY.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (18): India (Kerala):\nconfirmed 20070723.2365\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (17): India (Delhi) 20070722.2355\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (16): India (Kerala) 20070718.2305\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (15): India (Kerala) 20070717.2296\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (14): India (Kerala) 20070712.2235\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (13): India (Kerala) 20070621.2008\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (11): India (Kerala) 20070531.1757\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Orissa): susp. 20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vadodara) susp. 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India, Islands 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\n...................................dk/ty/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
