Other reports\ncame in from Kesavappuram, Manamboor, Vizhinjam, Perumkadavila,\nVellarada, Neyyattinkara and Nedumangad. Suspected chikungunya cases\nare being reported frequently from Peroorkada area.\nThe outpatient clinic at Peroorkada Government hospital has been very\ncrowded in the past few weeks [8-21 Jul 2007] with fever patients.\nHowever, the hospital authorities had not been sending the stipulated\nnumber of blood samples daily for analysis. The Central team members\nwho had visited the hospital sought an explanation for this from the\ndistrict health administration. Blood samples are now being sent from\nthe hospital and a few suspected and confirmed cases of chikungunya\nhave been reported from Peroorkada.\nA section of the doctors are worried about the sustained pattern of\nviral fever incidence and the fact that chicken pox cases are also\nbeing reported now, during the rainy season.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previous reports of febrile cases of chikungunya, as well as fevers\ncaused by other etiological agents, continues with this report.\nChikungunya virus transmission can be reduced by vigorous _Aedes_\nmosquito control. Confirmed laboratory diagnosis is critical to know\nto what extent chikungunya virus infection is responsible for these\ncases, in order to mount an effective control campaign.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand a map of Kerala, showing districts, at:\n<http://www.naturemagics.com/kerala-maps/kerala-map.shtm>. - Mod.TY.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (18): India (Kerala):\nconfirmed 20070723.2365\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (17): India (Delhi) 20070722.2355\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (16): India (Kerala) 20070718.2305\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (15): India (Kerala) 20070717.2296\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (14): India (Kerala) 20070712.2235\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (13): India (Kerala) 20070621.2008\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (11): India (Kerala) 20070531.1757\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Orissa): susp. 20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vadodara) susp. 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India, Islands 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\n...................................dk/ty/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Other reports\ncame in from Kesavappuram, Manamboor, Vizhinjam, Perumkadavila,\nVellarada, Neyyattinkara and Nedumangad. Suspected chikungunya cases\nare being reported frequently from Peroorkada area.\nThe outpatient clinic at Peroorkada Government hospital has been very\ncrowded in the past few weeks [8-21 Jul 2007] with fever patients.\nHowever, the hospital authorities had not been sending the stipulated\nnumber of blood samples daily for analysis. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-21 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nedumangad", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Vellarada", "country": "India"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Sri Lanka", "country": "Sri Lanka"}, {"location": "Manamboor", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neyyattinkara", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "20789", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Indian Ocean update (20): India (Kerala)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=20789", "date": "2007-07-24 23:00:22", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (19): INDIA (KERALA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 24 Jul 2007\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\n<http://www.hindu.com/2007/07/24/stories/2007072460500300.htm>\n\nThiruvananthapuram: The district reported 3788 cases of viral fever\non Monday [23 Jul 2007], including 23 cases of suspected chikungunya\n[virus infection].\nFrom Parassala 212 viral fever cases were reported. Other reports\ncame in from Kesavappuram, Manamboor, Vizhinjam, Perumkadavila,\nVellarada, Neyyattinkara and Nedumangad. Suspected chikungunya cases\nare being reported frequently from Peroorkada area.\nThe outpatient clinic at Peroorkada Government hospital has been very\ncrowded in the past few weeks [8-21 Jul 2007] with fever patients.\nHowever, the hospital authorities had not been sending the stipulated\nnumber of blood samples daily for analysis. The Central team members\nwho had visited the hospital sought an explanation for this from the\ndistrict health administration. Blood samples are now being sent from\nthe hospital and a few suspected and confirmed cases of chikungunya\nhave been reported from Peroorkada.\nA section of the doctors are worried about the sustained pattern of\nviral fever incidence and the fact that chicken pox cases are also\nbeing reported now, during the rainy season.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previous reports of febrile cases of chikungunya, as well as fevers\ncaused by other etiological agents, continues with this report.\nChikungunya virus transmission can be reduced by vigorous _Aedes_\nmosquito control. Confirmed laboratory diagnosis is critical to know\nto what extent chikungunya virus infection is responsible for these\ncases, in order to mount an effective control campaign.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand a map of Kerala, showing districts, at:\n<http://www.naturemagics.com/kerala-maps/kerala-map.shtm>. - Mod.TY.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (18): India (Kerala):\nconfirmed 20070723.2365\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (17): India (Delhi) 20070722.2355\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (16): India (Kerala) 20070718.2305\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (15): India (Kerala) 20070717.2296\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (14): India (Kerala) 20070712.2235\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (13): India (Kerala) 20070621.2008\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (11): India (Kerala) 20070531.1757\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Orissa): susp. 20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vadodara) susp. 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India, Islands 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\n...................................dk/ty/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Other reports\ncame in from Kesavappuram, Manamboor, Vizhinjam, Perumkadavila,\nVellarada, Neyyattinkara and Nedumangad. Suspected chikungunya cases\nare being reported frequently from Peroorkada area.\nThe outpatient clinic at Peroorkada Government hospital has been very\ncrowded in the past few weeks [8-21 Jul 2007] with fever patients.\nHowever, the hospital authorities had not been sending the stipulated\nnumber of blood samples daily for analysis. The Central team members\nwho had visited the hospital sought an explanation for this from the\ndistrict health administration. Blood samples are now being sent from\nthe hospital and a few suspected and confirmed cases of chikungunya\nhave been reported from Peroorkada.\nA section of the doctors are worried about the sustained pattern of\nviral fever incidence and the fact that chicken pox cases are also\nbeing reported now, during the rainy season.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Previous reports of febrile cases of chikungunya, as well as fevers\ncaused by other etiological agents, continues with this report.\nChikungunya virus transmission can be reduced by vigorous _Aedes_\nmosquito control. Confirmed laboratory diagnosis is critical to know\nto what extent chikungunya virus infection is responsible for these\ncases, in order to mount an effective control campaign.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand a map of Kerala, showing districts, at:\n<http://www.naturemagics.com/kerala-maps/kerala-map.shtm>. - Mod.TY.]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (18): India (Kerala):\nconfirmed 20070723.2365\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (17): India (Delhi) 20070722.2355\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (16): India (Kerala) 20070718.2305\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (15): India (Kerala) 20070717.2296\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (14): India (Kerala) 20070712.2235\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (13): India (Kerala) 20070621.2008\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (11): India (Kerala) 20070531.1757\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Orissa): susp. 20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vadodara) susp. 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India, Islands 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\n...................................dk/ty/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. K. Sreemati said here on Thursday\n[31 May 2007]. [According to another news article, 25,000 are\nhospitalized with fever of which over 25% are suspected to be\ninfected with chikungunya.-Mod.DK] Thousands more with fever and\nother symptoms were undergoing outpatient treatment in districts such\nas Kottayam, Pathanamthitta, Ernakulam, Kollam and\nThiruvananthapuram. The disease is spread by mosquitoes, which had\nmultiplied in the southern districts during the past few weeks.\nThe Minister said that the Health Department in association with the\nDepartment of Local Self Government would undertake a week-long drive\nstarting on 5 Jun 2007 for vector control with public participation.\nThe mosquito density in the districts is greater than that observed\nin an outbreak that occurred last year [2006] in Alappuzha.\nMs. Sreemati said that the cabinet had sanctioned a week's free\nrations to poor families affected by the disease in all districts.\nAbout Rs. 2 crores [INR 20 million or USD 496 000 - CopyEd.MSP] had\nbeen sanctioned for providing mosquito nets for the patients and\nacquiring fogging machines and sprayers.\nLocal bodies would be implementing special schemes for improving\nsanitation and clearing waterlogged canals and streams.\n[Byline: Roy Mathew]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Since 24 May 2007, the number of patients hospitalized in Kelala\nwith acute chikungunya fever has risen from around 100 to many\nthousands on 31 May 2007. Although the outbreak is extensive and the\neffects of infection severe and incapacitating in many cases, there\nhave been no reports of fatalities.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand an interactive map of Kerala at\n<http://www.kerala.cc/keralamap/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India,... 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex ... 20070217.0606\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): Indonesia 20070308.0818\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vad... 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Ori... 20070527.1704,\n20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Indonesia ... 20070530.1750\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32): spread to ... 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\n.....................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. K. Sreemati said here on Thursday\n[31 May 2007]. [According to another news article, 25,000 are\nhospitalized with fever of which over 25% are suspected to be\ninfected with chikungunya.-Mod.DK] Thousands more with fever and\nother symptoms were undergoing outpatient treatment in districts such\nas Kottayam, Pathanamthitta, Ernakulam, Kollam and\nThiruvananthapuram. The disease is spread by mosquitoes, which had\nmultiplied in the southern districts during the past few weeks.\nThe Minister said that the Health Department in association with the\nDepartment of Local Self Government would undertake a week-long drive\nstarting on 5 Jun 2007 for vector control with public participation.\nThe mosquito density in the districts is greater than that observed\nin an outbreak that occurred last year [2006] in Alappuzha.\nMs. Sreemati said that the cabinet had sanctioned a week's free\nrations to poor families affected by the disease in all districts.\nAbout Rs. 2 crores [INR 20 million or USD 496 000 - CopyEd.MSP] had\nbeen sanctioned for providing mosquito nets for the patients and\nacquiring fogging machines and sprayers.\nLocal bodies would be implementing special schemes for improving\nsanitation and clearing waterlogged canals and streams.\n[Byline: Roy Mathew]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Since 24 May 2007, the number of patients hospitalized in Kelala\nwith acute chikungunya fever has risen from around 100 to many\nthousands on 31 May 2007. Although the outbreak is extensive and the\neffects of infection severe and incapacitating in many cases, there\nhave been no reports of fatalities.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand an interactive map of Kerala at\n<http://www.kerala.cc/keralamap/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India,... 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex ... 20070217.0606\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): Indonesia 20070308.0818\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vad... 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Ori... 20070527.1704,\n20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Indonesia ... 20070530.1750\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32): spread to ... 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\n.....................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease is spread by mosquitoes, which had\nmultiplied in the southern districts during the past few weeks.\nThe Minister said that the Health Department in association with the\nDepartment of Local Self Government would undertake a week-long drive\nstarting on 5 Jun 2007 for vector control with public participation.\nThe mosquito density in the districts is greater than that observed\nin an outbreak that occurred last year [2006] in Alappuzha.\nMs. Sreemati said that the cabinet had sanctioned a week's free\nrations to poor families affected by the disease in all districts.\nAbout Rs. 2 crores [INR 20 million or USD 496 000 - CopyEd.MSP] had\nbeen sanctioned for providing mosquito nets for the patients and\nacquiring fogging machines and sprayers.\nLocal bodies would be implementing special schemes for improving\nsanitation and clearing waterlogged canals and streams.\n[Byline: Roy Mathew]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Since 24 May 2007, the number of patients hospitalized in Kelala\nwith acute chikungunya fever has risen from around 100 to many\nthousands on 31 May 2007. Although the outbreak is extensive and the\neffects of infection severe and incapacitating in many cases, there\nhave been no reports of fatalities.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand an interactive map of Kerala at\n<http://www.kerala.cc/keralamap/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India,... 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex ... 20070217.0606\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): Indonesia 20070308.0818\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vad... 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Ori... 20070527.1704,\n20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Indonesia ... 20070530.1750\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32): spread to ... 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\n.....................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. K. Sreemati said here on Thursday\n[31 May 2007]. [According to another news article, 25,000 are\nhospitalized with fever of which over 25% are suspected to be\ninfected with chikungunya.-Mod.DK] Thousands more with fever and\nother symptoms were undergoing outpatient treatment in districts such\nas Kottayam, Pathanamthitta, Ernakulam, Kollam and\nThiruvananthapuram. The disease is spread by mosquitoes, which had\nmultiplied in the southern districts during the past few weeks.\nThe Minister said that the Health Department in association with the\nDepartment of Local Self Government would undertake a week-long drive\nstarting on 5 Jun 2007 for vector control with public participation.\nThe mosquito density in the districts is greater than that observed\nin an outbreak that occurred last year [2006] in Alappuzha.\nMs. Sreemati said that the cabinet had sanctioned a week's free\nrations to poor families affected by the disease in all districts.\nAbout Rs. 2 crores [INR 20 million or USD 496 000 - CopyEd.MSP] had\nbeen sanctioned for providing mosquito nets for the patients and\nacquiring fogging machines and sprayers.\nLocal bodies would be implementing special schemes for improving\nsanitation and clearing waterlogged canals and streams.\n[Byline: Roy Mathew]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Since 24 May 2007, the number of patients hospitalized in Kelala\nwith acute chikungunya fever has risen from around 100 to many\nthousands on 31 May 2007. Although the outbreak is extensive and the\neffects of infection severe and incapacitating in many cases, there\nhave been no reports of fatalities.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand an interactive map of Kerala at\n<http://www.kerala.cc/keralamap/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India,... 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex ... 20070217.0606\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): Indonesia 20070308.0818\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vad... 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Ori... 20070527.1704,\n20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Indonesia ... 20070530.1750\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32): spread to ... 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\n.....................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. K. Sreemati said here on Thursday\n[31 May 2007]. [According to another news article, 25,000 are\nhospitalized with fever of which over 25% are suspected to be\ninfected with chikungunya.-Mod.DK] Thousands more with fever and\nother symptoms were undergoing outpatient treatment in districts such\nas Kottayam, Pathanamthitta, Ernakulam, Kollam and\nThiruvananthapuram. K. Sreemati said here on Thursday\n[31 May 2007]. [According to another news article, 25,000 are\nhospitalized with fever of which over 25% are suspected to be\ninfected with chikungunya.-Mod.DK] Thousands more with fever and\nother symptoms were undergoing outpatient treatment in districts such\nas Kottayam, Pathanamthitta, Ernakulam, Kollam and\nThiruvananthapuram. The disease is spread by mosquitoes, which had\nmultiplied in the southern districts during the past few weeks.\nThe Minister said that the Health Department in association with the\nDepartment of Local Self Government would undertake a week-long drive\nstarting on 5 Jun 2007 for vector control with public participation.\nThe mosquito density in the districts is greater than that observed\nin an outbreak that occurred last year [2006] in Alappuzha.\nMs. Sreemati said that the cabinet had sanctioned a week's free\nrations to poor families affected by the disease in all districts.\nAbout Rs. 2 crores [INR 20 million or USD 496 000 - CopyEd.MSP] had\nbeen sanctioned for providing mosquito nets for the patients and\nacquiring fogging machines and sprayers.\nLocal bodies would be implementing special schemes for improving\nsanitation and clearing waterlogged canals and streams.\n[Byline: Roy Mathew]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Since 24 May 2007, the number of patients hospitalized in Kelala\nwith acute chikungunya fever has risen from around 100 to many\nthousands on 31 May 2007. Although the outbreak is extensive and the\neffects of infection severe and incapacitating in many cases, there\nhave been no reports of fatalities.\nA map of India can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>,\nand an interactive map of Kerala at\n<http://www.kerala.cc/keralamap/>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (06): Sri Lanka, India,... 20070320.0974\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex ... 20070217.0606\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): Indonesia 20070308.0818\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): India (Vad... 20070430.1405\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08): India (Kerala) 20070524.1669\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09): India (Ori... 20070527.1704,\n20070527.1705\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Indonesia ... 20070530.1750\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32): spread to ... 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - India Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\n.....................cp/msp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Indian Ocean update (10): Indonesia (Bandarlampung)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10775", "date": "2007-03-08 14:00:02", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (05): INDONESIA\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 7 Mar 2007\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: The Jakarta Post [edited]\n<http://www.thejakartapost.com/yesterdaydetail.asp?fileid=20070307.C08>\n\nThe disabling mosquito-borne disease, chikungunya, has been diagnosed\nin 98 people from Bekasi, the capital city of the regency, and the\nnumber is expected to rise, a health official said Monday [5 Mar 2007].\nTitin Restuwatuti from the Aren Jaya community health center said\nmost of the cases were detected during routine health checks. The\ncenter has already notified the Bekasi Health Agency as required by\nthe regency's post-flood program.\n\"The disease is spreading rapidly. Shortly after the flood (early\nlast month [February 2007]), it was confined to areas that had been\ninundated, but now we're also diagnosing chikungunya in people from\nother areas,\" she said.\nTo curb the spread of the disease, the center has fumigated homes in\nareas where cases have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[One wonders if the heavy rains associated with the floods have\ncreated water catchments suitable as breeding sites for the mosquito\nvector, _Aedes aegypti_, over a broader geographic area. Although\nfumigation of homes may temporarily reduce the vector population, a\nvigorous, community-based campaign educating home and business owners\nto constantly search for and eliminate the breeding sites of this\nmosquito and reduce the risk of chikungunya and dengue virus\ntransmission long-term.\nA map of Indonesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/indonesia_pol_2002.jpg>;\nand a map of the flooded areas, including Bekasi, is available at\n<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/idn/sitreps/indonesia_floods_map_affected_areas_5feb2007.pdf>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex Madagascar 20070217.0606\nChikungunya, imported, risk of transmission 20070125.0338\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Japan ex Sri Lanka 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya vaccine: RFI 20070109.0089\n2006\n----\nChikungunya - Taipei ex Singapore 20061126.3359\nChikungunya - USA ex Asia, Africa 20061125.3349\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (31): spread to USA 20060928.2780\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (29): spread to France 20060829.2452\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\n....................ty/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\ncenter has already notified the Bekasi Health Agency as required by\nthe regency's post-flood program.\n\"The disease is spreading rapidly. Shortly after the flood (early\nlast month [February 2007]), it was confined to areas that had been\ninundated, but now we're also diagnosing chikungunya in people from\nother areas,\" she said.\nTo curb the spread of the disease, the center has fumigated homes in\nareas where cases have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[One wonders if the heavy rains associated with the floods have\ncreated water catchments suitable as breeding sites for the mosquito\nvector, _Aedes aegypti_, over a broader geographic area. Although\nfumigation of homes may temporarily reduce the vector population, a\nvigorous, community-based campaign educating home and business owners\nto constantly search for and eliminate the breeding sites of this\nmosquito and reduce the risk of chikungunya and dengue virus\ntransmission long-term.\nA map of Indonesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/indonesia_pol_2002.jpg>;\nand a map of the flooded areas, including Bekasi, is available at\n<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/idn/sitreps/indonesia_floods_map_affected_areas_5feb2007.pdf>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex Madagascar 20070217.0606\nChikungunya, imported, risk of transmission 20070125.0338\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Japan ex Sri Lanka 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya vaccine: RFI 20070109.0089\n2006\n----\nChikungunya - Taipei ex Singapore 20061126.3359\nChikungunya - USA ex Asia, Africa 20061125.3349\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (31): spread to USA 20060928.2780\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (29): spread to France 20060829.2452\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\n....................ty/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\ncenter has already notified the Bekasi Health Agency as required by\nthe regency's post-flood program.\n\"The disease is spreading rapidly. Shortly after the flood (early\nlast month [February 2007]), it was confined to areas that had been\ninundated, but now we're also diagnosing chikungunya in people from\nother areas,\" she said.\nTo curb the spread of the disease, the center has fumigated homes in\nareas where cases have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[One wonders if the heavy rains associated with the floods have\ncreated water catchments suitable as breeding sites for the mosquito\nvector, _Aedes aegypti_, over a broader geographic area. The\ncenter has already notified the Bekasi Health Agency as required by\nthe regency's post-flood program.\n\"The disease is spreading rapidly. Shortly after the flood (early\nlast month [February 2007]), it was confined to areas that had been\ninundated, but now we're also diagnosing chikungunya in people from\nother areas,\" she said.\nTo curb the spread of the disease, the center has fumigated homes in\nareas where cases have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[One wonders if the heavy rains associated with the floods have\ncreated water catchments suitable as breeding sites for the mosquito\nvector, _Aedes aegypti_, over a broader geographic area. Although\nfumigation of homes may temporarily reduce the vector population, a\nvigorous, community-based campaign educating home and business owners\nto constantly search for and eliminate the breeding sites of this\nmosquito and reduce the risk of chikungunya and dengue virus\ntransmission long-term.\nA map of Indonesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/indonesia_pol_2002.jpg>;\nand a map of the flooded areas, including Bekasi, is available at\n<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/idn/sitreps/indonesia_floods_map_affected_areas_5feb2007.pdf>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex Madagascar 20070217.0606\nChikungunya, imported, risk of transmission 20070125.0338\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Japan ex Sri Lanka 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya vaccine: RFI 20070109.0089\n2006\n----\nChikungunya - Taipei ex Singapore 20061126.3359\nChikungunya - USA ex Asia, Africa 20061125.3349\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (31): spread to USA 20060928.2780\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (29): spread to France 20060829.2452\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\n....................ty/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\ncenter has already notified the Bekasi Health Agency as required by\nthe regency's post-flood program.\n\"The disease is spreading rapidly. Shortly after the flood (early\nlast month [February 2007]), it was confined to areas that had been\ninundated, but now we're also diagnosing chikungunya in people from\nother areas,\" she said.\nTo curb the spread of the disease, the center has fumigated homes in\nareas where cases have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[One wonders if the heavy rains associated with the floods have\ncreated water catchments suitable as breeding sites for the mosquito\nvector, _Aedes aegypti_, over a broader geographic area. Although\nfumigation of homes may temporarily reduce the vector population, a\nvigorous, community-based campaign educating home and business owners\nto constantly search for and eliminate the breeding sites of this\nmosquito and reduce the risk of chikungunya and dengue virus\ntransmission long-term.\nA map of Indonesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/indonesia_pol_2002.jpg>;\nand a map of the flooded areas, including Bekasi, is available at\n<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/idn/sitreps/indonesia_floods_map_affected_areas_5feb2007.pdf>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex Madagascar 20070217.0606\nChikungunya, imported, risk of transmission 20070125.0338\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Japan ex Sri Lanka 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya vaccine: RFI 20070109.0089\n2006\n----\nChikungunya - Taipei ex Singapore 20061126.3359\nChikungunya - USA ex Asia, Africa 20061125.3349\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (31): spread to USA 20060928.2780\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (29): spread to France 20060829.2452\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\n....................ty/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\ncenter has already notified the Bekasi Health Agency as required by\nthe regency's post-flood program.\n\"The disease is spreading rapidly. Shortly after the flood (early\nlast month [February 2007]), it was confined to areas that had been\ninundated, but now we're also diagnosing chikungunya in people from\nother areas,\" she said.\nTo curb the spread of the disease, the center has fumigated homes in\nareas where cases have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[One wonders if the heavy rains associated with the floods have\ncreated water catchments suitable as breeding sites for the mosquito\nvector, _Aedes aegypti_, over a broader geographic area. Although\nfumigation of homes may temporarily reduce the vector population, a\nvigorous, community-based campaign educating home and business owners\nto constantly search for and eliminate the breeding sites of this\nmosquito and reduce the risk of chikungunya and dengue virus\ntransmission long-term.\nA map of Indonesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/indonesia_pol_2002.jpg>;\nand a map of the flooded areas, including Bekasi, is available at\n<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/idn/sitreps/indonesia_floods_map_affected_areas_5feb2007.pdf>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex Madagascar 20070217.0606\nChikungunya, imported, risk of transmission 20070125.0338\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Japan ex Sri Lanka 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya vaccine: RFI 20070109.0089\n2006\n----\nChikungunya - Taipei ex Singapore 20061126.3359\nChikungunya - USA ex Asia, Africa 20061125.3349\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (31): spread to USA 20060928.2780\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (29): spread to France 20060829.2452\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\n....................ty/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\ncenter has already notified the Bekasi Health Agency as required by\nthe regency's post-flood program.\n\"The disease is spreading rapidly. Shortly after the flood (early\nlast month [February 2007]), it was confined to areas that had been\ninundated, but now we're also diagnosing chikungunya in people from\nother areas,\" she said.\nTo curb the spread of the disease, the center has fumigated homes in\nareas where cases have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[One wonders if the heavy rains associated with the floods have\ncreated water catchments suitable as breeding sites for the mosquito\nvector, _Aedes aegypti_, over a broader geographic area. Although\nfumigation of homes may temporarily reduce the vector population, a\nvigorous, community-based campaign educating home and business owners\nto constantly search for and eliminate the breeding sites of this\nmosquito and reduce the risk of chikungunya and dengue virus\ntransmission long-term.\nA map of Indonesia can be accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/indonesia_pol_2002.jpg>;\nand a map of the flooded areas, including Bekasi, is available at\n<http://www.who.int/hac/crises/idn/sitreps/indonesia_floods_map_affected_areas_5feb2007.pdf>.\n- Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): India 20070226.0689\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): France ex Madagascar 20070217.0606\nChikungunya, imported, risk of transmission 20070125.0338\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Japan ex Sri Lanka 20070124.0320\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20070121.0285\nChikungunya vaccine: RFI 20070109.0089\n2006\n----\nChikungunya - Taipei ex Singapore 20061126.3359\nChikungunya - USA ex Asia, Africa 20061125.3349\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean (31): spread to USA 20060928.2780\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (29): spread to France 20060829.2452\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\n....................ty/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The hospital's\ntropical medicine experts explained that these\ncases were diagnosed in people who had traveled\nto the Mauritius Islands, Equatorial Guinea,\nCameroon and India, where they had been infected\nby the bite of infected mosquitoes. This series\nof [chikungunya] cases being studied by [medical\npersonnel] in the hospital is the most extensive ever registered in Spain.\nThe specialists advise that persons intending to\ntravel to tropical areas should consult travel\nmedicine specialists, such as those at the Carlos\nIII Hospital, at least a month before departure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st report ProMED has seen this year\n[2006] of CHIK infection occurring in West Africa\n(Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon). The literature\nrecords that up to 1978 CHIK infection had not\nbeen recorded in West Africa other than Nigeria\nand Senegal, Sierra Leone and Liberia (by\nserology) -- ref: A W Woodruff, E T Bowen, & G S\nPlatt 1978 Viral infections in travellers from\ntropical Africa. Br Med J. 1978 April 15;\n1(6118): 956\ufffd958 (full text accessible\nonline). A later paper reported CHIK positive\nserology in Namibia -- ref: Joubert JJ, et al.\n1983 Prevalence of hepatitis virus and some\narbovirus infections in Kavango, northern\nSWA/Namibia. S Afr Med J. 1985 Mar\n30;67(13):500-2, and a still later one on the\nRepublic of Guinea.(not to be confused with\nEquatorial Guinea) -- ref: Ivanov AP, et\nal. Serological investigations of Chikungunya\nvirus in the Republic of Guinea. Ann Soc Belg\nMed Trop. 1992 Mar;72(1):73-4. Anyone with\nfurther information of the current situation in\nWest Africa is asked to tell us, giving date, name & URL of source. - Mod.JW]\n[It is always prudent that travelers be aware of\nthe health risks they may encounter in foreign\ncountries and receive appropriate vaccinations in\nadvance. Unfortunately, there is no vaccine\navailable against chikungunya virus, although\ntravelers need to know that they should avoid\nbeing bitten by _Aedes aegypti_ and _Ae.\nalbopictus_ mosquitoes that transmit the\nvirus. This report from Spain is a compelling\nexample of importation of a single viral disease\nfrom several widely divergent foreign sources,\nmaking it essential that primary health providers\ntake adequate travel histories from their\npatients and know what diseases are being\nactively transmitted abroad. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean Update (33): Maldives 20061224.3598\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32) 20061014.2953\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (28): India 20060624.1754\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq. 20060323.0896\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09) 20060320.0864\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. Indian Ocean update (03): France ex Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8163", "date": "2006-12-26 00:00:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (34): SPAIN, IMPORTED\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 20 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: 20 minutos.es, Espana 20/12/06 [translation by Mod.TY; edited]\n<http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/184297/0/detectado/virus/africano/>\n\nThe tropical medicine unit in the Carlos III\nHospital has diagnosed the first 7 cases of\nchikungunya virus infection. The hospital's\ntropical medicine experts explained that these\ncases were diagnosed in people who had traveled\nto the Mauritius Islands, Equatorial Guinea,\nCameroon and India, where they had been infected\nby the bite of infected mosquitoes. This series\nof [chikungunya] cases being studied by [medical\npersonnel] in the hospital is the most extensive ever registered in Spain.\nThe specialists advise that persons intending to\ntravel to tropical areas should consult travel\nmedicine specialists, such as those at the Carlos\nIII Hospital, at least a month before departure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st report ProMED has seen this year\n[2006] of CHIK infection occurring in West Africa\n(Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon). The literature\nrecords that up to 1978 CHIK infection had not\nbeen recorded in West Africa other than Nigeria\nand Senegal, Sierra Leone and Liberia (by\nserology) -- ref: A W Woodruff, E T Bowen, & G S\nPlatt 1978 Viral infections in travellers from\ntropical Africa. Br Med J. 1978 April 15;\n1(6118): 956\ufffd958 (full text accessible\nonline). A later paper reported CHIK positive\nserology in Namibia -- ref: Joubert JJ, et al.\n1983 Prevalence of hepatitis virus and some\narbovirus infections in Kavango, northern\nSWA/Namibia. S Afr Med J. 1985 Mar\n30;67(13):500-2, and a still later one on the\nRepublic of Guinea.(not to be confused with\nEquatorial Guinea) -- ref: Ivanov AP, et\nal. Serological investigations of Chikungunya\nvirus in the Republic of Guinea. Ann Soc Belg\nMed Trop. 1992 Mar;72(1):73-4. Anyone with\nfurther information of the current situation in\nWest Africa is asked to tell us, giving date, name & URL of source. - Mod.JW]\n[It is always prudent that travelers be aware of\nthe health risks they may encounter in foreign\ncountries and receive appropriate vaccinations in\nadvance. Unfortunately, there is no vaccine\navailable against chikungunya virus, although\ntravelers need to know that they should avoid\nbeing bitten by _Aedes aegypti_ and _Ae.\nalbopictus_ mosquitoes that transmit the\nvirus. This report from Spain is a compelling\nexample of importation of a single viral disease\nfrom several widely divergent foreign sources,\nmaking it essential that primary health providers\ntake adequate travel histories from their\npatients and know what diseases are being\nactively transmitted abroad. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean Update (33): Maldives 20061224.3598\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32) 20061014.2953\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (28): India 20060624.1754\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq. 20060323.0896\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09) 20060320.0864\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (34): SPAIN, IMPORTED\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 20 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: 20 minutos.es, Espana 20/12/06 [translation by Mod.TY; edited]\n<http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/184297/0/detectado/virus/africano/>\n\nThe tropical medicine unit in the Carlos III\nHospital has diagnosed the first 7 cases of\nchikungunya virus infection. The hospital's\ntropical medicine experts explained that these\ncases were diagnosed in people who had traveled\nto the Mauritius Islands, Equatorial Guinea,\nCameroon and India, where they had been infected\nby the bite of infected mosquitoes. This series\nof [chikungunya] cases being studied by [medical\npersonnel] in the hospital is the most extensive ever registered in Spain.\nThe specialists advise that persons intending to\ntravel to tropical areas should consult travel\nmedicine specialists, such as those at the Carlos\nIII Hospital, at least a month before departure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st report ProMED has seen this year\n[2006] of CHIK infection occurring in West Africa\n(Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon). Anyone with\nfurther information of the current situation in\nWest Africa is asked to tell us, giving date, name & URL of source. - Mod.JW]\n[It is always prudent that travelers be aware of\nthe health risks they may encounter in foreign\ncountries and receive appropriate vaccinations in\nadvance. The hospital's\ntropical medicine experts explained that these\ncases were diagnosed in people who had traveled\nto the Mauritius Islands, Equatorial Guinea,\nCameroon and India, where they had been infected\nby the bite of infected mosquitoes. This series\nof [chikungunya] cases being studied by [medical\npersonnel] in the hospital is the most extensive ever registered in Spain.\nThe specialists advise that persons intending to\ntravel to tropical areas should consult travel\nmedicine specialists, such as those at the Carlos\nIII Hospital, at least a month before departure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st report ProMED has seen this year\n[2006] of CHIK infection occurring in West Africa\n(Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon). Indian Ocean update (32): spread to Japan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6931", "date": "2006-12-26 00:00:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (34): SPAIN, IMPORTED\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 20 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: 20 minutos.es, Espana 20/12/06 [translation by Mod.TY; edited]\n<http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/184297/0/detectado/virus/africano/>\n\nThe tropical medicine unit in the Carlos III\nHospital has diagnosed the first 7 cases of\nchikungunya virus infection. The hospital's\ntropical medicine experts explained that these\ncases were diagnosed in people who had traveled\nto the Mauritius Islands, Equatorial Guinea,\nCameroon and India, where they had been infected\nby the bite of infected mosquitoes. This series\nof [chikungunya] cases being studied by [medical\npersonnel] in the hospital is the most extensive ever registered in Spain.\nThe specialists advise that persons intending to\ntravel to tropical areas should consult travel\nmedicine specialists, such as those at the Carlos\nIII Hospital, at least a month before departure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st report ProMED has seen this year\n[2006] of CHIK infection occurring in West Africa\n(Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon). The literature\nrecords that up to 1978 CHIK infection had not\nbeen recorded in West Africa other than Nigeria\nand Senegal, Sierra Leone and Liberia (by\nserology) -- ref: A W Woodruff, E T Bowen, & G S\nPlatt 1978 Viral infections in travellers from\ntropical Africa. Br Med J. 1978 April 15;\n1(6118): 956\ufffd958 (full text accessible\nonline). A later paper reported CHIK positive\nserology in Namibia -- ref: Joubert JJ, et al.\n1983 Prevalence of hepatitis virus and some\narbovirus infections in Kavango, northern\nSWA/Namibia. S Afr Med J. 1985 Mar\n30;67(13):500-2, and a still later one on the\nRepublic of Guinea.(not to be confused with\nEquatorial Guinea) -- ref: Ivanov AP, et\nal. Serological investigations of Chikungunya\nvirus in the Republic of Guinea. Ann Soc Belg\nMed Trop. 1992 Mar;72(1):73-4. Anyone with\nfurther information of the current situation in\nWest Africa is asked to tell us, giving date, name & URL of source. - Mod.JW]\n[It is always prudent that travelers be aware of\nthe health risks they may encounter in foreign\ncountries and receive appropriate vaccinations in\nadvance. Unfortunately, there is no vaccine\navailable against chikungunya virus, although\ntravelers need to know that they should avoid\nbeing bitten by _Aedes aegypti_ and _Ae.\nalbopictus_ mosquitoes that transmit the\nvirus. This report from Spain is a compelling\nexample of importation of a single viral disease\nfrom several widely divergent foreign sources,\nmaking it essential that primary health providers\ntake adequate travel histories from their\npatients and know what diseases are being\nactively transmitted abroad. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean Update (33): Maldives 20061224.3598\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32) 20061014.2953\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (28): India 20060624.1754\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq. 20060323.0896\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09) 20060320.0864\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (34): SPAIN, IMPORTED\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 20 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: 20 minutos.es, Espana 20/12/06 [translation by Mod.TY; edited]\n<http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/184297/0/detectado/virus/africano/>\n\nThe tropical medicine unit in the Carlos III\nHospital has diagnosed the first 7 cases of\nchikungunya virus infection. The hospital's\ntropical medicine experts explained that these\ncases were diagnosed in people who had traveled\nto the Mauritius Islands, Equatorial Guinea,\nCameroon and India, where they had been infected\nby the bite of infected mosquitoes. This series\nof [chikungunya] cases being studied by [medical\npersonnel] in the hospital is the most extensive ever registered in Spain.\nThe specialists advise that persons intending to\ntravel to tropical areas should consult travel\nmedicine specialists, such as those at the Carlos\nIII Hospital, at least a month before departure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st report ProMED has seen this year\n[2006] of CHIK infection occurring in West Africa\n(Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon). The literature\nrecords that up to 1978 CHIK infection had not\nbeen recorded in West Africa other than Nigeria\nand Senegal, Sierra Leone and Liberia (by\nserology) -- ref: A W Woodruff, E T Bowen, & G S\nPlatt 1978 Viral infections in travellers from\ntropical Africa. Br Med J. 1978 April 15;\n1(6118): 956\ufffd958 (full text accessible\nonline). A later paper reported CHIK positive\nserology in Namibia -- ref: Joubert JJ, et al.\n1983 Prevalence of hepatitis virus and some\narbovirus infections in Kavango, northern\nSWA/Namibia. S Afr Med J. 1985 Mar\n30;67(13):500-2, and a still later one on the\nRepublic of Guinea.(not to be confused with\nEquatorial Guinea) -- ref: Ivanov AP, et\nal. Serological investigations of Chikungunya\nvirus in the Republic of Guinea. Ann Soc Belg\nMed Trop. 1992 Mar;72(1):73-4. Anyone with\nfurther information of the current situation in\nWest Africa is asked to tell us, giving date, name & URL of source. - Mod.JW]\n[It is always prudent that travelers be aware of\nthe health risks they may encounter in foreign\ncountries and receive appropriate vaccinations in\nadvance. Unfortunately, there is no vaccine\navailable against chikungunya virus, although\ntravelers need to know that they should avoid\nbeing bitten by _Aedes aegypti_ and _Ae.\nalbopictus_ mosquitoes that transmit the\nvirus. This report from Spain is a compelling\nexample of importation of a single viral disease\nfrom several widely divergent foreign sources,\nmaking it essential that primary health providers\ntake adequate travel histories from their\npatients and know what diseases are being\nactively transmitted abroad. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean Update (33): Maldives 20061224.3598\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32) 20061014.2953\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (28): India 20060624.1754\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq. 20060323.0896\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09) 20060320.0864\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2034-03-15 00:00:00", "1983-03-15 00:00:00", "1985-03-15 00:00:00", "1992-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Liberia", "country": "Liberia"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Kavango", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Cameroon", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "the Mauritius Islands", "country": "Mauritius"}, {"location": "the Republic of Guinea", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "the \n Republic of Guinea.(not", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Gambia"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Equatorial Guinea", "country": "Equatorial Guinea"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6159", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - India Ocean update (34): Spain, imported", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6159", "date": "2006-12-26 00:00:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (34): SPAIN, IMPORTED\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 20 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: 20 minutos.es, Espana 20/12/06 [translation by Mod.TY; edited]\n<http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/184297/0/detectado/virus/africano/>\n\nThe tropical medicine unit in the Carlos III\nHospital has diagnosed the first 7 cases of\nchikungunya virus infection. The hospital's\ntropical medicine experts explained that these\ncases were diagnosed in people who had traveled\nto the Mauritius Islands, Equatorial Guinea,\nCameroon and India, where they had been infected\nby the bite of infected mosquitoes. This series\nof [chikungunya] cases being studied by [medical\npersonnel] in the hospital is the most extensive ever registered in Spain.\nThe specialists advise that persons intending to\ntravel to tropical areas should consult travel\nmedicine specialists, such as those at the Carlos\nIII Hospital, at least a month before departure.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is the 1st report ProMED has seen this year\n[2006] of CHIK infection occurring in West Africa\n(Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon). The literature\nrecords that up to 1978 CHIK infection had not\nbeen recorded in West Africa other than Nigeria\nand Senegal, Sierra Leone and Liberia (by\nserology) -- ref: A W Woodruff, E T Bowen, & G S\nPlatt 1978 Viral infections in travellers from\ntropical Africa. Br Med J. 1978 April 15;\n1(6118): 956\ufffd958 (full text accessible\nonline). A later paper reported CHIK positive\nserology in Namibia -- ref: Joubert JJ, et al.\n1983 Prevalence of hepatitis virus and some\narbovirus infections in Kavango, northern\nSWA/Namibia. S Afr Med J. 1985 Mar\n30;67(13):500-2, and a still later one on the\nRepublic of Guinea.(not to be confused with\nEquatorial Guinea) -- ref: Ivanov AP, et\nal. Serological investigations of Chikungunya\nvirus in the Republic of Guinea. Ann Soc Belg\nMed Trop. 1992 Mar;72(1):73-4. Anyone with\nfurther information of the current situation in\nWest Africa is asked to tell us, giving date, name & URL of source. - Mod.JW]\n[It is always prudent that travelers be aware of\nthe health risks they may encounter in foreign\ncountries and receive appropriate vaccinations in\nadvance. Unfortunately, there is no vaccine\navailable against chikungunya virus, although\ntravelers need to know that they should avoid\nbeing bitten by _Aedes aegypti_ and _Ae.\nalbopictus_ mosquitoes that transmit the\nvirus. This report from Spain is a compelling\nexample of importation of a single viral disease\nfrom several widely divergent foreign sources,\nmaking it essential that primary health providers\ntake adequate travel histories from their\npatients and know what diseases are being\nactively transmitted abroad. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean Update (33): Maldives 20061224.3598\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32) 20061014.2953\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (28): India 20060624.1754\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq. 20060323.0896\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (09) 20060320.0864\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. Indian Ocean Update (33): Maldives", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6130", "date": "2006-11-29 00:00:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - SRI LANKA (03)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 28 Nov 2006\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: News-Medical.net, Sydney, Australia [edited]\n<http://www.news-medical.net/?id=21116>\n\nThe Sri Lankan government has confirmed that the viral fever\nspreading rapidly amongst people in Jaffna is the mosquito-borne\nchikungunya fever. It is suspected that more than 5000 people have\nbeen infected with the virus, now at epidemic levels.\nSri Lankan Health authorities have called on the public to clean up\nareas where mosquitoes breed in an effort to prevent the spread of\nthe disease.\nThe symptoms of the disease -- high fever, joint and muscular pain,\nsevere headaches, body aches and rash -- are similar to those caused\nby dengue fever, another mosquito-borne illness.\nThe disease has now spread rapidly in Kalmunai, Mannar, Batticaloa,\nPuttalam and parts of Colombo.\nThe closure of the main highway to the northern peninsula because of\nheavy fighting in August 2006 has resulted in a shortage of food and\nmedical supplies in the north, and Dr. Nihal Abeysinghe, director of\nthe state Epidemiology Department, said pockets of the fever had now\nalso been detected in Sri Lanka's northwest, south and east.\nThe outbreak has coincided with an outbreak of dengue fever cases, as\nmonsoon rains create breeding conditions for the mosquitoes that\ncarry the diseases, and health workers are struggling to cope.\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says that\nwhile the disease is painful, no deaths from chikungunya have been\ndocumented in the scientific literature. [True, but there is a recent\nevaluation by French epidemiologists that points strongly to\nfatalities due to chikungunya virus infections [see archive number\n20061014.2953]. Several deaths in the current Indian Ocean outbreak\nhave been attributed to chikungunya virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20061122.3320\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka; Susp., RFI 20061108.3210\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32) 20061014.2953\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq. 20060323.0896\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Reunion 20060224.0609\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\n................lm/ty/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It is suspected that more than 5000 people have\nbeen infected with the virus, now at epidemic levels.\nSri Lankan Health authorities have called on the public to clean up\nareas where mosquitoes breed in an effort to prevent the spread of\nthe disease.\nThe symptoms of the disease -- high fever, joint and muscular pain,\nsevere headaches, body aches and rash -- are similar to those caused\nby dengue fever, another mosquito-borne illness.\nThe disease has now spread rapidly in Kalmunai, Mannar, Batticaloa,\nPuttalam and parts of Colombo.\nThe closure of the main highway to the northern peninsula because of\nheavy fighting in August 2006 has resulted in a shortage of food and\nmedical supplies in the north, and Dr. Nihal Abeysinghe, director of\nthe state Epidemiology Department, said pockets of the fever had now\nalso been detected in Sri Lanka's northwest, south and east.\nThe outbreak has coincided with an outbreak of dengue fever cases, as\nmonsoon rains create breeding conditions for the mosquitoes that\ncarry the diseases, and health workers are struggling to cope.\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says that\nwhile the disease is painful, no deaths from chikungunya have been\ndocumented in the scientific literature. [True, but there is a recent\nevaluation by French epidemiologists that points strongly to\nfatalities due to chikungunya virus infections [see archive number\n20061014.2953]. Several deaths in the current Indian Ocean outbreak\nhave been attributed to chikungunya virus infections. - Mod.TY]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20061122.3320\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka; Susp., RFI 20061108.3210\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (32) 20061014.2953\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq. 20060323.0896\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Reunion 20060224.0609\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\n................lm/ty/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It is suspected that more than 5000 people have\nbeen infected with the virus, now at epidemic levels.\nSri Lankan Health authorities have called on the public to clean up\nareas where mosquitoes breed in an effort to prevent the spread of\nthe disease.\nThe symptoms of the disease -- high fever, joint and muscular pain,\nsevere headaches, body aches and rash -- are similar to those caused\nby dengue fever, another mosquito-borne illness.\nThe disease has now spread rapidly in Kalmunai, Mannar, Batticaloa,\nPuttalam and parts of Colombo.\nThe closure of the main highway to the northern peninsula because of\nheavy fighting in August 2006 has resulted in a shortage of food and\nmedical supplies in the north, and Dr. Nihal Abeysinghe, director of\nthe state Epidemiology Department, said pockets of the fever had now\nalso been detected in Sri Lanka's northwest, south and east.\nThe outbreak has coincided with an outbreak of dengue fever cases, as\nmonsoon rains create breeding conditions for the mosquitoes that\ncarry the diseases, and health workers are struggling to cope.\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says that\nwhile the disease is painful, no deaths from chikungunya have been\ndocumented in the scientific literature. [True, but there is a recent\nevaluation by French epidemiologists that points strongly to\nfatalities due to chikungunya virus infections [see archive number\n20061014.2953]. It subsequently transpired that we\nhad received multiple samples from a number of patients and we have\ntherefore refined the number of cases down from 115 to 93.\nIn all other respects the press release is accurate, in that this is\na significant increase, and travellers should take appropriate\nprecautions to avoid being bitten. We have corrected the numbers on\nthe version of the press release posted on our website and wanted to\nmake you aware of the situation in case this leads to any confusion.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Luton for this timely information. The reduction\nin the numbers of chikungunya cases imported into the UK does not\nalter the importance of this observation, or the need to avoid\nmosquito bites and remain vigilant to detect the possible presence of\nthe vector, _Aedes albopictus_, in the UK, which could provide\nsuitable conditions for its establishment.\n- Mod.TY]\n[see also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595]\n....................................................jw/ty/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It subsequently transpired that we\nhad received multiple samples from a number of patients and we have\ntherefore refined the number of cases down from 115 to 93.\nIn all other respects the press release is accurate, in that this is\na significant increase, and travellers should take appropriate\nprecautions to avoid being bitten. We have corrected the numbers on\nthe version of the press release posted on our website and wanted to\nmake you aware of the situation in case this leads to any confusion.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Luton for this timely information. The reduction\nin the numbers of chikungunya cases imported into the UK does not\nalter the importance of this observation, or the need to avoid\nmosquito bites and remain vigilant to detect the possible presence of\nthe vector, _Aedes albopictus_, in the UK, which could provide\nsuitable conditions for its establishment.\n- Mod.TY]\n[see also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595]\n....................................................jw/ty/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It subsequently transpired that we\nhad received multiple samples from a number of patients and we have\ntherefore refined the number of cases down from 115 to 93.\nIn all other respects the press release is accurate, in that this is\na significant increase, and travellers should take appropriate\nprecautions to avoid being bitten. We have corrected the numbers on\nthe version of the press release posted on our website and wanted to\nmake you aware of the situation in case this leads to any confusion.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Luton for this timely information. It subsequently transpired that we\nhad received multiple samples from a number of patients and we have\ntherefore refined the number of cases down from 115 to 93.\nIn all other respects the press release is accurate, in that this is\na significant increase, and travellers should take appropriate\nprecautions to avoid being bitten. We have corrected the numbers on\nthe version of the press release posted on our website and wanted to\nmake you aware of the situation in case this leads to any confusion.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Luton for this timely information. It subsequently transpired that we\nhad received multiple samples from a number of patients and we have\ntherefore refined the number of cases down from 115 to 93.\nIn all other respects the press release is accurate, in that this is\na significant increase, and travellers should take appropriate\nprecautions to avoid being bitten. We have corrected the numbers on\nthe version of the press release posted on our website and wanted to\nmake you aware of the situation in case this leads to any confusion.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Luton for this timely information. The reduction\nin the numbers of chikungunya cases imported into the UK does not\nalter the importance of this observation, or the need to avoid\nmosquito bites and remain vigilant to detect the possible presence of\nthe vector, _Aedes albopictus_, in the UK, which could provide\nsuitable conditions for its establishment.\n- Mod.TY]\n[see also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK 20060913.2595]\n....................................................jw/ty/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Indian Ocean update (30): spread to UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2652", "date": "2006-08-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIA (04)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 29 Jul 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: India News [edited]\n<http://indiaenews.com/2006-07/16586-viral-fever-spreads-states.htm>\n\nA high incidence of a rare form of viral fever spread by mosquitoes has\nbeen reported in 5 states, the minister of state for health and family\nwelfare, Panabaka Lakshmi, said on Friday [28 Jul 2006].\n\"High incidence of fever cases with arthralgia were reported from 18\ndistricts of Andhra Pradesh, 27 district of Karnataka, 31 districts each of\nMaharashtra and Tamil Nadu and 4 districts of Madhya Pradesh,\" Lakshmi told\nthe Rajya Sabha.\nLakshmi informed the house that 66 109 cases of suspected chikungunya fever\nhad been reported in Andhra Pradesh, compared with 543 286 in Karnataka,\n202 114 in Maharashtra, 41 211 in Tamil Nadu and 43 784 in Madhya Pradesh.\nShe said the government had created teams consisting of epidemiologists,\npublic health specialists, microbiologists and entomologists for assessment\nof the situation and providing technical assistance and guidelines to the\nstate.\nLakshmi also said that the states had been provided larvicides and\npyrethrum extract for fogging.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of India can be found at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>. -\nMod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya -
