India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karnataka", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2067", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - India (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2067", "date": "2006-08-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIA (04)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 29 Jul 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: India News [edited]\n<http://indiaenews.com/2006-07/16586-viral-fever-spreads-states.htm>\n\nA high incidence of a rare form of viral fever spread by mosquitoes has\nbeen reported in 5 states, the minister of state for health and family\nwelfare, Panabaka Lakshmi, said on Friday [28 Jul 2006].\n\"High incidence of fever cases with arthralgia were reported from 18\ndistricts of Andhra Pradesh, 27 district of Karnataka, 31 districts each of\nMaharashtra and Tamil Nadu and 4 districts of Madhya Pradesh,\" Lakshmi told\nthe Rajya Sabha.\nLakshmi informed the house that 66 109 cases of suspected chikungunya fever\nhad been reported in Andhra Pradesh, compared with 543 286 in Karnataka,\n202 114 in Maharashtra, 41 211 in Tamil Nadu and 43 784 in Madhya Pradesh.\nShe said the government had created teams consisting of epidemiologists,\npublic health specialists, microbiologists and entomologists for assessment\nof the situation and providing technical assistance and guidelines to the\nstate.\nLakshmi also said that the states had been provided larvicides and\npyrethrum extract for fogging.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of India can be found at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>. -\nMod.TY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Infections other\nthan hemorrhagic fevers: Chikungunya:\n1. Baden-Wurttemberg, 16-year-old female (Source of infection: Reunion)\n2. Bavaria, 42-year-old male (Source of infection: Seychelles)\n3. Baden-Wurttemberg, 36-year-old male (Source of infection: Indonesia)\n4. North Rhine-Westfalia, 77-year-old female (Source of infection:\nSeychelles, Mauritius, Reunion)\n5. Bavaria, 46-year-old female (Source of infection: Reunion)\n--\nThomas Roesel\n<roesel@lycos.com>\n[A map of Germany can be accessed at:\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/europe/germany/germany.htm>, or\n<http://www.cia.gov/cia/publications/factbook/geos/gm.html>.\nThe exact dates of these cases are not stated in the report. Exported\ncases of chikungunya have been reported during the past month in many\ncountries outside the Indian Ocean basin, such as France,\nSwitzerland, Germany, French Guiana, and China. For details, please\nsee archived posts 20060304.0695, 20060316.0814, and 20060402.0989,\nrespectively. So far, no secondary spread from the exported cases in\nthese non-endemic countries has been found. Infections other\nthan hemorrhagic fevers: Chikungunya:\n1. Baden-Wurttemberg, 16-year-old female (Source of infection: Reunion)\n2. Bavaria, 42-year-old male (Source of infection: Seychelles)\n3. Exported\ncases of chikungunya have been reported during the past month in many\ncountries outside the Indian Ocean basin, such as France,\nSwitzerland, Germany, French Guiana, and China. For details, please\nsee archived posts 20060304.0695, 20060316.0814, and 20060402.0989,\nrespectively. So far, no secondary spread from the exported cases in\nthese non-endemic countries has been found. Estimations from a mathematical model evaluate\nthat 204 000 people may have been infected by chikungunya virus since March\n2005 on La Reunion, including 13 000 persons during the week 27 Feb - 5 Mar\n2006. Between 1 Jan 2006 - 5 Mar 2006, 25 patients with clinical symptoms\nconsistent with dengue fever were laboratory confirmed. 5 were isolated\ncases and 20 were suspected cases of co-infection chikungunya-dengue.\nSince the beginning of January 2006, other countries in the south west\nIndian Ocean have reported chikungunya cases: Mayotte (9 Jan - 10 Mar, 2833\nsuspected cases), Mauritius (1 Jan - 5 Mar, c. 6000 suspected cases\nincluding 1200 confirmed cases), and the Seychelles (1 Jan - 26 Feb, 8818\nsuspected cases).\nSeveral European countries have reported imported cases in people returning\nfrom these islands: France (160 imported cases), Germany, Italy, Norway and\nSwitzerland.\nA mixed outbreak of chikungunya, with sporadic cases of dengue has been\nreported in Andhra Pradesh state, India. Between 1 Dec 2005 - 17 Feb 2006,\n5671 cases of fever with arthralgia were reported. A high density of _Aedes\naegypti_ was observed in the area. From 1-15 Mar 2006, over 2000 cases of\nchikungunya have been reported from Malegaon town in Nasik district,\nMaharashtra state, India. In Orissa state, India, 4904 cases of fever\nassociated with myalgia and headache have been reported between 27 Feb - 5\nMar 2006. These signs are consistent with an arbovirus outbreak. Results of\na biological investigation are awaited.\nControl measures:\nA WHO team from the Regional Office for Africa and from headquarters was\ndeployed to the south west Indian Ocean in February-March 2006 to assess\nthe control measures underway in the islands and to discuss a sub-regional\ncoordinated strategy for surveillance and control of arboviruses in the\narea with national authorities (see previous report). Additional expertise\nin the COMBI approach has been sent to Madagascar and Mauritius for\nfollow-up. Similarly, Maldives has received support for their social\nmobilization activities on dengue vector control.\nIn India, a multidisciplinary national team was deployed from 13-17 Feb\n2006 to assist local health authorities in improving public health\nmeasures, including strengthening of arbovirus surveillance, clinical\nmanagement of cases, vector control and social mobilization.\nAlthough transmission of chikungunya and dengue is continuing in the\naffected areas, WHO recommends no special restrictions on travel or trade\nto or from these areas. However, it is recommended that individuals take\nprecautions to protect themselves from mosquito bites, e.g., by wearing\nclothes that minimize skin exposure and applying insect repellents to\nexposed skin or clothing in accordance with label instructions.\nFor more information about chikungunya and the outbreak on La Reunion,\nplease see the website of the Observatoire Regional de la Sante de La Reunion:\n<http://www.orsrun.net/>\nand the web site of the Institut National de Veille Sanitaire:\n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/>.\nFor more information on COMBI [The Communications-for-Behavioral Impact],\nplease see the web site of the WHO Mediterranean Centre for Vulnerability\nReduction (WMC) in Tunis:\n<http://wmc.who.int/>.\nFor more information on dengue, see the WHO dengue website:\n<http://www.who.int/topics/dengue/en/index.html>.\nFor more information on pesticides and their application for the control of\n_Aedes_ mosquitoes and other public health pests, see:\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2006/WHO_CDS_NTD_WHOPES_GCDPP_2006.1_eng.pdf>.\nFor more information on vector control and the use of pesticides, please\nsee the web site of the WHO Pesticide Evaluation Scheme:\n<http://www.who.int/whopes/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For a locator map of the Indian Ocean, please visit the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/Regional_Chykungunya_largeb.jpg>.\nWith the seemingly uncontrollable widespread epidemic of chikungunya from\nthe south western and western to the northern regions of the Indian Ocean,\nProMED-mail would appreciate greatly further information from knowledgeable\nsources. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. RFI 20060307.0734\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (06) 20060304.0699\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Reunion 20060224.0609\nChikungunya - India (AP): susp. 20060220.0551\nChikungunya virus vaccine 20060219.0544\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (09): Reunion 20060214.0491\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (08): Reunion 20060205.0378\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (07): Reunion 20060204.0358\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\n...................ry/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2005-01-01 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-02-17 20:06:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "ISLANDS", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Orissa", "country": "India"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nasik district", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209498", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Indian Ocean update (14): Malaysia, India", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209498", "date": "2006-03-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (09): ISLANDS, INDIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO, 17 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_03_17/en/print.html>\n\nFrom 5 Mar 2005 - 28 Mar 2006 [the latter is an obviously mistaken date],\n3115 cases of chikungunya (CHIK) have been notified by 31 physicians from a\nsentinel network on La Reunion, including 196 cases reported during the\nweek 27 Feb - 5 Mar 2006. Estimations from a mathematical model evaluate\nthat 204 000 people may have been infected by chikungunya virus since March\n2005 on La Reunion, including 13 000 persons during the week 27 Feb - 5 Mar\n2006. Between 1 Jan 2006 - 5 Mar 2006, 25 patients with clinical symptoms\nconsistent with dengue fever were laboratory confirmed. 5 were isolated\ncases and 20 were suspected cases of co-infection chikungunya-dengue.\nSince the beginning of January 2006, other countries in the south west\nIndian Ocean have reported chikungunya cases: Mayotte (9 Jan - 10 Mar, 2833\nsuspected cases), Mauritius (1 Jan - 5 Mar, c. 6000 suspected cases\nincluding 1200 confirmed cases), and the Seychelles (1 Jan - 26 Feb, 8818\nsuspected cases).\nSeveral European countries have reported imported cases in people returning\nfrom these islands: France (160 imported cases), Germany, Italy, Norway and\nSwitzerland.\nA mixed outbreak of chikungunya, with sporadic cases of dengue has been\nreported in Andhra Pradesh state, India. Between 1 Dec 2005 - 17 Feb 2006,\n5671 cases of fever with arthralgia were reported. A high density of _Aedes\naegypti_ was observed in the area. From 1-15 Mar 2006, over 2000 cases of\nchikungunya have been reported from Malegaon town in Nasik district,\nMaharashtra state, India. In Orissa state, India, 4904 cases of fever\nassociated with myalgia and headache have been reported between 27 Feb - 5\nMar 2006. These signs are consistent with an arbovirus outbreak. Results of\na biological investigation are awaited.\nControl measures:\nA WHO team from the Regional Office for Africa and from headquarters was\ndeployed to the south west Indian Ocean in February-March 2006 to assess\nthe control measures underway in the islands and to discuss a sub-regional\ncoordinated strategy for surveillance and control of arboviruses in the\narea with national authorities (see previous report). Additional expertise\nin the COMBI approach has been sent to Madagascar and Mauritius for\nfollow-up. Similarly, Maldives has received support for their social\nmobilization activities on dengue vector control.\nIn India, a multidisciplinary national team was deployed from 13-17 Feb\n2006 to assist local health authorities in improving public health\nmeasures, including strengthening of arbovirus surveillance, clinical\nmanagement of cases, vector control and social mobilization.\nAlthough transmission of chikungunya and dengue is continuing in the\naffected areas, WHO recommends no special restrictions on travel or trade\nto or from these areas. However, it is recommended that individuals take\nprecautions to protect themselves from mosquito bites, e.g., by wearing\nclothes that minimize skin exposure and applying insect repellents to\nexposed skin or clothing in accordance with label instructions.\nFor more information about chikungunya and the outbreak on La Reunion,\nplease see the website of the Observatoire Regional de la Sante de La Reunion:\n<http://www.orsrun.net/>\nand the web site of the Institut National de Veille Sanitaire:\n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/>.\nFor more information on COMBI [The Communications-for-Behavioral Impact],\nplease see the web site of the WHO Mediterranean Centre for Vulnerability\nReduction (WMC) in Tunis:\n<http://wmc.who.int/>.\nFor more information on dengue, see the WHO dengue website:\n<http://www.who.int/topics/dengue/en/index.html>.\nFor more information on pesticides and their application for the control of\n_Aedes_ mosquitoes and other public health pests, see:\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2006/WHO_CDS_NTD_WHOPES_GCDPP_2006.1_eng.pdf>.\nFor more information on vector control and the use of pesticides, please\nsee the web site of the WHO Pesticide Evaluation Scheme:\n<http://www.who.int/whopes/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For a locator map of the Indian Ocean, please visit the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/Regional_Chykungunya_largeb.jpg>.\nWith the seemingly uncontrollable widespread epidemic of chikungunya from\nthe south western and western to the northern regions of the Indian Ocean,\nProMED-mail would appreciate greatly further information from knowledgeable\nsources. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. RFI 20060307.0734\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (06) 20060304.0699\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe 20060304.0695\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (04): vector 20060302.0664\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France 20060225.0619\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (02): Reunion 20060224.0609\nChikungunya - India (AP): susp. 20060220.0551\nChikungunya virus vaccine 20060219.0544\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (09): Reunion 20060214.0491\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (08): Reunion 20060205.0378\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (07): Reunion 20060204.0358\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - 5 Mar 2006. Estimations from a mathematical model evaluate\nthat 204 000 people may have been infected by chikungunya virus since March\n2005 on La Reunion, including 13 000 persons during the week 27 Feb - 5 Mar\n2006. Additional expertise\nin the COMBI approach has been sent to Madagascar and Mauritius for\nfollow-up. Similarly, Maldives has received support for their social\nmobilization activities on dengue vector control.\nIn India, a multidisciplinary national team was deployed from 13-17 Feb\n2006 to assist local health authorities in improving public health\nmeasures, including strengthening of arbovirus surveillance, clinical\nmanagement of cases, vector control and social mobilization.\nAlthough transmission of chikungunya and dengue is continuing in the\naffected areas, WHO recommends no special restrictions on travel or trade\nto or from these areas. However, it is recommended that individuals take\nprecautions to protect themselves from mosquito bites, e.g., by wearing\nclothes that minimize skin exposure and applying insect repellents to\nexposed skin or clothing in accordance with label instructions.\nFor more information about chikungunya and the outbreak on La Reunion,\nplease see the website of the Observatoire Regional de la Sante de La Reunion:\n<http://www.orsrun.net/>\nand the web site of the Institut National de Veille Sanitaire:\n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/>.\nFor more information on COMBI [The Communications-for-Behavioral Impact],\nplease see the web site of the WHO Mediterranean Centre for Vulnerability\nReduction (WMC) in Tunis:\n<http://wmc.who.int/>.\nFor more information on dengue, see the WHO dengue website:\n<http://www.who.int/topics/dengue/en/index.html>.\nFor more information on pesticides and their application for the control of\n_Aedes_ mosquitoes and other public health pests, see:\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2006/WHO_CDS_NTD_WHOPES_GCDPP_2006.1_eng.pdf>.\nFor more information on vector control and the use of pesticides, please\nsee the web site of the WHO Pesticide Evaluation Scheme:\n<http://www.who.int/whopes/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For a locator map of the Indian Ocean, please visit the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/Regional_Chykungunya_largeb.jpg>.\nWith the seemingly uncontrollable widespread epidemic of chikungunya from\nthe south western and western to the northern regions of the Indian Ocean,\nProMED-mail would appreciate greatly further information from knowledgeable\nsources. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. China (Hong Kong) ex Mauritius: conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209487", "date": "2006-03-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (09): ISLANDS, INDIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO, 17 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_03_17/en/print.html>\n\nFrom 5 Mar 2005 - 28 Mar 2006 [the latter is an obviously mistaken date],\n3115 cases of chikungunya (CHIK) have been notified by 31 physicians from a\nsentinel network on La Reunion, including 196 cases reported during the\nweek 27 Feb - 5 Mar 2006. Estimations from a mathematical model evaluate\nthat 204 000 people may have been infected by chikungunya virus since March\n2005 on La Reunion, including 13 000 persons during the week 27 Feb - 5 Mar\n2006. Between 1 Jan 2006 - 5 Mar 2006, 25 patients with clinical symptoms\nconsistent with dengue fever were laboratory confirmed. 5 were isolated\ncases and 20 were suspected cases of co-infection chikungunya-dengue.\nSince the beginning of January 2006, other countries in the south west\nIndian Ocean have reported chikungunya cases: Mayotte (9 Jan - 10 Mar, 2833\nsuspected cases), Mauritius (1 Jan - 5 Mar, c. 6000 suspected cases\nincluding 1200 confirmed cases), and the Seychelles (1 Jan - 26 Feb, 8818\nsuspected cases).\nSeveral European countries have reported imported cases in people returning\nfrom these islands: France (160 imported cases), Germany, Italy, Norway and\nSwitzerland.\nA mixed outbreak of chikungunya, with sporadic cases of dengue has been\nreported in Andhra Pradesh state, India. Between 1 Dec 2005 - 17 Feb 2006,\n5671 cases of fever with arthralgia were reported. A high density of _Aedes\naegypti_ was observed in the area. From 1-15 Mar 2006, over 2000 cases of\nchikungunya have been reported from Malegaon town in Nasik district,\nMaharashtra state, India. In Orissa state, India, 4904 cases of fever\nassociated with myalgia and headache have been reported between 27 Feb - 5\nMar 2006. These signs are consistent with an arbovirus outbreak. Results of\na biological investigation are awaited.\nControl measures:\nA WHO team from the Regional Office for Africa and from headquarters was\ndeployed to the south west Indian Ocean in February-March 2006 to assess\nthe control measures underway in the islands and to discuss a sub-regional\ncoordinated strategy for surveillance and control of arboviruses in the\narea with national authorities (see previous report). Additional expertise\nin the COMBI approach has been sent to Madagascar and Mauritius for\nfollow-up. Similarly, Maldives has received support for their social\nmobilization activities on dengue vector control.\nIn India, a multidisciplinary national team was deployed from 13-17 Feb\n2006 to assist local health authorities in improving public health\nmeasures, including strengthening of arbovirus surveillance, clinical\nmanagement of cases, vector control and social mobilization.\nAlthough transmission of chikungunya and dengue is continuing in the\naffected areas, WHO recommends no special restrictions on travel or trade\nto or from these areas. However, it is recommended that individuals take\nprecautions to protect themselves from mosquito bites, e.g., by wearing\nclothes that minimize skin exposure and applying insect repellents to\nexposed skin or clothing in accordance with label instructions.\nFor more information about chikungunya and the outbreak on La Reunion,\nplease see the website of the Observatoire Regional de la Sante de La Reunion:\n<http://www.orsrun.net/>\nand the web site of the Institut National de Veille Sanitaire:\n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/>.\nFor more information on COMBI [The Communications-for-Behavioral Impact],\nplease see the web site of the WHO Mediterranean Centre for Vulnerability\nReduction (WMC) in Tunis:\n<http://wmc.who.int/>.\nFor more information on dengue, see the WHO dengue website:\n<http://www.who.int/topics/dengue/en/index.html>.\nFor more information on pesticides and their application for the control of\n_Aedes_ mosquitoes and other public health pests, see:\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2006/WHO_CDS_NTD_WHOPES_GCDPP_2006.1_eng.pdf>.\nFor more information on vector control and the use of pesticides, please\nsee the web site of the WHO Pesticide Evaluation Scheme:\n<http://www.who.int/whopes/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For a locator map of the Indian Ocean, please visit the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/Regional_Chykungunya_largeb.jpg>.\nWith the seemingly uncontrollable widespread epidemic of chikungunya from\nthe south western and western to the northern regions of the Indian Ocean,\nProMED-mail would appreciate greatly further information from knowledgeable\nsources. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. Indian Ocean update (10): Reunion seq.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209451", "date": "2006-03-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (09): ISLANDS, INDIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO, 17 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_03_17/en/print.html>\n\nFrom 5 Mar 2005 - 28 Mar 2006 [the latter is an obviously mistaken date],\n3115 cases of chikungunya (CHIK) have been notified by 31 physicians from a\nsentinel network on La Reunion, including 196 cases reported during the\nweek 27 Feb - 5 Mar 2006. Estimations from a mathematical model evaluate\nthat 204 000 people may have been infected by chikungunya virus since March\n2005 on La Reunion, including 13 000 persons during the week 27 Feb - 5 Mar\n2006. Between 1 Jan 2006 - 5 Mar 2006, 25 patients with clinical symptoms\nconsistent with dengue fever were laboratory confirmed. 5 were isolated\ncases and 20 were suspected cases of co-infection chikungunya-dengue.\nSince the beginning of January 2006, other countries in the south west\nIndian Ocean have reported chikungunya cases: Mayotte (9 Jan - 10 Mar, 2833\nsuspected cases), Mauritius (1 Jan - 5 Mar, c. 6000 suspected cases\nincluding 1200 confirmed cases), and the Seychelles (1 Jan - 26 Feb, 8818\nsuspected cases).\nSeveral European countries have reported imported cases in people returning\nfrom these islands: France (160 imported cases), Germany, Italy, Norway and\nSwitzerland.\nA mixed outbreak of chikungunya, with sporadic cases of dengue has been\nreported in Andhra Pradesh state, India. Between 1 Dec 2005 - 17 Feb 2006,\n5671 cases of fever with arthralgia were reported. A high density of _Aedes\naegypti_ was observed in the area. From 1-15 Mar 2006, over 2000 cases of\nchikungunya have been reported from Malegaon town in Nasik district,\nMaharashtra state, India. In Orissa state, India, 4904 cases of fever\nassociated with myalgia and headache have been reported between 27 Feb - 5\nMar 2006. These signs are consistent with an arbovirus outbreak. Results of\na biological investigation are awaited.\nControl measures:\nA WHO team from the Regional Office for Africa and from headquarters was\ndeployed to the south west Indian Ocean in February-March 2006 to assess\nthe control measures underway in the islands and to discuss a sub-regional\ncoordinated strategy for surveillance and control of arboviruses in the\narea with national authorities (see previous report). Additional expertise\nin the COMBI approach has been sent to Madagascar and Mauritius for\nfollow-up. Similarly, Maldives has received support for their social\nmobilization activities on dengue vector control.\nIn India, a multidisciplinary national team was deployed from 13-17 Feb\n2006 to assist local health authorities in improving public health\nmeasures, including strengthening of arbovirus surveillance, clinical\nmanagement of cases, vector control and social mobilization.\nAlthough transmission of chikungunya and dengue is continuing in the\naffected areas, WHO recommends no special restrictions on travel or trade\nto or from these areas. However, it is recommended that individuals take\nprecautions to protect themselves from mosquito bites, e.g., by wearing\nclothes that minimize skin exposure and applying insect repellents to\nexposed skin or clothing in accordance with label instructions.\nFor more information about chikungunya and the outbreak on La Reunion,\nplease see the website of the Observatoire Regional de la Sante de La Reunion:\n<http://www.orsrun.net/>\nand the web site of the Institut National de Veille Sanitaire:\n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/>.\nFor more information on COMBI [The Communications-for-Behavioral Impact],\nplease see the web site of the WHO Mediterranean Centre for Vulnerability\nReduction (WMC) in Tunis:\n<http://wmc.who.int/>.\nFor more information on dengue, see the WHO dengue website:\n<http://www.who.int/topics/dengue/en/index.html>.\nFor more information on pesticides and their application for the control of\n_Aedes_ mosquitoes and other public health pests, see:\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2006/WHO_CDS_NTD_WHOPES_GCDPP_2006.1_eng.pdf>.\nFor more information on vector control and the use of pesticides, please\nsee the web site of the WHO Pesticide Evaluation Scheme:\n<http://www.who.int/whopes/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For a locator map of the Indian Ocean, please visit the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/Regional_Chykungunya_largeb.jpg>.\nWith the seemingly uncontrollable widespread epidemic of chikungunya from\nthe south western and western to the northern regions of the Indian Ocean,\nProMED-mail would appreciate greatly further information from knowledgeable\nsources. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08) 20060316.0819\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2005-01-01 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-02-17 20:06:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "ISLANDS", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Orissa", "country": "India"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nasik district", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209425", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Indian Ocean update (08)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209425", "date": "2006-02-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (02): REUNION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Reuters AlertNet, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L23786228.htm>\n\nA mosquito-borne disease has directly or indirectly killed 77 people\non France's Indian Ocean island of La Reunion, French Health Minister\nXavier Bertrand said on Thursday.\nChikungunya fever, for which there is no known cure or vaccine, had\naffected some 130 000 people [an incidence rate of 16.8 per cent] on\nthe island off the southeast coast of Africa. Bertrand said that was\n20 000 more than a week ago.\nAround one in 6 inhabitants has now been affected on Reunion, which\nhas a total population of some 775 000 people.\n\"The last numbers ... refer to 77 deaths, directly or indirectly\nattributable to the epidemic for the month of January 2006,\" Bertrand\nsaid. \"(This is) a radically new situation, which was not expected\nbecause scientific research showed that chikungunya did not kill,\" he\nsaid.\nThe illness, which has also travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean islands of\nthe Seychelles and Mauritius [and Mayotte. - Mod.JW], is marked by high fever\nand severe [joint pains and]rashes. Most people recover although it is\nextremely painful.\nFirst recognized in East Africa in 1952, it also leaves the immune\nsystem weak, [providing] opportunities for other diseases to set in.\nThe name chikungunya comes from the Swahili for stooped walk,\nreferring to the posture of those afflicted.\nFrench Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, who is to travel to\nReunion on Sunday, said the entire island should be ridden of\nmosquitoes to stop the disease from spreading.\nVillepin said it was still safe to visit the island, which is a\npopular tourist destination for European travellers. The Reunion\nCommittee on Tourism has reported tour cancellations but has not\nprovided figures for costs incurred.\n\"You can certainly go there. The proof is that I'm going there,\"\nVillepin told Canal Plus television. \"You have to take some\nprecautions and use (certain) products,\" he said.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: New Scientist, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn8765>\n\nA team of 4 experts from the World Health Organization has left for\nthe Indian Ocean island of Reunion to investigate a massive outbreak\nof a debilitating mosquito-borne disease which causes its victims to\ndouble over.\nThe largest-ever epidemic of the chikungunya virus among people in\nReunion started in February 2005, but has gathered pace since\nDecember 2005, spreading to neighbouring countries.\nReports and estimates suggest that 110 000 of the island's 800 000 population\nhas been afflicted by the stooping disease, says WHO, although official\nfigures, from a voluntary sentinel system on the island, suggest just 1700\ncases. During the first week of February 2006, Mauritius reported 206 cases\nand the Seychelles reported 1255 cases. [110 000 is an estimate, based on\nextrapolating the number detected by the sentinel physicians to the entire\npopulation. - Mod.JW]\nThe WHO experts will assess the current actions being taken to fight\nthe chikungunya virus's spread, which include educating people about\nhow to protect themselves against the disease and bolstering\nepidemiological surveillance.\nPeople infected by the virus can also experience recurring episodes\nof pain, even after the virus appears to have cleared from their\nbodies, says Robert Tesh, an expert on mosquito-borne viruses at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston, USA. He says that\nthese returning arthritic pains may be caused by an immune system\nresponse.\nTesh explains that no quick treatment exists for chikungunya disease. Doctors\nprimarily help to alleviate the symptoms, such as fever and\ndehydration. \"There isn't much else you can do,\" he says, adding that\nhe knows of no approved vaccine against the virus.\nChikungunya is typically found in sub-Saharan Africa and tropical regions of\nAsia as far away as Indonesia. As for why such a large outbreak would occur in\nthe southwest Indian Ocean, Tesh says that this may have something to do\nwith \"herd immunity\". This describes the phenomenon in which populations\ninfected by the virus recover and gain immunity against it. When there are\nenough people in one location who boast immunity to chikungunya, the virus\ncannot easily pass from one host to another and cause an outbreak. Conversely,\nif there has been no outbreak for a long time, herd immunity falls as fewer\npeople have encountered the disease before, allowing the virus to spread more\neffectively.\n\"Weather can also play a role as it affects the abundance and\nactivity of the mosquitoes that transmit the virus,\" Tesh adds. Wet\nconditions, for example, can cause an upsurge in mosquito populations.\n[Byline: Roxanne Khamsi]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A safe and highly immunogenic live vaccine has been evaluated\nthrough phase II clinical trial since 2000. So far no further study,\nsuch as phase III multi-center clinical trial, has been documented.\nSee also: 20060219.0544. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - India (AP): susp. 20060220.0551\nChikungunya virus vaccine 20060219.0544\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (09): Reunion 20060214.0491\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (08): Reunion 20060205.0378\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (07): Reunion 20060204.0358\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\n...................ry/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "1255-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galveston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209424", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - French Guiana ex Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209424", "date": "2006-02-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (02): REUNION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Reuters AlertNet, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L23786228.htm>\n\nA mosquito-borne disease has directly or indirectly killed 77 people\non France's Indian Ocean island of La Reunion, French Health Minister\nXavier Bertrand said on Thursday.\nChikungunya fever, for which there is no known cure or vaccine, had\naffected some 130 000 people [an incidence rate of 16.8 per cent] on\nthe island off the southeast coast of Africa. Bertrand said that was\n20 000 more than a week ago.\nAround one in 6 inhabitants has now been affected on Reunion, which\nhas a total population of some 775 000 people.\n\"The last numbers ... refer to 77 deaths, directly or indirectly\nattributable to the epidemic for the month of January 2006,\" Bertrand\nsaid. \"(This is) a radically new situation, which was not expected\nbecause scientific research showed that chikungunya did not kill,\" he\nsaid.\nThe illness, which has also travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean islands of\nthe Seychelles and Mauritius [and Mayotte. - Mod.JW], is marked by high fever\nand severe [joint pains and]rashes. Most people recover although it is\nextremely painful.\nFirst recognized in East Africa in 1952, it also leaves the immune\nsystem weak, [providing] opportunities for other diseases to set in.\nThe name chikungunya comes from the Swahili for stooped walk,\nreferring to the posture of those afflicted.\nFrench Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, who is to travel to\nReunion on Sunday, said the entire island should be ridden of\nmosquitoes to stop the disease from spreading.\nVillepin said it was still safe to visit the island, which is a\npopular tourist destination for European travellers. The Reunion\nCommittee on Tourism has reported tour cancellations but has not\nprovided figures for costs incurred.\n\"You can certainly go there. The proof is that I'm going there,\"\nVillepin told Canal Plus television. \"You have to take some\nprecautions and use (certain) products,\" he said.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: New Scientist, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn8765>\n\nA team of 4 experts from the World Health Organization has left for\nthe Indian Ocean island of Reunion to investigate a massive outbreak\nof a debilitating mosquito-borne disease which causes its victims to\ndouble over.\nThe largest-ever epidemic of the chikungunya virus among people in\nReunion started in February 2005, but has gathered pace since\nDecember 2005, spreading to neighbouring countries.\nReports and estimates suggest that 110 000 of the island's 800 000 population\nhas been afflicted by the stooping disease, says WHO, although official\nfigures, from a voluntary sentinel system on the island, suggest just 1700\ncases. During the first week of February 2006, Mauritius reported 206 cases\nand the Seychelles reported 1255 cases. [110 000 is an estimate, based on\nextrapolating the number detected by the sentinel physicians to the entire\npopulation. - Mod.JW]\nThe WHO experts will assess the current actions being taken to fight\nthe chikungunya virus's spread, which include educating people about\nhow to protect themselves against the disease and bolstering\nepidemiological surveillance.\nPeople infected by the virus can also experience recurring episodes\nof pain, even after the virus appears to have cleared from their\nbodies, says Robert Tesh, an expert on mosquito-borne viruses at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston, USA. He says that\nthese returning arthritic pains may be caused by an immune system\nresponse.\nTesh explains that no quick treatment exists for chikungunya disease. Doctors\nprimarily help to alleviate the symptoms, such as fever and\ndehydration. \"There isn't much else you can do,\" he says, adding that\nhe knows of no approved vaccine against the virus.\nChikungunya is typically found in sub-Saharan Africa and tropical regions of\nAsia as far away as Indonesia. As for why such a large outbreak would occur in\nthe southwest Indian Ocean, Tesh says that this may have something to do\nwith \"herd immunity\". This describes the phenomenon in which populations\ninfected by the virus recover and gain immunity against it. When there are\nenough people in one location who boast immunity to chikungunya, the virus\ncannot easily pass from one host to another and cause an outbreak. Conversely,\nif there has been no outbreak for a long time, herd immunity falls as fewer\npeople have encountered the disease before, allowing the virus to spread more\neffectively.\n\"Weather can also play a role as it affects the abundance and\nactivity of the mosquitoes that transmit the virus,\" Tesh adds. Wet\nconditions, for example, can cause an upsurge in mosquito populations.\n[Byline: Roxanne Khamsi]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A safe and highly immunogenic live vaccine has been evaluated\nthrough phase II clinical trial since 2000. So far no further study,\nsuch as phase III multi-center clinical trial, has been documented.\nSee also: 20060219.0544. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - India (AP): susp. 20060220.0551\nChikungunya virus vaccine 20060219.0544\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (09): Reunion 20060214.0491\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (08): Reunion 20060205.0378\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (07): Reunion 20060204.0358\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\n...................ry/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "1255-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galveston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209397", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Indian Ocean update (07): Madagascar conf. Indian Ocean update (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209379", "date": "2006-02-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (02): REUNION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Reuters AlertNet, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L23786228.htm>\n\nA mosquito-borne disease has directly or indirectly killed 77 people\non France's Indian Ocean island of La Reunion, French Health Minister\nXavier Bertrand said on Thursday.\nChikungunya fever, for which there is no known cure or vaccine, had\naffected some 130 000 people [an incidence rate of 16.8 per cent] on\nthe island off the southeast coast of Africa. Most people recover although it is\nextremely painful.\nFirst recognized in East Africa in 1952, it also leaves the immune\nsystem weak, [providing] opportunities for other diseases to set in.\nThe name chikungunya comes from the Swahili for stooped walk,\nreferring to the posture of those afflicted.\nFrench Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, who is to travel to\nReunion on Sunday, said the entire island should be ridden of\nmosquitoes to stop the disease from spreading.\nVillepin said it was still safe to visit the island, which is a\npopular tourist destination for European travellers. The Reunion\nCommittee on Tourism has reported tour cancellations but has not\nprovided figures for costs incurred.\n\"You can certainly go there. The proof is that I'm going there,\"\nVillepin told Canal Plus television. \"You have to take some\nprecautions and use (certain) products,\" he said.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: New Scientist, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn8765>\n\nA team of 4 experts from the World Health Organization has left for\nthe Indian Ocean island of Reunion to investigate a massive outbreak\nof a debilitating mosquito-borne disease which causes its victims to\ndouble over.\nThe largest-ever epidemic of the chikungunya virus among people in\nReunion started in February 2005, but has gathered pace since\nDecember 2005, spreading to neighbouring countries.\nReports and estimates suggest that 110 000 of the island's 800 000 population\nhas been afflicted by the stooping disease, says WHO, although official\nfigures, from a voluntary sentinel system on the island, suggest just 1700\ncases. During the first week of February 2006, Mauritius reported 206 cases\nand the Seychelles reported 1255 cases. [110 000 is an estimate, based on\nextrapolating the number detected by the sentinel physicians to the entire\npopulation. - Mod.JW]\nThe WHO experts will assess the current actions being taken to fight\nthe chikungunya virus's spread, which include educating people about\nhow to protect themselves against the disease and bolstering\nepidemiological surveillance.\nPeople infected by the virus can also experience recurring episodes\nof pain, even after the virus appears to have cleared from their\nbodies, says Robert Tesh, an expert on mosquito-borne viruses at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston, USA. He says that\nthese returning arthritic pains may be caused by an immune system\nresponse.\nTesh explains that no quick treatment exists for chikungunya disease. Doctors\nprimarily help to alleviate the symptoms, such as fever and\ndehydration. \"There isn't much else you can do,\" he says, adding that\nhe knows of no approved vaccine against the virus.\nChikungunya is typically found in sub-Saharan Africa and tropical regions of\nAsia as far away as Indonesia. As for why such a large outbreak would occur in\nthe southwest Indian Ocean, Tesh says that this may have something to do\nwith \"herd immunity\". This describes the phenomenon in which populations\ninfected by the virus recover and gain immunity against it. When there are\nenough people in one location who boast immunity to chikungunya, the virus\ncannot easily pass from one host to another and cause an outbreak. Conversely,\nif there has been no outbreak for a long time, herd immunity falls as fewer\npeople have encountered the disease before, allowing the virus to spread more\neffectively.\n\"Weather can also play a role as it affects the abundance and\nactivity of the mosquitoes that transmit the virus,\" Tesh adds. Wet\nconditions, for example, can cause an upsurge in mosquito populations.\n[Byline: Roxanne Khamsi]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A safe and highly immunogenic live vaccine has been evaluated\nthrough phase II clinical trial since 2000. So far no further study,\nsuch as phase III multi-center clinical trial, has been documented.\nSee also: 20060219.0544. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - India (AP): susp. 20060220.0551\nChikungunya virus vaccine 20060219.0544\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (09): Reunion 20060214.0491\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (08): Reunion 20060205.0378\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (07): Reunion 20060204.0358\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\n...................ry/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "1255-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galveston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5304", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Indian Ocean update (05): spread to Europe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5304", "date": "2006-02-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (02): REUNION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Reuters AlertNet, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L23786228.htm>\n\nA mosquito-borne disease has directly or indirectly killed 77 people\non France's Indian Ocean island of La Reunion, French Health Minister\nXavier Bertrand said on Thursday.\nChikungunya fever, for which there is no known cure or vaccine, had\naffected some 130 000 people [an incidence rate of 16.8 per cent] on\nthe island off the southeast coast of Africa. Bertrand said that was\n20 000 more than a week ago.\nAround one in 6 inhabitants has now been affected on Reunion, which\nhas a total population of some 775 000 people.\n\"The last numbers ... refer to 77 deaths, directly or indirectly\nattributable to the epidemic for the month of January 2006,\" Bertrand\nsaid. \"(This is) a radically new situation, which was not expected\nbecause scientific research showed that chikungunya did not kill,\" he\nsaid.\nThe illness, which has also travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean islands of\nthe Seychelles and Mauritius [and Mayotte. - Mod.JW], is marked by high fever\nand severe [joint pains and]rashes. Most people recover although it is\nextremely painful.\nFirst recognized in East Africa in 1952, it also leaves the immune\nsystem weak, [providing] opportunities for other diseases to set in.\nThe name chikungunya comes from the Swahili for stooped walk,\nreferring to the posture of those afflicted.\nFrench Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, who is to travel to\nReunion on Sunday, said the entire island should be ridden of\nmosquitoes to stop the disease from spreading.\nVillepin said it was still safe to visit the island, which is a\npopular tourist destination for European travellers. The Reunion\nCommittee on Tourism has reported tour cancellations but has not\nprovided figures for costs incurred.\n\"You can certainly go there. The proof is that I'm going there,\"\nVillepin told Canal Plus television. \"You have to take some\nprecautions and use (certain) products,\" he said.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: New Scientist, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn8765>\n\nA team of 4 experts from the World Health Organization has left for\nthe Indian Ocean island of Reunion to investigate a massive outbreak\nof a debilitating mosquito-borne disease which causes its victims to\ndouble over.\nThe largest-ever epidemic of the chikungunya virus among people in\nReunion started in February 2005, but has gathered pace since\nDecember 2005, spreading to neighbouring countries.\nReports and estimates suggest that 110 000 of the island's 800 000 population\nhas been afflicted by the stooping disease, says WHO, although official\nfigures, from a voluntary sentinel system on the island, suggest just 1700\ncases. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "1255-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galveston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5281", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Indian Ocean update (03): spread to France", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5281", "date": "2006-02-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - INDIAN OCEAN UPDATE (02): REUNION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Reuters AlertNet, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L23786228.htm>\n\nA mosquito-borne disease has directly or indirectly killed 77 people\non France's Indian Ocean island of La Reunion, French Health Minister\nXavier Bertrand said on Thursday.\nChikungunya fever, for which there is no known cure or vaccine, had\naffected some 130 000 people [an incidence rate of 16.8 per cent] on\nthe island off the southeast coast of Africa. Bertrand said that was\n20 000 more than a week ago.\nAround one in 6 inhabitants has now been affected on Reunion, which\nhas a total population of some 775 000 people.\n\"The last numbers ... refer to 77 deaths, directly or indirectly\nattributable to the epidemic for the month of January 2006,\" Bertrand\nsaid. \"(This is) a radically new situation, which was not expected\nbecause scientific research showed that chikungunya did not kill,\" he\nsaid.\nThe illness, which has also travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean islands of\nthe Seychelles and Mauritius [and Mayotte. - Mod.JW], is marked by high fever\nand severe [joint pains and]rashes. Most people recover although it is\nextremely painful.\nFirst recognized in East Africa in 1952, it also leaves the immune\nsystem weak, [providing] opportunities for other diseases to set in.\nThe name chikungunya comes from the Swahili for stooped walk,\nreferring to the posture of those afflicted.\nFrench Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, who is to travel to\nReunion on Sunday, said the entire island should be ridden of\nmosquitoes to stop the disease from spreading.\nVillepin said it was still safe to visit the island, which is a\npopular tourist destination for European travellers. The Reunion\nCommittee on Tourism has reported tour cancellations but has not\nprovided figures for costs incurred.\n\"You can certainly go there. The proof is that I'm going there,\"\nVillepin told Canal Plus television. \"You have to take some\nprecautions and use (certain) products,\" he said.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 05:07:38 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <a-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: New Scientist, 24 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn8765>\n\nA team of 4 experts from the World Health Organization has left for\nthe Indian Ocean island of Reunion to investigate a massive outbreak\nof a debilitating mosquito-borne disease which causes its victims to\ndouble over.\nThe largest-ever epidemic of the chikungunya virus among people in\nReunion started in February 2005, but has gathered pace since\nDecember 2005, spreading to neighbouring countries.\nReports and estimates suggest that 110 000 of the island's 800 000 population\nhas been afflicted by the stooping disease, says WHO, although official\nfigures, from a voluntary sentinel system on the island, suggest just 1700\ncases. During the first week of February 2006, Mauritius reported 206 cases\nand the Seychelles reported 1255 cases. [110 000 is an estimate, based on\nextrapolating the number detected by the sentinel physicians to the entire\npopulation. - Mod.JW]\nThe WHO experts will assess the current actions being taken to fight\nthe chikungunya virus's spread, which include educating people about\nhow to protect themselves against the disease and bolstering\nepidemiological surveillance.\nPeople infected by the virus can also experience recurring episodes\nof pain, even after the virus appears to have cleared from their\nbodies, says Robert Tesh, an expert on mosquito-borne viruses at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston, USA. He says that\nthese returning arthritic pains may be caused by an immune system\nresponse.\nTesh explains that no quick treatment exists for chikungunya disease. Doctors\nprimarily help to alleviate the symptoms, such as fever and\ndehydration. \"There isn't much else you can do,\" he says, adding that\nhe knows of no approved vaccine against the virus.\nChikungunya is typically found in sub-Saharan Africa and tropical regions of\nAsia as far away as Indonesia. As for why such a large outbreak would occur in\nthe southwest Indian Ocean, Tesh says that this may have something to do\nwith \"herd immunity\". This describes the phenomenon in which populations\ninfected by the virus recover and gain immunity against it. When there are\nenough people in one location who boast immunity to chikungunya, the virus\ncannot easily pass from one host to another and cause an outbreak. Conversely,\nif there has been no outbreak for a long time, herd immunity falls as fewer\npeople have encountered the disease before, allowing the virus to spread more\neffectively.\n\"Weather can also play a role as it affects the abundance and\nactivity of the mosquitoes that transmit the virus,\" Tesh adds. Wet\nconditions, for example, can cause an upsurge in mosquito populations.\n[Byline: Roxanne Khamsi]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A safe and highly immunogenic live vaccine has been evaluated\nthrough phase II clinical trial since 2000. So far no further study,\nsuch as phase III multi-center clinical trial, has been documented.\nSee also: 20060219.0544. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - India (AP): susp. 20060220.0551\nChikungunya virus vaccine 20060219.0544\nChikungunya - Indian Ocean update 20060218.0525\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius 20060216.0509\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (09): Reunion 20060214.0491\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (08): Reunion 20060205.0378\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (07): Reunion 20060204.0358\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\n...................ry/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
