For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2006-02-24 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "1255-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galveston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209314", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - India (AP): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209314", "date": "2006-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND (07): REUNION\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this issue:\n[1] Reunion update\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\n[3] Mauritius\n******\n[1] Reunion\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 05:56:22 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: BBC News, UK, 3 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4674376.stm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease is spreading at an accelerating\nrate on the French Indian Ocean island of Reunion, health officials say.\nThey say the number of cases of the viral illness, known as\nchikungunya, had risen to 50 000, an increase of 15 000 in the past week alone.\nThe disease is not fatal, but those affected suffer high fever and\nsevere pain. There is no cure or vaccine.\nHundreds of troops have been deployed on the island to eradicate mosquitoes.\nOfficials said the troops would be spraying the whole island against\nmosquitoes in the coming days.\nThe latest outbreak was first noticed there in February 2005 - but\nhas spread at an accelerating rate since December.\nMeanwhile, neighboring territories are mobilizing to contain the disease.\nOn the Seychelles - where 2,000 cases have been reported in the past\n4 weeks - the army has been mobilized to exterminate mosquitoes,\nReuters news agency reports.\nThe authorities in Madagascar also fear the disease may have reached\ntheir island, AFP news agency says.\nChikungunya fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that which\nbends up\" - referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The spreading speed at 15 000 cases per week, or 2143 per day, is\nincredible. A bit of geography and climate may be of interest to our\nreaders. Reunion is located east of Madagascar and is a part of the\nMadagascar archipelago. Situated between the equator and the tropic\nof Capricorn, Reunion's climate is of tropical type (southern\nhemisphere) with oceanic influence. The island is home to one of the\nworld's most active volcanoes. There are 2 seasons: cool or dry\nseason (May till October) and warm or wet season (November till\nApril). Currently it is in the middle of the warm season when\nmosquitoes are most active and proliferative. The island was ruled as\na colony until 1946, when it was made a \"departement\" (=department),\nor administrative unit, of France. - Mod.RY]\n******\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\nDate: 4 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alert [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L04459988.htm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease has claimed its first life and\ninfected more than 50 000 people on the volcanic French island of\nReunion, spooking tourists in the region, local authorities said.\nThe \"chikungunya\" disease, which is extremely painful and causes high\nfever, was not previously thought to be lethal and there is no known\ncure or vaccine.\nThe Reunion Regional Agency for Hospitalisation said late on Friday\nthe virus was the only explanation for the death of a 9-year-old in\nJanuary [2006].\nThe \"chikungunya\" fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that\nwhich bends up,\" referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\nFirst recognised in epidemic form in East Africa in 1952, it also\nleaves immune systems weak, providing opportunities for other\ndiseases to set in.\nThe disease, which has already travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean\nislands of Seychelles, Mauritius and Mayotte, has prompted tourists\nto cancel bookings.\nSince 23 Jan [2006], the Reunion Committee on Tourism said at least\n1500 tours had been cancelled and the costs incurred from\ncancellations over the past 2 weeks were equal to its annual\nadvertising budget. It did not provide any figures.\nOn Thursday [2 Feb 2006], Seychelles said it had mobilised its army\nto control the virus which has infected 2000 of the idyllic\narchipelago's 80 000 people.\nReunion last week earmarked $720 000 to fight the outbreak, drafting\n400 extra troops to help fight the mosquitoes that have spread the\ndisease for nearly a year.\nIn neighbouring Mauritius, authorities are screening people at the\nairport and port, spraying places near hotels and guest houses and\nwarning the public to take precautions.\nThe Reunion authorities said they planned to set up a scientific\ncommittee to better understand the disease. They said they had\nregistered some 25 deaths citing the virus as a possible cause.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fatalities are not commonly seen with chikungunya. More information\non these above mentioned cases would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3] Mauritius\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 14:43:53 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: Mohammad Issack <missack@intnet.mu>\nSource: Le Mauricien, 3 Feb 2006 [trans. and edited]\n<http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/index.html>\n\nMauritian authorities are on high alert after the identification of 2\nconfirmed cases of Chikungunya in Mahebourg. A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. [Even if] the port\nand the airport are watched closely by the Health Inspectorate\nDivision, there is no protocol to quarantine travellers arriving from\nReunion Island. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. The Ministry of Health is requesting all hotels and all\nmedical practitioners in private practice to notify any suspect case.\nPersonal comment:\nIn Mauritius, the peak of the Chikungunya outbreak occurred in May\n[2005] when several hundred cases were reported per week. The number\nof cases started to fall in June and by September, only occasional\ncases were reported. Most cases reported in January [2006] occurred\nin people who had a history of recent travel to Reunion Island.\nHowever, in the [last] 10 days, some cases in people without history\nof travel have been reported. Some have been confirmed by virus\nisolation in tissue culture from blood samples. With the exception of\nthe cluster in Mahebourg, the other cases live in different regions\nof Mauritius.\nUp to now, the situation with Chikungunya virus has been much less\ndramatic than in Reunion Island. However, this may change. December\n[2005] was very dry in Mauritius, and heavy summer rainfall did not\noccur until 23 Jan 2006.\n--\nDr. M. I. Issack\nPathologist (Microbiology)\nCentral Health Laboratory\nMauritius\n<missack@intnet.mu>\n[ProMED is grateful for the timely information and comment given by\nDr. M. I. Issack from Mauritius. In the wake of the extraordinary\nepidemic of chikungunya on Reunion Island, spread of the epidemic to\nother islands seems inevitable. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2143-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2021-04-15 00:00:00", "1946-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2006-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahebourg", "country": "Mauritius"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209310", "headline": "PRO> Chikungunya virus vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209310", "date": "2006-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND (07): REUNION\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this issue:\n[1] Reunion update\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\n[3] Mauritius\n******\n[1] Reunion\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 05:56:22 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: BBC News, UK, 3 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4674376.stm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease is spreading at an accelerating\nrate on the French Indian Ocean island of Reunion, health officials say.\nThey say the number of cases of the viral illness, known as\nchikungunya, had risen to 50 000, an increase of 15 000 in the past week alone.\nThe disease is not fatal, but those affected suffer high fever and\nsevere pain. There is no cure or vaccine.\nHundreds of troops have been deployed on the island to eradicate mosquitoes.\nOfficials said the troops would be spraying the whole island against\nmosquitoes in the coming days.\nThe latest outbreak was first noticed there in February 2005 - but\nhas spread at an accelerating rate since December.\nMeanwhile, neighboring territories are mobilizing to contain the disease.\nOn the Seychelles - where 2,000 cases have been reported in the past\n4 weeks - the army has been mobilized to exterminate mosquitoes,\nReuters news agency reports.\nThe authorities in Madagascar also fear the disease may have reached\ntheir island, AFP news agency says.\nChikungunya fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that which\nbends up\" - referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The spreading speed at 15 000 cases per week, or 2143 per day, is\nincredible. A bit of geography and climate may be of interest to our\nreaders. Reunion is located east of Madagascar and is a part of the\nMadagascar archipelago. Situated between the equator and the tropic\nof Capricorn, Reunion's climate is of tropical type (southern\nhemisphere) with oceanic influence. The island is home to one of the\nworld's most active volcanoes. There are 2 seasons: cool or dry\nseason (May till October) and warm or wet season (November till\nApril). Currently it is in the middle of the warm season when\nmosquitoes are most active and proliferative. The island was ruled as\na colony until 1946, when it was made a \"departement\" (=department),\nor administrative unit, of France. - Mod.RY]\n******\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\nDate: 4 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alert [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L04459988.htm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease has claimed its first life and\ninfected more than 50 000 people on the volcanic French island of\nReunion, spooking tourists in the region, local authorities said.\nThe \"chikungunya\" disease, which is extremely painful and causes high\nfever, was not previously thought to be lethal and there is no known\ncure or vaccine.\nThe Reunion Regional Agency for Hospitalisation said late on Friday\nthe virus was the only explanation for the death of a 9-year-old in\nJanuary [2006].\nThe \"chikungunya\" fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that\nwhich bends up,\" referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\nFirst recognised in epidemic form in East Africa in 1952, it also\nleaves immune systems weak, providing opportunities for other\ndiseases to set in.\nThe disease, which has already travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean\nislands of Seychelles, Mauritius and Mayotte, has prompted tourists\nto cancel bookings.\nSince 23 Jan [2006], the Reunion Committee on Tourism said at least\n1500 tours had been cancelled and the costs incurred from\ncancellations over the past 2 weeks were equal to its annual\nadvertising budget. It did not provide any figures.\nOn Thursday [2 Feb 2006], Seychelles said it had mobilised its army\nto control the virus which has infected 2000 of the idyllic\narchipelago's 80 000 people.\nReunion last week earmarked $720 000 to fight the outbreak, drafting\n400 extra troops to help fight the mosquitoes that have spread the\ndisease for nearly a year.\nIn neighbouring Mauritius, authorities are screening people at the\nairport and port, spraying places near hotels and guest houses and\nwarning the public to take precautions.\nThe Reunion authorities said they planned to set up a scientific\ncommittee to better understand the disease. They said they had\nregistered some 25 deaths citing the virus as a possible cause.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fatalities are not commonly seen with chikungunya. More information\non these above mentioned cases would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3] Mauritius\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 14:43:53 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: Mohammad Issack <missack@intnet.mu>\nSource: Le Mauricien, 3 Feb 2006 [trans. and edited]\n<http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/index.html>\n\nMauritian authorities are on high alert after the identification of 2\nconfirmed cases of Chikungunya in Mahebourg. A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. [Even if] the port\nand the airport are watched closely by the Health Inspectorate\nDivision, there is no protocol to quarantine travellers arriving from\nReunion Island. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. The Ministry of Health is requesting all hotels and all\nmedical practitioners in private practice to notify any suspect case.\nPersonal comment:\nIn Mauritius, the peak of the Chikungunya outbreak occurred in May\n[2005] when several hundred cases were reported per week. The number\nof cases started to fall in June and by September, only occasional\ncases were reported. Most cases reported in January [2006] occurred\nin people who had a history of recent travel to Reunion Island.\nHowever, in the [last] 10 days, some cases in people without history\nof travel have been reported. Some have been confirmed by virus\nisolation in tissue culture from blood samples. With the exception of\nthe cluster in Mahebourg, the other cases live in different regions\nof Mauritius.\nUp to now, the situation with Chikungunya virus has been much less\ndramatic than in Reunion Island. However, this may change. December\n[2005] was very dry in Mauritius, and heavy summer rainfall did not\noccur until 23 Jan 2006.\n--\nDr. M. I. Issack\nPathologist (Microbiology)\nCentral Health Laboratory\nMauritius\n<missack@intnet.mu>\n[ProMED is grateful for the timely information and comment given by\nDr. M. I. Issack from Mauritius. In the wake of the extraordinary\nepidemic of chikungunya on Reunion Island, spread of the epidemic to\nother islands seems inevitable. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n...................ry/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2143-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2021-04-15 00:00:00", "1946-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2006-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahebourg", "country": "Mauritius"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209295", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (10): Mauritius", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209295", "date": "2006-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND (07): REUNION\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this issue:\n[1] Reunion update\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\n[3] Mauritius\n******\n[1] Reunion\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 05:56:22 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: BBC News, UK, 3 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4674376.stm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease is spreading at an accelerating\nrate on the French Indian Ocean island of Reunion, health officials say.\nThey say the number of cases of the viral illness, known as\nchikungunya, had risen to 50 000, an increase of 15 000 in the past week alone.\nThe disease is not fatal, but those affected suffer high fever and\nsevere pain. There is no cure or vaccine.\nHundreds of troops have been deployed on the island to eradicate mosquitoes.\nOfficials said the troops would be spraying the whole island against\nmosquitoes in the coming days.\nThe latest outbreak was first noticed there in February 2005 - but\nhas spread at an accelerating rate since December.\nMeanwhile, neighboring territories are mobilizing to contain the disease.\nOn the Seychelles - where 2,000 cases have been reported in the past\n4 weeks - the army has been mobilized to exterminate mosquitoes,\nReuters news agency reports.\nThe authorities in Madagascar also fear the disease may have reached\ntheir island, AFP news agency says.\nChikungunya fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that which\nbends up\" - referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The spreading speed at 15 000 cases per week, or 2143 per day, is\nincredible. A bit of geography and climate may be of interest to our\nreaders. Reunion is located east of Madagascar and is a part of the\nMadagascar archipelago. Situated between the equator and the tropic\nof Capricorn, Reunion's climate is of tropical type (southern\nhemisphere) with oceanic influence. The island is home to one of the\nworld's most active volcanoes. There are 2 seasons: cool or dry\nseason (May till October) and warm or wet season (November till\nApril). Currently it is in the middle of the warm season when\nmosquitoes are most active and proliferative. The island was ruled as\na colony until 1946, when it was made a \"departement\" (=department),\nor administrative unit, of France. - Mod.RY]\n******\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\nDate: 4 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alert [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L04459988.htm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease has claimed its first life and\ninfected more than 50 000 people on the volcanic French island of\nReunion, spooking tourists in the region, local authorities said.\nThe \"chikungunya\" disease, which is extremely painful and causes high\nfever, was not previously thought to be lethal and there is no known\ncure or vaccine.\nThe Reunion Regional Agency for Hospitalisation said late on Friday\nthe virus was the only explanation for the death of a 9-year-old in\nJanuary [2006].\nThe \"chikungunya\" fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that\nwhich bends up,\" referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\nFirst recognised in epidemic form in East Africa in 1952, it also\nleaves immune systems weak, providing opportunities for other\ndiseases to set in.\nThe disease, which has already travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean\nislands of Seychelles, Mauritius and Mayotte, has prompted tourists\nto cancel bookings.\nSince 23 Jan [2006], the Reunion Committee on Tourism said at least\n1500 tours had been cancelled and the costs incurred from\ncancellations over the past 2 weeks were equal to its annual\nadvertising budget. It did not provide any figures.\nOn Thursday [2 Feb 2006], Seychelles said it had mobilised its army\nto control the virus which has infected 2000 of the idyllic\narchipelago's 80 000 people.\nReunion last week earmarked $720 000 to fight the outbreak, drafting\n400 extra troops to help fight the mosquitoes that have spread the\ndisease for nearly a year.\nIn neighbouring Mauritius, authorities are screening people at the\nairport and port, spraying places near hotels and guest houses and\nwarning the public to take precautions.\nThe Reunion authorities said they planned to set up a scientific\ncommittee to better understand the disease. They said they had\nregistered some 25 deaths citing the virus as a possible cause.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fatalities are not commonly seen with chikungunya. More information\non these above mentioned cases would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3] Mauritius\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 14:43:53 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: Mohammad Issack <missack@intnet.mu>\nSource: Le Mauricien, 3 Feb 2006 [trans. and edited]\n<http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/index.html>\n\nMauritian authorities are on high alert after the identification of 2\nconfirmed cases of Chikungunya in Mahebourg. A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. [Even if] the port\nand the airport are watched closely by the Health Inspectorate\nDivision, there is no protocol to quarantine travellers arriving from\nReunion Island. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. The Ministry of Health is requesting all hotels and all\nmedical practitioners in private practice to notify any suspect case.\nPersonal comment:\nIn Mauritius, the peak of the Chikungunya outbreak occurred in May\n[2005] when several hundred cases were reported per week. The number\nof cases started to fall in June and by September, only occasional\ncases were reported. Most cases reported in January [2006] occurred\nin people who had a history of recent travel to Reunion Island.\nHowever, in the [last] 10 days, some cases in people without history\nof travel have been reported. Some have been confirmed by virus\nisolation in tissue culture from blood samples. With the exception of\nthe cluster in Mahebourg, the other cases live in different regions\nof Mauritius.\nUp to now, the situation with Chikungunya virus has been much less\ndramatic than in Reunion Island. However, this may change. December\n[2005] was very dry in Mauritius, and heavy summer rainfall did not\noccur until 23 Jan 2006.\n--\nDr. M. I. Issack\nPathologist (Microbiology)\nCentral Health Laboratory\nMauritius\n<missack@intnet.mu>\n[ProMED is grateful for the timely information and comment given by\nDr. M. I. Issack from Mauritius. In the wake of the extraordinary\nepidemic of chikungunya on Reunion Island, spread of the epidemic to\nother islands seems inevitable. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion 20060203.0343\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (05): Reunion 20060131.0306\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20060127.0254\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n...................ry/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More information\non these above mentioned cases would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3] Mauritius\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 14:43:53 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: Mohammad Issack <missack@intnet.mu>\nSource: Le Mauricien, 3 Feb 2006 [trans. and edited]\n<http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/index.html>\n\nMauritian authorities are on high alert after the identification of 2\nconfirmed cases of Chikungunya in Mahebourg. A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. [Even if] the port\nand the airport are watched closely by the Health Inspectorate\nDivision, there is no protocol to quarantine travellers arriving from\nReunion Island. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. The Ministry of Health is requesting all hotels and all\nmedical practitioners in private practice to notify any suspect case.\nPersonal comment:\nIn Mauritius, the peak of the Chikungunya outbreak occurred in May\n[2005] when several hundred cases were reported per week. The number\nof cases started to fall in June and by September, only occasional\ncases were reported. Most cases reported in January [2006] occurred\nin people who had a history of recent travel to Reunion Island.\nHowever, in the [last] 10 days, some cases in people without history\nof travel have been reported. Some have been confirmed by virus\nisolation in tissue culture from blood samples. With the exception of\nthe cluster in Mahebourg, the other cases live in different regions\nof Mauritius.\nUp to now, the situation with Chikungunya virus has been much less\ndramatic than in Reunion Island. However, this may change. December\n[2005] was very dry in Mauritius, and heavy summer rainfall did not\noccur until 23 Jan 2006.\n--\nDr. M. I. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2143-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2021-04-15 00:00:00", "1946-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2006-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahebourg", "country": "Mauritius"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209285", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (09): Reunion", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209285", "date": "2006-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND (07): REUNION\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this issue:\n[1] Reunion update\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\n[3] Mauritius\n******\n[1] Reunion\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 05:56:22 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: BBC News, UK, 3 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4674376.stm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease is spreading at an accelerating\nrate on the French Indian Ocean island of Reunion, health officials say.\nThey say the number of cases of the viral illness, known as\nchikungunya, had risen to 50 000, an increase of 15 000 in the past week alone.\nThe disease is not fatal, but those affected suffer high fever and\nsevere pain. There is no cure or vaccine.\nHundreds of troops have been deployed on the island to eradicate mosquitoes.\nOfficials said the troops would be spraying the whole island against\nmosquitoes in the coming days.\nThe latest outbreak was first noticed there in February 2005 - but\nhas spread at an accelerating rate since December.\nMeanwhile, neighboring territories are mobilizing to contain the disease.\nOn the Seychelles - where 2,000 cases have been reported in the past\n4 weeks - the army has been mobilized to exterminate mosquitoes,\nReuters news agency reports.\nThe authorities in Madagascar also fear the disease may have reached\ntheir island, AFP news agency says.\nChikungunya fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that which\nbends up\" - referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The spreading speed at 15 000 cases per week, or 2143 per day, is\nincredible. A bit of geography and climate may be of interest to our\nreaders. Reunion is located east of Madagascar and is a part of the\nMadagascar archipelago. Situated between the equator and the tropic\nof Capricorn, Reunion's climate is of tropical type (southern\nhemisphere) with oceanic influence. The island is home to one of the\nworld's most active volcanoes. There are 2 seasons: cool or dry\nseason (May till October) and warm or wet season (November till\nApril). Currently it is in the middle of the warm season when\nmosquitoes are most active and proliferative. The island was ruled as\na colony until 1946, when it was made a \"departement\" (=department),\nor administrative unit, of France. - Mod.RY]\n******\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\nDate: 4 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alert [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L04459988.htm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease has claimed its first life and\ninfected more than 50 000 people on the volcanic French island of\nReunion, spooking tourists in the region, local authorities said.\nThe \"chikungunya\" disease, which is extremely painful and causes high\nfever, was not previously thought to be lethal and there is no known\ncure or vaccine.\nThe Reunion Regional Agency for Hospitalisation said late on Friday\nthe virus was the only explanation for the death of a 9-year-old in\nJanuary [2006].\nThe \"chikungunya\" fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that\nwhich bends up,\" referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\nFirst recognised in epidemic form in East Africa in 1952, it also\nleaves immune systems weak, providing opportunities for other\ndiseases to set in.\nThe disease, which has already travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean\nislands of Seychelles, Mauritius and Mayotte, has prompted tourists\nto cancel bookings.\nSince 23 Jan [2006], the Reunion Committee on Tourism said at least\n1500 tours had been cancelled and the costs incurred from\ncancellations over the past 2 weeks were equal to its annual\nadvertising budget. It did not provide any figures.\nOn Thursday [2 Feb 2006], Seychelles said it had mobilised its army\nto control the virus which has infected 2000 of the idyllic\narchipelago's 80 000 people.\nReunion last week earmarked $720 000 to fight the outbreak, drafting\n400 extra troops to help fight the mosquitoes that have spread the\ndisease for nearly a year.\nIn neighbouring Mauritius, authorities are screening people at the\nairport and port, spraying places near hotels and guest houses and\nwarning the public to take precautions.\nThe Reunion authorities said they planned to set up a scientific\ncommittee to better understand the disease. They said they had\nregistered some 25 deaths citing the virus as a possible cause.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fatalities are not commonly seen with chikungunya. More information\non these above mentioned cases would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3] Mauritius\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 14:43:53 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: Mohammad Issack <missack@intnet.mu>\nSource: Le Mauricien, 3 Feb 2006 [trans. and edited]\n<http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/index.html>\n\nMauritian authorities are on high alert after the identification of 2\nconfirmed cases of Chikungunya in Mahebourg. A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. [Even if] the port\nand the airport are watched closely by the Health Inspectorate\nDivision, there is no protocol to quarantine travellers arriving from\nReunion Island. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. The Ministry of Health is requesting all hotels and all\nmedical practitioners in private practice to notify any suspect case.\nPersonal comment:\nIn Mauritius, the peak of the Chikungunya outbreak occurred in May\n[2005] when several hundred cases were reported per week. The number\nof cases started to fall in June and by September, only occasional\ncases were reported. Most cases reported in January [2006] occurred\nin people who had a history of recent travel to Reunion Island.\nHowever, in the [last] 10 days, some cases in people without history\nof travel have been reported. Some have been confirmed by virus\nisolation in tissue culture from blood samples. With the exception of\nthe cluster in Mahebourg, the other cases live in different regions\nof Mauritius.\nUp to now, the situation with Chikungunya virus has been much less\ndramatic than in Reunion Island. However, this may change. December\n[2005] was very dry in Mauritius, and heavy summer rainfall did not\noccur until 23 Jan 2006.\n--\nDr. M. I. Issack\nPathologist (Microbiology)\nCentral Health Laboratory\nMauritius\n<missack@intnet.mu>\n[ProMED is grateful for the timely information and comment given by\nDr. M. I. Issack from Mauritius. In the wake of the extraordinary\nepidemic of chikungunya on Reunion Island, spread of the epidemic to\nother islands seems inevitable. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03): Reunion 20060124.0230\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (02): Reunion 20060121.0202\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island: Reunion 20060102.0007\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2143-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2021-04-15 00:00:00", "1946-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2006-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahebourg", "country": "Mauritius"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209245", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - The island was ruled as\na colony until 1946, when it was made a \"departement\" (=department),\nor administrative unit, of France. - Mod.RY]\n******\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\nDate: 4 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alert [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L04459988.htm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease has claimed its first life and\ninfected more than 50 000 people on the volcanic French island of\nReunion, spooking tourists in the region, local authorities said.\nThe \"chikungunya\" disease, which is extremely painful and causes high\nfever, was not previously thought to be lethal and there is no known\ncure or vaccine.\nThe Reunion Regional Agency for Hospitalisation said late on Friday\nthe virus was the only explanation for the death of a 9-year-old in\nJanuary [2006].\nThe \"chikungunya\" fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that\nwhich bends up,\" referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\nFirst recognised in epidemic form in East Africa in 1952, it also\nleaves immune systems weak, providing opportunities for other\ndiseases to set in.\nThe disease, which has already travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean\nislands of Seychelles, Mauritius and Mayotte, has prompted tourists\nto cancel bookings.\nSince 23 Jan [2006], the Reunion Committee on Tourism said at least\n1500 tours had been cancelled and the costs incurred from\ncancellations over the past 2 weeks were equal to its annual\nadvertising budget. More information\non these above mentioned cases would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3] Mauritius\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 14:43:53 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: Mohammad Issack <missack@intnet.mu>\nSource: Le Mauricien, 3 Feb 2006 [trans. and edited]\n<http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/index.html>\n\nMauritian authorities are on high alert after the identification of 2\nconfirmed cases of Chikungunya in Mahebourg. A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. [Even if] the port\nand the airport are watched closely by the Health Inspectorate\nDivision, there is no protocol to quarantine travellers arriving from\nReunion Island. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. The Ministry of Health is requesting all hotels and all\nmedical practitioners in private practice to notify any suspect case.\nPersonal comment:\nIn Mauritius, the peak of the Chikungunya outbreak occurred in May\n[2005] when several hundred cases were reported per week. The number\nof cases started to fall in June and by September, only occasional\ncases were reported. Most cases reported in January [2006] occurred\nin people who had a history of recent travel to Reunion Island.\nHowever, in the [last] 10 days, some cases in people without history\nof travel have been reported. Some have been confirmed by virus\nisolation in tissue culture from blood samples. With the exception of\nthe cluster in Mahebourg, the other cases live in different regions\nof Mauritius.\nUp to now, the situation with Chikungunya virus has been much less\ndramatic than in Reunion Island. However, this may change. December\n[2005] was very dry in Mauritius, and heavy summer rainfall did not\noccur until 23 Jan 2006.\n--\nDr. M. I. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2143-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2021-04-15 00:00:00", "1946-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2006-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahebourg", "country": "Mauritius"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4964", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (07): Reunion", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4964", "date": "2006-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND (07): REUNION\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this issue:\n[1] Reunion update\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\n[3] Mauritius\n******\n[1] Reunion\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 05:56:22 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: BBC News, UK, 3 Feb 2006 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4674376.stm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease is spreading at an accelerating\nrate on the French Indian Ocean island of Reunion, health officials say.\nThey say the number of cases of the viral illness, known as\nchikungunya, had risen to 50 000, an increase of 15 000 in the past week alone.\nThe disease is not fatal, but those affected suffer high fever and\nsevere pain. There is no cure or vaccine.\nHundreds of troops have been deployed on the island to eradicate mosquitoes.\nOfficials said the troops would be spraying the whole island against\nmosquitoes in the coming days.\nThe latest outbreak was first noticed there in February 2005 - but\nhas spread at an accelerating rate since December.\nMeanwhile, neighboring territories are mobilizing to contain the disease.\nOn the Seychelles - where 2,000 cases have been reported in the past\n4 weeks - the army has been mobilized to exterminate mosquitoes,\nReuters news agency reports.\nThe authorities in Madagascar also fear the disease may have reached\ntheir island, AFP news agency says.\nChikungunya fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that which\nbends up\" - referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The spreading speed at 15 000 cases per week, or 2143 per day, is\nincredible. A bit of geography and climate may be of interest to our\nreaders. Reunion is located east of Madagascar and is a part of the\nMadagascar archipelago. Situated between the equator and the tropic\nof Capricorn, Reunion's climate is of tropical type (southern\nhemisphere) with oceanic influence. The island is home to one of the\nworld's most active volcanoes. There are 2 seasons: cool or dry\nseason (May till October) and warm or wet season (November till\nApril). Currently it is in the middle of the warm season when\nmosquitoes are most active and proliferative. The island was ruled as\na colony until 1946, when it was made a \"departement\" (=department),\nor administrative unit, of France. - Mod.RY]\n******\n[2] Reunion - fatal case\nDate: 4 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters alert [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L04459988.htm>\n\nA crippling mosquito-borne disease has claimed its first life and\ninfected more than 50 000 people on the volcanic French island of\nReunion, spooking tourists in the region, local authorities said.\nThe \"chikungunya\" disease, which is extremely painful and causes high\nfever, was not previously thought to be lethal and there is no known\ncure or vaccine.\nThe Reunion Regional Agency for Hospitalisation said late on Friday\nthe virus was the only explanation for the death of a 9-year-old in\nJanuary [2006].\nThe \"chikungunya\" fever is named after a Swahili word meaning \"that\nwhich bends up,\" referring to the stooped posture of those afflicted.\nFirst recognised in epidemic form in East Africa in 1952, it also\nleaves immune systems weak, providing opportunities for other\ndiseases to set in.\nThe disease, which has already travelled to the nearby Indian Ocean\nislands of Seychelles, Mauritius and Mayotte, has prompted tourists\nto cancel bookings.\nSince 23 Jan [2006], the Reunion Committee on Tourism said at least\n1500 tours had been cancelled and the costs incurred from\ncancellations over the past 2 weeks were equal to its annual\nadvertising budget. It did not provide any figures.\nOn Thursday [2 Feb 2006], Seychelles said it had mobilised its army\nto control the virus which has infected 2000 of the idyllic\narchipelago's 80 000 people.\nReunion last week earmarked $720 000 to fight the outbreak, drafting\n400 extra troops to help fight the mosquitoes that have spread the\ndisease for nearly a year.\nIn neighbouring Mauritius, authorities are screening people at the\nairport and port, spraying places near hotels and guest houses and\nwarning the public to take precautions.\nThe Reunion authorities said they planned to set up a scientific\ncommittee to better understand the disease. They said they had\nregistered some 25 deaths citing the virus as a possible cause.\nAuthorities say people should remove stagnant water, use mosquito\nrepellents and bed nets and spray bedrooms at night.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fatalities are not commonly seen with chikungunya. More information\non these above mentioned cases would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3] Mauritius\nDate: Fri, 3 Feb 2006 14:43:53 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: Mohammad Issack <missack@intnet.mu>\nSource: Le Mauricien, 3 Feb 2006 [trans. and edited]\n<http://lemauricien.com/mauricien/index.html>\n\nMauritian authorities are on high alert after the identification of 2\nconfirmed cases of Chikungunya in Mahebourg. A ministerial committee\nis chaired by the Prime Minister, Navin Ramgoolam, to decide on\nmeasures to take to prevent infection by the _Aedes albopictus_\nmosquito, which transmits this viral illness that is characterized\nmainly by fever, muscular pain and joint swellings. 15 cases have\nbeen registered from January up to 2 Feb 2006; the ministry of Health\nin 2005 detected 3500 cases that it prefers to call suspected cases\nof Chikungunya.\nThe government is buying equipment for disinfection in order to\ndestroy all mosquitoes liable to infect people. [Even if] the port\nand the airport are watched closely by the Health Inspectorate\nDivision, there is no protocol to quarantine travellers arriving from\nReunion Island. A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said this\nmorning [3 Feb] that provisions for keeping people in quarantine\nexist [only] in protocols on avian influenza and in cases of a\npotentially fatal illness that is transmissible from person to\nperson. The Ministry of Health is requesting all hotels and all\nmedical practitioners in private practice to notify any suspect case.\nPersonal comment:\nIn Mauritius, the peak of the Chikungunya outbreak occurred in May\n[2005] when several hundred cases were reported per week. The number\nof cases started to fall in June and by September, only occasional\ncases were reported. Most cases reported in January [2006] occurred\nin people who had a history of recent travel to Reunion Island.\nHowever, in the [last] 10 days, some cases in people without history\nof travel have been reported. Some have been confirmed by virus\nisolation in tissue culture from blood samples. With the exception of\nthe cluster in Mahebourg, the other cases live in different regions\nof Mauritius.\nUp to now, the situation with Chikungunya virus has been much less\ndramatic than in Reunion Island. However, this may change. December\n[2005] was very dry in Mauritius, and heavy summer rainfall did not\noccur until 23 Jan 2006.\n--\nDr. M. I. Issack\nPathologist (Microbiology)\nCentral Health Laboratory\nMauritius\n<missack@intnet.mu>\n[ProMED is grateful for the timely information and comment given by\nDr. M. I. Issack from Mauritius. In the wake of the extraordinary\nepidemic of chikungunya on Reunion Island, spread of the epidemic to\nother islands seems inevitable. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nChikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI 20060202.0340\nChikungunya - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2143-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2021-04-15 00:00:00", "1946-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2006-02-03 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-15 00:00:00", "2021-12-15 00:00:00", "2006-01-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahebourg", "country": "Mauritius"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "Seychelles"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209233", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Seychelles", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209233", "date": "2006-01-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND: REUNION\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 2 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\nFurther to the recent post on the outbreak of Chikungunya virus on\nReunion island (20051231.3716) it seems appropriate to add a few\ncomments on possible mosquito vectors.\nThere are many mosquito aedine vectors of Chikungunya virus in\nsub-Saharan Africa, including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes africanus_,\nbut despite several outbreaks in Reunion, there is little information\non the vectors or potential vectors.\nThe usual suspect in most outbreaks of Chikungunya is _Ae. aegypti_,\na mosquito that is largely anthropophagic and commonly breeds in\nwater-storage pots. But on Reunion island, _Ae. aegypti_ is unusual\nin that it rarely bites humans and breeds mainly in natural container\nhabitats, such as water-filled tree holes. An informative publication\non these 2 mosquitoes on Reunion is by M. Salvan and J. Mouchet (Ann.\nSoc. Belg. Med. Trop. (1994) 74, 323-326).\nAs far as I know, _Ae. africanus_ has not been recorded from Reunion.\nA more likely vector on Reunion is _Aedes albopictus_, where it\nbreeds in both man-made and natural container-type habitats and\ncommonly bites humans.\n--\nMichael Service\nProMED-mail Medical Entomology Moderator\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n...................ms/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-02 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1974-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reunion", "country": "R\u00e9union"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209225", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (06): Reunion", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209225", "date": "2006-01-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND: REUNION\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 2 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\nFurther to the recent post on the outbreak of Chikungunya virus on\nReunion island (20051231.3716) it seems appropriate to add a few\ncomments on possible mosquito vectors.\nThere are many mosquito aedine vectors of Chikungunya virus in\nsub-Saharan Africa, including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes africanus_,\nbut despite several outbreaks in Reunion, there is little information\non the vectors or potential vectors.\nThe usual suspect in most outbreaks of Chikungunya is _Ae. aegypti_,\na mosquito that is largely anthropophagic and commonly breeds in\nwater-storage pots. But on Reunion island, _Ae. aegypti_ is unusual\nin that it rarely bites humans and breeds mainly in natural container\nhabitats, such as water-filled tree holes. An informative publication\non these 2 mosquitoes on Reunion is by M. Salvan and J. Mouchet (Ann.\nSoc. Belg. Med. Trop. (1994) 74, 323-326).\nAs far as I know, _Ae. africanus_ has not been recorded from Reunion.\nA more likely vector on Reunion is _Aedes albopictus_, where it\nbreeds in both man-made and natural container-type habitats and\ncommonly bites humans.\n--\nMichael Service\nProMED-mail Medical Entomology Moderator\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n...................ms/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-02 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1974-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reunion", "country": "R\u00e9union"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209224", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Madagascar: susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209224", "date": "2006-01-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MAURITIUS AND REUNION ISLAND: REUNION\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 2 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\nFurther to the recent post on the outbreak of Chikungunya virus on\nReunion island (20051231.3716) it seems appropriate to add a few\ncomments on possible mosquito vectors.\nThere are many mosquito aedine vectors of Chikungunya virus in\nsub-Saharan Africa, including _Aedes aegypti_ and _Aedes africanus_,\nbut despite several outbreaks in Reunion, there is little information\non the vectors or potential vectors.\nThe usual suspect in most outbreaks of Chikungunya is _Ae. aegypti_,\na mosquito that is largely anthropophagic and commonly breeds in\nwater-storage pots. But on Reunion island, _Ae. aegypti_ is unusual\nin that it rarely bites humans and breeds mainly in natural container\nhabitats, such as water-filled tree holes. An informative publication\non these 2 mosquitoes on Reunion is by M. Salvan and J. Mouchet (Ann.\nSoc. Belg. Med. Trop. (1994) 74, 323-326).\nAs far as I know, _Ae. africanus_ has not been recorded from Reunion.\nA more likely vector on Reunion is _Aedes albopictus_, where it\nbreeds in both man-made and natural container-type habitats and\ncommonly bites humans.\n--\nMichael Service\nProMED-mail Medical Entomology Moderator\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n...................ms/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. But on Reunion island, _Ae. aegypti_ is unusual\nin that it rarely bites humans and breeds mainly in natural container\nhabitats, such as water-filled tree holes. An informative publication\non these 2 mosquitoes on Reunion is by M. Salvan and J. Mouchet (Ann.\nSoc. Belg. Med. Trop. (1994) 74, 323-326).\nAs far as I know, _Ae. africanus_ has not been recorded from Reunion.\nA more likely vector on Reunion is _Aedes albopictus_, where it\nbreeds in both man-made and natural container-type habitats and\ncommonly bites humans.\n--\nMichael Service\nProMED-mail Medical Entomology Moderator\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n...................ms/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. But on Reunion island, _Ae. aegypti_ is unusual\nin that it rarely bites humans and breeds mainly in natural container\nhabitats, such as water-filled tree holes. An informative publication\non these 2 mosquitoes on Reunion is by M. Salvan and J. Mouchet (Ann.\nSoc. Belg. Med. Trop. (1994) 74, 323-326).\nAs far as I know, _Ae. africanus_ has not been recorded from Reunion.\nA more likely vector on Reunion is _Aedes albopictus_, where it\nbreeds in both man-made and natural container-type habitats and\ncommonly bites humans.\n--\nMichael Service\nProMED-mail Medical Entomology Moderator\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion 20051231.3716\nChikungunya - Mayotte, Reunion, Comoros 20050913.2707\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Tangerang) 20050717.2059\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (03) 20050624.1770\nDeaths at sea - France (Reunion Island): RFI 20050622.1759\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (2) 20050520.1384\nChikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island 20050519.1372\nChikungunya - Indonesia (West Lombok) 20050422.1121\nChikungunya - Comoros (Ngazidja) 20050405.0986\nChikungunya - Sri Lanka (02) 20050223.0581\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n...................ms/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
