For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-02 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1974-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reunion", "country": "R\u00e9union"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209100", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island (04): Reunion", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209100", "date": "2005-04-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - COMOROS (NGAZIDJA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2005\nFrom: \"Shirley Bannatyne\" <Shirley.Bannatyne@masta.org>\nSource: MASTA Health Report, Mon 4 Apr 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.masta.org>\n\nComoros: Chikungunya Virus Identified as Cause of Epidemic\n---------------------------------------------------\nDoctors have now confirmed that Chikungunya virus is the cause of an\nepidemic in Ngazidja for about 4 months, since January 2005, and that the\ndisease is not dengue fever as initially supposed. The diagnosis has been\nconfirmed by results of laboratory tests carried out in a US Laboratory.\nThe number of cases is declining notably in the central part of the island,\nwhich was the 1st region to be affected by the virus.\n--\nShirley Bannatyne\nNurse Adviser\nMASTA\n<Shirley.Bannatyne@masta.org>\n[Chikungunya virus is a mosquito-transmitted virus classified in the family\n_Togaviridae_ (not related to dengue virus which is an arbovirus classified\nin the family _Flaviviridae_). Chikungunya (meaning \"doubled up\") virus\nwas isolated during an epidemic in Tanzania in 1952 from both patients and\nmosquitoes. Subsequently it has been isolated frequently from humans and\nmosquitoes in tropical Africa, India, and Southeast Asia. Non-human\nreservoir species have not been identified unequivocally, and migrants and\ntravellers are blamed frequently for spread of infection; e.g., for the\ncomparatively recent introduction of the disease into Malaysia.\nRecent laboratory studies suggest that in Southeast Asia, _Stegomyia\nalbopicta_ [_Aedes albopictus_] is a more competent vector of chikungunya\nvirus than _Stegomyia aegypti_ [_Aedes aegypti_].\nThe largest epidemics of chikungunya in recent years have occurred in India\nand Indonesia. The clinical features of the disease associated with this\nvirus resemble to some extent those of dengue fever with which it is often\nconfused. In the case of chikungunya virus infection, after an incubation\nperiod of 2 to 4 days, there is sudden onset of fever, followed by\ncrippling joint pains which may temporarily incapacitate the patient.\nArthralgia is the most typical sign, occurring in around 70 percent of\ncases. The acute phase of the disease lasts for 2 to 4 days with recovery\nin 5 to 7 days. Treatment is palliative.\nThe Comoros Islands lie off the east coast of Africa, approximately midway\nbetween northern Mozambique and the northern tip of Madagascar. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The diagnosis has been\nconfirmed by results of laboratory tests carried out in a US Laboratory.\nThe number of cases is declining notably in the central part of the island,\nwhich was the 1st region to be affected by the virus.\n--\nShirley Bannatyne\nNurse Adviser\nMASTA\n<Shirley.Bannatyne@masta.org>\n[Chikungunya virus is a mosquito-transmitted virus classified in the family\n_Togaviridae_ (not related to dengue virus which is an arbovirus classified\nin the family _Flaviviridae_). Chikungunya (meaning \"doubled up\") virus\nwas isolated during an epidemic in Tanzania in 1952 from both patients and\nmosquitoes. Subsequently it has been isolated frequently from humans and\nmosquitoes in tropical Africa, India, and Southeast Asia. Non-human\nreservoir species have not been identified unequivocally, and migrants and\ntravellers are blamed frequently for spread of infection; e.g., for the\ncomparatively recent introduction of the disease into Malaysia.\nRecent laboratory studies suggest that in Southeast Asia, _Stegomyia\nalbopicta_ [_Aedes albopictus_] is a more competent vector of chikungunya\nvirus than _Stegomyia aegypti_ [_Aedes aegypti_].\nThe largest epidemics of chikungunya in recent years have occurred in India\nand Indonesia. The clinical features of the disease associated with this\nvirus resemble to some extent those of dengue fever with which it is often\nconfused. In the case of chikungunya virus infection, after an incubation\nperiod of 2 to 4 days, there is sudden onset of fever, followed by\ncrippling joint pains which may temporarily incapacitate the patient.\nArthralgia is the most typical sign, occurring in around 70 percent of\ncases. The acute phase of the disease lasts for 2 to 4 days with recovery\nin 5 to 7 days. Treatment is palliative.\nThe Comoros Islands lie off the east coast of Africa, approximately midway\nbetween northern Mozambique and the northern tip of Madagascar. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Subsequently it has been isolated frequently from humans and\nmosquitoes in tropical Africa, India, and Southeast Asia. In the case of chikungunya virus infection, after an incubation\nperiod of 2 to 4 days, there is sudden onset of fever, followed by\ncrippling joint pains which may temporarily incapacitate the patient.\nArthralgia is the most typical sign, occurring in around 70 percent of\ncases. The acute phase of the disease lasts for 2 to 4 days with recovery\nin 5 to 7 days. Treatment is palliative.\nThe Comoros Islands lie off the east coast of Africa, approximately midway\nbetween northern Mozambique and the northern tip of Madagascar. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Arthralgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ngazidja", "country": "Comoros"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207890", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Mauritius and Reunion Island", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207890", "date": "2005-04-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - COMOROS (NGAZIDJA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2005\nFrom: \"Shirley Bannatyne\" <Shirley.Bannatyne@masta.org>\nSource: MASTA Health Report, Mon 4 Apr 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.masta.org>\n\nComoros: Chikungunya Virus Identified as Cause of Epidemic\n---------------------------------------------------\nDoctors have now confirmed that Chikungunya virus is the cause of an\nepidemic in Ngazidja for about 4 months, since January 2005, and that the\ndisease is not dengue fever as initially supposed. The diagnosis has been\nconfirmed by results of laboratory tests carried out in a US Laboratory.\nThe number of cases is declining notably in the central part of the island,\nwhich was the 1st region to be affected by the virus.\n--\nShirley Bannatyne\nNurse Adviser\nMASTA\n<Shirley.Bannatyne@masta.org>\n[Chikungunya virus is a mosquito-transmitted virus classified in the family\n_Togaviridae_ (not related to dengue virus which is an arbovirus classified\nin the family _Flaviviridae_). Chikungunya (meaning \"doubled up\") virus\nwas isolated during an epidemic in Tanzania in 1952 from both patients and\nmosquitoes. Subsequently it has been isolated frequently from humans and\nmosquitoes in tropical Africa, India, and Southeast Asia. Non-human\nreservoir species have not been identified unequivocally, and migrants and\ntravellers are blamed frequently for spread of infection; e.g., for the\ncomparatively recent introduction of the disease into Malaysia.\nRecent laboratory studies suggest that in Southeast Asia, _Stegomyia\nalbopicta_ [_Aedes albopictus_] is a more competent vector of chikungunya\nvirus than _Stegomyia aegypti_ [_Aedes aegypti_].\nThe largest epidemics of chikungunya in recent years have occurred in India\nand Indonesia. The clinical features of the disease associated with this\nvirus resemble to some extent those of dengue fever with which it is often\nconfused. In the case of chikungunya virus infection, after an incubation\nperiod of 2 to 4 days, there is sudden onset of fever, followed by\ncrippling joint pains which may temporarily incapacitate the patient.\nArthralgia is the most typical sign, occurring in around 70 percent of\ncases. The acute phase of the disease lasts for 2 to 4 days with recovery\nin 5 to 7 days. Treatment is palliative.\nThe Comoros Islands lie off the east coast of Africa, approximately midway\nbetween northern Mozambique and the northern tip of Madagascar. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The diagnosis has been\nconfirmed by results of laboratory tests carried out in a US Laboratory.\nThe number of cases is declining notably in the central part of the island,\nwhich was the 1st region to be affected by the virus.\n--\nShirley Bannatyne\nNurse Adviser\nMASTA\n<Shirley.Bannatyne@masta.org>\n[Chikungunya virus is a mosquito-transmitted virus classified in the family\n_Togaviridae_ (not related to dengue virus which is an arbovirus classified\nin the family _Flaviviridae_). Chikungunya (meaning \"doubled up\") virus\nwas isolated during an epidemic in Tanzania in 1952 from both patients and\nmosquitoes. Subsequently it has been isolated frequently from humans and\nmosquitoes in tropical Africa, India, and Southeast Asia. Non-human\nreservoir species have not been identified unequivocally, and migrants and\ntravellers are blamed frequently for spread of infection; e.g., for the\ncomparatively recent introduction of the disease into Malaysia.\nRecent laboratory studies suggest that in Southeast Asia, _Stegomyia\nalbopicta_ [_Aedes albopictus_] is a more competent vector of chikungunya\nvirus than _Stegomyia aegypti_ [_Aedes aegypti_].\nThe largest epidemics of chikungunya in recent years have occurred in India\nand Indonesia. The clinical features of the disease associated with this\nvirus resemble to some extent those of dengue fever with which it is often\nconfused. In the case of chikungunya virus infection, after an incubation\nperiod of 2 to 4 days, there is sudden onset of fever, followed by\ncrippling joint pains which may temporarily incapacitate the patient.\nArthralgia is the most typical sign, occurring in around 70 percent of\ncases. The acute phase of the disease lasts for 2 to 4 days with recovery\nin 5 to 7 days. Treatment is palliative.\nThe Comoros Islands lie off the east coast of Africa, approximately midway\nbetween northern Mozambique and the northern tip of Madagascar. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nChikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003 20040226.0604\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (03) 20040125.0297\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20040117.0183\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20040115.0164\n2003\n----\nChikungunya - Indonesia (East Java) 20031209.3019\nChikungunya - Indonesia (03) 20030226.0485\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02) 20030223.0469\nChikungunya - Indonesia (Java) 20030217.0410\n1999\n----\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Petaling Jaya) 19990427.0700\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (03) 19990320.0441\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) (02) 19990317.0400\nChikungunya - Malaysia (Port Klang) 19990206.0171\n......................cp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["chikungunya", "dengue"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-01-15 00:00:00", "1952-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "East Java", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Arthralgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ngazidja", "country": "Comoros"}, {"location": "Chikungunya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205342", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya fever - Indonesia 2003", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205342", "date": "1999-02-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MALAYSIA (PORT KLANG)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Sat, 6 Feb 1999\nFrom: Chan Yow Cheong <chanyowcheong@pacific.net.sg>\nProMED-mail Regional Moderator for Asia\nSource: Communication from S K Lam, 6 Feb 1999\n\nThe following information was received from Prof S K Lam in connection\nwith\nthe recent chikungunya (CHIK) outbreak in Port Klang:\n>Chikungunya virus is a member of the alphavirus group and related to\nRoss\nRiver virus, Barmah Forest virus and Sindbis virus. Malaysia had never\nexperienced such an outbreak, although a paper by Marchette et al. in\n1980\nindicated serological evidence of CHIK in the country (Southeast Asian J\nTrop Med Pub Hlth 11: 14-23, 1980).\nThe clinical picture of this outbreak was classical of CHIK infection,\nwith\nabrupt onset of fever, maculopapular rash and rheumatic manifestations.\nThe\noutbreak started in early December 1998 and to date, 27 cases have been\nidentified, with 10 hospital admissions. 80% of the patients were adult\nfemales, predominantly among Indians which made up the bulk of the\npopulation in this area. Several patients experienced severe\narthralgias\nwhich were polyarticular, migratory and predominantly affecting the\nsmall\njoints of the hands, wrists, ankles and feet.\nThe outbreak started after flooding in the locality and the _Aedes\naegypti_\nindex then was 3.2. [House index -- no. of _A.aegypti_/house? - Mod.JW]\nWorking in close collaboration with Dr David W Smith, Clinical Director,\nDivision of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, The Western Australian\nCentre for Pathology and Medical Research, Perth, Australia, rubella,\ndengue,\nand other alphaviruses were ruled out. CHIK IgM was detected in 6 out of\n6\nsamples tested and HI showed cross-reaction with Sindbis and Ross River\n[viruses].\nIn anticipation of the further spread of the outbreak, the WHO\nCollaborating\nCentre for Arbovirus Reference and Research (DF/DHF) in Kuala Lumpur,\nwith\nthe help of Australia, will have the test available locally soon.\nCountries\nin the region where dengue is endemic should take note of the\npossibility of\nCHIK infection.\n--\nProf S K Lam and Dr K B Chua\nWHO CCRR (DF/DHF)\nDepartment of Medical Microbiology\nFaculty of Medicine\nUniversity of Malaya\n50603 Kuala Lumpur\nMalaysia.\nLam Sai Kit, Kenneth <lamsk@medicine.med.um.edu.my>\n[Note that the mosquito vector of CHIK is identical to that of dengue, &\nthe symptoms are identical to those of dengue with the exception that\ndengue predominantly affects the large joints -- elbows & knees. Mixed\noutbreaks of both CHIK & dengue have been recorded, I think in the\nPhilippines - Mod.JW]\n...........................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Malaysia had never\nexperienced such an outbreak, although a paper by Marchette et al. in\n1980\nindicated serological evidence of CHIK in the country (Southeast Asian J\nTrop Med Pub Hlth 11: 14-23, 1980).\nThe clinical picture of this outbreak was classical of CHIK infection,\nwith\nabrupt onset of fever, maculopapular rash and rheumatic manifestations.\nThe\noutbreak started in early December 1998 and to date, 27 cases have been\nidentified, with 10 hospital admissions. 80% of the patients were adult\nfemales, predominantly among Indians which made up the bulk of the\npopulation in this area. CHIK IgM was detected in 6 out of\n6\nsamples tested and HI showed cross-reaction with Sindbis and Ross River\n[viruses].\nIn anticipation of the further spread of the outbreak, the WHO\nCollaborating\nCentre for Arbovirus Reference and Research (DF/DHF) in Kuala Lumpur,\nwith\nthe help of Australia, will have the test available locally soon.\nCountries\nin the region where dengue is endemic should take note of the\npossibility of\nCHIK infection.\n--\nProf S K Lam and Dr K B Chua\nWHO CCRR (DF/DHF)\nDepartment of Medical Microbiology\nFaculty of Medicine\nUniversity of Malaya\n50603 Kuala Lumpur\nMalaysia.\nLam Sai Kit, Kenneth <lamsk@medicine.med.um.edu.my>\n[Note that the mosquito vector of CHIK is identical to that of dengue, &\nthe symptoms are identical to those of dengue with the exception that\ndengue predominantly affects the large joints -- elbows & knees. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "chikungunya", "dengue", "rubella"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-02-06 00:00:00", "1999-02-06 00:00:00", "1980-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Perth", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Kuala Lumpur", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203413", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Chikungunya - Indonesia (Java) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203413", "date": "1999-02-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHIKUNGUNYA - MALAYSIA (PORT KLANG)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Sat, 6 Feb 1999\nFrom: Chan Yow Cheong <chanyowcheong@pacific.net.sg>\nProMED-mail Regional Moderator for Asia\nSource: Communication from S K Lam, 6 Feb 1999\n\nThe following information was received from Prof S K Lam in connection\nwith\nthe recent chikungunya (CHIK) outbreak in Port Klang:\n>Chikungunya virus is a member of the alphavirus group and related to\nRoss\nRiver virus, Barmah Forest virus and Sindbis virus. Malaysia had never\nexperienced such an outbreak, although a paper by Marchette et al. in\n1980\nindicated serological evidence of CHIK in the country (Southeast Asian J\nTrop Med Pub Hlth 11: 14-23, 1980).\nThe clinical picture of this outbreak was classical of CHIK infection,\nwith\nabrupt onset of fever, maculopapular rash and rheumatic manifestations.\nThe\noutbreak started in early December 1998 and to date, 27 cases have been\nidentified, with 10 hospital admissions. 80% of the patients were adult\nfemales, predominantly among Indians which made up the bulk of the\npopulation in this area. Several patients experienced severe\narthralgias\nwhich were polyarticular, migratory and predominantly affecting the\nsmall\njoints of the hands, wrists, ankles and feet.\nThe outbreak started after flooding in the locality and the _Aedes\naegypti_\nindex then was 3.2. [House index -- no. of _A.aegypti_/house? - Mod.JW]\nWorking in close collaboration with Dr David W Smith, Clinical Director,\nDivision of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, The Western Australian\nCentre for Pathology and Medical Research, Perth, Australia, rubella,\ndengue,\nand other alphaviruses were ruled out. CHIK IgM was detected in 6 out of\n6\nsamples tested and HI showed cross-reaction with Sindbis and Ross River\n[viruses].\nIn anticipation of the further spread of the outbreak, the WHO\nCollaborating\nCentre for Arbovirus Reference and Research (DF/DHF) in Kuala Lumpur,\nwith\nthe help of Australia, will have the test available locally soon.\nCountries\nin the region where dengue is endemic should take note of the\npossibility of\nCHIK infection.\n--\nProf S K Lam and Dr K B Chua\nWHO CCRR (DF/DHF)\nDepartment of Medical Microbiology\nFaculty of Medicine\nUniversity of Malaya\n50603 Kuala Lumpur\nMalaysia.\nLam Sai Kit, Kenneth <lamsk@medicine.med.um.edu.my>\n[Note that the mosquito vector of CHIK is identical to that of dengue, &\nthe symptoms are identical to those of dengue with the exception that\ndengue predominantly affects the large joints -- elbows & knees. Mixed\noutbreaks of both CHIK & dengue have been recorded, I think in the\nPhilippines - Mod.JW]\n...........................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Malaysia had never\nexperienced such an outbreak, although a paper by Marchette et al. in\n1980\nindicated serological evidence of CHIK in the country (Southeast Asian J\nTrop Med Pub Hlth 11: 14-23, 1980).\nThe clinical picture of this outbreak was classical of CHIK infection,\nwith\nabrupt onset of fever, maculopapular rash and rheumatic manifestations.\nThe\noutbreak started in early December 1998 and to date, 27 cases have been\nidentified, with 10 hospital admissions. 80% of the patients were adult\nfemales, predominantly among Indians which made up the bulk of the\npopulation in this area. Several patients experienced severe\narthralgias\nwhich were polyarticular, migratory and predominantly affecting the\nsmall\njoints of the hands, wrists, ankles and feet.\nThe outbreak started after flooding in the locality and the _Aedes\naegypti_\nindex then was 3.2. [House index -- no. of _A.aegypti_/house? - Mod.JW]\nWorking in close collaboration with Dr David W Smith, Clinical Director,\nDivision of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, The Western Australian\nCentre for Pathology and Medical Research, Perth, Australia, rubella,\ndengue,\nand other alphaviruses were ruled out. CHIK IgM was detected in 6 out of\n6\nsamples tested and HI showed cross-reaction with Sindbis and Ross River\n[viruses].\nIn anticipation of the further spread of the outbreak, the WHO\nCollaborating\nCentre for Arbovirus Reference and Research (DF/DHF) in Kuala Lumpur,\nwith\nthe help of Australia, will have the test available locally soon.\nCountries\nin the region where dengue is endemic should take note of the\npossibility of\nCHIK infection.\n--\nProf S K Lam and Dr K B Chua\nWHO CCRR (DF/DHF)\nDepartment of Medical Microbiology\nFaculty of Medicine\nUniversity of Malaya\n50603 Kuala Lumpur\nMalaysia.\nLam Sai Kit, Kenneth <lamsk@medicine.med.um.edu.my>\n[Note that the mosquito vector of CHIK is identical to that of dengue, &\nthe symptoms are identical to those of dengue with the exception that\ndengue predominantly affects the large joints -- elbows & knees. Mixed\noutbreaks of both CHIK & dengue have been recorded, I think in the\nPhilippines - Mod.JW]\n...........................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Malaysia had never\nexperienced such an outbreak, although a paper by Marchette et al. in\n1980\nindicated serological evidence of CHIK in the country (Southeast Asian J\nTrop Med Pub Hlth 11: 14-23, 1980).\nThe clinical picture of this outbreak was classical of CHIK infection,\nwith\nabrupt onset of fever, maculopapular rash and rheumatic manifestations.\nThe\noutbreak started in early December 1998 and to date, 27 cases have been\nidentified, with 10 hospital admissions. 80% of the patients were adult\nfemales, predominantly among Indians which made up the bulk of the\npopulation in this area. CHIK IgM was detected in 6 out of\n6\nsamples tested and HI showed cross-reaction with Sindbis and Ross River\n[viruses].\nIn anticipation of the further spread of the outbreak, the WHO\nCollaborating\nCentre for Arbovirus Reference and Research (DF/DHF) in Kuala Lumpur,\nwith\nthe help of Australia, will have the test available locally soon.\nCountries\nin the region where dengue is endemic should take note of the\npossibility of\nCHIK infection.\n--\nProf S K Lam and Dr K B Chua\nWHO CCRR (DF/DHF)\nDepartment of Medical Microbiology\nFaculty of Medicine\nUniversity of Malaya\n50603 Kuala Lumpur\nMalaysia.\nLam Sai Kit, Kenneth <lamsk@medicine.med.um.edu.my>\n[Note that the mosquito vector of CHIK is identical to that of dengue, &\nthe symptoms are identical to those of dengue with the exception that\ndengue predominantly affects the large joints -- elbows & knees.
